content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL: DR= Get this game.Where to begin? This game is so awesome and so clever, it's hard to know how to start.Hand of Fate is an early access game of indeterminate genre. Roguelike is probably closest fit, but it's a blend of deck-building, rogue-likes and Arkham Asylum's combat with a dark fantasy setting.Early Access: Entirely playable. Very solid beta release. Gameplay: You build an encounter deck and an equipment deck using cards you win through playing the game and defeating encouters. How this plays out narratively and mechanically is so clever. As an example, there are "Ratling Hunters" cards that become locked into your encounter deck until you defeat the "Ratling Exterminators" encounter.When you encounter monsters, the action takes place in a small instanced arena where you must fight for your life. You start out with very little but as you gain cards you can become an incredible killing machine. Once you have the "counter" ability, it becomes similar to Batman Arkham Whatever's combat.The encounters you face are randomly laid out as a tarot style reading. And you're going to die. Die a lot. Asthetics: Visually, the game is nice enough to look at. It won't blow you away but it sets the dark fantasy mood. The audio for the game is mostly good but there are bugs. The music is fitting, the VO for the dealer is acerbic but sometimes the sounds are annoying. Spawning enemies all sound like the 60's version of the Penguin (waaaark wark wark wark) and your dude sounds like Link but looks like an ancient celtic bad♥♥♥♥♥ Still, early access, it's forgivable.This game is amazing. Get it. Just get it. The only thing I really want is more customisation over my character, or possibly mulitple characters. Playing as a mage or something like that would require a different eq. deck and thus DLC is born.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												This game is very cinematic; between its mostly turn-based and dialogue-option-heavy gameplay, the great writing and voice acting for the Dealer, and its excellent atmosphere, this is a great game to play with a friend in a dark room (no, it's not horror or jump scare trash). I picked it up after seeing it on a late-night stream, and I've since had friends watch it via Steam broadcast and heckle me to go disturb that ancient tomb because there might be loot in it. It even draws heavily enough from traditional storytelling and keeps its (most visible) video-gamey mechanics simple enough that I could imagine even someone who doesn't play video games enjoying it as a spectator/backseat player; try it with a family member or loved one and leave a comment here about how it goes! I mean that.That said, it's also enjoyable alone. I've spent enough nights with the Dealer, on hard mode because I like a good roguelike challenge, dying over and over at the hands of vampires or old gods or that bloody kraken that isn't even the final boss or what have you. His dialogue is intimate, and like I said, he does a great job setting the tone and atmosphere of the piece; like so many adventurers before you who have tried and failed, you have wandered into his parlour, and you now play a magical card game built from memories of your adventuring life that may very well have your immortal soul hanging in the balance.I admit to having been spoiled by free MMOs, to having sinking thousands of hours and zeroes of dollars into individual games skew my perception of value, but most non-free games feel outrageously expensive to me for what they offer, especially when they're short. Hand of Fate is a glorious exception, one of the very few games that I have not once regretted buying, an honour limited among my Steam library to it, FTL, and possibly Portal 1.tl;dr 10/10 shining ♥♥♥♥ing diamond of game design buy it now

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Rating 7.5/10Overview: Rogue, Card builder with Real-time combatThe Good:+ When different genres are mixed together the results can be very unpredictable, yet when they work you get a pleasant surprise. Hands of fate thankfully does a successful job of mixing rogue with building a card deck with real-time combat. The game is pretty simple in its execution, you build a deck with equipment and 'encounter' cards, the dealer then mixes in his own cards (usually bad ones). The deck is then shuffled and the cards are placed faced down on the table. Most cards have a game of chance involved, the higher the reward the higher the risk. By completing cards, you then unlock new cards that can be used in subsequent play-through’s, usually resulting in greater rewards. + Unlocking new cards and equipment is very satisfying+ You also have to manage 3 types of resources, health, food and gold. Every time you select a card you lose one food. Run out of food and you begin to lose health after every selection. Certain cards reward gold/food/health. Acquired gold can then be used to purchase food, equipment etc at a shop.+ To make things interesting the dealer mixes in 'curse' cards in the deck. These cards are numerous and can drastically change the way the game is played. I.e. enemies do double damage, lose gold after every turn etc. + SoundtrackThe Average:Combat is a big part of the game and it just isn’t as good as other games. Combat is identical to Rocksteady's Batman games, you have a strike, counter and dodge button. The animations feel stiff, hitting enemies doesn't feel satisfying and the mechanics never change. The combat starts to feel rather repetitive after awhile. I found it strange the developers decided to use real time combat instead of a combat system that used cards which is the games entire premise. Glitchy achievements. Conclusion:This is a great unique game on Steam that is a bit rough around the edges but ultimately provides a very enjoyable and satisfying experience. I understand they are making a sequel which aims to improve many of the weaknesses from this game. If you like rogue-lite type of games and are looking for something a bit different, hands of fate will certainly deliver hours of fun.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												this game is the definition of wasted potential. sure it's fun for the first couple hours. you'll breeze past the first half of the content in about 2-4 hours, but once you get about two thirds of the way through, the game takes a massive difficulty spike. the game starts reusing old boss fights, but they use them along side other groups of enemies, in addition to the ones that that the boss comes bundled with. see every time you fight a boss they summon 2-4 enemies to fight along side them at the start of the battle. it's impossible to fight *just* a boss. this wouldn't be a huge problem, except that in addition to fighting the bosses again, with more enemies this time, the bosses and their mooks are all powered up, they have more health, and more (and more powerful) moves. now all of theses things combine would be challenging, but managable if not for one major flaw: the arenas in which you fight get smaller and smaller as the game progresses. at the start of the game you fight 1 boss and about 2-3 enemies in a REALLY big arena making it possible to divide and conquer, and avoid attacks. by the end of the game, you can wind up facing about 10+ enemies including 2 bosses in an arena about a quarter of the size in which you found the original boss encounter. oh by the way the second to last boss is in one of the smallest arenas in the game, spawns with 4 ranged units with shields, has undblockable attacks, can block attacks himself, AAAANNNNNDDDDD his minions can't be killed until AFTER you kill the boss. oh and his unkillable minions (seemingly intentionally) position themselves between you and the big guy, and even when they aren't in your way, sometimes your character just seems to ignore him. the autoaim on your attacks seem to prioritize his unkillable minions for some reason, and even when he's alone, it will just ignore him entirely.all of this only outlines the problems with the combat encounters. most of the other encouters in the game are strictly luck based, and rely entirely on you winning a 25% roll, or you lose most of your equipment/health/provisions. all I can say is, I hope the devs look at this game, figure out all the stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they got wrong, and make an awesome sequel, because if not for its compeletly unforgivable, unignorable, experience ruining flaws, this game would be in the running for the greatest game I've ever played. that said, don't buy it. it's not worth you money because you'll never be able to actually beat it without getting incredibly lucky and I mean that literally, no matter how well you play, no matter how clever you are, most of the game comes down to situations where you have a 75-100% chanace of immediately dying a completely unvoidable death.--------------------------------------------------------------------Response to developer's comment:the graveyard deals a ton of damage (I think I lost like 45 health most of it in max health reduction) to you if you are cursed, and you are always cursed passed the first wing if I'm not mistaken (100% chance for a negative, potentially run ruinning outcome especially on levels like the king of scales where you lose health/food/gold randomly and can easily starve). also the treasure chest goes from being a nearly garunteed free gain to a nearly garunteed chance to lose most of your health to gas and a mimick (again, often in permanent health reduction). those are the ones that come to mind right now, but I know there are others.basically some cards like the graveyard have a garunteed negative outcome if you don't know what they do ahead of time and put them in your deck at the wrong time, and others go from being really good during the early stages of the game to just being a death sentence later like treasure chest.now don't get me wrong, I don't mind that the cards change as the game progresses, I mind that they change completely *without any warning.* if the game told you ahead of time that certain encounters where going to get more difficult that would be one thing, but when an important part of my strategy for getting a good run going with decent gear arbitrarily decides to kill me with out warning... that's when I get a bit upset.my reccomendation would be to put a level indicator on encouters similar to the monster cards to warn you "hey this has a much bigger chance to go south, you sure you still want it in your deck?" but instead you have to learn that it can screw over your entire run by having it screw over your entire run, and that really sucks.all that said, I love the ideas you guys put into the game, it's really REALLY cool, it's just that the luck vs. skill could use a little bit of balancing more towards skill --or at least informed deck building-- and the arenas just get way to small and crowded to fight in later on and both those things really ruin an otherwise ingenious game.oh and btw, I hate playing games on easy mode x)

												If you loved table-top fantasy roll playing games like Tunnels & Trolls and Dungeons & Dragons but don't have anyone to play with, Hand of Fate will quickly convince you that you don't need anyone else.Story Mode is an Epic Adventure, Adventure Mode is better than that. In Adventure Mode there are many classes to play each with their own perks and drawbacks and special quest line you'll only see on that class, but the other non-class specific quest lines can show up in any class you play and be continued when switching classes.So you can play as the Explorer class and start the Minotaur Hunt quest and get a few phases into it then play as a Monk or Shadow Agent and pick up right where you left off and still reap the rewards...if you survive.Pros:CursesDangerBlessingsMagical weapons, armor and ringsBags of goldSacks of applesAdventureCons:The Jack of Dust's wife...man I hate her...

												Been looking forward to playing this game ever since I saw it in the store.There's one word I'd use to describe this game:  gravitas.Everything about it has a flair for the epic; for the dramatic....Think of this game as something like Diablo II in Card/Choose Your Own Adventure formatFrom the way story arcs are presented, the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, the combat presentation, the voice work, and the profound commentary provided by your card dealer, you will be left with goosebumps and O_O eyes along the way.There are various challenge modes you can go through after you've completed the game; there is also an option to wipe your progress should you wish to unlock all the cards again.There aren't many games like this - and I'm interested in seeing what the sequel will bring.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												I will recommend Hand of Fate, but certainly not without qualification.  Many elements of this game involve the RNG - the success/failure card picks, the combination of enemies you face in a given encounter (and the environment in which you face them), the weapons/magic/blessings/armor you have access to in a given game.  All of this can lead to a very frustrating experience.  You may desire to complete a "quest," only to find that you can't seem to get the "success" card multiple times in the card game. Sometimes, you won't even see the quest card that game.  Perhaps I should've seen all this coming? I enjoyed the Arkham Asylum-esque combat, and the ability to create both your equipment and encounter decks. My main recommendation would be simply to quit after you finish the campaign. Tying up the lose ends, even if you enjoy the game, may be more trouble than it's worth.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
This review is created for  My Curation Page.   Skip to the bottom for my Final Thoughts I purchased this game as a part of the Humble Freedom BundleHand of Fate is an innovative roguelike RPG card game with heavy top down slasher gameplay. You play a game of chance and adventure against the Master in a similar fashion to Dungeons & Dragons with hands on combat.GraphicsHand of Fate is visually beautiful. There are a plethora of maps, equipment, enemies, and, of course, the cards. The small maps are all unique and different from the last and are very nice to look at. Whether you're in a forest or arena, the backgrounds are all detailed and very well done. Every card in the game as it's own card art as well as it's in game model.GameplayHand of Fate is both luck-based as well as skill-based. Luck is a big portion of the game as it is in Dungeons & Dragons. Whether you succeed or fail an event boils down to whether you pull a successful card or a failure which can have positive outcomes or disastrous complications. Before every "campaign", you can choose the deck; what equipment cards there are, randomised events, and enemies that all have set required amounts to keep the game both challenging and interesting.After every campaign you complete, you are rewarded with new cards, events, and bosses. Every campaign can completely change the next, for better or for worse. Completing a campaign isn't completely rainbows and sunshine. Everytime you beat the Master, he bites back; with increased difficulty in monsters, and bosses. The amount of replay value in Hand of Fate is astonishing. There is never a dull moment. The first campaign can very well be your last because of how your deck varies with the increasing amount of cards added to the pool.Audio & SoundtrackThe music in Hand of Fate as well as the voice acting are amazingly well done. The voice actor for the Master is both mysterious and beckoning. To whoever did the voice acting; well done to you, good sir. The Master narrates the story that unfolds before your eyes with lulling words that pull you in the more you play. He taunts you but also supports you. Is he a villain, anti-villain, or a silent hero? The music is also very well done. The genre in music varies but keeps you on your feet with adventurous music pushing you forward toward the final boss and the sweet rewards that await you. As I previously mentioned, the music varies through the levels and campaigns and never bores you with endless looping tracks. The atmosphere the music creates is like no other and can help create impact with the narration of the Master.StorylineThe story for Hand of Fate is rich and interesting. Every campaign has a different story that seemingly interconnect. Every boss has a different backstory that the Master pulls you into. Some bosses have stories that make you pitiful for the hardships they went through, while other backstories make you want to drive a stake through the heart of the scoundrel. The Master is simply that. A master. He crafted all the stories, cards, equipement, and events himself. He is the storywriter of the whole game and everything that happens is from his creation. Hand of Fate is a game about a game that the Master has invited you into.Developer RecommendationsI don't have much to complain about Hand of Fate, but if I were to complain about any one thing, it would have to be the controls. The combat is fluent only after you really get a hang of the controls. The first few hostile encounters I engaged in had me beaten and battered as I tried to figure out how to really dodge and roll around the enemies before they attacked. Combat against ranged enemies is also a little bit awkward but once you get used to the contant running and rolling, you'll be good to go.Final ThoughtsHand of Fate is one of my favourite games so far. It's fun, and that's what I look for in a game. It drew me in from in the first 20 minutes and just like that; I'm hooked. I want to defeat the Master and come out on top of his elaborate story. I believe that everyone should try out Hand of Fate, even for a couple minutes. Rating:Graphics: 8.6/10Audio: 8.9/10Gameplay: 8.6/10Overall: 8.7/10Enjoy the review? Please check out  My Curator Page  as well as my  YouTube Channel .

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												  Dag, ya'll.  If there ever was a game I'm mad *I* didn't make, it's 'Hand of Fate'.  A sweet-spot mashup of roguelike, deck builder, narrative choose-your-own-adventure and ARPG, this game swooped in and became my favorite new game in my Steam library(which is pretty substantial at 520+, because I'm a Humble Bundle Hoarder).  The game is really pretty, first of all - very well polished.  The art on the cards is funky, medieval-illustration inspired, and the renderings on the 3D characters are really well done - ragdoll physics as enemies croak are super fun to watch, having them careen all floppy into the edges of the arena.  The random element to the game in terms of the choice cards is shell game style - you see which cards are which, and then you can watch them shuffle before your eyes - you can actually FOLLOW them.  The difficulty arises with multiple shuffles, but it's still great that it doesn't fall to RNG; there is some skill there.  The game is laid out like a tarot spread, and your pawn moves from card to card - you can hop to any adjacent one - and that flips them over, wherein you encounter what's beneath.  Could be a shop, could be an encounter, could be a token encounter - the tokens are a really interesting way to progress the game, and add replay value: each card with icons on the bottom have a chance to give generic tokens, unlocking random cards from the 'common' deck - when you finish a run, the tokens break like seals to reveal new cards.  But there are also storyline encounters - tokens with colored and unique icons - that when broken, give new cards that often progress the storyline for THAT specific card.  You may not reach the objective on the card - in fact, often you're not told what the objective is - depending on how you play you may or may not achieve the card's purpose... but the fun part is putting that card back in your deck to figure out how to defeat it.  Combat is Arkham-styled(when you have a shield), wherein you hit a button to counter when you get the green icons above your head(slap back ranged weapons, slide over and face-smash melee attackers), and red icons are unblockable so you can smoothly dodge-roll out of the way.  Weapons all feel different, they all LOOK cool, and all have different abilities, and not just simple "double damage to undead" type of stuff.  There's that too... but the additions are super sweet, like gaining cash from smacking bandits.  Arguably my favorite portion of the game is the Narrator himself - a mystic with a face veil and a hood who tells the stories of the cards as you progress through the game, and his voice acting is top notch.  He actually comes through with some creepy and cryptic nuggets of wisdom - his narration never seems overdone or trite, there's just enough to keep you entertained, and well crafted.  Listen to him; he reveals secrets, if you pay attention.  This game is a work of art, seriously.  One of the most unique and well crafted experiences on Steam and absolutely highly recommended.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												Hand of Fate is a card game brought to life with Batman Arkham combat and deckbuilding to customize your events and equipment pool.It also has an endless mode where you have to survive for as long as possible with every card you've ever gotten mixed in the frey.Let me just say that for an indie game the production values feel triple AAA.So here are my biggest pro and cons of this game.Pros Responsive combat. A huge variety of equipment, monsters and events. The card artwork artist really outdid himself. Fantastic music by Jeff van Dyck. The dealers narration is incredible. A fairly lenghty story mode and a more rogue-like endless mode. Very stylized graphics that looks great. The game dynamically get's more difficult as your opponent's own deck improves alongside yours with more enemies and negative outcomes.Cons Unlike other rogue-likes the combat is easy enough that you can more or less get through the game despite what the RNG gives you. If you're good enough this does create a weird meta where good players will have a 100% win rate. Bosses are fairly weak when you first encounter them so it feels sligthly anticlimactic. Several of the weapons are straight up just upgrades over others meaning that meta decks get very similar. Every weapon is one handed so despite what you're using combat is always very samey.I really enjoyed Hand of Fate, it's one of the best surprise diamonds I have played in years.I highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a good rogue-like and also for people unfamiliar with the genre and want a more simplistic game with easy to learn but hard to master combat.10/10 Truly a shining gemstone to display on the cabinet.

												Pros:This game has hands-down the best atmosphere of anything I've ever played.  I really can't think of another experience that's sucked me in so completely.  The action is mostly quick and intense, with the card-sequences providing suspense and tension for an overall very well-paced experience.  Hand of Fate is one of my personal favourites; it's just one of those games I just keep circling back to again and again.  Cons:Most of the DLC is unfortunately based on long linear chains of events, and these clash badly with the much more freeform vanilla cards.  The camera is annoying on any of the bigger maps.  The combat is really frustrating if you don't have a gamepad.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Where did this mystery of a game come from? Out of nowhere it seems. I was intrigued when I saw the store page and watched some videos via Steam broadcasting. There's nothing quite like it. At its core its a card game where you start immediately in some mysterious location, at a very creepy gaming table and even more mysterious dealer. He deals encounter cards which form your "playing board". You move your token around the board uncovering the cards and your story or "fate" unfolds as the title implies. The encounter cards vary from quests, travelers, monsters, combat, shops, weapons, artifacts, blessings, curses, mazes and all sorts of other things (good and bad) too numerous to mention. Many of the cards offer you a choice which you must consider carefully as it will affect the outcome of the game. Your goal is to defeat boss encounters and move your way up to more challenging decks and bosses. All the while the dealer talking and commentating on the state of the game. The voice acting is superb. A very well done and hypnotizing soundtrack really sets the mood and makes you feel like your taking place in something epic.As you play you unlock more cards which then go into your deck and the dealer's deck both of which you can customize within the game rules. This makes the game even more interesting and varied as you go and replay again. In the end though each play session is procedurally generated as he deals the cards, adding some of his own and making each play through unique. Will you live or die? What waits for you at the end of the card chain? You'll just have to play to find out.Your three primary resources are health, gold and food, all of which are necessary to proceed. Along the way you'll need to (hopefully) acquire enough and manage/spend them all wisely or you might find yourself rich and starving, or poor and overfed with not enough gear to stay alive in combat. It's your choice but balance seems to work the best.The combat takes place in 3D top down arenas played Diablo style. It's fast paced, dramatic, very tense and requires quick reflexes. Here you can use artifacts, special weapon powers and abilities if you're fortunate enough to have found them to help you in your fight. If not then well.....good luck.Table graphics are excellent. The card art is average. The fighting arena graphics won't win any awards but are decent enough to get the job done. It doesn't matter though because the gameplay trumps everything else and that's clearly where the devs put most of their efforts. With the exception of the final level difficulty which is miserably hard, the game is near perfect.It's risky pushing the boundaries of stale genres and the litany of "card" games that flood the store. This game succeeds in doing so on so many levels. Highly recommended if you're looking for something different.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Firstly, I need to enter in my overall bias for the game. It's Australian made, therefore it's freaking awesome! That aside the game delivers a turned based competent along with a live-action platform environment. I'm going to describe both for you.The turned based competent is a card delivery system where prior to going on your adventure you can select your deck of cards for scenario's and then select your deck of cards for equipment (ranging from weapons, sheilds, armour, rings and spells). The higher you rank in your adventuring quest the more cards you can have in your deck. You start your adventure on a 'dungeon crawl' in a turned based environment where food and gold is your life essence to get to the end game/boss. On each move a random card is flipped to tell you a tale or a random scenario that you will need to select your course of action. The course of action may having you flipping on a x4 success or failure card. Failure could result in lost health or food/gold. Getting to traders and selling some of your gear helps you move on.A scenario based could result in an encounter - which then brings you to the live-action platform part of the game, you have your warrior in a rear facing fight controlled by mouse and keyboard (gamepad optional). The card flip will result in the amount of monsters you are engaging and the tier level of monsters. Your fight then has you fighting trying to keep your hit sequence as high as you can to score crits, so it can bea a fast flowing combat.Overall this is a great go to game when you have 15 minutes or 2 hours to spare gaming. End of game will score you 'chips' which give you more cards to play with. There are modes you can play in for difficulty and an endless mode to see how far you can really go too, which is highly enjoyable or at times distarous based on your choices.A great game for the avid casual gamer market.Oh and the dealer has pure sex for a voice :)7.5 / 10

Early Access Review
								Intresting, stylish adventure awaits! Storyline and setting make this game a very enjoyable expierence, concept of a card-driven rogue game add a rather plesant taste.However, there are some problems with battle system. And this is actually the only problems I can think of.Firstly, in a battle everything against you, even the camera. It is sort of fixed and how many times I got hit just because I can't see the enemy right in front of my character - I can't even count. Secondly, slowmotion. It happens, yeah, cool stuff, but... It throw timing of the strike off balance so much, that it feels like your opponent DOES NOT GET AFFECTED by slow-mo. It can be just a feeling, though, but it leaves a bitter aftertaste.And third problem is the time which your char needs to react to a pressed button. Even if you press counter at the moment an emblem of a throwing weapon appear above your head, it doesn't mean you will reflect it at all. Timings a bit of odd.But! This game is great, seriously. And very good. Especially, the comments of your wizard opponent, so much soul put in this game... It rocks.

Posted: May 9, 2016
												Worth its price and more.Excellent concept, incredible replayability, wonderful voice acting (The Dealer is the only person speaking), cool fusion between a card game and a hack-and-slash, where the meta card game sets your abilities, equipment, blessings, curses, and challenges in the short hack-and-slash battles in closed rooms.Great variety of cards and stories.The downsides - can't customize your character, big discrepancy between very easy and very hard cards, the Dealer's voice actor is so good you'll wish they recorded more lines for him. Really, I'd pay more for a DLC where he talks more.Overall, very satisfied, an 8 or 9 out of 10 (5 being an average game, so that's pretty high score).Worth up to $40 in my opinion. DLC is worthwhile as well, but I would play the main story first and see if you like it. You'll love it or hate it. If you love it, buy the DLC before continuing.

												If you love the risk and reward game this is it for you, Hand of Fate is an exciting and really really chanllenging game it's like Dark Souls combine with Darkest Dungeon where things can go heavenly or very very badly really really quick.At first glance you might think Hand of Fate is relying on a lot of an RNG(luck) which can lead to frustration because of it's randomness but believe it or not, i think it's really balance in this game, since the game gave you a choice almost everytime and like i said it's risk or reward, win it you gain a lot but if you lose it then prepare to get punished.One negative thing i can think of is the combat system, if you think Dark Souls is a dodge fest this is like even more dodge fest especially the end game where there's lot of uncountable attack and you fighting like 5-10 enemy almost everytime so it just came down to spamming dodge button with hit & run tactic, i really hope they balanced this and make the fight more tactical than just like smashing dodge like crazy.Overall Hand of Fate is an exciting and challenging game with interesting story and excellent voice acting in the game if you love these kind of stuff then hesitate no more trust me from hard core Souls fan here.

												This game has a cool idea but is poorly executed. In my opinion the combat is the most fun to be had but felt too simple. The only time I struggled in combat was when there were a ton of traps or when I was getting spammed with ranged attacks. The rest of the game just feels like complete luck. I guess there's some strategy in building the encounter deck but really the "hardest" encounters are just luck in my opinion. Also I feel a big disconnect between the exploration and the combat. I didn't really feel like I wanted any of the things I could get from the encounters or the shops, I just wanted to get to the boss with a decent amount of health and at least my starting equipment.Also the illusion of choice in picking cards is annoying instead of adding anything in my opinion; a simple roll without my input would feel much better to me.

												Hand of Fate is a great twist on the roguelike genre that bursts with potential. Its full of surprising charm, from its charismatic dealer to its invigorating music, and the deckbuilding and evolving encounters are addictive. Its real-time combat is a welcome change and ought to tip the balance in your favour, but too often it feels more unfair than the chance elements themselves. It will both involve and frustrate, but overall it's a success and worth the purchase.

Posted: March 22
												This game is a lot of fun, but I can only recommend with caution as it has some extremely frustrating issues.The devs did an excellent job blending a deck-building game with Batman/Arkham style combat sequences. As you progress through the game with the starting deck, you get to unlock more cards that build up equipment, gold, stats, blessings (buffs and other bonuses), curses (debuffs and other penalites), and different story-driven encounters. This helps as you grow more powerful through the game as you play randomly generated matches from your deck (with cards added by the Dealer) and each culminating in a mini-boss fight.A mini-boss is a stronger version of an ordinary mob with a unique and deadly uninterruptible attack that will be spammed with gusto. If you see them preparing to launch one, your only defense is to get away.During a match you will have any number of encounters that throw you into a succeed/fail situation, a choice-making situation, a pit stop to buy/sell stuff, or a combat situation. Combat has all the basic Arkham moves: Strike, Counter, Stun, and Dodge. There's also a combo meter that improves your damage if you can keep chaining hits. If you've equipped a weapon that has a magical power it will have unlimited uses + cooldown. You can also have an artifact equipped with limited uses + cooldown (artifact vanishes after last charge is spent).if you run out of health for any reason (damage from combat, starvation or a failure on a random event) you have to start the entire match over again, but any new unlocked cards are always added to your permanent deck. A match contains 3-5 levels made up of 6-12 randomly drawn encounter cards per level. The random layout of the cards at any level determine if you have to proceed through all of them or get to pick your path while searching for the exit to the next level. Also, you start every match with basic equipment. You only get your upgraded equipment via card draw awards or having enough money to buy an item from a shop. This means it's entirely possible to reach the end of a match and face off against the mini-boss with only starting armor/shield/weapon. There are no guarantees. You can even lose your starting items along the way from failed encounters and be forced to use light armour, a rusty axe, and/or no shield.Despite the set-up sounding a bit tilted against you, it actually tends to balance out pretty well.Well, most of the time. Then you get into the clunky stuff:Unlike the Batman games, you have no camera control. Therefore in a 3D space certain maps will have blocked lines of sight due to poor camera placement -- either you won't be able to see enemies or you won't be able to see your own character. While most combat scenarios don't suffer too much from this, it can cause serious health loss when fighting large numbers, especially if a mini-boss is thrown into the mix. Imagine playing an Arkham game where a building suddenly blocks your view of the combat and only resolves if you blindly roll some direction until the camera clears the building. The same thing can happen with a ton of mobs in the foreground, so being near the back of the map is almost never a good idea. Healing in combat is tied to a handful of items and even then it's all passive (except for one weapon's magic ability) and almost never enough to make a difference. So there is no failsafe against taking hits due to camera issues -- the only rule of combat is "don't get hit".This alone wouldn't cause me to dislike the game. In fact I was having a blast despite this. Until the final match...Normal difficulty was already plenty challenging, but the final match of story mode where you face off against the Dealer is close to impossible without extremely good luck. (I don't even want to think about the odds at hard difficulty.)Your only true advantages in the Dealer match are: Like all matches you get to choose 32 equipment and 32 encounters you will use from among all your unlocked cards. In this case you must stack your play deck like mad to avoid as many potentially bad outcomes as possible. You get a ring that reveals which cards are shops at the beginning of each level in the match. You get one random piece of equipment. Usefulness depends on what you chose to put in your play deck.The disadvantages are: You start with two curses. One removes any blessings and prevents you from acquiring others. The other adds a curse card every time you move to the next level in the match. The Dealer's pain cards are significantly shifted toward removing health permanently, lowering your survivability. Most combat encounters no longer drop loot, meaning fewer chances to snag equipment upgrades or money to buy them. Increased chance to fail in succeed/fail encounters. Some choice scenarios also get worse.  For instance, there is an encounter card where a wounded knight lies on the side of the road with the option to help him or ignore him. Under normal circumstances you could ignore him and nothing will happen, but in this match if you ignore him you'll draw a curse card and sometimes you won't get the option to help, he'll just attack. More pain cards are drawn for failure and huge failures.The entire match leads up to the final combat against the Dealer. But you don't fight him. Instead he summons four waves of enemies each containing THREE mini-bosses you fought before and sometimes a few adds. You'll have at least 5 curses unless you spent money to remove some, no blessings, most likely a 10-25% health penalty, very possibly not at full health when combat starts, no healing, mostly the starting armor/shield/weapon, and possibly a useful magic weapon or artifact. And that's assuming you actually make it to the fight. If you die at any point, you have to replay the entire match.So while normal story mode keeps raising the challenge gradually from match-to-match, in the last one the difficulty spikes drastically. The imbalance has caused the average player to either give up or spend more time on the last match than the rest of the game combined to beat it. This is the most commented topic on the game's discussion boards.And yet, would draw cards again in Endless Mode. And looking forward to ... :DRating: 7.5/10Excellent concept. Definitely worth playing as long as you can make peace with the fact that you'll probably never complete story mode unless you play at easy difficulty (or the devs fix the final match balance). Seriously needs camera rotation to improve combat.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								         A card game rougue like. It says "Beta" which while true they aren't missing much. Mainly a few sounds here and there. So there will be an odd silence when you would expect a clink of metal or for your masked opponent to say something to you. Other than that maybe a few features here and there are missing like custom cards, characters and annoyingly enough a tutorial. I would love to see classes implemented and more in depth card play.        The 3D combat is simple but works well into the game. Each battle is short and usually is kept spiced up with traps, new enemies, and modifiers to gameplay. Its got a very batman arkham feel to it. With dodging countering and attacking while you bounce from enemy to enemy beating them over the head with that shiny new mace you got from a gorge. Then you play a little bit more of the card game and get some rewards and get excited for the next combat so you can test out that hail of daggers power you got. I'm perfectly fine with the simple short combat and never felt like it was hindering gameplay.        Now I should note that the whole card game bit is rather soft. It is a deck builder but the element is light and plays more of a thematic role (which by the way is my favorite part and by no means is a bad thing) The whole time your playing the game you are constantly getting new cards which you get to discover and play with. Everything very much feels like a mystical card game of sorts. Not a hearthstone/magic the gathering feel but none the less a mystical card game. (also my other favorite thing no microtransactions unlike many card games) The price may seem steep but I went ahead and took a quick peak of gameplay and was quite impressed. I won't expect you to get this game after my review but I would at least ask that you go take a peak at some gameplay even if you skip around the video. Short Hand: Love the theme and constant rewards.Mildly annoyed at a few small features that I feel are missing.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												- This review isn't written by a native speaker, thank you for your understanding -- If you haven't found this review helpful or if you have found a mistake please leave a comment below -Rating Must Play- Key features below ---- Review after -----------------------------------------------Play time needed (perfect) About 60 hours.Gaming level from Casual to GamerAchievement level between Casual and GamerGame style Role-Playing-Game (choices, encounter); Card game (deck building, encounters, equipment); Fighting; Rogue-like (treasure vault)Game modes Story mode; Endless modeStory Through the role-play.Playthrough One (story), One (endless)Voice Only the dealer, very good !Music Good too !Camera Not bad !Controls Keyboard or Controller (#)Tutorial Yes !Unmissable / backtracking content Yes !Customization Yeah, cards and character.Download contents DLC Yes, one additional needed, the other is the soundtrack.Glitches / bugs Good one. (*)Worth price It definitely worth its price ($28) even if it can be hard to get through some encounters or achievements.- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------Such an awesome game indeed ! The music is good, the dealer's voice is great with his speeches, the deck of card is really wide and so the choices too !The story mode let you beat each Jack, Queen and King of each 4 series through chapters. At the end of each chapter you have to deal with the Jack or Queen or King with a battle, a kind of small boss ! When you beat 3 or 4 of them you unlock a starting bonus and malus. When you succeed any encounter you unlock more cards by acquiring its token. Also each chapter have their own encounters, curses, blessings and shop that are added to the deck.The battle are played in real time with the stuff you got, the highest combo you make the heavier you attack. You need to manage your health and many items can help you like shields (reflect projectiles, counter attack, stun), artifacts (magical spells) and others ! You can also discover some vault to steal some gold if you dare avoiding all the traps ! There are also many enemies you can defeat, many encounters and lot of gold to gain and spend but do not forget to buy food before starving to death ! Don't worry you can still continue your journey while starving, but you'll soon need to find supplies before your last breath.In this game there is also a part of luck, you can still see the shuffle to guess where the card will be if you are able good enough or you can also have some equipment or blessing that will help you a lot. Also some fight can be really tough but you can easily get the strongest equipment you can to succeed every battle.(#):There is at least one little annoying thing with the controller, you can be really precise that much while you're moving. Indeed, when you're facing north and want to get south you'll need to go in circles instead of turning back. So that may be a little tougher to avoid traps.(*):The good thing is you can quit the game whenever you want and resume it before you reached the previous encounter. So you can use that to avoid death or avoid some encounters failures whenever you want.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												Hand of Fate is a rogue-like-like.  It has randomly generated "dungeons" with random beneficial and detrimental events and effects that either help or hinder your progress.The story mode:- gives you a short, multi-level dungeon to defeat- with the boss of the dungeon being the major goal.- Can you find and defeat this boss before you die?- If so, you win and are granted access to the next story mode level/dungeon/boss.The endless mode:- is very similar to the story mode, except for three main things:- First, it never ends... there's no final dungeon floor with a boss on it, and you just keep going until you die.- Second, you have no control over which cards are included in the deck - they all are, including the ones you hate.- Third, every floor  grants some sort of curse or other detrimental effect that will usually follow you for the remainder of that run - better hope it's just 5 hp damage or something, which you can generally recover from quickly, and not some intense curse that affects food/gold acquisition.As you succeed at card events, you will unlock additional cards, including new equipment, new card events, and new bonuses.  In this way, even though your blessings/curses/equipment/etc. don't carry from dungeon run to dungeon run, you do progress.  You are unlocking a deck, much like opening a booster pack in a trading card game.  It's a fun way to progress in a game that otherwise focuses on each single challenging run.Is it worth buying?  I got it as part of a Humble Bundle, and honestly, I can see myself coming back to play this for years to come.  I don't like buying games at full price, but if I knew there'd never be a deal on this game, I'd probably buy it.  I see it as a must have for any fan of rogue-like-likes.Oddly enough, it reminds me most of FTL (Faster Than Light), the rogue-like-like where you pilot a spaceship attempting to avoid and eventually defeat the evil fleet that wants you dead.  FTL is another exceptionally good game that deserves your attention if you enjoy rogue-like-likes.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Terrificly executed game. It's a mash up of everything great in video games. When I read that it had Arkham style combat and deck building I immediately thought, "How in the world would that work? They're not even part of the same genre!" This game pulls it off and adds a ton a replayability through the use of random board paths.As the game progresses, it becomes brutal. There's a good chance you will die even when everything seems to be going your way. Score some critical successes on a few events and it doesn't look like anything can slow you down? Critical failure. You're now starving and down to 23 health before a pack of 10 Ratmen gang up on you and poison you to death with their lingering acid.It's both oddly satisfying and frustrating at the same time. It's not perfect, but you'll have so much fun starting up another run that you won't even care.

												Test your hand of fate as the dealer progressively stacks the deck against you in this rogue-like rpg.This is one of the most enchanting games I've ever played - It's the perfect combination of story telling, atmosphere, action, strategy and rogue-like rpg mixed into one.+Slow motion killing blows and ragdoll physics make you feel like a god.+Active support from the developers.+Engrossing music- The only drawback is that you can have a bad streak of cards drawn against you that will completely cripple your run.I recommend buying this game even at full price!Overall - 9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 26
												25% chance to just game over on an ironman style game. Game over, and very very angry.Let me explain. This is a game where many of your decisions are opaque; you have to make so many choices without full information, and without an idea what might go wrong. This is generally a bad design decision, but in Hand of Fate it is a feature. Early on there are simple challenges with simple outcomes. You keep encountering the same things, and discover through trial and error which things are worth attempting, avoiding.The game screws with you a bit. The same card can have different outcomes that are not visible. When you're out of food, there seems to be a bias for gaining food from encounters, even ones you would not expect it from. There are variations of the same encounters too, which keeps the game fresh. These are excellent designs, though not perfect. I've had at least one run where I found 0 food. Which is annoying, but it's a proceedural game. It's bound to happen from time to time.Settling encounters is done three ways: Decisions, chance and combatCombat, which is often difficult depending on circumstance, but largely skill based (though having the right equipment and blessings will make you into an unstoppable monster). It's possible to win almost every fight regardless of what you are fighting, and your circumstances.Decisions, as I have mentioned are largely opaque, until you have encountered a card many times, and seen all the outcomes.And chance is settled by four cards, which are shown to begin with, then shuffled a number of times depending on the difficulty of the check. A 1 shuffle is really slow, and you can follow the cards with your eyes easily, so can more easily pick the success or failures. A 6 shuffle is so fast you are basically choosing at random.BUT, the great success/success/fail/great failure is again opaque. Sometimes less successful checks bring greater boons.And this brings me to where the system starts to have trouble: Sometimes to progress stories you must fail. Narratively, these make sense, but it takes away your agency. You are already making blind decisions. But now you're expected to go for a failure, when the rest of the game has trained you to avoid it?Finally, the situation I found myself in. Play this game of chance with some devils (the fourth in the chain, I believe, and might be the first time I encountered this particular one). Yes/No. Hrm. These guys have cursed me in the past for failing. I can deal with more curses, if it comes to that. See the range of cards. Keep an eye on the great success... shuffleshuffleshuffleshuffleshuffleshuffle. Oh well. Ok. Hm. Pick. Total failure "At least you got an achievement, (12 fails/total fails in a single session)". Great, probably going to get two more curses... Auto dead. Game over.So:Opaque choice.One random, skill-free check.Automatic game-over despite all other conditions.Automatic loss, on an effective total random 25% chance.OK. That just happened. Can I play a game, that through no fault of the player, you can simply lose?I could just avoid that card... but I also know that other cards have several variations. This same run I lost 150 gold and an artifact to a card that I thought only had beneficial effects. So yeah. Instant death can be in other places too. It could be on every card, hidden behind a check I have so far never failed before, or a variation I haven't faced.My trust is broken. I cannot play this game anymore.

								Hand of Fate is a mixing of genres. The goal of the game is to ultimately beat the Dungeon Master-esque character sitting across the table from you. while overall a great game it really shines when you actually start. the game starts you off with a pre-made deck and a relativley linear route to take. as you progress you will have random events and encounters the combat encounters are well made and the combat system a "callback" to my batman days. as you progress through the game you eventually reach the boss which scales in difficulty to what level you are on. obviously while this game IS in early acess it is still a worthy mix of binding of isaac, the batman game franchises, and even tabletop RPG's like DnD.definitley a85/100

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I have only played Hand of Fate for through about half of the Story mode decks but, I must say it is one of the greatest games I have ever played.  Combining the death and start over mechanic of a Rogue Like, with the addictive nature of a Deck Builder was an absolutely brilliant idea.  Having the encounters with monster cards be played out in a slightly Arkham Style (Attack/Counter/Dodge/Stun) was an even further brilliant idea.  Although the combat is the weakest part with a fixed camera, it is still manageable and fun.  Trap Rooms are also played out in this 3rd person camera style as you dodge your way through a trap maze.Even if you complete all 12 of the storymode levels there is an Endless mode to see how far you can go.  The game starts out relatively simple, but starts to become challenging about 1/4 of the way through the Story decks.Add to this the amazing way it's presented, the dealer is well voice acted and doesn't get annoying.  I cannot recommend this game enough.It's reminds me of playing a game of Munchkin, but against a dealer instead of a group of friends.  Absolutely brilliant.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I usually never complete games. Even if I like a game, I play it for a few hours and rarely do I play them again. I usually manage to play free to play or horde mode games more than 30 hours. But this game...I am well over 20 hours already and not even beginning to feel like I should stop anytime soon. Only just now am I nearing the end of the game content wise, but that does not mean that the game is over. It just means that I am almost ready to start playing Endless mode properly. An unique game that is a wonderful combination of different genres you would not usually mix.  A collectible card game mixed with a third person arkham style brawler is something you would not expect to work this well, but it just does.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								A great mixture of rogue-like, RPG, and card based elements makes this a terrific game.  It combines the combat of the Arkham series with the elements of any fantasy table top, pencil and paper RPG.  At the beginning of each story quest which culminates in a boss encounter, you build up an encounter and an equipment deck of cards that you have acquired previously.  The events of the story and the rewards of various adventures in that quest are randomized from these decks and a couple other decks the Dealer has at his disposal.  This gives the player more agency in the sequence of events and what equipment could be acquired during gameplay.  In addition, the game includes some resource management which presents obstacles to the player.One downside is that, like all rogue-likes, there is the possibility of having a "bad run."  You may not receive enough food and starve to death, not receive enough gold and be unable to purchase items or possibly be unable to complete encounter cards requiring gold, or have bad luck in general leading to the character's untimely demise.  However, the randomness that causes this problem also makes each iteration of a quest different than the previous ones and so, keeps the game interesting and alive.Presently, this game is in beta and the devs are still balancing it.  Even so, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys pencil and paper RPGs, Arkham style combat, and rogue-likes.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hand of Fate is a strange combination of genres - collectible card game meets 3rd person action. The premise is rather vague at present, but it boils down to you gambling for your life in a complex card game. You have an Encounter and Equipment deck, which you can edit as you see fit, and the cards are dealt into game boards of varying shape. You move around the board, revealing challenges and encounters, which you must then complete to move on. Some of them are choise or chance based, others are pure combat encounters, some are a mix of the two.Completing encounters sometimes earns you more cards, which you can add to the deck for future games, and undesireable encounters can be removed, allowing an interesting sort of customization. Which encounters you see in a given game is still random, but you can influence the pool of encounters that's available.The game features 12 bosses, each of which has some unique encounters, rules or effects to contend with, and after each 3 bosses, the old enemies get stronger, new encounters are introduced, and the player's starting equipment improves, creating a very well-designed progressive difficulty curve, where the same encounter card will increase in difficulty as the pool of enemies and detrimental effects grows.Combat is simple but very fluid and works very well for the game. Your equipment has a great impact on how combat flows, and with a few exceptions, the controls are very tight.Movement is a little clunky feeling - turning 180 degrees causes you to move to one side slightly (picture a very tight turn on a bicycle - you're can't turn in place), which doesn't usually cause problems, but some encounters involve negotiating complex series of traps, and imprecise movement can easily result in taking otherwise avoidable damage from these. Overall, this is a fairly minor inconvenience, though, and certainly isn't a major detriment to the enjoyment of the game.Some attacks in combat 'track' targets, which is good, but they do it from a very long distance (often resulting in the character lunging around the battlefield from target to target). This works, but it looks a little silly, and it can be both beneficial and detrimental - it makes it easy to hit targets that're a good distance apart, but at the same time, it feels a little unpredictable, and will sometimes cause the player to lunge into an attack that they were well out of range of otherwise.Some of the encounters feel a little unfair - for example, there's a (very) late-game encounter that gives you a 50% chance of failure - and failure means instant death. Once you've unlocked it, you can't remove it from the deck until you've 'succeeded' at the encounter, and I died to it 7 times before finally making that 50% die roll. Since there's very few ways to see that the encounter is coming up before you step on it, this feels a little cheap, and I could have done with less of this, but the flavor of the encounter was at least appropriate, and a single 'game' only takes 15-20 minutes in most cases, so dying to this card at least wasn't as frustrating as it could have been.Overall, the game is extremely fun. It starts off slow and ramps up quickly with a very reasonable feeling difficulty curve, and the recent addition of an 'Endless' mode adds a ton of replayability even after defeating the 12 bosses. The 'ending' is not yet in the game (early access), but even considering only the content currently available (which is very substantial), this game is absolutely worth the money - even at 'full price', which is not something I will often say - if you enjoy the genres it's combining.

Early Access Review
								A mixture of random dungeon, table top cards, and third person combat arenas Hand of Fate takes the random chance of dice and tosses them out the window. While your travels may lead you to an unknown destination as the cards on the table are unknown until you traverse them when it comes to combat and tactics it's all on you to know when to block, when to attack, and when to run. Step on a card and you may get a boost to your money, a travelling salesman may be passing by, or you may get ambushed in your sleep by goblins who steal your favorite weapon. Regardless of the incidents manage your health, your gear, and your food well and you may stay alive long enough to defeat the boss at the end of each dungeon and earn some excellent rewards for your next trip through.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								In-depth analytical video on Hand of Fate: (written review below)


YouTube™ Video: Swash! ❧ Hand of Fate Peek (Early Access Review) 

			Views: 2,776		

			An in-depth peek, towards Hand of Fate, a mixture of dungeon crawler, third-person brawler and some smaller deck building elements thrown into the mix, brought to you by SwashbucklingSir.		

The aesthetics of Hand of Fate are undoubtedly stellar. The high quality ranges from great sketches for every card, to beautiful 3D graphics as soon as the brawling starts. Most notably here are the lighting and special effects that manage to bring the whole scenery to life. Especially the fight against the Queen of Dust did impress me with its flying sand everywhere. Hand of Fate makes it abundantly clear that the overall aesthetics are not meant to be overlooked and it succeeds in creating a very appealing style overall.Almost the same could be said about the sound design of Hand of Fate. The dungeon master for example is exquisitely voice acted, the effects give precise feedback and underline every nook and cranny. Sadly, all of the event texts are not voice acted and have to be read, which is understandable in terms of budget for voice acting, however sad due to the competent voice actor already in the game. Since the music is mainly meant to create an atmospheric background noise instead of carrying emotion or story, it is competent in what it tries to achieve, however forgettable. All in all, the sound design of Hand of Fate is very good, could however be improved in terms of the quantity of voice acting.Let’s delve into the rather unique gameplay mixture of Hand of Fate. For every story adventure you start, not taking the endless mode into account, you prepare two deck of cards. On the left hand side the equipment that can be found during your dungeon crawling. Which consists not only of stronger weapons, but also of armour, helmets, gloves, rings, artefacts and trinkets. Ideally you would want to include cards specifically against a certain type of enemy that you suspect to encounter, however I mostly threw in new cards that I had not used before to keep the game experience fresh. On the right hand side of the decks, you can select the encounters that you want to possibly face during your adventure. Hereby it is important that some encounters cannot be removed until you fulfil certain conditions. The same procedures holds true as previously: I mainly selected encounters that I did either not face before to keep experiencing new content or that I did not manage to complete previously. As soon as you are satisfied with your decks, you start the story. Depending on the boss you plan to encounter at the end of the adventure, the card dealer adds some fixed cards into the mix, indicated by their purple tint and as soon as all decks are shuffled the game begins.The dungeon master begins by laying down the encounters face down in a randomly selected pattern. Now you strife to reveal the final boss and defeat said enemy to claim victory of this part of the story. Your character is indicated as golden statue and you always move by one card either horizontally or vertically hereby consuming one food, healing a bit and revealing the encounter you step on. One possible card is the choose-your-own-adventure style encounters, whereby you select an option and more often than not the final result is determined by your selection of one of four cards, ranging from huge success to huge failure and thus affecting the outcome rather randomly. While the encounters themselves are fun at their core, I do see a problem in the random nature of selection as there is no skill or learning involved from the player’s side and thus it fails to feel rewarding when selecting success and at the same time also unreasonably punishing when you hit that huge failure card, especially when this ends up costing you your weapon just before facing the final boss. I would have preferred a system similar to how FTL manages random encounters by which certain abilities or other pre-collected items can affect the outcome positively.Another possible encounter is one of the multiple combat scenarios. This is where the third person brawling comes into play and the graphical fidelity turns up several notches. Depending on the encounter or just by random selection you will be spawned into one of several arenas together with a bunch of enemies and possibly even traps. These short brawling segments are highly reminiscent of the Batman Arkham series without being as fluent and as responsive. Make no mistake, the brawling in itself is good, however the animations are not quite as top notch as the basically perfect ones of the Arkham games. Also, at least in the first three hours, the combat is not as strategic and as deep as the inspiration. Hand of Fate mainly relies on counter-attacking on green indicators and dodging on red indicators, while there are only very few special moves or strategic approaches to the combat in itself. This problem obviously arises as the game relies on random generation and thus you are always dependent to create enemies that could be faced with the basic equipment, while other story-driven games can later on throw enemies into your way that require you to use the latest acquired item or special move and the like. To summarise, the brawling is competent and refreshing, however does feel repetitive after a while. A perfect example for this is the spawning animation. While it is highly enjoyable the first few times your character spawns and gets all his equipment step by step and lastly your huge hammer falls from the sky just before you charge the flabbergasted and underpowered bandits, after a couple of hours game time though, I wished this animation could be skipped or disabled entirely, as it eats up so much time, especially when going from combat to combat encounter and thus this delay turns to be obnoxious rather quickly. Oh, and speaking of annoying, the camera cannot be rotated while in the combat arena, which can lead to some weird angles and fighting directions. Hopefully that will be fixed in the future.After defeating the final boss at the end of the adventure or by dying in between due to combat or starvation, the tokens you collected along the way are opened and thus new cards are unlocked, keeping the encounters fresh and empowering your equipment for future approaches. With these new cards you start the cycle over again, selecting a new boss, adapting your decks and facing the latest random encounters you selected beforehand.All in all, Hand of Fate is a beautiful, very competent mixture of dungeon crawling choose-your-own-adventure, third person brawling and deck building, with a few flaws in between. Nonetheless, Hand of Fate is one of the best Steam Early Access games I have played and I am very much looking forward to future improvements, which in my opinion should mainly target the repetitive combat, possibly granting you permanent special moves every few defeated bosses and thus creating more depth and tactical approaches overall.UPDATEAs I now played a little more and stand before the Queen of Skulls, I must say that the further the game progresses, the more infuriating the random nature becomes. There are several encounters with three failure cards resulting in severe penalties like losing 50 health and 30 permanent health, basically rendering the whole remaining adventure impossible. Also, due to the entirely random nature of encounters, it happened multiple times that I died on the first floor. If the brawling would be a bit tighter and more fluent overall, I am rather sure that you could go through these encounters with ease, however for example a ranged attack from close up is impossible to block and if enemies swarm you, there is a good chance that an unblockable attack will it you while you are countering another one. All in all, Hand of Fate is still a good game, however the further I progress (now over 4 hours played) the less fun I have, thus I now doubt the longevity of this dungeon crawler.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												TL:DR Great game, unique premise, tonnes of replayability. One of the few kickstarter success stories, definitely worth your time and money.Basically, the premise of the game is that you are playing a card game against "The Dealer", the game is based around "Encounter" cards, this may be you finding a treasure chest but needing to go through a series of obstacles to get to it, being ambushed by skeletons or going to a demon clubhouse and gambling your soul after getting drunk. There are loads of them and they are very varied.The encounters usually come in sets, miniture stories that unlock as you complete each card in the sequence, which is dead cool and a good reason to keep unlocking cards. For every action in an encounter (that isn't directly combat) you pick from a set of four dealer shuffled cards, which indicate how much you failed or succeeded at the action, which adds a nice RNG element to the game (you can follow the card shuffle with your eyes, so not ENTIRELY luck based) and keeps things interesting.Your characters equipment and blessings/curses can also interact with some of the encounters, suprising me even 20+ hours in with new paths in the old cards I thought I knew. Even once you are finished with the story there is an endless mode which uses all the cards you have unlocked to create a neverending run which gets harder the longer you play. The replay value is huge.The combat is Arkham styled (counter system and very flowy in how you move between enemies), here the equipment from encounters will really come into play, it's fairly simple in terms of what you can do but gets quite tactical, as the battlegrounds can have traps and the enemies get harder and more complex as the game goes on. The dealers starts adding curses and difficult encounters to the deck, making the later levels very difficult.The game never feels like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or cheating, pretty much every encounter can be run away from/refused and the combat can be difficult but it never feels like any enemy is particularly over powered, it's always down to your own skill. Due to the huge number of encounters and equipment, your freedom to choose and balance risk/reward, and the RNG element every run feels unique, the only downside I would add is that the combat is fairly simplistic, but considering this is an indie development, it's a very impressive accomplishment.One of the few kickstarter success stories, definitely worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has a wonderfull strangeness about it. You go through a dungeon, gaining equipment, and fighting random encounters, much akin to a Roguelike. It's a deckbuilding game, wherein your decks, are built, by you to choose what encounters and equipment you are going to encounter. Simple Batman like controls, and you have yourself something that plays rather smooth, and is kinda neat. Later dungeons add elements such as curses and blessings that can change the way you handle it, giving you a much different way of approaching things. For instance, one of the games, in which I lost gold based on health remaining.  Do I forsake food, so that I can lower my health, as to not lose gold to buy things? Do I rely on my combat mastery to survive? Should I sell this item now, knowing I may well lose the excess gold left over from what I want to buy?  A simple thing can change it up quite a bit.But then there's the atmosphere. This game has a wonderful sense of mystery to it. It's dark, illuminated by candles, told in a haze. It is you vs. a mage who is playing cards that are symbolic of encounters from your past. The narration for him sells it very hard. His comments about what you do, the achievements you just got, how he feels about the cards,  and if you can handle them. As the sole talking bit of the game, he is fantastic, and his voice fits perfectly.  With a large amount of card unlocks, variable outcomes, and an atmosphere that I cannot emphasize enough, this game is something else. It was well worth breaking my Early Access embargo on it.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Hand of Fate is the perfect card game: everything revolves around doing your best with the cards you have, whenever they're good or bad (mostly bad). It's an interesting mix of deck building, rogue-like elements, dungeon crawling and third person action during battles. You build a deck of events, that will build the path of the dungeons, and of equipments, the rewards you'll get for successful encounters: sometimes you'll have to fight, sometimes you'll have to 'roll a dice', sometimes you'll have to make the right choice. It's a very interesting and well developed concept. Of course the Dealer will do his best to make things worse for you, but as he says "The game is fair and you'll be defeated fairly".Hand of Fate has a well built learning curve and difficulty curve, knowing when to challenge you and how to do that. Sometimes you'll get frustrated by unfair conditions (like fighting twelve enemies in a small arena), but that's part of the rogue-like nature. I LOVED the atmosphere and the monologues of the Dealer, a very charismatic and interesting character: his presence alone is worth buying the game if you ask me. There are a couple of downsides, mostly regarding the battle system: a targeting system and a health bar above the enemies would have been useful and made the battle less chaotic; a couple of collisions are off and a very limited number of arenas have some visibility issues in certain points. All around it's a great game, if you like mixing the chance of card games with the risks of rogue-likes. It could use some polishing, but its atmosphere and concept are so fantastic that you can overlook it.8,5/10

												Possibly one of my favorite games! I won't go into all the details, theres enough reviews for that, just here to say that this is an amazing game, and definitely worth full price in my opinion. Here is why:PROS:- This game is based on both luck, skill, a small amount of tactics, and then luck again. These factors combined give a, to me, unrivalled sense of accomplishment upon reaching the final floor of a level. (Though thats posdibly due to me not usually playing rogue-likes)- It's vastly replayable. I've been stuck on the final boss for at least three hours already, I've rage quited twice, and yet every time I start it back up right away to give it another go, because even the same level is never the same. And then there's endless mode...- Extremely interesting design. Just look at the trailer and other descriptions. Enough said.- Better than Telltale when it comes to immersing you in an engaging story. Each time you gain a token you just can't wait to find out what kind of card it will unlock next.- The dealer. I will just get in on the hype and mention, like everyone else, hoe great the voice acting on this guy is.CONS:(Seriously, just get the game)- The dealer again. Though his voice acting is great, after 30 hours of play he gets a bit repetitive. Only slightly anoying though. And probably just to me.- If you rage quite by Alt-F4'ing because you died during battle you start on the card you were standing on in the turn before the battle, making it possible to try again in the same session. Don't abuse this. Just don't. It kills the rogue-like ferl.- Charity VI. You'll know what I mean once you unlock it. Do I look like Jesus to you? I can't do that trick with the bread and the fish y' know...

Posted: May 30, 2015
												This game is truly an incredible surprise.  It is only a card game in the sense that there are random elements and you get to pick some of the deck those elements are drawn from.  It is only an action game in the sense that you play the encounters you draw, but these encounters are not as tiresome and repetitive as in most 3D action brawlers.  It is only a RPG in the sense that you pick, sell, buy, and loot equipment with different properties and you can choose a "fate" for your character that changes the rules of the game.  But if you take those pieces and put them together, and add in elements of choose-your-own-adventure and rogue-likes, you get a unique, fun, changing game with beautiful presentation.  If you only tried it in early access, try it again.  I was shocked when I went back to this in my library.
