content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												Halfway through the game I can recommend (when on sale) to those interested in a combination strategy/rouge experience. The strategy part isn't that deep however; mostly you have to decide how to keep enough food and health (and get some good gear) to reach the boss. Beat the boss, and start fresh on each new level. Though there isn't that much variety in turns of battling (bascially move really fast/dodge/attack, repeat), there is enough skill challenge to keep it fairly interesting. Hand of Fate is more than the sum of its parts: everything comes together to give you 12 short and relatively enjoyable rouge-like levels in story mode. Chance has more of an effect in your ability to beat a level than most games, and sometimes luck will go against you. Only had really bad luck in one level out of 6 so far, which perhaps means the odds are stacked in the player's favor. Three consecutive pain cards was indeed painful; lost 60 health right before boss, lost boss battle, needed to repeat entire level.     7/10: Would randomnly lose 60 health again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												    - Short version: Truly an inspiring, creative, fun game. Beware though, this is not a card game. Yes the theme is about card games but the combat is the 50% of the gameplay and it is the ultimate deciding factor between the win or loss condition. Definately watch a gameplay video of Totalbiscuit or whatever before purchasing!!! aside from that, this is totally worth the purchase.    - Long version: Although the price seems a tad bit high, you will probably feel like the game deserves it in the first 30 minutes of gameplay. The theme is laid out elegantly, voice acting, soundtrack and the general atmosphere is just amazing.      You get to create your own deck of possibilities (cards are events). Your decisions and sometimes mere chance decides the outcome of that event. Events can sometimes turn into a battle ( AC style 3rd person combat style) .     Combat is the 50% of this game in the beginning. However in the later stages of the game, the strategy, deck-building and the choices made outside of the combat is the bigger deciding factor. So its safe to say that combat is probably around 25% of importance once you get better at it.   ---------------PROS:       *  TONS of replay value. (This is the part that deserves the full price);         *  Awesome presentation. Artwork just fits with the theme like a glove;      *  Great gameplay mechanics. Combats last as long as they should, no more or less;       *  Simple UI design is just relaxing, the game has almost no menu's or complicated screens;      *  Most importantly, The game makes you want to play again, and again, and again...-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------CONS:       * Combat. This game would be PERFECT withouth combat (or at least with different styles) . I can't describe the exact reason but the game is just too perfect "on the table" with the atmosphere, that I want to sit on that table, face to face with the dealer. Combat feels like a chore, something to get out of the way before I can come back. It just feels like a break from the actual game. Totally breaks the immersion for me.      *  In the story mode, everything builds up to combat, and resolves with the outcome of the combats (or at least the final combat). God I just wish cards would be a little bit more important. (not just determining the variables of combat)     Overall: A perfect game for some, but not the game for everyone. Has its own style. Really original ideas that should not be missed out. Worth the purchase

content:
Posted: January 3
												It is hard to put this game into words that describe it well. It is in some way a deck building / card game, but all fights are conducted as hack&slay 3rd person fights where the moves are a bit similar to the batman games (evade, counter, attack, some special skills). So what happens in a standard round of Hand of Fate?1. I select a story / main quest to play2. I select a preset deck and review it to exchange cards3. Play (the following steps a & b repeat multiple times):3.a. Move your character across a map made of cards which are revealed upon reaching them. These may then trigger sidequests, encounters, shops, traps etc. They come along with stories where you can often choose how to react to an encounter, which gives you different results.3.b. In case you engage in a fight, you go into the battle mode. This is classic hack and slay action with block, dodge, attack.4. You complete the round by beating the final boss (or dying). During 3. you have completed many events that gave you tokens. These unlock future side quests, weapons or other cards to be used in future rounds. So once done, go back to step 2, to make use of your sweet loot!I really enjoy RPGs, good progression systems, deckbuilding and a fresh gamestyle. In my opinion, Hand of Fate combines these mechanisms into an oh so refreshing and satisfying experience that anyone with similar preferences should not miss!

content:
Posted: January 4
												Graphics: I was satisfied with the graphics, they fit the theme very well and are easy on the eyes.Gameplay: Incredibly addicting. The adventure-as-a-card-game theme worked beautifully and you get a real sense of progression: 1) In each individual game you build up hoards of equipment/blessings/gold/food as you move from encounter to encounter.  2) In the overarching game you collect new tokens that unlocks new encounters/equipment as you complete the story mode and also as you trudge along in the endless mode. The combat is crisp and controls are reasonably well implemented. There are occassional frustrations with the non-controllable / constantly-chaning camera angles that messes up your combat movements but they are bearable.The game give players a good challenge that ramps up as you move further into the game (especially in endless mode).  The balance is a good one - you'll never feel so overpowered that you get bored. No matter how much equipment / gold / food you accumulate, everything can change in a second with a bad encounter or curse in the late game.  In the beginning, everything's easy and the loot rains down with very forgiving bad encounters. Towards the late-game of endless mode, when you're decked out with all the good equipment and blessings and gold and food, the game really ramps up the consequences such as losing multiple equipments in a single bad encounter, get 10+ curses thrown on you (one for each ring you have and players are generally encouraged to hoard all the different rings they can buy/find because the effects stack), or get thrown in a gladiator pit with no equipment to help you out in the battle (did I mention that the monsters are usually powered up 2-3 times already at this point due to accumulating curses?).Story:No real story to the game, though the backstory (or at least hints of it) of the dealer and game itself can be interesting for a bit as the dealer provides cryptic comments. Each game is a create-your-own adventure that is formed by all the encounters you experience.Replay Value:Extremely high. No two games are alike and it'll take you 30-40+ hours to unlock all the tokens and see all the equipment/encounters that the game has to offer.Other:Hand of Fate and FTL are the two games that really perked my interest in rogue-like games. Their take on genre are different but both are highly effective in that they immerse you into the game, give you a good challenge, and provides a lot of unpredictability / replay value.  Also, the voice acting in this game is quite good as well.Overall:I found the gameplay incredibly addicting and would highly recommend this to fans of RPG, action. or rogue-like genre.

												"The whole is greater than the sum of its parts."This game is a living testament to that.  The cards and mechanics are simple and generic, the combat experience is average with little to no depth, and after a few hours, the narrator begins to repeat himself.  And yet, Hand of Fate is an excellent game!  I love this game! Convenient ui and the tarot atmosphere (and, dear God, I LOVE the narrator!) made all the difference.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												A few games in one: Deck building, slight RPG, and "follow that card" games.Certainly a *deck building* game. Once I understood that, and released myself from an RPG mindset, I enjoyed it much more.You do *not* develop a character in the traditional RPG style. Instead, you build a deck that you pull from for each 'episode'.For example: You found a wonderful weapon that you equpied during your last adventure. For your next adventure, it is not a piece of equipment to start with - but rather a possible piece of equipment that you may find on the current adventure.The sense of progress comes not from developing your character, but instead from adding to the possibilities your character will have.If and when you can understand and accept that mechanic the game will become an adventure with each play.It also has an action combat mechanic - whenever you encounter enemy cards you will often be shifted to another game mode where you have to battle these enemies arcade style.Rather random, slightly challenging, and in my opinion, replayable enough to keep me wondering what will be next.Recommended for those who like - deck building, medium randomness, and replayability.Not recommended for those who - want RPG like character progression, want one play mode, get frustrated with "bad luck".

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												Halfway through the game I can recommend (when on sale) to those interested in a combination strategy/rouge experience. The strategy part isn't that deep however; mostly you have to decide how to keep enough food and health (and get some good gear) to reach the boss. Beat the boss, and start fresh on each new level. Though there isn't that much variety in turns of battling (bascially move really fast/dodge/attack, repeat), there is enough skill challenge to keep it fairly interesting. Hand of Fate is more than the sum of its parts: everything comes together to give you 12 short and relatively enjoyable rouge-like levels in story mode. Chance has more of an effect in your ability to beat a level than most games, and sometimes luck will go against you. Only had really bad luck in one level out of 6 so far, which perhaps means the odds are stacked in the player's favor. Three consecutive pain cards was indeed painful; lost 60 health right before boss, lost boss battle, needed to repeat entire level.     7/10: Would randomnly lose 60 health again.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I will not comment on game play, since that has probably been explained a million times over in other reviews and videos. But this I will say:The Dealer is your Narrator, as well as your Savior and your Opponent. He has offered you the chance to play his Game. As the Player, you are in charge of a pawn - a nondescript adventurer. You are given cards upon which the Game is played. You build the pawn's equipment deck, and the story's encounter deck. The Dealer will deal out the cards and lead you on an incredible tale of greed, hubris and honor. Your pawn will face endless, faceless foes as well as specific boss villains. There will be violence, traps, treasure and horror. The Dealer will attempt to entice you to send your pawn into situations most peril for the offer of a few tokens. These tokens unlock more cards, which unlock more adventure and equipment/treasure.And as you defeat each boss villain, the Dealer will put the card into his cabinet, where you will be able to choose the next villain. Defeat a row of villains, gain a special item. But beware, every Game, every card, every victory will add to the complexity and danger that your pawn will face as you struggle to reach and win the final Game. Your pawns will die, but never fear - there are countless pawns waiting for you to guide them. Who is this man in the robe, who created these cards that influence a world, individuals and items? Who are you, Player? Are we Gods who are meant to play with the lives of mortals? Maybe.You'll have play to experience it.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Hand of Fate is a fantastic blend of Adventure, RNG, rouge-like and card games. I picked this game up recently on sale for a steal and it was worth every cent. The introduction to the game is simple and easy to follow allowing you to pick up the game quickly and play at your own pace. As you play the game you step from card to card in stages and deal with a number of random events including; battles, moral choices, ethical choices, gambling, quests and visiting shops while progressing through the stage towards the goal of a boss fight. The main story consists of 12 stages each with a boss of its own. All heading towards a final 13th stage that you will not be prepared for the first time. Around about the time you defeat the 4th boss you will unlock a game mode called "endless". Endless mode is never ending stages progressively getting harder until you can go no further. I suppose the goal is around stage 30 as this is the achievement awarding level. I personally was never able to beat my record of stage 26. It gets seriously rough. The addition of "endless" mode allows you to unlock more cards/ rewards as you complete each cards requirement which can then be used in both story mode and endless. A great addition to the game is the ability to edit the "world" or "level" by using the deck builder which is available basically at the start of the game. Once you have an idea for the game, the events and items you have preference for you are able to open the deck builder before a main story level and adjust it to your specific liking. The game does offer an auto recommended deck which is fine but once you hit that final 13th level you will most likely need to adjust the deck to your specific play and equipment style. Overall I had a great time with this game, an interesting story, great narration/ music and a play style that was addictive, punishing and rewarding. If this sounds even remotely interesting to you I would suggest you pick it up and give it a try. I loved my time spent on Hand of Fate and I couldn't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												My overall rating for Hand of Fate: 100/100Hand of Fate is something I was missing for a long time. Card deckbuidling game mixed with RPG-games, all hidden in a rogue-like coat. The game is hard, shows no mercy, yet is enjoyable as hell. Let's see why.GAMEPLAY+ Card game base+ Real-time fights+ Roguelike board game+ Various encounters+ Cards are changing and getting more difficult+ Strategy needs to be changed a lot+ Well made DLCs!o Sometimes clunky controls (training is needed :-D )- Luck is needed (lack of it can be potential game-ender)Gameplay is based on solving cards, either through choices, or you have to deal with threat personally in combat. As you progress further, game becomes more and more difficult, but there is one thing that has to be cleared. Game is rogue-like, so if it seems unfair to you, then it is right and you have to try your luck. That can be frustrating sometimes, because hardly defeatable encounter with full gear can be your first card in dungeon! Anyway, both DLCs added some cards and new strategies to defeat upcoming challenges. Still, with all possibilities, the game is a step ahead. Bugged achievements got fixed, so good luck!VISUALS+ Marvelous art style+ Formidable combat + Backgrounds and battlefields- Minor bugs and glitchesThere is nothing I can complain about visual style. Cards are stylish, they are looking like an old card game played in some mysterious temple. The atmosphere is mystical and full of tension and expectations. Combat is also perfectly created, though, some creatures might get bugged after hits, but that seems more funny than annoying to me.CHARACTERS+ Dealer and Warrior+ StoryIt is a game of life and death. Just the Dealer and unknown Warrior. Nothing more or less. Perfect.SOUNDTRACK+ Arabic-style songs+ Credit songJeff van Dyck showed us many excellent performances and this music belongs to one of his best. Arabic-themed songs are adding its piece to whole impression of this mystical game. My favourites - Life and Death, Welcome to the Game, Deal of the Millenia, Dead Skin, Dune Storm, Hand of Fate (Instrumental) and Hand of Fate.SUMMARYCard game with real fights, what more can be desired? With music of that kind and perfect voice-acting it was a pleasure to play and discover the secrets of this game. And also to return to it again. Many mysteries were revealed and more are awaiting to be. But is it possible? Let's find out. Perhaps ;-)

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This is a great game, and definitely worth the money, although getting it on sale makes it a no-brainer.It's essentially a dungeon crawler where your equipment and encounters are determined at random by the cards you put in your deck.  The challenges get progressively harder but are relatively easy until about 2/3 of the way through, when the difficulty ramps up considerably.  The combat is akin to a slightly less polished Batman-esque attack, doge, shield bash type affair, it's still quite fun.  Voices, music, and sound are all pretty good, but is that really the reason you're buying this thing?  The game is probably good for about 15 hours for a playthrough.The negatives have been touched on in other reviews but those that stand out to me are the "fate" based challenges you'll encounter here or there.  It's true that, at a certain point, getting the right card (success or fail) becomes a complete guessing game.  This negative in no way detracts from an otherwise awesome game.  While the randomness may bother some people, the game is called Hand of FATE, and that last word really sums it all up.  All in all, tons of fun, highly recommended.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Tabletop, roguelike, RPG, TCG, third person action RPG... Add it all up and what do you get?A strange, yet extremely fitting merge of genres, with beautiful use of lighting, shading, art and music.Not only does it look and sound amazing, but it plays even better, with an amazingly well designed deck building system that allows you to, in a sense, build your own adventure with equipment and encounters alike, all while the dealer throws his own tricks into the mix.You can take on every challenge, blade in hand, with a battle cry as you rip through your foes, or you can lower your weapon and offer your food and gold to help villagers, and your actions change the outcome, and in some cases, the reward. Hand of Fate isn't trying to do a lot of things, but what it does, it does well. Easy to use deck building system, or an automatic option for those not interested in the deck building.A very basic "map" screen, where your adventure takes place, yet with more than enough depth to keep you engaged and thinking about your actions, with food, gold, equipment, and curses.A very basic combat area, yet once again, with a surprising amount of depth, and a little planning sometimes, with the use of artifacts, curses, blessing, and enchanted equipment. If you have any interest in Hand of Fate, and are deciding if you should buy it. Do it. I cannot recommend this game enough, especially if you're a fan of roguelike elements.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm not much of a reviewer, let alone one for passing on my opinion of games onto others (since it's highly subjective).However, this game is so original & unique its compels me to do so. In an industry that has become highly itterative, Hand of Fate combines tried and true fighting game mechanics with a rogue-lite/dungeon-crawler and blends it into an original package with "trading" card game mechanics.The combat is a cross between Batman: Arkham City and Witcher 2. It has the style of combat from Arkham (different enemies do different attacks, organizing which enemies to eliminate first, counter system) but it has the pace of Witcher, in that it is quite slow and you cannot constantly spam the counter button, but instead must really time your attacks and counters. In addition, in this game you are not invincible, each strike landed on you will take away 5-10 health and your health persists for the entire dungeon (you get +5 health regen per "turn"). this is where my comparison to witcher makes more sense, this isnt a pure action game like Arkham, instead you must really plan the weapons and armor you take into combat, and you must manage your resources, if you run out of resources (-1 per turn) you enter starvation where you lose 10hp per turn. There is also an interesting mechanic where the instances that the game transports you to, is filled with traps that can harm you and your opponents. It a nice little touch that adds to the difficulty. As for the card game element of the game, its not like your traditional TCG like scrolls or Hearthstone, instead the cards you acquire are used to create the dungeon that you will traverse to reach the final boss, you can make an "easy" dungeon in some sense of the word, but that will yield very little buffs when you face the dungeon boss. Also, that strategy will limit the amount of gold you get and the Holy card buffs you receive that carryover from dungeon to dungeon. So far I've been raving about the game, but there are some grievances, mostly it comes down the combat. So far the combat is great, but this game essentially revolves around its combat system and for that it has to be flawless. My only gripe is subjective, in that it doesnt quite feel as "tigh/responsive" as I would prefer. In leans more towards the witcher style of combat, which is not a bad thing to say; the game just needs some polish. The devs needs to reduce the delay between pressing a button and it registering in the game. Also, at times, the enemies (usually bosses) will have canned animations that they must complete which prevents you from attacking them. Ie, they will continue slashing and NOT take damage from you while they are finishing the animation. That and the fact that the counter attack isnt always responsive does take away from the combat experience. Lastly, the camera is kind of janky and to my knowledge you cannot control it, which can be very annoying at times. However, the game is in early access, so I will give the benefit of the doubt to the devs in that they will sort these things out. Like I said, im not a "professional" reviewer, but the game is so unique that it deserves some attention. At the least, check out some lets plays on youtube.  Question is, is it worth it? for me, yes, at the $25 price range, even in the early access state, you can get a lot of enjoyment out of it. However, as a wise consumer, its always best to wait until the official release, but if you are a fan of the genres it combines or have some disposable cash to spend on steam, give it a shot. TLDR: Action game mixed with a rogue-lite dungeon crawler and some card-game elements. Combat is a mix of Batman: arkham asylum and Witcher 2, leaning more towards Witcher. The game is actually pretty challenging, its not a superhero simulator like Batman or even Assassins Creed where you just counter continuously. If devs are reading this, find a way to add MP/CO-OP, perhaps take turns being the "dungeon master", the game has soooo much potential.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access - Things are subject to change!REALLY interesting twist on rogue-lite genre that seems to be popular now with stuff like Magicite, Binding of Isaac (and Rebirth around the corner) and Nuclear Throne. Hand of Fate mixes deckbuilding with 3rd person hack and slash combat and roguelite-elements. It still is kind of barebones and kinda unresponsive, but that's early access for you. As a game It really hooked me and I did really enjoy playing this. Deckbuilding is kind of stale until you actually get more cards by beating bosses and succeeding in events.Fighting feels good and meaty and slow-mo-last-hit -effect feels amazing! Still, it isn't really too complex and mostly just spamming X to do damage, in my honest opinion the combat doesn't flow too well having quite long animations and a split-second "stop-period" after them if there are no enemies nearby, this makes you really vulnerable, especially if you do not have weapon with counter attacking-modifier and can cause you take lots of unnessecary damage. My biggest gripe about the game is the random element. I see what they're trying to do as drawing cards from deck for random outcome really is the games namesake, but especially early on if you draw an event that really hurts you (takes away lots of your food or health) or do not draw any weapon/armor cards at all can get REALLY frustrating. One could argue that it brings challange to game, but honestly, if how well you're doing is dependant on just pure dumb luck, it really doesn't feel good.That being said, I really don't know how that could be fixed without seriously hurting the games premise and after you beat first three bosses that is negated by little bit, but that can take way long depending on your luck, sooo-- yeah.Overall, I have high hopes about this game, I did enjoy playing it and will return to it when I have more time!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Summary / Mechanics- This is a randomized dungeon crawler in which your encounters are embodied by cards.- For completing an encounter in a special way you can unlock its follow-up encounter and new equipment.- This game has permanent progression in the way that you can enhance your card deck (encounters and equipment) with your new cards.- Combat is real time slash/counter/dodge action (batman-like), with more depth once you have weapons and artifacts with special powers.Characters / Quests(Edit: The different Characters are part of the Wildcard-Addon, didn't know that because I bought in Early Access)- There are several playable characters (visual differences only through equipment) that each have some pros and cons, and each adds special cards to your deck.- 3 of them are the equivalents to easy/normal/hard modes, the other ones enable different play styles and offer unique challenges.- Each character has his own questline that is linked to their profession and special abilities.- Quests are successions of encounters (some branch out), you will complete them over several rounds of gameplay.- Quest encounters have a coherent story and reward you equipment that was featured in the quest etc.Game ModesStory mode- For every "level" you have to clear a number of dungeon floors and fight a boss- Each level will let you start with different gifts and curses, so that there are varying challenges- After every third level you will gain better starting equipment but enemies will get tougherEndless mode- Endless dungeon floors, highscore mode.- In this mode you don't build a deck, it uses all cards.- Every floor will add tougher cards to the enemy card deck and you will get a random punishment.- You can use this mode to complete quests (and get better cards for your story deck) or play the character quests without the additional difficulty of the later story mode levels.Recommendation:If you are interested in game mechanics or like card and tabletop games, GET THIS

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Surprisingly good.  Very unique.  You move around a board made up of cards with each card representing an encounter.  The encounters are randomly selected based on your own "deck" that you put together and those selected for your by the computer based on what mode you're playing.  The encounters are comprised of a bit of text that tells you what's going on and then you will either have a selection of options based on the encounter, a "chance" card selection where you pick a card and it tells you weather it's a "success", "failure" and such.  If you encounter monsters you go into a 3d, real time combat arena where you battle the creatures.  The battles are actually really fun for something so simple.   While moving around the board you need to manage gold for quests and shops, food that gets comsumed from each move as well as encounters and your equipment that helps you in a myriad of ways throughout the game.You have to try it.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Many developers set out with clever genre-crossover ideas, and this may not be the cleverest but it is by far the best executed. The card system doesnt feel like its forced onto the arena-fighting element, nor do the rogue-like elements are not ever compromised for the sake of story or the card mechanic. The game has the same replayability of games like Binding of Isaac or Rogue Legacy. Even simple things like "draw 2 gain cards" (each of which is slightly different) instead of just "gain 10 gold" make you glad nobody else thought to make this game first. And if they did and I just don't know about them, they probably didnt make as smooth (or graphically impressive) a game as this.As for the mob-fighting type of combat that people keep comparing to the Batman: Arkham series, dont let that scare you off. Its not the 'repeatedly tap x' kind of fighting, but a type of combat were you still have the cool animations of batman, but you actually need to control your character's direction and time your attacks and counters.This game would still be the best digital-card-game/rpg/rogue-like/text-adventure/arena-fighter even there were two of them.10/10

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												This game is one of the greatest I've ever played. That's not an easy thing for me to say. Everything about this game is unique. It gets a perfect score in my book. Also, it has the all time greatest boss fight at the end of the game, hands down. I love this game to death.The gameplay is the best part of this game, the game can twist and turn any which way when your progress is lead by pure luck. The way the card system works is very simple and easy to wrap your mind around. The combat is excellent and fluid, it's awesome to watch. The combat isn't just hacking and slashing, it's about timing blocks and dodging opponents you can't fight all at once. The combat is reminscent to the first Fable, in fact, much of this game really is a Fable game without the brand name, but the combat is so much more interesting here than in any Fable.The graphics are lush and colourful. It has that wonderful atmospheric fantasy mood that Fable set so perfectly.The sound quality is top notch for the most part. There is a few times when the sound does cut out but a simple restart fixes that immediately. The soundtrack is awesome and really has an epic vibe to it. I was even thinking of buying it if it's sold on Steam. It's one of those soundtracks that'll take me back years from now. I love the clanging of the swords and the thumping of swords against shields. The voice actor behind the Dealer is on the same level of deep and mesmerizing as Morgan Freeman. He's like an English Morgan Freeman, I can't stress enough how good of a voice actor he is.The story line is interesting, it's not a normal storyline. You enter at the end of the adventurer's story. This is a retelling of all his adventures. So it's a game about retrospective and reflection. The Dealer makes very interesting remarks and ponderings that make me think on a philosophical level. What kind of game does that?I love a game that I can put hundreds and hundreds of hours into. A game that has endless replayability and isn't limited by just having a storyline. This is one of those games. It doesn't ever have to end. There's an endless mode. There's also 200+ cards to collect. Each card is an encounter. Every game randomizes these encounters and even throws in some that benefit you and some that debilitate you to a certain extent. This game definitely earns its pay and has lot of bang for very little buck.If you're on the fence about getting it, don't be. This game isn't hard to fall in love with. I'd recommend this game to absolutely anyone.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												The care and attention which has gone into crafting this game - from music to voice over to the little touches in how the graphics are handled - show an incredible amount of love not normally encountered in modern games. With the addition of being bug free, it's an absolute pleasure to dip in and out of. The mechanics are interesting, the randomisation makes replayability a joy, and endless mode is an interesting challenge. One or two obtuse mechanics do exist, but there is strategy in the gameplay, and the combat, though essentially an arcade element, is also entertaining because it is fulfilled in short bursts. Not necessarily the kind of game that addicts you to play in long sessions, the game takes a different approach with enough intriguingness to make you come back. One for the library.What's it worth? £12 / $15

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a fantastic Fantasy/RPG card game look no further. You get to customize your deck of cards to fit your playstyle. You play as a hero who is trying to make it through all of the trials and tribulations of a warrior, all that matters is defeating the next boss (and eventually the main boss a.k.a the dealer of cards). Every card you draw can either help you or hurt you, it is very random. Whatever you end up drawing will be the equipment you end up with. The randomness of what you can get is what makes this game so appealing.        There are small battles in which you can physically take controll of your hero to hack and slah the enemies to death. These battles help break the monotony of just playing a card game. You might draw a good set of armor and a decent sword or you could end up with a nasty group of gremlins to fight, either way you will still end up having a blast. Once you defeat a boss you will continue unto the next boss and set of challenges untill you get to the last boss.      You earn in-game gold through defeating mobs or completeing quests. There are shops in every set of cards in which you can use this gold to buy/ sell armor, weapons, or even cure curses and heal health. You can also completely customize your equipment/encounter decks to make sure you are having the most personal experience possible.      If you are a fan of strategey games or just a card game fanatic then this is a must buy. I am not in any way partial to these types of games, yet I can't help but have a blast playing this.      If you can find this on-sale I'd say grab it no questions asked. Even if this wasn't on sale I still believe it's worth 25$. There is an enormous ammount of replayability to be had. Buy and trust me you will not regret it. -Casey

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
This game was a pleasant surprise! It’s a bit or RPG Strategy mixed into a dungeon crawling type of story with some hack and slash combat. You interact with, use, or equip cards for the main aspects of the game, and gain more cards as time goes on (depending on your success/failure). If you don’t like a card, you can remove it from the deck and not play with it again later (as long as you have enough cards required for the play through).  This deck building aspect allows you to choose what possible events you encounter in your adventure.It’s hard to summarize this game without going in depth since there are so many different things from so many different genres here; however, you’re pretty likely to find something you like about the game. I will admit that it can become repetitive depending on how you arrange your deck, and the combat might turn into button spamming, but you don’t have to let it...you can play the game as you choose.What is nice about this game is that you can either go “endless”, or use the “story mode” which gives you “break points” as you finish each piece once you beat the boss at the end of the dungeon. Like I said, it’s hard to explain...but you’re bound to like at least a couple aspects of this games layout. I enjoy the dialogue from the card master quite a bit and it really adds character to the game.The Bad News:  This game is a currently an unoptimized resource hog. It has memory leak issues. After about 30 minutes of play today, Windows was asking me to close the program because it had nearly 3 GB of RAM in use and was eating resources like crazy. (It didn’t crash, but Windows noted the issue, and presented the event to me for action.)Once this game is optimized, I think it will become very popular with the gaming community.

												Buy this!! If your're on the fence about this game (and especially if it is on sale) BUY IT!!! It is well worth the investment. It's kind of one of those easy to learn hard to master kind of games so I got sucked into it pretty fast. A good sign is that the developers are responsive to the game community. And the Dealer has a lot of dialogue (especially as you get to newer levels). Plus he's not just a bad guy - he has a complex character that you get to know. Their is a certain amount of random chance to the game (but their is too in life) and it can get a little maddening trying to get the right cards in sequence. But overall this is a good investment even if you don't like active fighting games. I didn't but now I do thanks to this game. Plus if you get stuck just go to the community board and ask. It can be very satisfying to kill a monster you had thought was unbeatable. Another nice thing is that if you really hate a card you can often just not select it. Don't always go by the Recommended deck (although I would advise that you do at first until you get a feel for the "ropes" and what you like). This is game is very customizable.

content:
Posted: February 19
												I got this as part of a Humble Bundle and knew nothing about it before trying.I'm a huge fan of tabletop board gaming, so I was interested when it was described as a deck-builder mixed with an action combat game. The concept is really neat, but the game ultimately falls flat, in my opinion.As you'll read in other reviews, the game does have solid voice acting and graphics. I agree with those assessments, but that's about as far as I can go with the positive aspects.My biggest concern with this game is that the card gameplay is extremely shallow and random with very few interesting decisions; it's full of illusion-of-choice where the game shuffles 4 cards and you pick one -- the act of picking a single card from a shuffled pile is NOT the same as making a decision. The game ultimately feels like a fancy skin over a bunch of die rolls and linear movement. After 5 minutes of playing the game, it becomes apparent that this is the core gameplay loop.The pacing of the card gameplay is sluggish, with animations being just a tad too slow. And with so many of these animations being the same and/or with nearly inconsequential effects, it quickly feels repetetive and grindy. Couple this with the lack of decision making, and the game begins to feel like a chore.The game uses a tarot style graphic design on the cards, only showing a card name in addition to the art. The issue with that is that there are at least dozens (hundreds?) of unique cards that each do different things, and they these effects are not immediately apparent. So when you complete a mission and win a booster pack, it totally takes the excitement out of the reveal because you have no idea what you just opened. This may seem like a small detail, but it sucks out SO MUCH of the immersion and underlying story. When you have a wall of completed missions with no descriptions, the experience feels hollow.The combat is very similar to Batman. I didn't know this before playing, and if I did, I probably would have avoided the game based purely on personal preference (I didn't care for the Batman combat system). This game really tried to capture the same feel, but is again ultimately quite sluggish in its execution. As well, this combat system feels at odds with the balance of the card system. With so many opportunities to block and counter and dodge, what even is the difference between a +25 ATK weapon vs +27 ATK weapon? Part of the excitement and strategy/tactics of a more traditional card game is working out lines of play that let you edge out small victories with just enough damage in different situations. The action combat in this game blurs this aspect of gameplay to the point where it begins to feel arbitrary and lacking a cohesive design.In conclusion, even if the gameplay itself was more compelling, the user experience (card descriptions, pacing, etc) really made a mediocre/boring game into a frustrating one. I definitely do not recommend buying this at full price, and would only recommend getting it on sale if you enjoyed the combat in Batman and are intrigued by the concept of a mixed card game/action game. DO NOT buy this if you want deep card game experiences because you will be disappointed.

												Fantastic mix of RPG, card and board-game with a Dungeons and Dragons feel and also it's own flavour, which is great. Love the sound-track, love the narrator/dealer and how the game is pretty much a random rogue-like.You basically go on an adventure to achieve certain goals, usually beating the boss of the level. Each space you move onto is a card in a deck, each piece of equipment is another card, each gain and loss, another card. All of this is packaged into a lovely game of choice, chance and action, with the game cutting to an arena-like fight so you can take control and bash some monsters!Overall, definitely worth a look if you have ever liked D&D, Board-game RPGs or card games. Cannot recommend enough.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												The rouge-like for people who dislike rogue-likes. Also a great game in it's own right.The combat is akin to the more recent Batman games. Not the same level of polish, but still very good. Combat is at a moderate pace and the variety of equipment (and their effects) make combat a more thoughtful endeavor, asking you how and in what order you will deal with the steadily growing variety of opponents and their abilities.Outside of the combat the game is somewhat of a choose-your-own-adventure game with each step being a new encounter of some sort. There's a decent variety of encounters with new ones added each successful playthrough. In some cases the ways to deal with these encounters can be equally as varied. And thankfully I've yet to see any encounters of the 'Rocks fall, everyone dies' kind. Every encounter can be dealt with potently even turning a bad encounter into a total gain. Even those based on chance have ways to tip chance in your favor. Again the lack of time limited choices allow content to be handled at your own pace.Overall the game is almost relaxing to play. It doesn't throw any cheap shots, but it also doesn't pull any punches. That and the well versed DM that is the mysterious dealer across from you makes it a +5 game of goodness.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								A great game which desserves more recognition then it gets. It is early access but what is already there is more then enought to persuade you to buy the game now, it is one of those "good enought now and will only get better" kinda deals.The game itself plays kinda like the board games like zombie in my pocket. You are faced with a bunch of faced down cards and you have a choice of which card to travel to. The card is then fliped over and will show you an event on your journey, it may be a skill task (govern by a pick a card to see outcome mechanic), a shop to by food or magic items, or a combat encounter to spend the magic items on.The combat encounters are special in that you are put into a 3D space with a brawler ruleset. You get with the weapons and items you have picked up from events and shops and are to fight a couple or monsters, or face a difficult maze, depending on the card.The game is rich in lore and story, with every senario covering a specific target and the story of how he or she came to be the target. Each scenario starts with the player building the deck of encounters and dangers (except for a small number of predetermine scenariobased cards) which makes this game really unique in that a dungeon is as hard as player balances it to be.Highly recommended

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I might be a huge fan of rogue-light games, like Hand of Fate, but I'm still surprised to see just how much I got into this one. It's such a weird blending of random generation, board game/card game elements, and brawling that it's hard to believe all that could've worked together in one game, but Hand of Fate surely showed me how it's done.The theming with all of the narration and storytelling is fanstastic and well appriciated. It's actually surprising to see just how much of that was put into the DLCs too. It invokes that D&D style of love and care in storytelling that makes lonely nights of gaming more warm and inviting. As I said: Very much appriciated.The fighting begins simple and innocent enough, but, after unlocking loads of card (An event that's quite enjoyable in of itself), you'll begin to realize just how much awareness and management you'll need to worry about as your adventures drag on; especially in Endless Mode. It's still not a hugely complex task in comparison to other brawler games, but it's usually a brief excursion that helps liven up the experiance of play. When you start to form a powerful character, it becomes all the more enjoyable watching 16+ hordes of enemies fall before you as you rake in the spoils of battle.The free DLCs are a great welcome to the game and I'm still working to try and finish off the last couple of cards involved with them, but the paid DLC that offers a multitude of new characters to play as also adds in some new questlines to experiance. The fact that the character modifiers really do change up the experiance is good enough, but I really do appriciate their lasting contibution to the events deck in the end. Variety of play is something I really appriciate on some nights when I only have a couple of hours to play and, for the price of it all, it's more than fair enough from my standpoint.The Story Mode really does ease you into the game as it begins to build upon itself, raising the states and difficulty until the final battle. You can fully customize most elements of the game during so too, which really helps when you want to fix things to your favor or work in some new cards to reap their tokens. Endless Mode starts off very simply but rapidly escalates into a really rough experiance and is great for experianced players wanting to test their skills (Works well for unlocking more cards too, in some cases). Story mode is fully replayable, which is great, and Endless Mode is my jam when I just want to dive into play. Everything I need for whatever mood I'm in.Anything else to gush about? Hmm... I don't think so. This game's an easy recommendation from me, but I will advise against it for a couple of things:1) There's a lot of RNG in the game that will work hard against you. Not all the time, but at some points. It sucks when you get screwed, but it doesn't wreck you completely; At least, most of the time.2) This game just isn't for everyone. It's easy to see that from the general game in of itself, but it's just the truth. For anyone that's open to playing a variety of games to play, Hand of Fate is a fairly safe purchase, but not for those types of people that like to stick to their narrow pool of genres. If you're one of those types of people and still want to experiance something weird and new for yourself, I'd probably recommend something else to you.Want a number rating? I'd say an 8/10; at the very least, a 7/10. It's not your GotY, but there's a lot to enjoy from this game and, if you can get it and the DLC all for under $10.00, then you'll be getting great value from it all.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This is the first Steam review I have ever written, I normally wouldn't write them, but I enjoy this game so very much that I thought I would share my thoughts.This game is, hands down, one of the most compelling roguelike-rpg-combat games I have ever played. It has a very tight core gameplay loop, it scratches that collectable itch, and the combat is fun, with enough mechanics to keep it interesting. But let me speak to the one feature that really sold this game to me. The Dealer. God I hate that man. But I also love him. He narrates the game, he goads you, he encourages you, he hints at a story behind why you and him are playing the game, Every snide aside and every grudging compliment I feel like I earn, and when I defeat one of his cards I literally whoop with victory. As for the RNG (random number generator for those not familar with acronyms) aspect of the game, I never feel like it was unfair, because you can choose which cards to include in your deck. For the past 3 games I was insta killed by one particular card. Am I complaining? No, I chose to include that card specifically because I want to unlock the next card after that. I like to intentionally make the hardest deck I can, just to see if I can beat it. Because there is that element of choice, I never feel like the game is unfair.Finally, the difficulty curve. It is rather seductive. It lures you in the first couple of bosses, and then decides to smack you around a bit. I like it, I feel like it lengthens the game. The one issue I have is that I feel like it was way too easy on the outset, so I managed to get to the 10th boss with minimal losses. That could be just me, and it is taking quite a few runs to even see the boss I am currently on.That gets to my final point, and only criticism, such as it is. I need more. I am worried I will be running out of cards to find, of things to see, and I need more. Fortunately the game seems very well set up to add content to, and I for one will be getting whatever the developers put out. I hope they support this game for a very long time. I wholeheartly recommend this game to players who enjoy a good dungeon crawl, who like paying for their mistakes, and especially to those who love the feel of a board game, where you can look across the table at your opponent and think, "Time to take this jacka-- down. "

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												As only a dabbler in Rogue-lite games, I was not expecting to enjoy Hand of Fate nearly as much as I did.  Now I could sit here and attempt to describe all of the gameplay elements that go into Hand of Fate, (Rogue-lite action rpg with CCG-style deck-building and progression) but that doesn't really describe what the game IS or why I enjoy it so much.  This game pulled me in, and really got me into the " just one more run" Rogue-lite mindset in a way most others in the genre have not.The basic premise of the game is that you construct a deck of equipment and encounter cards and use it to try and defeat each of the dealer's decks of minions.  Each deck progresses over several randomly laid out "dungeon floors" constructed from the encounter cards you chose, plus a few from the dealer.  The goal is to get to the bottom and defeat the deck boss, while unlocking new cards and equipment along the way.The difficulty curve in this mode is really nice (especially for a Rogue-lite), by which I mean that most action rpg veterans will find that they breeze through the first few deck challenges purely on the strength of their combat.  That, however, does not last.  As the game progresses, unlocking more cards and building your encounter and equipment decks around the specific challenges of an enemy deck becomes more and more important.  This is the part of the game that keeps hooking me back in.  I'd find myself failing a run, but super-excited to start a new one just to see what the new cards I unlocked did.  Also, the artwork for the cards is really really well done and the dealer character has some of the best voice-acting (and one-liner writing) I've heard in a game for quite a while.A few minor gripes:  The controls for the combat sections aren't quite as tight as I would like (read: as tight as in Arkham City / Asylum), but they are more than adequate by action-rpg standards.  That said, the combat can get a bit repetitive after a while, as the combat system itself doesn't have quite the depth of a full-on action rpg.  Different weapons and abilities help some, but the 15th time you draw a 6 of Scales does start to feel grind-y.Endless mode is a bit of a mixed bag: it's more of the traditional rogue-lite experience (starts off relatively easy, and just gets continuously harder until you die), but without any of the custom deck-building from Story Mode (it just throws every card you have into the mix).Final word:  If you like Rogue-lites, I highly reccomend this one, especially if you're also into CCG-driven mechanics.  If you don't like Rogue-lites at all, I'm curious why you're still reading this review, but if you got this far, this one *might* be worth giving a chance, especially since the difficulty curve starts out a bit more forgiving than most of the genre and doesn't really start ramping up until you've cleared 4 or 5 decks.  That said, it is still a Rogue-lite, which means you will occasionally have the runs that end in 4 moves because you drew the hardest 2 monsters in the deck after losing your shield and half your health to bad luck.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Mixes cards and dungeon exploring to a result that's both satisfying and interesting. Hand of Fate challenges you to chase down 12 bosses before you can challenge the dealer himself. Each boss quest is like a dungeon adventure, where you choose from cards on a table. Whatever is picked is what you'll have to face. These range from random events, to equipment pickups, groups of enemies, travelling salesmen and lots more. For each step you take on the map, you consume one food. As the story progresses these settings may increase and various curses will make your adventures more difficult. The second part of the game is in the combat, where the game switches to a third person action game. Overcome them and you'll move on.All in all it's an enjoyable mix of two different game genres that I cannot recall to have seen before Hand of Fate did it - and it works surprisingly well. Rating: 8/10 - Play it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
Product received for free
												I'm going to start off by saying that Hand of Fate is one of the most original and entertaining games I've played in a long time. My friend got it for me for Christmas, and I can definitely say it was an excellent gift (even if it took me a while to get around to playing it). It's well worth the $20 it costs; if you find it on sale, even more so. That being said, there is a very, very big issue I had with it.If I had to rate HoF based on everything except the final boss fight, I'd easily give it a solid 4/5. It does rely quite heavily on luck, which can be frustrating at times, which is the only thing preventing it from being 5/5. However, if I were to rate the entire game as a whole, the final boss sadly drops it down to 3/5. Yes, it's that big of a sore spot for me. The first time I reached the final boss (not an easy feat, I should add, given the high degree of luck involved in dungeon and loot generation in the game), I was in very good shape, and cleared the first part of the fight without much difficulty.Then, out of nowhere, there was a cinematic Quicktime Event. A QTE that, if failed, causes instant death. Now, I'm not a fan of QTEs in general, but this one was particularly egregious because prior to the final boss, there is not a single QTE in the entire game. The player has absolutely no reason to expect one. Not only that, since the game revolves around enemies that correspond to various suits of cards, when a giant Q popped up on my screen at the start of the event, I thought it meant the boss was summoning a Queen enemy. A moment later, however, SPACE popped up, and I realized it was a QTE, but by then it was too late. Instant death. And in Hand of Fate, death means having to start the entire randomly generated dungeon over again from the beginning, losing all your collected gear and gold, and getting reverted back to starting equipment.Quite frankly, it was a dirty move on the part of the developers. It's the gameplay equivalent of a jumpscare; the fight would have been legitimately fun and challenging without the QTE, but they decided to randomly give the player a chance to die instantly, regardless of their gear or combat skill. Not only that, it actively punishes the player for not spoiling the final boss fight for themselves; reading online guides or FAQs beforehand would have given me advance warning, so I would have known to be ready for the Quicktime Event, but since I wanted to get through the game on my own, I was sucker punched.Regardless, I would still recommend the game, but I will definitely not be picking up the sequel until I have determined that it is free of 'press X to not die' moments.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16
												Medicore combat used pretty much for making the rest of the game feel better. It's essentially a CYOA with roguelike elements to it that expand the game more  the long you play, for the most part. Unfortunately, bad luck in this case can elongate how long it takes to even look at certain types of cards, which means if you really want to look at all the cards, you'll probably just have to grind easier difficulties to anywhere any time soon. While the CYOA part is fun, eventually it unfortunately tends to be more boring than fun as you see the same dialogue for the same choices over and over and over, and the same dialogue over and over and over and over, and it begins to feel less like an exploration than just choosing which buffs you'd like to get and hopefully getting good rolls. If the rolling was more fun or more interesting, it would be great. If the choices felt actually varied, that would be great. If the combat and items supported the rest of the game better, that'd be great. Unfortunately, none of that is true, and it becomes a mediocre roguelike where the main selling point is the uniqueness. Being able to influence your dungeon is kind of fun, but not nearly as much as it sounds unfortunately. Certain items are worthless or absolutely BoS, so instead of having a variety you usually just end up picking up stuff to make things better.All in all it was a fun experience in some part, and an absolute drudge when combat took precedence over the rest of the game. Combat's only benefit is the item choices you get to make, which means bad items make the combat absolutely boring, even when difficult. Really only recommended if you like CYOA, really.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having first learned of this game through YouTube, I decided to pick it up for myself and see what all the fuss is about.It's difficult to put this into one category of games. It's essentially a roguelike adventure game, which uses cards to determine your journey and has a bit of combat that's somewhat similar to the Batman games.The cards you draw affect various things, from your equipment, to your resources, to what enemies you face. Some cards are mini-quests which have different outcomes depending on your choices. I came across a card called "Devil's Choice", where I was given the choice to fight one of three cards: 2 of Dust, 2 of Dust and 3 of Dust. When I chose 3 of Dust, the Devil basically removed that card and made me fight the other two combined, "just for laughs".You won't have many cards at first, but as you complete dungeons, defeat bosses and complete quest cards, you will receive tokens that unlock new cards. You can then choose which cards to use in your deck. This offers a good amount of player freedom in how you want to shape your experience for each run. For example, if you wish an added challenge, you can choose to play a deck that contains no armour or shield cards.The game starts of easy enough, but after the 3 first "dungeons" it already gets exponentially more difficult, mainly because of what I like to call Roguelike Syndrome; basically, no matter how well you do, the game can mess you up worse than any one enemy can. My first attempt at the Jack of Plagues ended when I drew two consecutive Angry Mob challenges, and rolled the worst outcomes on both while I was already low on life and resources. While I'm perfectly alright with such events, do understand that if you're not used to Roguelike Syndrome, you will swear at this game for being unfair. A lot.There are currently two game modes; story mode and endless mode. Story mode pits you against the dealer in a quest to defeat his lieutenants (who are based on the the regular deck of cards - 4 jacks, 4 queens and 4 kings, one of each for each suit) and ultimately, him. Endless mode simply allows you to play for as long as you can.The few flaws I have found so far, I don't consider to be dealbreakers, and I believe these could be ironed out by the time this gets out of early access. The combat seems a little bit too easy. A "blind random" deckbuilding option would have been nice as well. And of course, more content is always nice.Other than that, it looks pretty good, the voice acting of the dealer is pretty solid, and there's already a good amount of content to keep you busy. But DO play with a controller, it makes the game infinitely better to handle.Highly recommended.

A Rogue-like, looking for an equal!I've started to notice this game because of TheReformist, therefore huge shoutout to him! https://www.youtube.com/user/ReformistTMGo check him out. Impressive Voice, enjoyable Pace of the presented content.If you played Binding of Isaac and really liked the increasing difficulty and the randomised Worlds you can discover, but felt that there was a story shortage or the story setting wasn't yours, Hand of Fate takes you into its medieval, fantasy world.My personal experience with the huge amount of Early Access games that are out there is: They have Content and Gameplay, which more often than not is tossed into your face, "Do or Die!". Hand of Fate is also in Early Access, but does an amazing job at introducing the Player to its mechanics in an enjoyable way.Facing The Dealer you journey through an ever changing deck of cards, encountering traps and fortunes alike, gaining treasures and surpassing hurdles or... not. But don't falter! For each surpassed challenge your fate shuffles again and may change to your likings. For each Boss beaten the challenge increases and the world expands. Who knows what The Dealer holds for You?

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This game is awesome, still, it made me rage so much... Why ? Because even if the game looks REALLY easy in the beginning, when action phases (fights and escape traps sequences) remain "simple", it becomes a real nightmare at the end of the game. The camera is NEVER looking in the right direction, so sometimes you'll have to fight ennemis you cannot see... or avoid traps hidden by the awful camera. Same goes for the action phases gameplay : it's impossible to precisely move around the map or attack from a certain angle, so you'll loose heath by falling into traps a lot. In the late game, you cannot really afford to loose health in such a way.It's a HUGE frustration because this game really rocks, but I get so angry when I play it, I just wanna smash my keyboard into my screen. For f**k sake, when you create a game, when you see its flaws (cause you've got to be blind if you don't), just don't put gameplay elements that emphasize them. Or FIX IT. For the traps sequences, WHY DON'T WE HAVE A GOD DAMN "RIGHT ON TOP OF THE CHARACTER CAMERA" ? Why did you put a stupid inertia to the main character's movement when you simply don't have it when you fight ? WHY ?I guess I'll wait for hand of fate 2 now, I don't wanna rage anymore trying to avoid things I simply cannot see.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												I have to say this a strange concept for a game and one I was hesitant to try at first but I am pleased to say it was excuted well. I would be wary if you get frustrated easily as this game is VERY dependent on the old RNG. For a hybrid action title this can be frustrating. I was stuck on one of the decks for a few days without coming anywhere close to completeing it when BAM I hit a couple lucky cards and breezed past the boss battle in about 40 seconds. I do not see this necessarily as a knock on the game as I feel it was really designed as a card game of choice and chance (with some deckbuilding elements mixed in) first and an action title second. I would Atmposphere is where this game really excels and has to be my #1 reason for giving this the thumbs up. From the narrator to the combat level layout and on to the basic but very fitting card art I get drawn in every playthrough. I strongly feel this is a title best played in the one or two runs per session.I am enjoying this title and recommend it to anyone who wants to try something different. There are some RNG frustrations that would make it a tough sell to some and Mechanically the combat gets a bit repetitive.7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Very entertaining game with a few flaws. You can read all about the great stuff in other reviews; other people have covered all the high points far better than I. The problems right now:1. Random chance of instant, nothing-you-can-do-about-it death. The Curse of Davey Jones, I'm looking at you. Nothing is more frustrating than your game ending with no way to mitigate the result.2. Gigantic ramp up in difficulty. The game starts out fairly easy and gradually gets more difficult as you progress. That's a good thing, but the last card, and the dealer, are difficult to the point of being obnoxiously ruthless. There's room for random chance in a game, but once you get to these portions, it's 95% luck and 5% skill. That's no fun.3. Some of the later battles are tedious. It's an exercise in meditation. Fighting several lava golems at once with the basic starting equipment isn't particularly difficult, but it takes a terribly long time and gets a bit stale after the first 15 minutes of the same attack, dodge, attack, dodge, attack, dodge routine.So, play on Endless Mode instead, hope you never draw The Curse of Davey Jones, and enjoy. (o:

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												I find myself moving down this dusty corridor, dodging flame traps and a spike ceiling trying to crush me.  I catch my breath for a moment, roll past some arrow traps, and grab a chest!And my reward is some cards.  And the man across the table from me makes some cryptic statements about my past, or the history of that card, or something vague and menacing.This is the sort of thing that happens in this game, and its amazing.Hand of Fate can be best described as a Deck Building Action RPG hybrid.  You are a nameless someone, who has decided to play a game of life and death against a mysterious Dealer.  Your goal is to defeat the 12 members of the Dealers Card Court.  Your weapons, tools, and even dungeons are the very cards being used in the game.I have not played for very long as I don't want to spoil the game for when I do a video playthrough of it, but suffice to say what I have played has my interest piqued.  I want to know who I am, where I came from, how I got to this place, and why this Dealer is such a snarky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.Recently, the devs put out a Free content expansion, which adds another little mini story to the game.The basic gameplay is that you have a deck of cards that you have built.  Well 2 actually: Equipment and Encounters.  The dealer then spices things up by adding cards to them, cards you have no knowledge of.  He then lays out a dungeon face down on the table, made up of cards.  You then move a token around from card to card, and experience a variety of things.  One card might be an Ambush of Skeletons, another might be meeting an Elf Lass, another might be a dangerous ravine, or a trap room.In the case of combat, or trap rooms, the game switches to an Action RPG setup, using a combat system very similar to the new Batman Arkham games.  You can dodge, roll, attack, and eventually should you find the gear cast spells or special powers.  One power I had early on let me cause all my attacks to generate cash on the ground that I could pick up.The devs have said the main campaign takes about 12 hours to get through, so about an hour per court member.  There is also Endless mode, which is of course Endless.Hopefully more content updates come down the pipe as I can see myself playing this for quite a while.

Early Access Review
								Very interesting. As a deck-building game, it starts off somewhat bland with few cards... but that's all a part of it as you learn basic mechanics and how the game is played. The menus aren't all that well-done and the combat needs a bit of tweaking. Overall, though, I recommend it.

												I'm going to start off by saying that Hand of Fate is one of the most original and entertaining games I've played in a long time. My friend got it for me for Christmas, and I can definitely say it was an excellent gift (even if it took me a while to get around to playing it). It's well worth the $20 it costs; if you find it on sale, even more so. That being said, there is a very, very big issue I had with it.If I had to rate HoF based on everything except the final boss fight, I'd easily give it a solid 4/5. It does rely quite heavily on luck, which can be frustrating at times, which is the only thing preventing it from being 5/5. However, if I were to rate the entire game as a whole, the final boss sadly drops it down to 3/5. Yes, it's that big of a sore spot for me. The first time I reached the final boss (not an easy feat, I should add, given the high degree of luck involved in dungeon and loot generation in the game), I was in very good shape, and cleared the first part of the fight without much difficulty.Then, out of nowhere, there was a cinematic Quicktime Event. A QTE that, if failed, causes instant death. Now, I'm not a fan of QTEs in general, but this one was particularly egregious because prior to the final boss, there is not a single QTE in the entire game. The player has absolutely no reason to expect one. Not only that, since the game revolves around enemies that correspond to various suits of cards, when a giant Q popped up on my screen at the start of the event, I thought it meant the boss was summoning a Queen enemy. A moment later, however, SPACE popped up, and I realized it was a QTE, but by then it was too late. Instant death. And in Hand of Fate, death means having to start the entire randomly generated dungeon over again from the beginning, losing all your collected gear and gold, and getting reverted back to starting equipment.Quite frankly, it was a dirty move on the part of the developers. It's the gameplay equivalent of a jumpscare; the fight would have been legitimately fun and challenging without the QTE, but they decided to randomly give the player a chance to die instantly, regardless of their gear or combat skill. Not only that, it actively punishes the player for not spoiling the final boss fight for themselves; reading online guides or FAQs beforehand would have given me advance warning, so I would have known to be ready for the Quicktime Event, but since I wanted to get through the game on my own, I was sucker punched.Regardless, I would still recommend the game, but I will definitely not be picking up the sequel until I have determined that it is free of 'press X to not die' moments.

												Only half an hour in and already I love it. The DM is excellently voice acted and every game feels unique. The combat can vary depending on your equipment. content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This game is awesome, still, it made me rage so much... Why ? Because even if the game looks REALLY easy in the beginning, when action phases (fights and escape traps sequences) remain "simple", it becomes a real nightmare at the end of the game. The camera is NEVER looking in the right direction, so sometimes you'll have to fight ennemis you cannot see... or avoid traps hidden by the awful camera. Same goes for the action phases gameplay : it's impossible to precisely move around the map or attack from a certain angle, so you'll loose heath by falling into traps a lot. In the late game, you cannot really afford to loose health in such a way.It's a HUGE frustration because this game really rocks, but I get so angry when I play it, I just wanna smash my keyboard into my screen. For f**k sake, when you create a game, when you see its flaws (cause you've got to be blind if you don't), just don't put gameplay elements that emphasize them. Or FIX IT. For the traps sequences, WHY DON'T WE HAVE A GOD DAMN "RIGHT ON TOP OF THE CHARACTER CAMERA" ? Why did you put a stupid inertia to the main character's movement when you simply don't have it when you fight ? WHY ?I guess I'll wait for hand of fate 2 now, I don't wanna rage anymore trying to avoid things I simply cannot see.
