number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												Starting Hand of Fate, I had no idea what was in store for me. The concept of being a trading card slash action game sounded quite interesting, but I just couldn’t imagine where or how the two would meet.Thankfully, when you initially sit down at the table where your fate is decided, all questions go out the window as soon as the deckmaster speaks. The dealer/deckmaster, voiced by Anthony Skordi, immediately pulls you into the fantasy that is Hand of Fate with his fantastic voice acting, and makes it so you can’t help but linger on his every word spoken.The ConceptThe idea for Hand of Fate is quite unique and reminiscent of old pen and paper games such as Dungeons & Dragons. The deckmaster is the one who narrates the story and you are the one who plays through it.The stories played out are controlled via cards that trigger certain events which provide you with multiple choices of how you’d like to proceed. To initially activate a card, you need to move your golden gamepiece on top of it.Your gameboard is made up of face down cards that have been positioned in a way to resemble a dungeon. Cards are placed side by side or above and below each other. Your gamepiece jumps from card to card, each time using up one food.Food is the currency that controls how far you can move, gold allows you to purchase new equipment, spells and more, and health is there for enemies to try and deplete.To begin with, the deckmaster takes you by the hand and introduces you to events, multiple choice outcomes, equipping items, combat and everything else needed to know when getting started.EventsWhen landing on an event card, you might end up walking away with some new gear, extra food or fighting some monsters. Some cards will take you through a little bit of story such as seeing a man being carried away by cultists into the forest. This particular event will give you the choice of leaving them alone or interrupting their ritual.Other times you might come across a maiden who can give you a bit of extra gold, food or health. Alternate encounters can see you parting with half of your food only to avoid going back one space. However, when each movement costs one food, you’ll have to weigh the options to see if it’s worth your while.Encounters can also come in the form of a travelling salesman, mage or other such spruiker. Here you can spend all of that hard-earned gold on new weapons, armour, spells and more. You can also stock up on food to help you move those extra few spaces.If there are particular events you don’t want to encounter, customise your deck before commencing a game so you only come across the encounters you want to.CombatEncountering enemies in Hand of Fate is actually quite fun albeit, a little easy. When the deckmaster deals out some monster cards for you to face, the game changes from being played on a tabletop to a third-person hack and slash style.On PC, the usual ‘WASD’ controls your movement while clicking is used to attack and stun. By pressing ‘space-bar’ you can perform a roll to escape enemy attacks.Depending on your characters equipment, other abilities become available such as, when you’re equipped with a shield, the ‘Q’ key is used to counter enemy attacks. The countering mechanic is similar to that seen in the Batman Arkham games. Green signals will appear above enemies’ heads which let you know the attack can be countered. Red signals indicate un-counterable attacks.Combat is actually really smooth and effortless, which personally I think is a bit of a downfall. It doesn’t take long to understand your enemies’ attack patterns and dodge/counter your way to victory. Having said that, boss fights can become quite troublesome as they each have differing mechanics. I.e. Queen of Dust is accompanied by a huge, immobile crossbow that fires at you every couple of seconds, whereas the King of Scales is accompanied by lizardmen who cannot be killed whilst the King is still alive.These accompaniments and extra abilities add a nice change of pace to combat. Boss fights become more of a challenge whilst regular encounters, in my opinion, act more as a way of honing your reaction times when countering, attacking and dodging.Along with extra abilities, bosses also bring curses. Take, for example, playing through the Jack of Plague stage. Doing so lands you with a curse called “Twice the Fail”. This curse makes it so when you roll to either fail or succeed a multiple choice option, every fail you get also loses you five gold. Every huge fail loses you ten gold. Curses make things that much more interesting.Earning New CardsThere are heaps of ways to earn new cards. Some cards become unlocked by succeeding in a certain event, thus carrying on the mini-story found in said event.Alternatively you can earn new cards by defeating bosses or winning certain battles. The cards all come in handy as you progress and can be put into your customised deck to give you the upper hand in your next game.Aesthetic CharmI’m finding myself expecting more and more from indie developers and their games. It was to my surprise to find out Defiant Development are based in Brisbane, Australia. So for me, that’s as indie as they come! And to have done such a wonderful job with the graphics and animations seen in Hand of Fate makes me very proud. The card illustrations utilise a satisfying woodcut artstyle which draws you further into the fantasy of it all.Musically it’s nothing spectacular but the voice acting of the deckmaster by Anthony Skordi is simply incredible. He’s responsible for voices in other games such as The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim, but I really feel that his work in Hand of Fate will go down in gaming history as one of the most engaging.The script and story writing by Defiant Development really adds to the whole experience and is literally the icing on the cake. I mean, I like cake, but when there’s icing as well, somebody stop me!Final ThoughtsHand of Fate brings the trading card and action genres together so seamlessly that you’ll be wondering why it hasn’t been done before. Each stage is longer and more exciting than the last, and gaining new cards after each game is always something to be looking forward to.There are a few things that bring the overall awesomeness down, such as: a lack of character customisation (everyone likes to make their player the way they want to, right?), relatively easy battles which often don’t require you to even think about touching your spells, and the general shortness of the Story mode, clocking in at around ten hours.Thankfully to fill in the gap between the Story mode and your next purchase, there is an Endless mode. Take your cards for a spin and see how far you can get. Hopefully if you’re good enough, you’ll make a decent appearance on the leaderboards!Ultimately I can’t recommend Hand of Fate enough to lovers of trading card games who also thoroughly enjoy smashing through monsters. If you ever tried your hand at the pen and paper version of Dungeons & Dragons and liked it, chances are you’ll find a satisfying experience playing through Hand of Fate.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												"Hand of Fate" could have been a total mess, a hybrid of a collectible card, board, choice, hack & slash, rouge-like and various other game elements, with an "opponent" who is sitting opposite of a table to you and just insults you most of the time.But somehow, it isn't a mess, but all it's aspects are put together in such a smart way, that it makes for an interesting, engaging, fun and awesome game to play.At the core of the game is a "deck of cards", packed with various encounters, events, vendors, monsters and equipment. Here a big part of it already starts, because as you progress through the game, you mostly become responsible for which cards are in the deck and you form your own adventure. Though, at the same time, the role of your "opponent", the dealer, becomes obvious soon, when he includes some cards himself into the deck and deals the cards to you, taunting you, looking down on you when you fail and showing his spite on your success.This theme and the dynamic presented by the only one who actually gets some character, which is the dealer, already creates an intriguing setup.Then, when the cards are dealt, you have to continue over a kind of "board" made of the encounters, which are usually revealed as you step on each card. Sometimes something mandatory happens, but most of the time a choice will follow, how you want to deal with the encounter and as you progress through the game, you will learn about the consequences of those decisions. And sometimes, through the encounters, you will have to play in a completely different setting, where a lot of the actual action and fighting happens, which requires your skill to overcome those chellenges, though sometimes it feels somewhat unprecise.And like that you progress through the game, board by board, gaining new cards, events, equipment, but also new monsters and other chellenges.And so the weird mix turns into this game, which you can influence in a lot of ways, the way you want to play, with which cards and how to act upon encounters, spiced with some chance and skill, delivered through an awesome theme, underlined with some story, which just makes it awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												I'm really enjoying this game. It reminds me of The Yawhg in that it gives you a set of choices in text format but you don't know which order they will come. I like that you can edit your decks because it gives the player some freedom to play how they want. I like playing the story driven cards but some might like the combat more. Also getting to alter your weapons deck is great because everyones fighting style will be different. I prefer Maces which do less damage but are faster while some will like the swords with more damage but slower attacks. The updates coming out are improving the gameplay and the developers are listening to the communitys feedback. I would totally recommend trying this game out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Ok so this game is really clever. The storytelling makes it. Sharp writing with an incredible flow that you could only get from an interactive experience. I love the way the stories play out across cards that you find, and that completing one card encounter, gives you the next part of the story in a card that you may draw next time you play. The dealer is wonderfully voice acted – something that is sorely missed when it comes to your average indie title. The only negative is that the real time combat is a bit clunky. It obviously draws from the Arkham series’ “Free Flow” mechanic, but is not executed with the same finesse. However, the combat does have some real weight, and seeing your gear materialise from their cards when the battle starts is ultra cool. This is a minor gripe, and something that will no doubt be addressed in Defiant’s future titles. Seriously – Hand of Fate is ridiculously good, and you should play it.Also it’s totally heart-warming to see such a great piece of entertainment come out of my home town. Well done!

												I know I have only played this for a little while, but daaayyum, I have been enjoying myself. I find the mechanics and the entire game itself really interesting. Its well worthy of competing against other AAA titles around. I recommend this game to anyone who wants to just lay back and have some fun. There are soo many different ways in which each encounter can be played again and again.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very interesting. As a deck-building game, it starts off somewhat bland with few cards... but that's all a part of it as you learn basic mechanics and how the game is played. As you progress, you build your deck full of new interesting encounters and gear that you can find during your adventure. The gameplay itself reminds me of the Batman games, though a little clunkier. As an Early Access game, I am not too worried about that.This has a lot of potential and I recommend it if you enjoyed the combat in the Batman Arkham series. This is scratching my 'action-rpg-loot' itch for the moment. The voice acting of the card dealer is also very well done. However, you should use a controller. The menus aren't all that well-done and the combat needs a bit of tweaking. Overall, though, I recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
Introduction:Hand of Fate is a mix between a tabletop card game and an action/RPG video game, with some added tarot, fantasy and roguelike inspiration thrown in.  Featuring hundreds of items, armor, weapons, artifacts, curses, blessings, encounters and quests, every single playthrough is unique.  On top of that, the deck-building mechanic adds even more variety as you customize your deck to suit your needs and playstyle.  All of this across two modes of gameplay.  Whew, someone deal the cards already!TLDR Highlights:++ Playthrough Randomness++ Quest Cards++ Deckbuilding System++ Voice Acting+ Action Combat+ Visuals/Graphics- Frustrating Chance and Luck of the Draw- Single Player Only= Truly an amazing game!  I wish I had thought of it.  Highly recommended!Review:PROS -- At the top of my list is the randomness of each playthrough.  Sure, you'll see the same cards a lot, but no two hands will ever be the same.  There are so many factors and variables at work that each time you play will be a different experience.  This is huge for me, because it's what will keep me coming back for more.One of the most fun features I've found in Hand of Fate are the quest cards.  These often have interesting situations, stories and adventures, that you get to see unfold right then or spread across several games if the quest has multiple parts.  Fun stuff and, again, keeps me coming back for more!Which brings me to the deckbuilding system.  By completing quest cards, defeating bosses, and other such things, you'll recieve tokens (which work similar to booster packs in a TCG) giving you more cards to add to your deck.  You can let the game recommend and build your deck for you, or you can hand select individual cards to build your own deck.  Granted, this system may seem pretty standard, but there was something about winning tokens and unlocking new cards that consistently gets me excited throughout the game.  Not to mention that it adds variety to my deck, which -- you guessed it! -- keeps me coming back for more.When it comes to voice acting, the dealer character is the only one that has any dialogue.  That being said, I don't think they could have found a better voice actor for the job.  It's done extremely well, and fits perfectly with the theme.  Not only that, but the script is excellent, because his idle chat and card/situation specific dialogue never seems to get old and has a genuine feel to it.  Mixing action RPG (Batman/Shadow of Mordor-esque) combat might have been a risking move on the developers part, but it was executed very well.  Combat starts out ridiculously easy as it teaches game mechanics, but as your deck gets stronger the enemies do too, thus making the fights more challenging.  A lot of reviewers say it's too easy all the way through, but I guarantee they died in combat plenty of times, and if they didn't then they didn't play very far into the game.  I will agree that combat might not be very complex, but it's fun and satisfying, and just challenging enough to mesh well with card game without drowning it out.  The last "pro" I have to add is that the visuals and graphics, even the animations, are really quite good.  It's all very pleasing to look at, and I was particularly impressed with the combat scenery.  The card artwork was well done too, and the theme fit perfectly.CONS --  Not much to add here, but like any card game, sometimes it comes down to the luck of the draw, which I can attest does not always go your way.  And it can be frustrating at times, especially later in the game when a single misstep can be very dangerous and potentially cost you the game.  Some people find this intolerable, but I don't really mind it that much.  It's a card game, after all, and chance is part of the territory.  Besides, there are blessing cards to help tip things it your favor (curse cards to make it worse too, so watch out).  And when you have to pick a card to determine success or failure, it's made so that you can try to follow movement of the card you want during the shuffle.  Still, it can be quite punishing at times, which turns some people off.Finally, I'm disappointed that there's no multiplayer.  Not entirely sure how it would work in this game, but I'd love to play a card game like this with friends!OVERALL --  There's so much to like about Hand of Fate, and very little to complain about. Without a doubt, this is one of the best games in my steam library.  I can't believe I never even heard of it until recently, but I'm very glad this game entered my crosshairs, because it's a true gem.  I most certainly recommend!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Ok so this game is really clever. The storytelling makes it. Sharp writing with an incredible flow that you could only get from an interactive experience. I love the way the stories play out across cards that you find, and that completing one card encounter, gives you the next part of the story in a card that you may draw next time you play. The dealer is wonderfully voice acted – something that is sorely missed when it comes to your average indie title. The only negative is that the real time combat is a bit clunky. It obviously draws from the Arkham series’ “Free Flow” mechanic, but is not executed with the same finesse. However, the combat does have some real weight, and seeing your gear materialise from their cards when the battle starts is ultra cool. This is a minor gripe, and something that will no doubt be addressed in Defiant’s future titles. Seriously – Hand of Fate is ridiculously good, and you should play it.Also it’s totally heart-warming to see such a great piece of entertainment come out of my home town. Well done!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												It's like they took elements from Card Hunter, Batman, Bastion, FTL, and Ziggurat, mixed it up in a blender, and ended up with something far more enchanting and wonderful than you would ever expect. It starts off pretty easy but the difficulty ramps up considerably as you unlock new cards.  It's one of those "Just one more round" games  I always seem to end up playing until 3AM without realizing it. There's also an endless mode for infinite replayability. If you're on the fence about this one, check out the Total Biscuit video for a really great synopsis of what makes this one so special. I can't wait to see what kind of stuff this developer has in store for the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												The First time I saw this game in my queue; I watched the video and said no thanks.  Few months later I am looking for a game to play while searching Google for ARPG style games and this game was on the list.  Went back and re-looked at the game a second time.  The reviews are good, with what I would say is a 90% rating based on the number of positive to negative reviews.  Sometimes my gut is wrong, after reading recent reviews trolling the discussion I decided for the 30$ CAD it might be worth a look see.There is a lot of goodness going on in this game; it pits you as the player against a dungeon master like character.  There is a randomness to the game that is fresh as you use decks of cards to determine how the game progresses.  This is an interesting concept, but there is a twist even through you can control the encounter deck, don’t expect the dealer to play fair especially as the game progresses.  The cards are dealt you move your table top piece unto the next encounter card, it plays out like a choose your own adventure novel, where you can encounter helpful goblins, or find yourself at the mercy of angry mobs.  There is also an arena type encounter where you fight in almost an arcade style fighting, cards determine how many mobs and of what type.  All leading to a Boss card at the end, the pace in the arcade game is pretty quick, but manageable even for old coots like myself.IF anything, the game suffers a bit from a lack of a good tutorial, there is a small game to begin your series, but it lacks instructions, while it is not hard, it would be nice to understand the mechanics a bit more before you are thrown into the fray.  The arcade sequence is a bit twitch as you have to use wasd as movement, along with Q and the 1 and 2 buttons, as well as the spacebar.  I am more comfortable now, but there can be a lot going on when you are being attacked by a large group when you are trying to figure out the combat mechanics.  There is no game save feature, you play, leave and resume.  Not sure if you can start over even if you wanted too. It also offers no player avatar customization, so you can’t choose what your avatar looks like, pity I think that is important sometimes to create that affinity between the player and the game.  Overall 7.5/10, this is a good solid fun casual game that is unique to play.  It offers up a never ending play value as you never know what the cards will have in store for you.  I think a few tweaks and this game easily could be 10.  Buy it and support them in the Sequel HOF2.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												This game is one of those rare gems that exceeds expectations. The game combines and rpg with a card game quite well, the gameplay switches between going through a board made of cards into live action combat and back again. It is quite clear the developers put a lot of work into making this game. The dealer and your antagonist makes the game feel quite interactive as he narrarates your story. He also has fun lines of dialogue that just add life to the game. The combat is very simple to master but allows you plenty of room to improve. The replayability of the game is probably its strength as every single game is different and allows for plenty of room for exploration with the deck building aspect of the game to change up every single playthrough.I look forward to seeing what else is done with this game, it is well worth the 25$ it costs.

Early Access Review
								I played this game for about an hour, even though it is in beta early access, its reminiscence of fable in looks, and plays like a card game while featuring dungeon crawling and fights that just top the exceptional uniqueness of this game. It also can be challenging with the random draw of cards because you dont know what monsters or mazes or traps you will have to face, you could say the game has a roguelikness to it because if you die you die. But you keep the cards you unlock and can build preset decks, and decide what you want to take with you into your next game such as armor, weapons, abilities, etc. Take in mind though that this game is in beta, and it needs a little more fine tuning in the fluidity of fighting and character movement but i beliieve that will be taken care of in one of the many updates being worked on in the future. This game is amazing and has great potential i would recommend this game to all my friends or any other gamer.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								This was a surprisingly fun random pick up. I would describe it as a Rogue-like mixed with a card game mixed with Gauntlet. You play against a narrating wizard who draws random card challenges as you progress through a dungeon and taunts you. It's a simple and fun mechanic and you can sit down to play a round in 15-30 minutes. As you encounter certain cards you get tokens to unlock new cards to put in your deck. All in all very nice.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Brilliant Concept!Interesting combination of:-Choose your own adventure (Like those books) :: Every card in your encounter deck is like single page in that kind of book. You build your own deck from the cards you have unlocked.-Action Adventure Game (god of war) :: While the combat is not impressive looking and visceral as those games tend to be, the combat has strategic and dynamic elements to keep you on your toes.-Rogue Like :: Rogue likes have always been about exploration and resource management. This game offers that in spades.When I played this for first few runs, I thought that "Soon I've seen all the encounters and items so it will lose it's charm" but I discovered that some of the encounter cards are not set in stone. They have multiple "forms". For example encounter called "Rock Fall" had very different conclusion.Also when player is given "random" positive or negative conclusion to encounter the player draws from Four different cards.Cards can be any combination of Fail, Greater Fail, Success, Greater Success.The fact that player is physically show the shuffle of these cards gives him opportunity to follow how the cards move and can eliminate possibilities.Also every encounter with "red spot" on it, is part of a quest of sorts. When dealt with correctly will unlock the next part of the quest available for your encounter deck. This is very neat way of not making the game all about getting to the boss but the path to the boss is also important.So that this review would not be complete hype lets bring up few issues:-Combat is every now and then very easy. When there are 1-4 opponents you can overwhelm the enemy quickly because your "auto targeting" attacks send you flying across the map. You feel like juggernaut from Dota 2-Block / Counter animations are too slow compared to your normal ones. You feel like everyone in the game stops for your to do your animation.-Enemies NEVER attack at same time. There is always only single enemy swinging a sword + one ranged enemy ready to fire.-Block / Counter "quick-time" prompts show for too long. I feel like being babied into the game. I wish there was some difficulty settings about this.-Blood. Game really needs blood right now the swings rarely give me that satisfaction. I barely get any feedback from hitting the enemy. Its even harder to discern how much damage I've done or have I actually killed one of my enemies without any blood splatters.As you can see Most gripes I have are in the combat of the game. Thankfully the combat still feels fun but could be more.And HEY! It's not all about the combat anyway. :3

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Hand of Fate is really something out of the ordinary;Designed as a card collecting/dungeon brawler game, it tries a fresh, new approach to both genres.+-Interesting gameplayGreat voice actingAmazing artworkVery forgiving, yet challengingOne-button combatsluggish animations in combatDescription to how the game works; (thought I'd put it a bit after the pro and cons, as it's a bit mundane to read.)At the start of each new dungeon, you'll get to choose, which cards are in your own "equipment" deck and which cards you want to add to the dealer's deck. So you decide whether you want this extra shield or ring, or rather add an extra sword into the deck. The same thing is possible with your dealer's deck, as it's your call to make your game easier and miss out on those card tokens, which you need for new cards, equipment as well as encounters, or choose the cards, which are yet to be beaten and try your best on the way.The dealer lays out a dungeon with the chosen cards, in which you navigate around with your little figurine, kinda like a board game. From time to time you'll encounter a monster or a trap, from where the game will switch into a Arkam City-style 3rd person combat system, which is debateably the weakest part of the game, in which you can move around a small area, dodge, attack and counter attacks.I really hope you found this review helpful in aiding your decision towards buying this game.If you have thoughts on improving this review, please contact me! (:

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								First Impressions:Combining an ARPG with the deck-building genre is both gutsy and interesting.  I had a hard time wrapping my head around what such a game would be like until I actually sat down with it and gave it a spin. The encounter deck, combined with the narrator's own stock, will make up the obstacles you'll have to overcome.  You'll gain equipment, food, and other goodies by successfully completing these encounters, allowing you to improve your character.  In between games however, your character starts over with just your basic equipment (though the cards you unlock can be seeded into your decks so that you can discover them next game).  The combat portions put you into an arena where you'll be actively trying to be the last one standing.  The flow of combat and the combat mechanics reminded me a bit of "Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor", albeit an extremely simplistic version. As a fan of deck-builders, "Hand of Fate" is an easy recommend.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												This is a really, really great game. I am so happy I found it.First of all, the dialogue is just outstanding. Not only is it well written and well spoken, it also makes the game very easy to understand. Unlike most other cards games, you don't need to learn all cards by hand, as all of these are explained in detail whenever you draw them.Furthermore, I am deeply a fan of the rogue-like aspect, which I never thought a card game could have. The gameplay is very original; there is no other game even close to this. Everytime you draw a card, you either gain resources, equipment, or you will enter a combat. I am still astonished at how one can combine so many different gaming aspects, whilst yet creating a wonderful game.With no doubt, from the old RTS games I've played to the FPS games that have been dominating the planet, this is one of the best single-player games ever made.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Stop reading reviews and just buy this game! It's absolutely worth the full price, and being on sale makes it a no-brainer!This is an amazing game to keep you busy between larger games, or just as something to play to unwind before bed. There's not a ton of over-arching story, which makes it ideal for dipping into for a few minutes at a time, even if you let weeks pass between play sessions.The general mechanic is that you've died, and are playing a card game against death. Death deals a set of cards that create a dungeon for your character to play through. Each card is a different room or event for you to play through, with everything from gambling events to stores to story-driven events to combat. Each dungeon you play through unlocks new cards -- both equipment for your adventurer as well as rooms and events to play through.  The next time Death deals a dungeon, it will be slightly longer than the last one you played through. One of the best mechanics is that when you hit a "combat" room, you actually "dive into" the card and control your adventurer as he fights the minions from the card. The combat mechanics are simple, but surprisingly fun. The minions have enough variation in attacks and style that combat never becomes dull, even though you have to fight several mobs per dungeon. The devs are also great people. They've added a ton of new contenet since the games release, and as you play through you'll notice their little DLC expansions peppered through -- you always have the option to dive into DLC from the main game. I hope they keep releasing these expansions!So all in all, this game is a no-brainer. It isn't likely to be one that you sit down an play through entirely without breaks, but it makes a perfect distraction between larger games or just for a short session at night. Add it to your collection now!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This game is very interesting, it would be the best word to describe it with.Hand of fate uses cards to basically tell a story of what happened in an adventure. With a lot of cards representing equipment, encounters and fights. It's usually up to the player to fill in the blanks in the story.Your only real contact is the Dealer. A mysterious man, sitting in a locale controlling the ''game'', which are shown through the cards. He is the person that sets it all in motion. Yet, you do not know what purpose he fulfills otherwise.The game is for the most time in the adventure on the cards. The encounter cards are laid out in a pattern, sometimes a linear path, other times a maze-like construction. Your goal is to move from your start point, to the exit, which remains hidden. Important to know, is that every move uses food. if you run out of food, you start losing health. As per usual in most games, no health = death.Some encounters require a luck-based desicion, this is represented by four different cards. in order: Huge succes, Succes, Failure and Huge failure. 4 cards are shown, with the possible outcomes for you to choose. the cards are flipped, shuffeled, and then it's up to you to choose the adventurers fate in the encounter. It's important to know that succeeding the challenge, does not always progress the encounter, nor does failure always have a bad outcome.Sometimes, an encounter happens to be a fight. You are then taken to a scene, which has a lot of variation in both size and looks. The game then turns in a 3rd person brawler. you must beat all enemies to continue, or die trying.The story of your character is vague at best, and it is up to you, as the player, to find out who he is. And most importantly, what happened to him as to how he got there. Do not think that the Dealer is there to help you, as he will remind you a lot of times.I personally like the setting a lot, it's simple, yet complicated, and shrouded in mystery. The Dealer as a character is awesome, and basically creates the atmosphere of the game on his own, commenting on your choices, your succeses, and failures.If a point of negativity is to be made, I would have liked to see some character customisation. Not that the game requires it, but it would have been nice. Also, the Dealer runs out of lines quickly, and sometimes his conversations are pretty long. Still, the story that he conveys through said dialogue is very nice.Overall, i had a great experience with the game as a whole. the DLC that i got, added a whole lot of semi-adventures to go through. I do not value scores, since a game should be your experience. A game that people generally dislike, may be the game you love the most.If a score is to be put up:8.5/10.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												To summarise - an atmospheric, rewarding and compelling game. There are other sources to explain how the game works so I won't re-explain that but I will highlight its key points.You build a deck of equipment and encounters, then run the level with that deck of cards, making progress towards expanding your deck (and thus your options), and in the middle of all that you engage in short third-person fights with creatures/enemies. And in the middle of ALL of that, you are continually listening to the comments of the dealer, the writing for which is superb and the voice acting for which really sets a very mysterious and compelling tone to the game. Added to that the animation as all this takes place, the atmosphere of the game is extremely enticing, full of exploration, mystery and intrigue.The deck building is compelling as it has a real impact on how you will play the level and has more depth that 'best equipment in, worst equipment out', actually requiring thought to get cards which may work well with your building of the encounters. Speaking of which, you also choose what the encounters are going to be during the level, mainly focusing on ones which you have not completed yet which in turn will expand your available cards. A very rewarding and compelling loop with surprising depth.The little battles are not too long or onerous and as they are very short and there is a lot of variety (some variety in enemies and variety in how you play based on what equipment you've managed to acquire, completely changing your abilities) they do not get repetitive quickly.The campaign is, as I have said, very atmospheric. It is all about exploring the encounters around you (as you don't know which ones they are), with success leading to rewards expanding your deck for the next run. There is a fair element of luck involved, which would be annoying if it weren't for the fact that you make permanent progress on each run even if you die, which means that you still feel like something was achieved.Overall, these factors combine to make a very compelling and enjoyable experience which is highly recommended for just about everyone, since it isn't really just a 'brawler' or a 'card building game' or any of those, but a great hybrid which takes the best elements from everything in my opinion. Add to that the updates by the developers, it is one to pick up and keep playing. (And the DLC also comes highly recommended as it adds yet another element to this great game!)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
Product received for free
												Hand of Fate is an action, indie, RPG game developed by the Australian company, Defiant Development. This is one of the best action based tabletop simulators so to speak. The gameplay is very unique with a system which is enjoyable and challenging at the same time.The story of the game is quite simple, your goal is to defeat the narrator of the game, the fate weaver.  The campaign mode contains 12 bosses that need to be defeated and after each four rounds you gain additional bonuses while the enemies become stronger. The game essentially plays as tabletop adventures with cards shuffled face down and your main hero being a pawn moving. Many times the path has different shapes which can make it tricky when it comes to planning your route.The three main stats that are used in this game are health, gold and food. Health is usually either lost or gained in combat/traps/boons, gold can be gained in multiple ways while food is the resource that makes everything more challenging and interesting in Hand of Fate. Each movement costs one food and it is also used in many events which adds a whole new depth to the game.The other important factors in this game are the gear and blessings/curses. The hero can gain during his adventures multiple pieces of equipment as well as blessings from various events. Combos can make a huge difference in this game and some pieces or blessings can save your life. For instance, one blessing found during the game let me re-draw any attempt during chance cards, saving my butt many times when I could have ended up in a sticky situation. The system itself is based on four factors: success, huge success, failure, huge failure which usually will either reward you handsomely or make you cry. Another factor that makes this game insanely addicting is the tokens. Each time you resolve a challenge at the end of the round, you unlock new tokens which adds additional ways to customize your deck.The game excels in particular in the music and storytelling department. The music is absolutely amazing and combined with the storytelling of the fate weaver, it makes the experience even more refreshing. Each time you activate a card the story teller will make a snarky remark depending on the outcome. After the player finishes campaign mode, the game can be continued in endless mode which functions similar to the campaign but with points given for successful actions, the floor number reached as well as your other stats. This in turn can provide a very long and amazing experience in which you can either unlock the cards you missed or simply enjoy Hand of Fate. After each floor the game becomes harder due to the extra trap cards added.Overall, Hand of Fate is one of the best tabletop simulator games I have ever played which makes it a must-buy. I give the game a 9/10, a must have to any tabletop/RPG/card games fan.For our popular daily giveaways and similar reviews head over to http://www.steamified.com/To begin your journey through our myriad of social media join our Steam Group

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Currently frustration outweighing fun for me personally.  Needs more balancing.  Certain cards produce encounters that are laughably easy and others that are pure hell.  You are literally at the mercy of total randomness in this game.  Queen of Dust fight brought realization as to how wierd and sluggish combat can be.  Combat tries to be like Batman Arkham games yet more linear and slow with one to two combat animations and no exciting combos to my knowledge.   Spent entire QoD fight lunge diving to evade and waiting to strike someone and thought to myself how ridiculous this mechanic is and has been in past fighting games.  If shield cards or blessings rolled may have been easier fight yet in my experience this is fith time fighting her and found nothing useful on my way to her so far.  Player seems to have enormous hitbox and compared to enemies and because of the stationary camera during fights it is easy to misjudge distance at a critical time.  Don't feel as if I am making any substantial progress in the game.  You unlock new cards but may never see them in a playthrough and more often than not they wont help you anyway (and can also possibly hurt you).  Once a new act is started you lose all equipment and have to pull from the deck all over again to gain items.  Mixed feelings about the game overall so far.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												I feel like I could sit around and play this game forever. The Game Master is your opponent. He sits across from you. Antagonizing, and narrating your every move. You best him and his cards/minions through puzzles, combat, and games of chance laid out before in a free to explore maze of face down cards.Success brings you gold, supplies, and equipment to brave his more challenging tricks, and traps. Each victory brings you better, stronger cards. Magical swords and armor. But, each success also gives him more cards to use against you. More traps and dangers for you to stumble into.Truly a great game, and a must have for your steam library.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												A really strange mix between a beat'em all and an RPG.The narrative part is very well done and you unlock differents parts of various stories as you complete challenges given by cards.Each card presents an event or an equipement, and each game shuffle your deck of events randomly to give you a challenge.The battle system is inspired by the Batman Arkham series and if not perfect (because it stays pretty basic), does its job.The RNG is present and sometimes can be a ♥♥♥♥♥. (Davy Jones, give me back my soul !). But the more vicious challenges tends to give the more interesting rewards (and if it's too hard, don't keep them in the deck). Several challenges are kept in the deck in order to unlock others events so you end up by keeping the difficult one only to complete them once.For an indie game, graphics are also really great and animations well executed. Presentation is top notch. The amount of work in this gem should have been huge.Reminds me the books where you are the hero.The result is original, well refined, and gives a game that you actually want to complete.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
TL;DR: Excellent visualization of what's happening in your head, when you play board-game IRLWe all love board-games, don't we? The only problem with them is that there's too much left for the imagination. If only there'd be a game with board-game rules and visualization of, say, Diablo III or Torchlight, or something similar... If you ever had a thought like that (and I know that I did), you're welcome to buy Hand of Fate as soon as you'll finish reading this review.Hand of Fate is a game that's very simple to play, yet very complex to explain: basically, it's a card game, where you move your token from card to card, encounter monsters, treasures and various obstacles. At the end of each scenario, you fight a boss. Though, the complex thing is that when you encounter an enemy, the game turns in something or an action-RPG with you controlling your hero, using skills and items to actually fight your enemies in real time.Graphics are good, I did enjoy both hacking and slashing, and browsing through on-board adventures (not all of the cards include you teleporting to the arena and fighting monsters, obviously enough). The dealer is a nifty masked dude with creepy yet charismatic voice (you might expect a new announcer with it in Dota 2, though), which follows his own rules and easily admits defeat if you slay his henchmen.As you progress through the storyline, you encounter more powerful enemies and gather a stronger loot. Every scenario is unique, thanks to the randomizer -- you can even call these levels procedurally generated, rogue-like style: every time you start over, both scenario decks (yours and dealer's) are shuffled, and you're getting a new adventure each time you start over.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - I'd strongly recommend this game to all of the RPG fans out there -- it's a breath of refreshing air on the modern RPG scene, really. If you're not into RPG, you might want to check the game out anyway -- it's well-done and interesting to play overall.Rating: 8.9 out of 10.0

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Admittedly I am not very good at this type of game yet but I've found it to be both fun and frustrating at the same time. The dealer is a narcissistic wind bag who spends most of his time boasting about all the warriors who have excepted his challenge , and then fallen by his hand (no pun intended) trying to beat him at his usually unfair scrimmage. For example win two food cards, lose 4 food on his very next move...and food is important because each move you make costs you 1 food..."oh I AM sorry" he smugly spouts...and let's just follow that up with a lose half your gold card as well, making it harder for you to buy food . That's fair right? There are other examples as well but seriously, it is very aggressive and it's pretty much like that through the entire game. SO if you don't have patience at all for this kind of mental abuse, you should probably avoid this one to spare yourself a lot of unnecessary stress and quite possibly the death of your favorite controller or any other throw-able object nearby ...But  If you can handle the dealers cockiness it...it's a pretty cool and challenging game.

It's well worth the price.Pros:- As original as it can be- Great graphics- Deck building, providing a different experience every time you play- Combat is good, basically the same as in the Batman Arkham series- Choose-your-own-adventure style gameplay- Has an endless mode- The transitions are amazing- Sometimes has a bit of morbid humor added into itAnd much more pros that I don't even bother to type down since there are so many.Cons:- Gets a bit boring after about an hour or two of gameplay (but that's in my opinion, may differ per person)So yeah. It's a great game. You should buy it. Right now.

Pros:+ Roguelike collectible card game dungeon delver brawler roleplaying game+ The dealer's narration is spot-on and immersive; some of the best voice-acting I've heard+ Graphics and ambient sounds are amazingly detailed+ Customizable decks allow you to play like you want+ Fun side-adventures that have unexpected consequences+ Collecting cards through gameplay allows for deeper and varied customization of your deck to fit whatever is needed+ Manages to stay fun, fresh and challenging the whole way through+ Enemies grow stronger with you, challenges get harder, random chance gets stacked against you... it's great+ Rewards skill while still utilizing luck of the draw+ Overall polished final product - and it shows+ I have never felt this conflicted about beating a final boss+ Developers are invested and involved with the community; are releasing more new content to continue spicing up the gameCons:- Typical repetitiveness that comes with any roguelike game (Mr. Lionel, hello, give me my shield please and I'll be on my way)- Typical aggravation associated with chance-only games (that treasure chest cost me half my health with nothing to show for it)Overall:  This is a game that seems strange at first, but then after the first game, I realized I was playing something inspired.  You make your deck, then the dealer adds his own cards to it.  These cards make up the "dungeon" and are placed face down (mostly) randomly.  You move your avatar from one card to the next to explore each dungeon, turning the cards face up and resolving their events or encounters as you go along.  Maybe it's a shop, maybe it's an ambush, maybe it's an event where you get lost in the swamp, or goblins steal your equipment and you have to kill them before they escape.  The variety and depth is impressive.  Some events rely on skill (beating down goblins who just stole all your weapons, for example), while others rely solely on chance/luck of the draw (picking from 3 success cards and 1 failure card to climb safely down into a ravine, for example).  As the game goes on, it introduces more and more facets, all of which give another layer of chance and strategy.  Combat takes place like the Batman: Arkham Whatever games, where you just smack enemies until they fall over and counter when it tells you to, but it's still fun, and the enemies provide enough challenges to keep from being boring/easy.Bottom Line: Absolute recommend.  This is one of those rare times where a game tries to do a little of everything, and manages to succeed at it fantastically.

content:
Posted: April 20
												TL;DR - There is absolutely nothing bad I can say about this game. It's a bit slow, but it fits the game. There's a lot of reading, but it fits the game - it's a "choose your own adventure" type game. It's amazing. Strongly, very strongly recommended.Positives:1. Atmosphere. It's really well made. It's consistent with it's themes and atmosphere, the ambient noises, dark visuals, hand drawn beautiful cards, etc etc. 2. Presentation. Amazing. The way your avatar appears on the battlefield from a card, the way each item appears from the cards... The way randomness is made - you pick a card from a shuffled deck. Great ideas, and implemented very well...3. Variety. This game is a huge mix of CCG, RPG, Dungeon Crawler, Action Adventure, Exploration, etc etc etc... There is so much to do, there are so many different things to do, and all that is hidden so well in the cards and general gameplay mechanics... 4. Visuals. Yeah, it's not as great visually as Crysis or Witcher 3 or whatever. Still, the visual art style is fitting, consistent and overall really great looking, and that's the most important for visuals - to look good.5. Gameplay. That is kinda covered in the variety point, but again, you are playing a choose your own Dungeon Crawling adventure CCG with RPG elements, customizable equipment and fighting style, as well as doing quest chains, mini quest chains, beating guys up, well, everything. 6. The Dealer. Oh, the dealer... I will leave it at that. The dealer.???1. The game is a bit slow, but it have a lot of reading. So it's understandable. I don't consider it a negative, but some people may dislike the slow progression speed. Some rounds can go WAY over an hour if you read every encounter..2. There is a lot of reading. A LOT of reading. The writing is good, which helps, but still, there is a lot of text, that needs to be crunched. After a few rounds some basic cards will start repeating themselves, so repetition may become an issue. I still don't consider that a negative, but some people may not enjoy the literature aspects as much as me.

Posted: July 28, 2015
												I'm going out of my way of not really bothering about reviewing games just to say this: -  If you don't like  any the multiple sub-genres involved in this game (deck-building, RPG, old-school tabletop, Rogue-like, Arkhan-like combat) just don't bother giving bad reviews, you won't get the message the game is trying to deliver (it could change your mind on those, hardly though); -  If you're new to  those genres, buy it and play with an open mind, don't give quick judgment and the game will show its beauty to you (don't just give up after a few plays);-  If you , like myself,  enjoy  most to all of the aspects of those genres, buy and play it, you'll surprise yourself with a richly complex and mysterious story inside this very much balanced (don't let the bad reviews get in your head) tabletop inspired (some luck involved, sometimes, and  not  unfair) and build your own adventure RPG. The combat element is tough, but satisfactory and rewarding, it's not 100% as perfect as some AAA titles but it does a good job and that's enough to have a good experience with the combat part. This is an indie game, so don't expect a perfectly polished game in all aspects, the Devs (who are such great guys and responsive towards the community) are constantly polishing and releasing patches (and DLCs) to fix and improve the game experience, so it just gets better and better.  TL:DR version  - Don't like the genres? Don't bother (but it would be nice of you if you bought it to help the indie community C: );- Aren't familiarized with the genres? Try it for yourself (truly do, you won't regret it) and don't let bad reviews get to you;-Like those genres?  YOU WILL ♥♥♥♥ING LOVE THIS PIECE OF ART CALLED   HAND OF FATE. (sorry if my english is not 100% ^^').

The game is extremely fascinating, combing a trading card game, with action rpg and rogue like. Many would have failed and given the public a hobbled mess of slapped on features. Instead Defiant have wonderfully crafted the game and mechanics, so as to make you feel like you're being guided by a Poker dealing Dungeon Master.I was pleasantly surprised by how well the it all blends together and plays. The game is still in development, and I have never liked the idea of Early Access, but Hand of Fate certainly has amazing promise. The music is good, although not finished, and the graphics despite using the unity engine runs and looks really well. Although sadly the maximum resolution was only 1920x1080. Something easily forgiven due to the game still actively being worked on.I certainly enjoy it, and I look forward to playing more as it develops.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												When I think about fantasy RPGs they tend to involve a whole lot of fighting and the occasional tavern break to play some dice or card games against the locals. In Hand of Fate you play cards with the occasional break for fighting. The combat is a little repetitive but encounters never last very long and is still fairly enjoyable. The card game itself, though, is great - a sort of progressive deck-builder with dealer-supplied cards thrown in to shake things up. You move across a randomised map of location cards, resolving the conflicts on each as you pass them, and gaining (or losing!) loot and resources as you make your way to the boss for the level. Then you start again for the next level... but with a couple new cards, a few new story items and a new item or two up for grabs.The style, story and narration are also quite charming and really add to the overall feeling and aesthetic of the game.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												NOTE: This review just covers the cons. If you'd like to read about what's good in this game just read one of the positive reviews--I agree with everyone else on the pros of this game, but unfortuantely the cons outweight the pros imo so I focus on them for that reason. What begins as a wonderful game full of fun and interesting play eventually becomes just another test of player versus sadistic game developers that's so common these days. The more you love this game, the more you'll end up hating it once you near the end.Unfortunately for players, the way this game ramps up difficulty is to cheat. By the time you reach the last level of the "story" mode (there's no story), the game is so unbelievably cheaty that it robs a very fun game of 100% of the fun it had previously contained. Just so you know what I mean: the last boss battle takes place in a 10 foot square environment so there's virtually no room to avoid the enemies. The problem? Just getting to the battle generally costs you between 30-50% of your health so you always start the battle at 65% or less health (due to curse cards on the last level which hit you every few turns so there's no way to avoid permanent health losses no matter how you play). The enemies surrounding the boss are all invincible until the boss is killed. But you're in a tiny environment so you can't dodge the enemies, and also they all protect the boss so you can't really get to him either. Invincible foes is the game developer equivalent to a slap in the face. It's a big F U to players that makes it very clear the developers enjoy punishing us for playing their game. There is no place in games for invincible enemies--it's a BS way to make a game harder that can only be described as cheating unless the player also has the ability to become invincible. What is so frustrating about this game is that it has so much potential completely spoiled by anti-player decisions which ruin the fun.I can't recommend this game because it's the most frustrating kind of game out there: the kind that draws you in, gets better and better, then because of really bad developer decisions becomes just a torture fest of "Can I get that 1 in 100 run where I can pull off a miracle based entirely on luck." I HATE games that force the player to rely entirely upon luck to succeed, and unfortunately by the end of the "story" mode, that's exactly what has happened. The game begins with maybe 25% luck and 75% skill and strategy but by the end it's more like 85% luck, which is FAR too high for any game under any circumstances. Also worth mentioning (even the most positive reviewers mention this as a negative) is the extremely generic and not-so-great battle system (which is about 40% of what you do in the game). You roll around and endlessly kite groups of enemies until you can catch one of them off on his own and get a few hits in before kiting again. Also, some of the camera angles in this game are so bad they can and will get you killed. I seriously haven't seen this bad of a use of camera angles since the early days of Resident Evil. It's truly shocking how bad the camera angles can be sometimes.On top of those issues, the narrator drones on and on endlessly and he only has like 8 or 9 things that he says for normal cards you frequently encounter, so you keep hearing him say the same boring thing over and over and over and over. It's maddening. When you first start playing, it's all very charming and wonderful, but by the 400th time of hearing him say the same thing (there's no way to skip or mute his monologues) it's gets really annoying and definitely takes away from the replay value.I hope the devs make better decisions for Hand of Fate 2, which is currently in development. I feel like this game had great potential and I believe that if they fix these glaring (imo game-breaking) problems they could have one of the best games in a long time. The parts of Hand of Fate that work, WORK. It's an incredibly fantastic game CONCEPT, but unfortuantely miles away from a fantastic game. Fingers crossed, I'd certainly check out Hand of Fate 2 when it comes out. I'd give this one a pass.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												After finally reaching the end, I can no longer recommend this game.  The ♥♥♥♥♥how that is combat in HoF frequently makes the game an infuriating chore, and the final boss fight is downright insulting.  After spending roughly 1/5th of my playtime fine-tuning my deck, doing repeated runs, and failing in the final boss encounter many times, I refuse to try again.  Some of those deaths were undoubtedly my fault, some due to bad luck in previous encounters (it is a roguelike, afterall), but most of them came from the shoddy combat.Here's what you can expect in fights: Getting stuck on invisible bits of geometry, that enemy AI seamlessly glide past.Not being able to interrupt your own attack in order to block or deflect projectiles, an absolute necessity to survive.A mostly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fixed camera that you have zero control over (causing you to constantly lose sight of enemies while evading).Maps so terrifically small and cluttered that fights with multiple enemies (or several large ones) can make it impossible to reliably target the enemy you want, because you can't see it behind the others.When fighting, any enemies knocked down or stunned will immediately get up and attack you when you try to finish any other downed enemy.  No matter how long the duration of a knockdown or stun is meant to be.As your combo goes higher, the screen becomes progressively darker, blurrier, and more red.  Most of your broken combos will be due to squinting at the screen.Many enemies will stand off-screen (remember the fixed camera?) and throw/shoot projectiles at you, but the indicator that something is being hurled at you is not always long enough to reach your screen.  Even if it were, at end-game there are so many enemies, so much clutter, and such a tight, fixed camera angle that you won't see them anyway.Enemies performing unblockable power attacks from a standing position will occasionally glide across the floor like it was glass, shooting straight at you.And, finally:Broken enemy targeting, creating issues such as: Missing the enemy you're aiming for, and hitting a shielded enemy that breaks your combo.  Being sucked in to the three-hit ground finisher, causing you to get hit/shot in the back. Hitting a pot (or other container) instead of an enemy. Ruining your combo by simply swinging in an entirely wrong direction, hitting nothing.If I sat and thought about it, I could probably come up with more flaws in the combat.  Instead, I'll say this: Hand of Fate has sold tens of thousands of copies, has several thousand positive reviews, and has only been completed by ~4% of the people who own it.  And, I've recently discovered, many of those people finished the game on Apprentice (Easy) not Adventurer (Normal) difficulty.  They likely wouldn't have had to, if you could reliably control your character in fights.Don't take my word for it, though.  Most of the glowing reviews for this game end with an admission that the combat becomes garbage by end-game. Skip past the first ten glowing paragraphs from the current top review (found here), and you'll even see it there.The sequel is in Early Access, I'd suggest waiting.  Hopefully they will have created a version of Hand of Fate that you won't be disgusted with by the end of it.

number of helpful: 37 of 73 people (51%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												I'll start by saying that I want to love this game. The atmosphere is incredible, the pretense for the story delivered through a card based roguelike dungeon is genius in how it capitalises on the strengths of both card games and roguelikes. Even the ambitious combat scheme is generally pretty engaging (if flawed in a few small ways). I adore a lot of what the game is doing. That said, I can't recommend it in its current state.I originally wanted to say that the game is too difficult, but that's not true. The game is outright unfair. I'd be fine with the game being difficult, because difficulty implies a requirement for careful application of thought and skill. This is not what this game offers. Especially nearer towards the end of the game, there are an incredible amount of cards the dealer plays that may as well read "Player loses game". For an example, in the final encounter I'd unlocked before giving up, the deck was stacked with entirely uncounterable cards that reduce maximum life by 50%. It wasn't uncommon for my health bar to consist of a maximum single hit point by the third floor, if I was lucky enough to make it that far.I've read on the Steam forums that as of the 2nd of July a rebalance patch has been planned, but with no current ETA I cannot recommend buying this game unless you are a) the proud owner of a 16 leaf clover or b) a supreme masochist.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is loads of fun, and really addictive. It combines a simple-to-learn (but challenging) combat system with the randomness of an old-school story-telling collectible card game (such as Mythos). In short, each session you navigate your character through a serious of cards (that represent scenarios) in a game. Each card is effectively a random chance for loot, health, upgrades or monsters. When a monster card is drawn, you fight the monster(s) in a third-person view and gain treasure. At the end of a "game", you fight a boss monster. If you win, you gain new scenario cards and bosses to add to your deck. Each time you play, the cards are shuffled - so your scenarios are randomised as well!Each session is quick, and exciting. I recommend this to fans of the boardgame Talisman, CCGs and action fantasy games. There are hours of fun to be had in this little gem.

content:

												TL;DR: Good Idea. Very Mediocre execution. Get it when it is highly reduced (66% and higher). Not worth the full price.__________Pros:Good, very immersive narration.Compelling gameplay design, despite the terrible combat.High replayability value.Very stable, crashes are very rare.Very accessible, it is easy to get in and start playing, no hour long tutorials.Good saving system. The game saves your progress very frequently, so even if you crash at some point (which is very rare), you can still restart the game and continue playing pretty much off where you left.__________Cons/Issues:The Combat System is pretty terrible and boring, pretty default button mashing with some QTE and hammering of space button to dodge. Camera viewport is also locked in position that follows the player.UI and the interaction with it is flat out terrible.Sometimes you get the entire board revealed to you, but you can't zoom in onto the board to see which cards are which so the revealing was entirely pointless because you can't see anything.The cursor for menu selections sticks to the screen stupidly when playing with the mouse, making you pick choices you didn't want and you get royaly f**ked. Pretty terrible.Alot of game mechanics are not explained to you, like if you uncover an event that requires you to have a better weapon, can you return to that event if you get one? Nobody knows,♥♥♥♥♥♥isn't explained.The game itself is poorly optimized on the visual side, with frequent framedrops which shouldn't be happening. The game is just not worth it at full price.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Okay, so this game is REALLY unique and cool. You play as a recently-deceased man who has passed onto the afterlife, and is reliving broken memories of his life in the form of a card game, played against a mysterious hooded figure known only as "The Dealer." The game's cards correspond to various memories of the man's life; trials he may have endured, enemies he may have faced, and the items and powers he may have wielded to vanquish his foes. Don't be fooled, though; this is definitely NOT a card game. It is more like a text-based choose-your-own-story adventure game, interspersed with hack-'n-slash combat encounters. The cards you possess on the table manifest themselves as equipment and abilities in the combat portions of the game, which are crucial to being able to take on the enemies you will face.The combat encounters will seem very familiar to anyone who has played the Assassin's Creed or Witcher games. The flow of combat follows the same attack/dodge/counter system that players will recongize from those titles. The real brilliance of the game comes from the sheer replayability. You're dead, after all, so the Dealer is perfectly content to sit at the table and play cards with you for the rest of eternity, and once you get the hang of the game, you might be, too. Matches take the form of multi-level dungeons, the floorplans of which are laid out face-down on the table, using a mixture of cards chosen by you, and by the Dealer. As you win matches, the dungeons become longer, harder, and more complex, but always different. Winning matches will earn you new cards, which equate to new weapons and armor, stronger powers, and even persistent quest-lines that you can explore or replay over the course of multiple matches. As you become more skilled, though, the Dealer will become increasingly frustrated with your success, and throw even harder obstacles in your way. Despite there being only one fully voiced character in the game, the Dealer's voice acting, model, and animations are rich and full of character, and you may even find yourself reveling in your rivalry as much as he does. Overall, this game is a solidly designed, well-polished, and unique experience that any mortal would be pleased to devote the rest of eternity to.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Hand of Fate in a nutshell could be described as "what if Supergiant Games made a narrative rogue-like". The trouble is, while the rogue-like aspect of the game is both fresh and innovative, the narrative side of things leaves much to be desired. First, the Good; This game is probably the most innovative take on the rogue-like genera I've played in months, if not years. The gist of it is that you create two decks, one of equipment cards and another of encounters, and then the storyteller adds a few more encounters based on what particular scenario you are playing. Resolving encounter cards sometimes rewards you with more encounters, as does clearing the final boss of each scenario. Encounters are quite flavourful and sometimes require lateral thinking to get the best (read: more encounters!) rewards, or a little bit of trial and error over the course of several scenarios can also do the trick. Combat switches to 3D environments based on descriptors found in the triggering encounter, and is fast and simple, being quite reminiscent of the combat gameplay of the Batman Arkham games. To wrap up the good side of things, combat rarely feels “unfair” as it sometimes can feel in rogue-likes, but don't you worry, because this game packs a mean RNG in it's encounter resolution mechanics for when chance is involved. Basically, combat can be mastered but encounters require a generous dose of luck to clear sometimes. Now, the Bad, or rather the Disappointing; The narrator. Just... The narrator. I said that this game is almost akin to the games made by Supergiant Games, in that the use of a narrator is central to the experience, but while Supergiant have proved over the course of both Bastion and Transistor that they know how to write unobtrusive, clever and dynamic narrators, it's really not the case with Defiant Development's Hand of Fate narrative. The issue is not the voice actor, not at all, but rather the script he reads and the way it's implemented. Expect to hear lines repeat, or play at really dumb junctions (for example, I had no shield and won one as a result of an Encounter, to which the narrator quipped with surprise something to the effect of “Really? Do you think that's the best choice?”. Yes, yes indeed a weak shield is still better than no shield. Difficult to get across but he has tons of these odd responses that just grate.), or just in general have him say stuff that someone might have thought was deep and/or mysterious but comes across more like pretentious drivel. The end result is that I play the game with Voice Volume muted and subtitles on, so I can at least chose to ignore him when he gets particularly grating. Now granted, Supergiant's games are linear and as such little repetition of dialogue was ever a problem, while Hand of Fate runs into the Oblivion-esque “Mudcrabs Topic” issue of procedurally pulling dialogue from a list: sooner or later the list starts repeating, or plays a comment at a dumb point, or is just filled with bad lines. I don't know, this feels like quite a let-down in such a narratively driven game. At least the encounters can more or less stand on their own merit and tell their own story, so his muted absence is no big loss in my book. Conclusion; If you are a rogue-like fan, pick this up, though expect it to not be as challenging or ruthless as you might be accustomed to. If you are a fan of non-linear storytelling and an interesting story, pick it up as well, but if he gets too much just mute him, no big loss. Otherwise, check a video review or two on YouTube for some hands-on analysis. I'm still happy enough to give it a broad Recommend.

You play as a recently-deceased man who has passed onto the afterlife, and is reliving broken memories of his life in the form of a card game, played against a mysterious hooded figure known only as "The Dealer." The game's cards correspond to various memories of the man's life; trials he may have endured, enemies he may have faced, and the items and powers he may have wielded to vanquish his foes. Don't be fooled, though; this is definitely NOT a card game. It is more like a text-based choose-your-own-story adventure game, interspersed with hack-'n-slash combat encounters. The cards you possess on the table manifest themselves as equipment and abilities in the combat portions of the game, which are crucial to being able to take on the enemies you will face.The combat encounters will seem very familiar to anyone who has played the Assassin's Creed or Witcher games. You're dead, after all, so the Dealer is perfectly content to sit at the table and play cards with you for the rest of eternity, and once you get the hang of the game, you might be, too. Matches take the form of multi-level dungeons, the floorplans of which are laid out face-down on the table, using a mixture of cards chosen by you, and by the Dealer. As you win matches, the dungeons become longer, harder, and more complex, but always different. Winning matches will earn you new cards, which equate to new weapons and armor, stronger powers, and even persistent quest-lines that you can explore or replay over the course of multiple matches. As you become more skilled, though, the Dealer will become increasingly frustrated with your success, and throw even harder obstacles in your way. Despite there being only one fully voiced character in the game, the Dealer's voice acting, model, and animations are rich and full of character, and you may even find yourself reveling in your rivalry as much as he does. Overall, this game is a solidly designed, well-polished, and unique experience that any mortal would be pleased to devote the rest of eternity to.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This game is pretty fun.  The main "story" starts off easy enough, and with the new difficulty cards, you can tailor the challenge to your own desire.  At the end, it gets incredibly challenging, requiring careful planning and an understanding of the game to actually beat.  The endless mode is also very fun, and there's a lot of new cards to unlock by following their unlock paths.  The only main problem is that the combat, while fun, can get rather repetitive.  The Batman style combat isn't bad, however, but with it dictating all of the combat encounters, a little more variety would breathe more life into the game and allow players to experiement more and increase diversification in playstyle.  Still a very fun game, and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys this sort of genre.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												"You play the hand you are dealt"A brilliantly creative indie game where you play against a card dealer fighting through encounters with equipment all in the form of cards. The game mechanics themselves are simple but solid but serve mainly as a vessle for its better elements, the lore and style. The thermatics of this game are expertly managed, often with slippets of lore being dropped by your nemisis the superbly voiced and acted "dealer", an enigmatic and charismatic foe. One of the problems worth mentioning is that the random elements can sometimes kill a player too easily especially at the early levels (where a large enemy type in a small stage often means certain demise). But as a whole the games merits far outweigh its faults.

content:

Early Access Review
								I want to make a couple things clear before you continue with this review. I am very hard to keep entertained, and I am very picky about games. That being said, even in it's Beta stage Hand of Fate is one of the best games I have ever played. It mixes together all the fun of a tabletop game, with the enjoyment of an RPG, and sprinkles in some humor. This game is a treasure for anyone looking for a new IP to get behind. I can only hope that it has a long life with many more installments in teh future to come.From customizing your own adventure deck (and watching those choices come back to bite you), even up to getting to pick what weapons and armor are waiting for you. You have a huge hand to play in your fate, becareful what you wish for, because it may be the one thing that kills you.
