content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												TL;DR: Good Idea. Very Mediocre execution. Get it when it is highly reduced (66% and higher). Not worth the full price.__________Pros:Good, very immersive narration.Compelling gameplay design, despite the terrible combat.High replayability value.Very stable, crashes are very rare.Very accessible, it is easy to get in and start playing, no hour long tutorials.Good saving system. The game saves your progress very frequently, so even if you crash at some point (which is very rare), you can still restart the game and continue playing pretty much off where you left.__________Cons/Issues:The Combat System is pretty terrible and boring, pretty default button mashing with some QTE and hammering of space button to dodge. Camera viewport is also locked in position that follows the player.UI and the interaction with it is flat out terrible.Sometimes you get the entire board revealed to you, but you can't zoom in onto the board to see which cards are which so the revealing was entirely pointless because you can't see anything.The cursor for menu selections sticks to the screen stupidly when playing with the mouse, making you pick choices you didn't want and you get royaly f**ked. Pretty terrible.Alot of game mechanics are not explained to you, like if you uncover an event that requires you to have a better weapon, can you return to that event if you get one? Nobody knows,♥♥♥♥♥♥isn't explained.The game itself is poorly optimized on the visual side, with frequent framedrops which shouldn't be happening. The game is just not worth it at full price.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												A very unique D&D inspired mix of card, tabletop and ARPG game. A fun way to spent a few minutes a day. Perfect if you don't want to commit to a full scale story RPG, but look for more than a short time filler.The ability to more or less design your own adventure adds a really nice touch.However - the variety of encounters sometimes feels limited this game could have used more different types of opponents.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Hand of Fate is  a strangely addicting mix of dungeon crawler, rpg and card collecting games. The game plays like a Roguelike with all encounters and items being randomly placed while the combat is reminiscent of simpler RPG games with a plethora of weapons, items and spells to combat your enemies. You can only encounter about 10% of the cards at first while you play to earn more, both increasing your chance at good loot on your next journey AND often making the game harder by adding more special encounters.In short, GOOD:- Combat can be pretty hard at the start, but feels very good to get better at.- Nice variation of monsters, bosses and other enemies. You can't have an RPG without cool enemies!- The Dealer is an interesting character and serves to make the game feel really alive.- Feels great with a 360 controller- Graphics and loading times are pretty good although it doesn't seem very optimised, which could result in framrate loss depending on your computer.- Enough originality to make you want to unlock more and more cards to see what more the game has to offer.- Addictive and can be played in short bursts AND long runs depending on how you like to play.- The studio guarantees more content for this game, so that means lot's of more stuff to explore in the future.NOT SO GOOD:- You miss half your combat moves at the start of the game, you can't even block. It feels good to unlock more stuff, but I remember really hating the first part of the game where I could only dodge all the time. This can make you put the game down before you even really start.- As it's basically a Dungeon Crawler the randomness factor can really mess you up sometimes. I guarantee you that you will have a run going great only to be ruined by an encounter card you couldn't possibly beat with your current equipment/health/whatever.- The Succes-Failure card system. On MANY encounters you're supposed to watch how he shuffles to choose the correct card, but it's basically impossible 80% of the time either because of shuffle speed is way too fast or because all the cards are layered over each other in a way you can't follow them. Feel a little too unfair.- Story mode might just be a bit too unfair, with luck kinda winning the game for you. Don't expect to kill the King of Scales without any stunning weapons. If the game doesn't give you any even after succesfully completing all encounters, then you're simply boned and ahve to start all over again.- No in-depth options to try and optimise some of the graphic problems this game has.Randomness aside the game actually has a pretty intruiging overarching story and the Dealer is a well-acted, expressive and likable character that gives the game most of it's tone. All in all I'm quite happy about my purchase. I'm sincerely hoping for some more content in the future which could hopefully also fix some of the more broken problems with the game.NEVERMIND DISREGARD ALL THAT YOU JUST GOT A +40 CURSE CARD INSTADIE ENJOY THE GAME.^^ the reason why I quit playing ^^

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Clever game. Highly suggest acquiring and playing it.It's difficult to describe -- you follow the game as if you'd be playing a tabletop RPG using cards for encounters, while the fights are classic 3rd person view battles in 3D. It includes inventory management (scaling your character) and resource management (health, food, gold). There some cards which represent skill check - pick one of four face-down cards to see the outcome (success or fail) -- it may appear like luck, but you can actually trace the cards while they are being shuffled.Also manages to do a decent amount of story telling in this odd format.9/10 would draw again

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20
												I got this with the Humble Freedom Bundle. I started off really enjoying this game, and was digging the deck building aspect, with the combat system as a nice bonus. However, the longer the game went on the less I was enjoying it. I played the King of Skulls level, 75% of the way through the game, about a dozen times before I just gave up in frustration.The roguelike elements of the game are just not balanced correctly for the difficulty and RNG, and I found myself trapped in a loop where I needed to draw better weapon & equipment cards to be able to reliably beat the random combat encounters, but instead drawing encounters that would either inevitably kill me or were designed in such a way (hello White Minotaur, you miserably stupid pile of dung) that getting through them was a total slog.In particular, I had multiple encounters where I drew two bosses from earlier levels, which with the starting gear were basically unkillable when paired with a dozen mooks. The ranged attacks in particular start to happen so often that you can't block or counter all attacks, ensuring you will (eventually) take so much damage the level becomes unbeatable.When coupled with the fact that the game insists on showing you every card flipping animation, store loading animation and level setup animation, I just couldn't take it anymore.Also, the RNG is just a royal, unfun pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Theoretically you can follow the cards when there is a single shuffle, but on multiple shuffles it just isn't possible (regardless of what smart alecks on the Interwebs claim) and it would be kinder to just tell me if I pass a 25% chance instead of forcing the player to pointlessly scroll across cards, pretending that it matters.So while there are some really interesting ideas in Hand of Fate and it starts promising, and the voice acting and art remain fantastic throughout, it ultimately is a very poor set of cards the game deals you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								First I must say i didn't finish the game yet, i'm about half way into the game, with this said i think it's a great game so far, with a great idea, the queen of dust needs serious nerfing in close quarters she's impossible to deal with, you have to dodge her attcks and run around constantly just to avoid the balista, just so you can land one attack and start the dance again, i feel the cards are a little unbalanced still, its more easy to lose then to win, or you gain only one piece of equipment but lose 50 hp in the process, i understand that luck plays a big part in the game, but i feel there is more bad luck then good at the moment, the Angry mob card seems to be bugged still i tried everything but i still cant get the coin, maybe i'm doing something wrong, none the less i like the game so far can't wait for the full realese.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								After I played this game for 10 minutes i was already hooked! This game is so much fun. It's a card game/ dungeon adventure in which your goal is to find and defeat the boss in combat that is kinda like the batman series. you travel through a randomly generated dungeon which is made with your current deck. I've played the same level tons just because every time you play the game it is a different but all the same brilliant experience.The price right now may seem but a bit much but it is WELL worth it. I HIGHLY recommend you buy the game and support the game to help improve it. While the game is still in early access it is already worth the money!

content:
Posted: February 21
												It's one of those games that asked whether it could but not whether it should.The action sections get in the way of the card game and the card game gets in the way of the action. Due to the divided attention both suffer. If you like third person combat get a game that focuses on that. If you like card games choose one that does that well. Mixing slow paced card gameplay and fast paced combat is more annoying than fun. Especially as everything is bogged down by slow animations and repetitive events. They're nice the first couple of times but they soon have you silently screaming "Get on with it!" and "Not this again!".

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												+ Whats great about this game + It's a living card game + It's a RPG+ It's a roguelike game + There are a lot of bosses 19 in total> Queen of scales> Jack of dust> King of skulls > king of dust> lava Golem> hell wolf> minotareus> Queen of dust> Lord of skulls> Queen of plague> kraken > King of skulls> King of scales> Queen of scales> Dealer> King of plague> jack of Skulls> Gobling king> Jack of plague + There are a lot of enemie types> Golem> ratman> bandits> Goblins> Lizardman> Dark wizards > Undead> Hellbeast+ It's  replayable+ A fantastic atmosphere+ There are a lot of weapons + It's a great game to play with a controller + It has a fantastic storyteller with a great voice+ It has a great combat system (it plays like batman) + It's a gamble game+ It has a endless mode+ Shields are OP+ Most of the time the levels are BIG+ It's a great indie game + It has almost only free DLC+ You can make your one deck+ it has a great quest system and you even get more Quest cards every time you have done a quest+ The end battle is great + It's a third person game + You have a level 1 and 2 and 3 enmies + bosses can appear out of nowhere+ enemies come in packs of 6 or lower + It has a cartoon feeling+ The combat playes like the arkhame games there combat but a little bit worse than the arhame games- What's not that great about this game - There is not a lot of custom session (you can only chang your head wear)- It's the easy you need to play it on hard to get a challenge- You always play the same guy- Bosses only have one special ability- It's a short game you can complete it within a day- Attacks from enemies are so slow you almost don't need to block there attacks- You only die from starvation or a boss or a trap or something else - Hellbeast look like rats on fire - There is a big plot hole the dealer doesn't let you die - You can get stuck behind a object really easy = 9/10 I never stop =Conclusion buy the game when it's 10/15 euro or lower=For who is this game It's for  Indie gamers that like roguelike games and like the arkhame comat style fighting

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												This game has massive potential but unfortunately didn't reach it.Card gameplay, concept, rogue-like / RNG additions, story telling, voice acting are very cool. Graphics are super crystal clear, sharp, well designed.However backbone of the game is fighting sequences and they are very bad, mazes are bad, fighting is super weak. So you collect items, money and loot to fight but when it comes to fight, it's boring unresponsive, animations are badly done. It's almost like they had this great idea but they couldn't execute it. They wanted to make fighting batman-esque but they failed in many levels. Animations, responsiveness, complexity, fun.... they all fail miserably short on fighting.If they change the fighting this would be one of the best games of recent years. With the current fighting I cannot really care whether I had a good upgrade, skill etc. Even a turn based simpler fighting would have make the game much better because then loot you collect to fight would matter, rather than dodge, dodge and spam (X) button.Hpoefully they'll make a HoF 2 and it'll have proper fighting gameplay that the player would care about.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												I got attached to Hand of Fate pretty quick.  It's a real fun role-play card game.  Basically you're sitting across the table of a card dealer or dungeon master, however you see it.  He deals you cards and that determines what enemies you fight, where you fight and items you get.  You also gain loot by chance by flipping cards or winning fights.  Sometimes there's a character on a card and you can select answers when they speak.  Unlike other card games, when the level and enemies have been drawn you're character is warped into that world and you really fight them!  I've found that the controls are just like the Batman Arkham series when using Xbox controller.  The game is fun right from the start and easy to figure out.ProsCard game and battle adventure gameEasy to learnGame outcome depends on cards drawn and player choiceGraphicsControlsConsPretty difficult at the end.  Most of the game plays easy but the ending can be unfair.Lack of game info.  While the game is easy to learn I wish it had an info page to give a breakdown on what everything does to serve as a reminder.  Like what cards do what, the rules on food, buying and selling, etc.  You just have to pick up on it as you play.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												**Note for Mac owners:- the OS X version performs noticeably worse than the Windows version on the same machine. Recommend you Boot Camp this.- I'm personally having problems with the controller support on OS X. They're looking into itOne of the most interesting RPGs I've played in recent years. Using cards to represent everything from encounters, monsters to equipment and stats, you start off with a limited deck but earn more cards as you beat major encounters, and can essentially customise the deck to stack encounters/drops in your favour or limit yourself for a more challenging game.As someone who is tired of the whole roguelike trend that's swept indie games recently, Hand of Fate is surprisingly fresh and isn't difficult for difficulty's sake. There's just the right balance of randomness with a consistent, well-written RPG experience, and superb narration (probably my favourite narrator since Bastion) and attention to detail to back it up.Very happy to see it out of Early Access. I had to stop myself from playing too much prior to launch!

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												Sadly, while this is a good game, it's not worth $25. Blah blah blah... it's like a good D&D game, but the controls are utterly atrocious. The camera seems determined to stay in the wrong place, you have very little control over your attacks other than when you attack: always. You're always spamming your auto-aim blocks and slashes and hoping they hit what you want them to and not kill you. However, this IS the only thing wrong with it... I don't think they'll overhaul it by this point, but you never know. I guarantee the negative reviews will disappear if the combat is fixed.

												+ Whats great about this game + It's a living card game + It's a RPG+ It's a roguelike game + There are a lot of bosses 19 in total> Queen of scales> Jack of dust> King of skulls > king of dust> lava Golem> hell wolf> minotareus> Queen of dust> Lord of skulls> Queen of plague> kraken > King of skulls> King of scales> Queen of scales> Dealer> King of plague> jack of Skulls> Gobling king> Jack of plague + There are a lot of enemie types> Golem> ratman> bandits> Goblins> Lizardman> Dark wizards > Undead> Hellbeast+ It's  replayable+ A fantastic atmosphere+ There are a lot of weapons + It's a great game to play with a controller + It has a fantastic storyteller with a great voice+ It has a great combat system (it plays like batman) + It's a gamble game+ It has a endless mode+ Shields are OP+ Most of the time the levels are BIG+ It's a great indie game + It has almost only free DLC+ You can make your one deck+ it has a great quest system and you even get more Quest cards every time you have done a quest+ The end battle is great + It's a third person game + You have a level 1 and 2 and 3 enmies + bosses can appear out of nowhere+ enemies come in packs of 6 or lower + It has a cartoon feeling+ The combat playes like the arkhame games there combat but a little bit worse than the arhame games- What's not that great about this game - There is not a lot of custom session (you can only chang your head wear)- It's the easy you need to play it on hard to get a challenge- You always play the same guy- Bosses only have one special ability- It's a short game you can complete it within a day- Attacks from enemies are so slow you almost don't need to block there attacks- You only die from starvation or a boss or a trap or something else - Hellbeast look like rats on fire - There is a big plot hole the dealer doesn't let you die - You can get stuck behind a object really easy = 9/10 I never stop =Conclusion buy the game when it's 10/15 euro or lower=For who is this game It's for  Indie gamers that like roguelike games and like the arkhame comat style fighting

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
 Do you want to make your own dungeon? And then complete it? And then fail because you were meant to complete it this time? Well then ... welcome to the RNG heaven and hell Hand of Fate is a mix of roguelike, dungeon-crawler and deckbuilding game. While you play, the dealer will narrate what is happening on the board and you will obey while you fight your way to the dealer. GAMEPLAY  The gameplay in Hand of Fate can be separated in several categories starting with the Deckbuilding ,Card unlocking, "Dungeons" , Items, Encounters/Enemies and Combat. Let's get it started.  Deckbuilding Deckbuilding is the neatest of the features I liked in the game because as said it let you make your own Dungeon. While in Endless Mode you dont have deckbuilding because you use all unlocked cards , in Story you have to build your deck, matching the required number of cards for Encounters and Equipment. While you have complete freedom in your Equipment deck, in the Encounters one you will  see locked cards ( one of them is the end boss of the dungeon). Some of the locked cards can be removed by completing them but often leads to new locked cards. Card Unlocking Cards are being unlocked by receiving card tokens. And you receive card tokens when you complete an encounter for first time. And you harvest the rewards at the end of the dungeon ... or after you die( its cool that you arent being punished for dying since a lot of card unlocks can end up terribly for you) . Different cards got different requirments to be completed and gest the best of RNG doesnt mean you will get the token. Once you get to the part where token breaks to reveal cards you will be welcomed with a neat animation. From the token you can get new equipment, encounter cards or gain cards. There are several "quest" chains that are worth doing. The newly obtained cards contain no information until you encounter them in-game so you can only guess what may happen. Dungeons Once your deck is ready  the party starts. Dealer will setup the board with separating the different decks in piles and then he starts drawing encounter cards to form dungeon levels. Once everything is setuped you start hoping from card to card till you reach the end... your end or dungeon's end. During story every dungeon comes up with bonus ... curses which will improve your game experience(or make you rage) . Every dungeon in story mode ends up with a boss fight(if you find it before you die) that will unlocks new cards, including the next level. At the end you will unlock new cards(hopefully) and will be able to increase your deck variety. While in the dungeon you have to take care of your supplies: Gold and Food. Food is beiung used on every turn and heals you. Items/Equipment One of your deck is filled with equipment that you can use during your adventures, if you get lucky to find it. You have Weapons,Armored,Gloves,Helmets,Rings, Artifacts(skills) and Blesses/Curses. While you can hoard all the equipments, you can change your active items before fights so you have to be picky and hope for the best. You can have only 1 active item from each category apart from Rings and Blesses/Curses. Encounters can remove any kind of item without blessing/curses(unless its stated otherwise). There are a lot of different items with their own pros and cons. Encounters and Enemies Ah the Encounter Deck, no matter how many good encounters you put in it, there will be always some that will screw everything. There are different kind of Encounters, from straight fights to short text-based adventures. Almost every encounter comes with a lovely RNG that features cards and there are 2 kinds of RNG : Success/failure that are represented with Huge Success,Success,Failure and Huge Failure cards. The amount of cards you can pick is 4 but they depends on the encounter themselves but you always have at least 1 success/failure card and the amount of cards you have to pick from is 4 ; Enemies are also represented by cards . You have the 4 basic enemies Skulls(skeletons), Dust(bandits), Plague(rats) and Scales(Lizardmen) . Each of them got melee and range model which puts the enemy count to 8. While playing you can unlock additional enemies( I got so far Mages, Liches and Lava Golems) which put the enemy count up to 11 . And the Iceing on the cake is the boss cards. Once you beat the boss its being unlocked in the monster deck and with 12 bosses to unlock you put the enemy count up to 23. So enemy variety is quite big for this kind of Game. Combat Last but not least, the Combat. Combat is pretty straightforward. You have Melee attack, Weapon Skill,Artefact Skill, Counter, Stun and Dodge. So you can say that the combat is similiar to Batman or Kingdoms of Amalur but with lower budget. Enemies attack are slowed most of the time so you can react accordingly. If you have shield you can counter melee attacks or reflect projectiles but thats only if the prompt for attack glows green... if its red you better get the f* out of there.  There is a friendlyfire so you can use this to your advantage with good positioning so you can let enemies tank the range attacks. Now.. one thing that I noticed is often so long leaps when you counter enemies at distance or being stuck in animation with no time to react. My main issue with the combat is the camera. You cant rotate it so at times you have no idea what are you gonna face or where exactly the enemy is. Apart from that combat is fine. Story and Narration Story is pretty simple : you are an adventurer who stumbled upon Dealer's home and you are invited for a game but you are free to leave whenever you want. In the said game you have to defeat the Dealer but before that you must defeat his strongest warriors(on every warrior's level you will meet new challenges so GL). Simple yet well presented thanks to the strong Narration. Voice actor did his job superb but there is still something more to be desired from the writing. Still even when Dealer repeats himself is often in the mood of the situation and there are just a view occassions when the line will not be fitting the situation. Difficulty/Fates Now this is more about the DLC "Wildcards" . Fates lets you change your playstyle. In base game you have 3 fates that serve as Easy/Normal/Hard difficulty in other games but if you have the DLC you get access to 9 more fates with different stats that affect your playstyle. It's a neat addition but there is still room for improvment. Endless Mode Once you are done with the story, Endless mode seems best option to play it .. but I personally didnt like it since it kills Deckbuilding. In Endless Mode you play with all the unlocked cards you have and on every floor the Dealer gets stronger and stronger. Overall  Its a neat roguelike with forgiving RNG and superb quest design and narration. Its good for short playsession and for people who like to unlock all cards.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												tl;dr: good game, but expensive. 8/10I have to give Hand of Fate credit. The presentation and style, as minimal as it is, is impressive. The game itself offers a unique and potentially engaging experience. The mysterious dealer sets the perfect mood with his appearance and narration. The only problem is HoF is one of those style over substance sorts of games. The flow of the game is entirely determined through cards as they're flipped over, and its this.... hand... that determines your fate. (eh? eh? that's the pun in the game's title)Most of the time the game itself never goes beyond making a choice based on the card flipped and then selecting a shuffled card to determine if your action is successful or not. This in of itself isn't bad, but if you're looking for an action-y graphically intense RPG experience with deep lore, you won't find it here.Infrequently, there are action-y bits. Usually in the form of a fight. Sometimes as an obstacle course. They're good place holders and don't do anything particularly wrong, but the AI is typically predictable and easy to overcome if you're a well seasoned gamer even on the harder mode. The action areas are also cramped looking and claustrophobic feeling.Playing off its card based mechanics, the more you play and beat the game, the more and different cards you unlock, and the longer the new games you start become. Longer games translate into higher difficulty. This is one of those games where moves are a resource represented as food. Running out of food typically means you lose HP until you die and starving is typically how you fail in Hand of Fate.Hand of Fate does come together very well though. It works as a game and, most importantly, is enjoyable and fun. The only major complaint I have is there isn't enough content or variety to justify the $25 price IMHO.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I didn't really expect much when I bought this, but it looked intruiging so I gave it a try. And I'm happy I did so, because this game is pretty great. It's not easy to describe. You play cards like in a mixture of a collectible card game and a board game, but it has also RPG-mechanics, a little bit of story, quests, descisions and an action based combat system. At first I thought that the latter was a bit too simple but I gotta admit - it's a lot of fun. Very fast paced, reaction based and dependent on what cards you already got, concerning equipment and abilities. And then there's the dealer of course. And this guy .. he really doesn't want you to win. It's great how he tells you little stories about what's happening and next thing you know, he throws you one of his own cards in your way and all goes to hell. I really, really like this game and I'm looking forward to playing more of it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I first became aware of this game on WFT is Hand of fate. I loved the art style and the Batman like fighting style. Some people dont really care for the Batman style. Basically its one button to punch and one to block one button to stun and one other button to dogdge. I enjoy this because its easy to understand and easy to pick up on and it looks really good for the most part. The game has a deck of cards and you have a piece that you move around the cards. Differents cards have different stuff inside of them.So for instance a card could contain a weapon of some sort after going down a ravine. The game is very well written and the guy who is the dungeon master looks and sounds great. So for fighting its sometimes one card and sometimes its 2 card with enemies. Sometimes its a boss plus more enemies. However fear not because the game gives you power ups.Via armor and weapons. Some have fire and some have stuns. Also you can get poisin for weapons or stuns or sometimes you can get the knife card that flies in 8 different directions. GOod stuff. I really like the graphics of this game even the fight scene are enjoyable. Watching that slow motion final death blow to an enemy always makes me smile. Even more so if its a boss that  I kill.You can also re arrange the deck or have the computer do it for you. If your wondering how to change the gameplay like I was. Go into the deck building part and click on the middle card and here you can select different cards that can change the game rules its also comes in handy for the dlc. I am playing the monk card right now.So graphics are very sharp looking, sounds are good. My complaints about the game are few. Sometimes you can get a lousy hand and either die because of bad drops or no food. I am halfway done with the game so it seems like it might be a tad short. Maybe around 12 or 15 hours long? Perhaps less it does have an endless mode.Some on the forum have complained of the game being too dark after they switched to the newer unity engine. I have not had this issue and they did roll back the changes but some are still having issues. The fix right now is windowed mode.My only other nit pick is sometimes the traps are a real pain. You fight in rooms and some are small and some are big and loaded with traps. It does hurt the bad guys as well however. So thats fair. I am having a good time with the game and I really enjoy it. One more thing the developers seem to be very active on the forums and seem to care so thats a very good thing.A fun and unique game. Most games  last around 10minutes up to 20 minutes or perhaps a little longer. Not super long. Buy it and you can thank me later.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												This game is a lot of whimsical, fantasy-based fun that makes my inner board-game junkie happy.The concept of Hand of Fate is awesome on paper, and even cooler when put to work! It's really challenging, it makes you use your brain, it's addicting, and it's just a cool idea!Once you start off, you get the basic set of cards. And as you use those cards and advance through each level, you unlock more cards. Not only does this make you want to keep playing with the mindset of "Oh man, I gotta use this new card I just got!" - But it also allows you to unlock better cards you can use to overcome that challenges that come with the harder levels, in a FUN WAY. I'd like to stress that as much as I can - This game takes elements that make other games not fun, and turns it into something that is incredibly fun, in a way that puts other games to shame.I would reccomend, however, using a Gamepad controller for this game. When I played this game on Keyboard + Mouse I found it really confusing and complicated, and didn't have that much fun overall. Once I started using a controller (Steam Controller to be precise) it got a lot better. I wasn't fighting the controls anymore, I didn't have to keep asking myself "Uhhh, does this button do anything or not? I can't remember..." and it was a much more relaxing time for me.Also, me and my brother made up a little alternate gamemode where there are two people playing. One person picks the character, the deck, and the level for the other person to play through. So if you've got any friends or family around who wanna play games, there's an option for ya. :P

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												A great game! Very well thought of game with a mixture of cards and action. This game has good narrative storyline, very polished gameplay, good bgm and sound effects. The game can also be quickly entertaining without having to spend alot of hours into it. It is easy to learn and pickup even with the lack of a subtle tutorial.In general this game allows you finish something like a quest given to you, and you gain a card token. After the end of each session, you open the card tokens revealing new adventures, new equipments that can be added into ur encounter deck, equipment deck and etc. This game is very well thought of because it uses a card interaction of allowing players to create their own encounters with a mixture of the dealers encounter cards. Very interactive gameplay. Players are required to do some sort of resource management from obtaining food resources, consuming food as each step taken requires you to consume one food resource. Sometimes you might think you will not gain anymore food, prompting you to quickly move on to the next level. One downside to this game is that by the time you are 80% completing this game. You realize that there are no new monsters and the background setting are always the same. But it's not a problem because the developers can choose to release new DLC's that feature new monsters and bosses in the near future.Overall, this is a great game that any gamer should add into their collection.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
TL:DR--------------------------------Get this game, it's great and unique.Full Review--------------------------------I played a lot of this game on GOG before eventually grabbing it on the Steam sale, and every penny is worth it. The basic premise of the game is that you build a deck of cards that are used to sudo-randomly determine the course of your game, and using these cards you must defeat the Dealer's face cards. (Jacks, Queens, and Kings)There is a HUGE amount of content in the game, and the developers still seem to be adding updates. You can get new weapons and armor and encounters that can be drawn during play to give you an advantage and help you defeat the Dealer's minions.It is highly recommended that you get the Wildcards DLC, as this adds many new options for crafting a new style of play through the course of the game. Well worth the $5.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												The game's not bad, but maybe not for full price. For 5$ - definitely worth it, for 10$ - worth it if you're into roguelike games.18 hours was enough to finish story mode and endless mode to wave 30 (on medium difficulty), and it doesn't feel like there is much replayability beyond this unless you're really into getting all the achievements.Combat is way more responsive than i thought it would be, so that's a plus. The type of battle is about on shadow of mordor/batman level (more simplified of course, but similar idea with hits/counters/finishes). Game has controller support too, which can make battle better/easier.Luck is a huge factor. Yes, you can get really bad runs with horrible loot and overpowered monsters, but you can also get great runs where everything goes super smooth. Skill also counts, if you're really good - you do have a chance of defeating toughest enemies with starting equipment, you just gotta pay attention and fight hard!

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Excellent game with an incredibly interesting concept, and solid execution. Cards become your gear, encounters, everything, and many of them have tokens. By succeeding at that card's encounter, you get the token, which create new cards for future games. I'm playing the Story mode, and it's fantastic. I've progressively unlocked a bunch of different new stories that I'm encountering in future games.You choose your equipment and some of the encounter cards to build each match, and then the story setup you've selected adds cards. It's clever and works well.Most cards are choices rather than combat, with semi-random success, others are static choices that you can learn and rely on in future games. This creates a great mix of surprise and predictability.Combat is fairly basic but engaging - not the highlight of the game, but it doesn't hurt it either.Story mode (Guessing 6-8 hours playtime), endless-play mode, and then modifiers that change the way some things work.

Posted: December 14, 2015
												Decided to buy the game after I read a ton of reviews.  Most talked about how easy the game was etc, etc.  For the first 75% is it not difficult at all. Some of the tokens require some luck of the draw to get but everything is definitely doable.The only difficult fight I found was the boss at the end but if you get a good trip to him with the right abilities you can beat him.  The heal is really needed.  However, it is pretty easy if you get the damage increase per curse as you have a lot of curses when you get there.  That makes him much easier.After reading reviews I was skeptical, but it was fun.  The graphcis are nothing to write home to mom about, but the play through was enjoyable.  I do not think I will play through it again, but I did enjoy it.If you catch this on sale, it is really worth a play through.  If you are looking for hack and slash or building up a character to just go one shot everything, this is not the game for you.  If you like a little strategy, luck of the dice, and some chance involved, this will keep you interested.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												It's  a rare occurence for an experimental game with mixed genres to succeed, but this game nailed it. Imagine a combination of Yugioh and Batman Arkham Series. Now mix them with unforgiving nature of roguelike genre, then you get this game. The battle is fun, thank to Arkham series rhytmic fight style. The amount of card combination you can use in your deck won't bore you for quite a long time. But I think this game need a little rebalance, especially with encounter chance and THAT last battle. Seriously, this game get kinda unfair near the end game. You need both LUCK and SKILL to succeed. Sometimes this game is harder then Darksouls, depends on the mood of the Dealer to wether give you that nice blesses or 5 curses in a row with lower max health cards involved.Rebalance issue aside, this game is one of kind and quite a masterpiece at that. If you enjoy Arkham fight style, randomized dungeon, and experimental idea, buy this game. You won't be disappointedOh, and The Dealer's voice is awesome

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												A narritively driven rougelike with turn based exploration and batman arkham style combat. Take risks and cheat lady luck as you go on an adventure that has an oddly new and yet familiar aspect to it. Are these new memories or perhaps old ones retreaded? Are they even your memories at all?Then, when your luck goes sour all combat takes place in real time using the simple arkham system. Loads of encounters, enemies and equipment. Equipment effects your stats and gives you passive bonuses while you can get activatable weapon skills and artefacts. Cureses and Blessings also effect gameplay in the combat and in the adventure. Plus, its got cards and deckbuilding elements too!Buy it full price, buy it on sale, buy the DLC, its all worth it. I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Hands down, one of the finest examples of an indie developed game around. A perfect blend of rogue-lite randomization, addictive card collecting, and a sprinkle of 3rd person combat made for a throughly enjoyable experience. But good gameplay isn't the only factor for my love of this game. The the icing on the cake for me was the absolutely stellar development team. Regular updates/bug fixes, open feedback discussions, and a pile of free DLC made me adore the game even more. Hand of Fate II can't come soon enough.Bottom line: Great game; even greater developer. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Decided to buy the game after I read a ton of reviews.  Most talked about how easy the game was etc, etc.  For the first 75% is it not difficult at all. Some of the tokens require some luck of the draw to get but everything is definitely doable.The only difficult fight I found was the boss at the end but if you get a good trip to him with the right abilities you can beat him.  The heal is really needed.  However, it is pretty easy if you get the damage increase per curse as you have a lot of curses when you get there.  That makes him much easier.After reading reviews I was skeptical, but it was fun.  The graphcis are nothing to write home to mom about, but the play through was enjoyable.  I do not think I will play through it again, but I did enjoy it.If you catch this on sale, it is really worth a play through.  If you are looking for hack and slash or building up a character to just go one shot everything, this is not the game for you.  If you like a little strategy, luck of the dice, and some chance involved, this will keep you interested.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												It's  a rare occurence for an experimental game with mixed genres to succeed, but this game nailed it. Imagine a combination of Yugioh and Batman Arkham Series. Now mix them with unforgiving nature of roguelike genre, then you get this game. The battle is fun, thank to Arkham series rhytmic fight style. The amount of card combination you can use in your deck won't bore you for quite a long time. But I think this game need a little rebalance, especially with encounter chance and THAT last battle. Seriously, this game get kinda unfair near the end game. You need both LUCK and SKILL to succeed. Sometimes this game is harder then Darksouls, depends on the mood of the Dealer to wether give you that nice blesses or 5 curses in a row with lower max health cards involved.Rebalance issue aside, this game is one of kind and quite a masterpiece at that. If you enjoy Arkham fight style, randomized dungeon, and experimental idea, buy this game. You won't be disappointedOh, and The Dealer's voice is awesome

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												A narritively driven rougelike with turn based exploration and batman arkham style combat. Take risks and cheat lady luck as you go on an adventure that has an oddly new and yet familiar aspect to it. Are these new memories or perhaps old ones retreaded? Are they even your memories at all?Then, when your luck goes sour all combat takes place in real time using the simple arkham system. Loads of encounters, enemies and equipment. Equipment effects your stats and gives you passive bonuses while you can get activatable weapon skills and artefacts. Cureses and Blessings also effect gameplay in the combat and in the adventure. Plus, its got cards and deckbuilding elements too!Buy it full price, buy it on sale, buy the DLC, its all worth it. I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.

												It's like Dungeons & Dragons, a card game, and an action adventure RPG had a baby.The actual weapon combat is quite easy, even on hard mode, but it's really fun, although RNG card rolls can completely screw you over sometimes which makes it frustrating, but can make it more challenging which is nice.Love the interface and it's really straight forward to understand. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This is a strange little game.  It incorporates elements of cards games, rpg games, and action style games and tries to wield them all together.  It shouldn't work, but somehow it does, creating something refreshingly different.The core of the games main story mode is that you pick a boss to go after (although you must beat each to go on to the next one) the assemble a deck of story cards and one of equipment.  The story cards are then mixed together with new cards by the mysterious Dealer and laid out to form a map.  As you move your character onto a story card, it flips over, usually resulting in a choose your own adventure style encounter, although there are also straight up combats and stores to discover.  Any equipment you find is usually drawn from your equipment deck, so what cards you put in that can be important as are what encounters you added into the mix. Some encounter cards come with tokens you can earn by achieving something during the encounter.WIn or lose, once your run is over, any tokens you've earned unlock new eqiupment and encounter cards.  It is no coincidence that some of the most useful cards are rewards for some of the most risky encounters, so going safe is not always good for the long run.Combat is handled with a battle system nearly identical to the Batman Arkham games.  If you enjoyed that system, you'll like this one.All in all a very unique game that is easy to pick up for a quick 30 minute run.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												This game is super AWESOME and fun! And it gets increasingly better value for money as time goes on! How is that even possible? you may ask: well this already fleshed out fully immersive game, keeps having more content added into it every month or so: I stopped playing for a couple months, come back and start playing, die in a dungeon yet again and am rewarded by unlocking 2 new DLC that got added without my knowing, Fantastic!The narrator/dealer of the game makes it such an awesomly immersive experiance, each step has a chance to get further dialogue.GAMEPLAY:Before statring a run;You have 2 decks of cards you can change up with your unlocked cards: 1st your equipment, 2nd your exploration/encounters. The dealer adds further encounter cards based on the level, of which there are 12.3rd deck option if you paid for it (which is a must, so worth, so good): is picking a class/difficulty for you character, that can affect combat and exploration, including unlocking more encounter cards.Each run attempt you can select different things for those 3 options, and each attempt will unlock more cards for your main 2 mentioned decks.3 resorces that needs various degrees of management and affect you are; HEALTH, FOOD, GOLD.Exploration:the cards are aranged face down in a path, you move 1 card at a time, flippping it over and selecting options to get through it. could be a fight, merchant, chance, or choice based options.The results can be anything from many of these cards, most of them have a chance to unlock further cards for future attempts, if you select correctly/choose well. Through these is the main way of drawing from your equipment deck and affecting your 3 resorces.The whole time the dealer has awesome dialogue based on the cards and your options as well as banter, this makes the atmospher of the game awesome.Combat:Is fairly simple but fun and can be heavily affected by equpitment, blessings and curses you have got hold of during that run. You have attack, combo damage, block,counter, stun, dodge roll, weapon ability, artifact ability.This from an overall perspective is a very unique and fun game, plenty of loot and replayablity, and you gain more options even on failing a run, so your time never feels completely wasted.VERDICT:There's nothing about the game I dislike or feel is badly done, so a full recommendation from me :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Hand of Fate is a card game.Hand of Fate is an action adventure.Hand of Fate is a board game.All of the above is true and executed remarkably well for a small unknown studio. The trinity of those three games might appear to suggest that Hand of Fate is a casual game. It is not. Actually it is quite hardcore on the higher difficulty levels, which one will need to play at to unlock all cards and events. Don't deprive yourself of 80% of the game by just playing it on easy. It's not just more difficult, the game plays very differently with different "decks".The only reason I would not recommend Hand of Fate is because of the RIDICULOUSLY difficult Kraken encounter which has soiled about 95% of my endless mode runs. **** you Kraken. 11/10 would get smashed by tentacles, stabbed by lizard men, eletrocuted, set on fire or chomped on by a Kraken all in one single encounter at the same time again.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												For those of you who would rather watch my video review, here ya go: 


YouTube™ Video: Hand of Fate Review 

			Views: 24		

			Link to the Hand of Fate steam page: http://store.steampowered.com/app/266510/ Please tell me what you thought about this game! If you have any feedback for me please let me know! Thanks for watching!		

What this game did well was make a very replayable game with an interesting story that makes you want to keep replaying it. It does this through the side stories in the game. For a lot of cards, when you land on them they will give you a side quest that you can complete. If you do complete it then it will unlock another card that keeps driving this side story into multiple play throughs. This really helps in making the game not stagnate the more you play it, because it is constantly adding new cards for you to interact with and furthering the stories at the same time. On the subject of RNG, this game is not always fair because a lot of it comes down to RNG. Most of the time you can handle what the game throws at you, but sometimes you will have a game where literally nothing goes your way. If you do not enjoy games that have RNG elements like this, then you will probably not enjoy this game. However, I feel like for the most part the RNG is not that bad. The main problem that this game has is the combat. The combat is fairly simplistic, where you mainly just dodge and counter enemy attacks, similar to the Batman Arkham games, but less polished. Something about the combat just isn’t very satisfying. The enemies usually take a good bit of hits before they go down and when they do go down they don’t really have any kind of death animation, they just go full ragdoll which isn’t very gratify. But, this game is still very enjoyable to play and I recommend checking it out.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Hand of Fate is perfect for fans of card games, deck-building, and role-playing games.   Questlines are randomly generated from a mix of cards owned by both you and the dealer.  Playing through the game rewards you with more cards to add into your decks.  While in a quest, you need to manage your health, money, and food.  You will encounter enemies, allies, and obstacles in your quests and they're always presented to you with choices similar to FTL: Faster than Light.  There's also an element of chance that goes along with your decisions.  An example could be that you're walking along a cliff, and you see a sword at the bottom among some bones.  Do you go on your way or try and climb down? If you try to climb down, you then have to watch four cards, with varying degrees of success or failure on them, be shuffled on-screen.  You pick your card and either get injured on your climb down, or succeed and get the sword (which you can then use in combat).  Combat encounters throw you into a room with enemies and the game turns into a simple version of the Arkham Batman games. The fighting is very similar with it's use of blocking, countering, and combos.As of the writing of this review, the game is currently 50% off! It's still worth the purchase at full-price though.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												This game is a lot of whimsical, fantasy-based fun that makes my inner board-game junkie happy.The concept of Hand of Fate is awesome on paper, and even cooler when put to work! It's really challenging, it makes you use your brain, it's addicting, and it's just a cool idea!Once you start off, you get the basic set of cards. And as you use those cards and advance through each level, you unlock more cards. Not only does this make you want to keep playing with the mindset of "Oh man, I gotta use this new card I just got!" - But it also allows you to unlock better cards you can use to overcome that challenges that come with the harder levels, in a FUN WAY. I'd like to stress that as much as I can - This game takes elements that make other games not fun, and turns it into something that is incredibly fun, in a way that puts other games to shame.I would reccomend, however, using a Gamepad controller for this game. When I played this game on Keyboard + Mouse I found it really confusing and complicated, and didn't have that much fun overall. Once I started using a controller (Steam Controller to be precise) it got a lot better. I wasn't fighting the controls anymore, I didn't have to keep asking myself "Uhhh, does this button do anything or not? I can't remember..." and it was a much more relaxing time for me.Also, me and my brother made up a little alternate gamemode where there are two people playing. content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												A great game! Very well thought of game with a mixture of cards and action. This game has good narrative storyline, very polished gameplay, good bgm and sound effects. The game can also be quickly entertaining without having to spend alot of hours into it. It is easy to learn and pickup even with the lack of a subtle tutorial.In general this game allows you finish something like a quest given to you, and you gain a card token. After the end of each session, you open the card tokens revealing new adventures, new equipments that can be added into ur encounter deck, equipment deck and etc. This game is very well thought of because it uses a card interaction of allowing players to create their own encounters with a mixture of the dealers encounter cards. Very interactive gameplay. Players are required to do some sort of resource management from obtaining food resources, consuming food as each step taken requires you to consume one food resource. Sometimes you might think you will not gain anymore food, prompting you to quickly move on to the next level. One downside to this game is that by the time you are 80% completing this game. You realize that there are no new monsters and the background setting are always the same. But it's not a problem because the developers can choose to release new DLC's that feature new monsters and bosses in the near future.Overall, this is a great game that any gamer should add into their collection.

TL:DR--------------------------------Get this game, it's great and unique.Full Review--------------------------------I played a lot of this game on GOG before eventually grabbing it on the Steam sale, and every penny is worth it. The basic premise of the game is that you build a deck of cards that are used to sudo-randomly determine the course of your game, and using these cards you must defeat the Dealer's face cards. (Jacks, Queens, and Kings)There is a HUGE amount of content in the game, and the developers still seem to be adding updates. You can get new weapons and armor and encounters that can be drawn during play to give you an advantage and help you defeat the Dealer's minions.It is highly recommended that you get the Wildcards DLC, as this adds many new options for crafting a new style of play through the course of the game. number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												This game is some kind of wierd amalgation of FTL's rogue-like runs, Batman's free flow combat, D&D's RPG mechanics (and setting... somewhat), as well as a good helping of tarot card and fortune teller theming. The difficulty is fairly easy at first, with the challenge becoming greater as you progress. Those who are at least adequate with the kind of combat described should be able to get right up to the end without too much difficulty, but the last encounter is an absolute nightmare that will take a lot of skill to get past.The game at first is only 16-ish levels long, which can easily take up at least an hour each. The story is very intriquing, delivered mostly through the narration of the dealer, your constant enemy and companion. This, in my opinion, is far more preferable than them just right out telling you everything at the beginning, and the mystic behind the game only fits with the theme of it all. There is also several stories hidden within the cards you will begin to collect as you progress through the game.Initially, I'd say this game is slightly overpriced, with a cost of $20 being more appropriate. However, the developers of the game have started releasing DLC for the game for absolutely nothing, which more than makes this game worth the price. Hand of Fate is a true gem on Steam, with an interesting take on the RPG genre.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												This game is a lot of whimsical, fantasy-based fun that makes my inner board-game junkie happy.The concept of Hand of Fate is awesome on paper, and even cooler when put to work! It's really challenging, it makes you use your brain, it's addicting, and it's just a cool idea!Once you start off, you get the basic set of cards. And as you use those cards and advance through each level, you unlock more cards. Not only does this make you want to keep playing with the mindset of "Oh man, I gotta use this new card I just got!" - But it also allows you to unlock better cards you can use to overcome that challenges that come with the harder levels, in a FUN WAY. I'd like to stress that as much as I can - This game takes elements that make other games not fun, and turns it into something that is incredibly fun, in a way that puts other games to shame.I would reccomend, however, using a Gamepad controller for this game. When I played this game on Keyboard + Mouse I found it really confusing and complicated, and didn't have that much fun overall. Once I started using a controller (Steam Controller to be precise) it got a lot better. I wasn't fighting the controls anymore, I didn't have to keep asking myself "Uhhh, does this button do anything or not? I can't remember..." and it was a much more relaxing time for me.Also, me and my brother made up a little alternate gamemode where there are two people playing. One person picks the character, the deck, and the level for the other person to play through. So if you've got any friends or family around who wanna play games, there's an option for ya. :P

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
 Do you want to make your own dungeon? And then complete it? And then fail because you were meant to complete it this time? Well then ... welcome to the RNG heaven and hell Hand of Fate is a mix of roguelike, dungeon-crawler and deckbuilding game. While you play, the dealer will narrate what is happening on the board and you will obey while you fight your way to the dealer. GAMEPLAY  The gameplay in Hand of Fate can be separated in several categories starting with the Deckbuilding ,Card unlocking, "Dungeons" , Items, Encounters/Enemies and Combat. Let's get it started.  Deckbuilding Deckbuilding is the neatest of the features I liked in the game because as said it let you make your own Dungeon. While in Endless Mode you dont have deckbuilding because you use all unlocked cards , in Story you have to build your deck, matching the required number of cards for Encounters and Equipment. While you have complete freedom in your Equipment deck, in the Encounters one you will  see locked cards ( one of them is the end boss of the dungeon). Some of the locked cards can be removed by completing them but often leads to new locked cards. Card Unlocking Cards are being unlocked by receiving card tokens. And you receive card tokens when you complete an encounter for first time. And you harvest the rewards at the end of the dungeon ... or after you die( its cool that you arent being punished for dying since a lot of card unlocks can end up terribly for you) . Different cards got different requirments to be completed and gest the best of RNG doesnt mean you will get the token. Once you get to the part where token breaks to reveal cards you will be welcomed with a neat animation. From the token you can get new equipment, encounter cards or gain cards. There are several "quest" chains that are worth doing. The newly obtained cards contain no information until you encounter them in-game so you can only guess what may happen. Dungeons Once your deck is ready  the party starts. Dealer will setup the board with separating the different decks in piles and then he starts drawing encounter cards to form dungeon levels. Once everything is setuped you start hoping from card to card till you reach the end... your end or dungeon's end. During story every dungeon comes up with bonus ... curses which will improve your game experience(or make you rage) . Every dungeon in story mode ends up with a boss fight(if you find it before you die) that will unlocks new cards, including the next level. At the end you will unlock new cards(hopefully) and will be able to increase your deck variety. While in the dungeon you have to take care of your supplies: Gold and Food. Food is beiung used on every turn and heals you. Items/Equipment One of your deck is filled with equipment that you can use during your adventures, if you get lucky to find it. You have Weapons,Armored,Gloves,Helmets,Rings, Artifacts(skills) and Blesses/Curses. While you can hoard all the equipments, you can change your active items before fights so you have to be picky and hope for the best. You can have only 1 active item from each category apart from Rings and Blesses/Curses. Encounters can remove any kind of item without blessing/curses(unless its stated otherwise). There are a lot of different items with their own pros and cons. Encounters and Enemies Ah the Encounter Deck, no matter how many good encounters you put in it, there will be always some that will screw everything. There are different kind of Encounters, from straight fights to short text-based adventures. Almost every encounter comes with a lovely RNG that features cards and there are 2 kinds of RNG : Success/failure that are represented with Huge Success,Success,Failure and Huge Failure cards. The amount of cards you can pick is 4 but they depends on the encounter themselves but you always have at least 1 success/failure card and the amount of cards you have to pick from is 4 ; Enemies are also represented by cards . You have the 4 basic enemies Skulls(skeletons), Dust(bandits), Plague(rats) and Scales(Lizardmen) . Each of them got melee and range model which puts the enemy count to 8. While playing you can unlock additional enemies( I got so far Mages, Liches and Lava Golems) which put the enemy count up to 11 . And the Iceing on the cake is the boss cards. Once you beat the boss its being unlocked in the monster deck and with 12 bosses to unlock you put the enemy count up to 23. So enemy variety is quite big for this kind of Game. Combat Last but not least, the Combat. Combat is pretty straightforward. You have Melee attack, Weapon Skill,Artefact Skill, Counter, Stun and Dodge. So you can say that the combat is similiar to Batman or Kingdoms of Amalur but with lower budget. Enemies attack are slowed most of the time so you can react accordingly. If you have shield you can counter melee attacks or reflect projectiles but thats only if the prompt for attack glows green... if its red you better get the f* out of there.  There is a friendlyfire so you can use this to your advantage with good positioning so you can let enemies tank the range attacks. Now.. one thing that I noticed is often so long leaps when you counter enemies at distance or being stuck in animation with no time to react. My main issue with the combat is the camera. You cant rotate it so at times you have no idea what are you gonna face or where exactly the enemy is. Apart from that combat is fine. Story and Narration Story is pretty simple : you are an adventurer who stumbled upon Dealer's home and you are invited for a game but you are free to leave whenever you want. In the said game you have to defeat the Dealer but before that you must defeat his strongest warriors(on every warrior's level you will meet new challenges so GL). Simple yet well presented thanks to the strong Narration. Voice actor did his job superb but there is still something more to be desired from the writing. Still even when Dealer repeats himself is often in the mood of the situation and there are just a view occassions when the line will not be fitting the situation. Difficulty/Fates Now this is more about the DLC "Wildcards" . Fates lets you change your playstyle. In base game you have 3 fates that serve as Easy/Normal/Hard difficulty in other games but if you have the DLC you get access to 9 more fates with different stats that affect your playstyle. It's a neat addition but there is still room for improvment. Endless Mode Once you are done with the story, Endless mode seems best option to play it .. but I personally didnt like it since it kills Deckbuilding. In Endless Mode you play with all the unlocked cards you have and on every floor the Dealer gets stronger and stronger. Overall  Its a neat roguelike with forgiving RNG and superb quest design and narration. Its good for short playsession and for people who like to unlock all cards.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												tl;dr: good game, but expensive. 8/10I have to give Hand of Fate credit. The presentation and style, as minimal as it is, is impressive. The game itself offers a unique and potentially engaging experience. The mysterious dealer sets the perfect mood with his appearance and narration. The only problem is HoF is one of those style over substance sorts of games. The flow of the game is entirely determined through cards as they're flipped over, and its this.... hand... that determines your fate. (eh? eh? that's the pun in the game's title)Most of the time the game itself never goes beyond making a choice based on the card flipped and then selecting a shuffled card to determine if your action is successful or not. This in of itself isn't bad, but if you're looking for an action-y graphically intense RPG experience with deep lore, you won't find it here.Infrequently, there are action-y bits. Usually in the form of a fight. Sometimes as an obstacle course. They're good place holders and don't do anything particularly wrong, but the AI is typically predictable and easy to overcome if you're a well seasoned gamer even on the harder mode. The action areas are also cramped looking and claustrophobic feeling.Playing off its card based mechanics, the more you play and beat the game, the more and different cards you unlock, and the longer the new games you start become. Longer games translate into higher difficulty. This is one of those games where moves are a resource represented as food. Running out of food typically means you lose HP until you die and starving is typically how you fail in Hand of Fate.Hand of Fate does come together very well though. It works as a game and, most importantly, is enjoyable and fun. The only major complaint I have is there isn't enough content or variety to justify the $25 price IMHO.

												I didn't really expect much when I bought this, but it looked intruiging so I gave it a try. And I'm happy I did so, because this game is pretty great. It's not easy to describe. You play cards like in a mixture of a collectible card game and a board game, but it has also RPG-mechanics, a little bit of story, quests, descisions and an action based combat system. At first I thought that the latter was a bit too simple but I gotta admit - it's a lot of fun. Very fast paced, reaction based and dependent on what cards you already got, concerning equipment and abilities. And then there's the dealer of course. And this guy .. he really doesn't want you to win. It's great how he tells you little stories about what's happening and next thing you know, he throws you one of his own cards in your way and all goes to hell. I really, really like this game and I'm looking forward to playing more of it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I first became aware of this game on WFT is Hand of fate. I loved the art style and the Batman like fighting style. Some people dont really care for the Batman style. Basically its one button to punch and one to block one button to stun and one other button to dogdge. I enjoy this because its easy to understand and easy to pick up on and it looks really good for the most part. The game has a deck of cards and you have a piece that you move around the cards. Differents cards have different stuff inside of them.So for instance a card could contain a weapon of some sort after going down a ravine. The game is very well written and the guy who is the dungeon master looks and sounds great. So for fighting its sometimes one card and sometimes its 2 card with enemies. Sometimes its a boss plus more enemies. However fear not because the game gives you power ups.Via armor and weapons. Some have fire and some have stuns. Also you can get poisin for weapons or stuns or sometimes you can get the knife card that flies in 8 different directions. GOod stuff. I really like the graphics of this game even the fight scene are enjoyable. Watching that slow motion final death blow to an enemy always makes me smile. Even more so if its a boss that  I kill.You can also re arrange the deck or have the computer do it for you. If your wondering how to change the gameplay like I was. Go into the deck building part and click on the middle card and here you can select different cards that can change the game rules its also comes in handy for the dlc. I am playing the monk card right now.So graphics are very sharp looking, sounds are good. My complaints about the game are few. Sometimes you can get a lousy hand and either die because of bad drops or no food. I am halfway done with the game so it seems like it might be a tad short. Maybe around 12 or 15 hours long? Perhaps less it does have an endless mode.Some on the forum have complained of the game being too dark after they switched to the newer unity engine. I have not had this issue and they did roll back the changes but some are still having issues. The fix right now is windowed mode.My only other nit pick is sometimes the traps are a real pain. You fight in rooms and some are small and some are big and loaded with traps. It does hurt the bad guys as well however. So thats fair. I am having a good time with the game and I really enjoy it. One more thing the developers seem to be very active on the forums and seem to care so thats a very good thing.A fun and unique game. Most games  last around 10minutes up to 20 minutes or perhaps a little longer. Not super long. Buy it and you can thank me later.

Early Access Review
								Amazing mix of rogue-lite with good old "choose your own adventure" books (here cards). Dressed up in nice visuals and great atmosphere thanks to awesome narrator.-> You build decks from collected cards as a base for your journey and means to enhance your character-> You travel through randomly generated levels (based on the cards you picked) with various events, decisions and encounters-> All battles are resolved via good old hack'n'slash 3rd person action8 hrs of fun to complete the main story and then the Endless Mode awaits. Well worth your money.PROS:+ Unique and interesting gameplay+ Great atmosphere and narration+ Good graphics and varied environments (for encounters)+ Fluent and responsive combat+ Varied enemies and interesting bosses+ Lot of replay valueCONS:- Static camera sometimes sucks- RNGesus may screw you overBONUS PRO: First game ever where I stayed in the main menu on purpose just to watch and enjoy the atmosphere. ^_^

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Early Access Review
Short: Hand of Fate is a weird concept that plays out surprisingly well. Very much unfinished and unpolished as of now, but the core concept is well done and people that enjoy games like FTL will probably get some fun out of this too. Fun, but there are caveats.Long:The Good: The strange genre mix plays out surprisingly well, with the ability to influence your dungeon and the RNG parts by careful considerations. The fighting system is heavily influenced by batmans free flow. The voiceover and presentation is atmospheric and the unlock system itself is telling a story. There are many interesting items and effects that keep runs fresh even after failing coupled with the unlocks.The Bad:The combat is at times clunky, sometimes bordering unfair and the camera can get into weird angles. Some items and effects are poorly balanced and the RNG can really screw you over sometimes. The aesthetics are ok, but it's no AAA title of course. Restarting a run does takes 30 seconds because of the presentation, that should really be skippable (and sometimes the token animation). For some token encounters, you have not the slightest clue how to get them.The Ugly:Terrible optimization (as of now): some rooms and angles can make your framerate dip very significantly but it doesn't offer a proper graphics options menu, only presets. Also, for some reason it is a big memory hog (in excess of 2GB).  I was unable to play the combat with KB+mouse as it didn't register the mouse buttons. Works fine with a controller, but that should work anyway. The key rebinding in the launcher is bad, listing controls for 9 gamepads (wtf?) and binding for attacks on KB+mouse didn't work for me.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hands of Fate is, usurprisingly, the hidden pearl of the new EC Humble Bundle. Hidden behind the $15 dollar paywall, it's most likely the one game people won't bother paying the extra few bucks to check out. Shame on them.The game is, hands down (ba dum tsh), awesome. For those of you living under a rock and that have never any of the Extra Credits reviews of this game (they actually did it twice), lemme summurize it for ya:The game is a cross between card game, Arkham City arena battles, and choose-your-adventure book. Basically you have a table with face-down cards and a character token that moves through those cards. Each card is an Event card, which can range from "You have been ambushed by Goblins who took your stuff" stage, made classic by the Golden Axe games, a maze stage filled with traps, or a plain-text event where you have to use your wits to avoid being on the receiving end of a prostate exam. The It's Toasted of the game is that during combat events the game zooms in and you control your character (with customizable gear!) to fight the hordes of enemies in the aforementioned Arkham City arena battles. It's pretty neat, althought it gets really unfair sometimes as the game has no challenge ballance - if you got dealt a bad hand of cards you're gonna have a bad time. You "improve" (as much as adding harder challenges is an improvement) by acquiring cards after beating the dealer's challenges along stages. So no way this is gonna be monetised in the future. Yey!The game is still in Early Access, as of the time of this review the latest patch marks it as Beta1, so there's a lot of unpolished and unfinished things. The dealer has only a couple few animations and sometimes runs out of voice lines, there's not much variation between enemy models, the menu's navigability is horrible, and every now and again you stumble into attrociously unballanced dificulty spikes, but this is all expected from Early Access titles. I highly recommend the game, even in it's current form. One of the best card game concepts I've seen, reminds me a lot of the old Shadowrun TGC game.
