number of helpful: 26 of 53 people (49%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												There's a lot of content in this game. There are tons of items and events to unlock, and there's a lot of good combat. I sank over 41 hours into this game, and most of that was probably grinding for trying to unlock specific cards. But it suffers from a couple serious design flaws.I appreciate the giant random element in the game, but when the difficulty ramps up about 7 bosses in, it makes a very large difficulty spike. Some of the dungeon curse combinations are punishingly difficult.There are cards which are close to impossible to beat unless you beat them early enough in the game. These can include Devil's Wager and The River.Too many of the encounters require you to either have  a ridiculous amount of gold or food, or require you to do a lengthy quest chain to unlock new cards. The random chance issues in some of these later encounters can make them ridiculously difficult to complete.By the end of the game, pain cards can aggregate to the point where you get insta-killed from max HP if you have enough curses. It happens.Do not ever quit the game in the middle of a run. Normally it will save your spot, but if the developers decide to patch the game, it can delete any in-progress runs you have going. The code to prevent that is simply to hard for them to implement, due to poor design choices. Just don't leave runs in-progress, as the developers should not be trusted.The dealer is usually funny, tends to get annoying when he runs out of new things to say and just repeats himself over and over. There were also issues with prejudiced and thoughtless dialogue of his which have since been patched out.The DLC isn't all that expensive, and it unlocks character classes for your protagonist, each which has its own quest chain, but each class has its own benefits and drawbacks. Some of the classes are ridiculously overpowered in certain fields, which kind of makes the DLC "pay to win".The graphics and controls are okay, usually. A couple of glitches here and there, and sometimes the controller seems unresponsive until a couple seconds after a battle has begun. That's no good.The developers have an unfortunate habit of "rebalancing" cards, moving around their place in the unlock system or difficulty levels they show up on, and completely changing the way the later dungeons work, and not for the better. This is the sort of negative developer behavior that similarly plagued Dark Souls II.The overall experience is marred by a couple of bad design choices.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												My review for Rogue-like: The Card Game.The Good:-A unique blend of 3rd Person Action RPG with a deck building card game that works incredibly well.-The voice actor for the game master is awesome.-Writing is great.-Top notch visuals and the art style is very Fable-esque.-Runs at a buttery smooth 144fps on my rig max settings, no PC problems as far as I can tell.-Branching paths on later levels which makes for a good amount of replayability.-Random card generation that leads to very different outcomes every time you play, you could get great card draw and have an easy ride to the boss, which leads to...The Meh:-Random card generation that leads to very different outcomes every time you play, you could end up with a pain card that may cause you to lose alot of heath or cripple you early on and make it very difficult to finish a run.-Combat is Arkham-like in which you fling back and forth between enemies and all too familiar counter system, its not as good as Arkham and a bit button mashy, but it works.-Kinda lacking in options, but hey, its a Unity game.-Encountered a small bug in one of the merchant shops where i'd pause the game and when i came back, my cursor was gone and i couldn't select anything...luckily i fixed it by alt-tabbing. Overall:An Early Access success, its nice to see a game come out of that hell hole and bring something very unique and special to the table. I hope to see this gain some huge publicity and enough sales to bring it to other platforms so that everybody has a chance to play this. Support the devs, buy this game!

												This game is amazing in so many ways I cannot describe.It gives you the freedom that you would recieve from open world games to where you can take the role of the Hero, A kind man who gives food to those who need other then worrying about yourself. Returning a well made and powerful weapon of a deceased Hero to his loved ones instead of taking it. Or choose the role of a Greedy-Bandit refusing to give food to hungry starving children. Killing someone crying for help for the small price of gold. The Adventure and Story is your own to decide. As if you were the one actually writing it out in a book and day by day falling head over heels for it because its such a amazing journey and the events that occur cause you to just scream in "Awe"The items you may find are pretty basic. Though I do admit some of them are quite laughable such as the RAT Cleaver. Which looks like a overgrown Butcher-Knife just waiting to cut down one of the pests you see moving around the Kitchen.The Characters are the same as you would see in any other MMO/RPG type game. Though the design is quite cool. Especially the Mages! The Bosses however are quite unique, Though they do have the predictable look as their name dictates such as "Jack of Dust" Who is the boss of a Group of Bandits referred to within the game as Dusts, Looks like Typical Bandana wearing Bandit with no shirt and Tattoos. Though I was always excited to fight a new one.This game is a thrill for people who love adventure! Cards! Battles! And even Bragging rights at times after going past 100 Floors. :P

Posted: June 19, 2016
												Interesting concept, fun at first, then falls flat fast.  Too many times encounters give you a 25% chance to succeed and when the cards are shuffled more than once it's impossible to follow a success card, so it's really blind luck to pass/succeed.  I like being in control of my game, not win by sheer random chance.  I forget the card, pay 3 gold for your future to be told, 25% chance to succeed, failed it several times in a row because it's just blind luck if you succeed.  Silly.  Too many times I'm in fights with traps, missile weapons, and 6+ mobs...and I've yet to have a chance to upgrade my weapon.  This game reminds me of Darkest Dungeon(though not to the same extreme) where the devs thinks it cool/fun to keep heaping on bad luck and misery onto the player and expect them to enjoy it and have fun.  Newsflash devs, constantly giving the play bad things and misery isn't fun unless it's balanced by good things also happening as often.  Lastly, combat in this game is simplistic as best...pure console game button mashing junk.

content:

Early Access Review
								A very intriguing game with solid (though not revolutionary) arena-style fighting, but with a groundbreaking kicker: it's all in the cards.It would be interesting just to have a deck for the player, but the opponent also has a deck that makes the encounters randomized and unique. Earning cards by completing challenges helps to stack your own deck helps to maximize your fortunes. There is some chance involved with some encounters, adding to the randomness and dynamic nature of each rouguelike run.I usually don't endorse early access, but this game seems to be heading in the right direction. I wouldn't blame some for waiting for the final release, but it's already very polished and enticing, and I'm having a blast playing it.

												[Edit to reflect new content and improvements in gameplay:I first reviewed this game in 2015, then stopped playing it because of problems with my PC which have since then been fixed. Recently started playing again, and I've been finding it even more entertaining than it was before. Since my initial experience the developers have added a bunch of new content, made some adjustments to the old cards, as well as improvements in the combat-system. And I swear the Dealer is even more amusing than he was before. I've missed his particular brand of snark.Go.Buy.WIN!]To say this game is ingenious would possibly be the understatement of the year.If this game were a woman, I would want her as my girlfriend, and I would stroll with her through the town square and feel my chest swell with immense pride and pleasure at the envying glances of others. I would thank the grace of fortune for having stumbled upon her and won her to my side. She'd be a woman of elegant beauty and subtle wit, possessed of a personality combining old-school sensibilities with modern flair. She'd be open to endless possibilities of adventure, unpredictable in her actions but kind enough to warn me ahead of time as to what she might have planned for me, allowing me time to prepare myself accordingly. Sure, she might try to knife me in the back from time to time, but she'd also have a fondness for surprising me with mind-blowing wakeup sex. Even after time bred more familiarity with her mercurial nature, I'd still find her to be a walking Wand of Wonder, and every day with her would be an awesome exercise of "What's Next?"She'd be the girl next door and the Devil in a blue dress rolled into one, and just how far she let me into her heart would all depend upon how well I played my cards (Well, and beat down the Raving Packs of Jealous Suitors who woud occasionally camp out in the front-yard, but hey. Details!).TL;DR? : Maud'dib, We have fun-sign the likes of which GOD has never seen.

								Part card game, part board game (at least, as far as the exploration/reveal encounters goes), part CCG, part 3rd person hack and slash action game, all mixed together rather well.The game is presented as a card game of life and death between you and a mysterious (He's a guy that lives in a "cabin at the end of the world" and I don't think he properly introduced himself. Really if you like any combination of the above (unless you HATE hack and slash games...then I can't in good faith recommend this to you), then this game is worth a look and most likely a buy.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Recomended, but a Roguelike, this isn't.  Theres a common notion that roguelike = perma-death.  And while Hand of Fate is merciless in this regard, the defining characteristic of a roguelike is randomness and replayability; a variable experience in every new game.  It is ironic that Defiant would choose to name this title Hand of "Fate" as there is limited variability in the "Hand" your dealt, at least in the first several levels I've played.  The game bills itself as a deckbuilder, indicating a level of tactical cunning is required to defeat the game.  In my time with the game, the key to victory seems to have nothing to do with cards or fate, but your ability to succeed in the action phase of the game.  More of a button mashing twitchfest than the card game I was hoping for, Hand of Fate would be best played with a console remote, feeling more like a God of War inspired beater than a Deckbuilder.  Being a early access title, the game is lacking any upfront system options, but atleast you can access them by holding shift when launching the game.  The voice acting and graphics are excellent, so hopefully Defiant will continue to enhance the core game to match the potential of the AV experience.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												If you don't have a controller don't buy this game. The targeting is finnicky enough with Analog, I can't imagine using WASD.I'm struggling as to whether or not I should recommend this game, and I don't think I can. The game starts out really fun, and it stays fun for quite a few runs. I've almost beaten it at four hours, and I don't know if I will end up finishing it. The Endless Mode sounds like it could be pretty fun with the right deck, but after starving to death on the last tile of the game thanks to an awful combination of curses and cards, as well as all the other BS this game has thrown at me, I just couldn't play it anymore.As I said, the game starts out really fun, and it stays fun for quite a few runs. Then you start running into the problems.The combat is really easy for anyone that's played an Arkham game. That is, when the game actually lets you do well in combat. Combat features a fixed camera, and incredibly small arenas with (as far as I've seen) at most 10 enemies. It also doesn't let you interrupt your attacks, which causes you to not be able to dodge. Combat also has a targeting problem, so occasionally you'll hit the wrong enemy. The power attacks that some enemies do are unblockable, and uninterruptible, which will cause you to get hit when you face one of the bosses for the twentieth time. Unless I missed it, the game also doesn't explain how to do finishers on enemies. As for the difficulty, in the early levels its easy, and in the later levels it just feels unfair. Don't bother trying to increase the difficulty before you get all your food upgrades though, because if you do you'll run out of food and probably end up starving to death.I will say I really enjoyed the different gear you could get.The card part about it was really good. I really enjoy that aspect of the game, and how you can choose which cards you'll be finding. Some of the cards however, are incredibly annoying, and basically only worth it to unlock whatever the card unlocks. Also some of the special cards, basically stories told through a couple cards, like The White Minotaur, or the Kraken, they were cool, but you're not gauranteed to find them during a run. That's fine I guess, it was a bit annoying not finding them, because I really liked them, but that's just the type of game it is. My problem with them, is that at a certain point, you have to find them, then roll the dice on whether or not you'll actually get to move on. I was doing one of them, spent 6 turns walking between cards, and then ended up failing because I got unlucky. This was with a blessing that let me reroll my successes and failures as well.Also the Ratmen. The Ratmen are the worst enemies in this game. They will end your combo because you killed them. Why does this happen? Because they leave a cloud of gas that will damage you over time, and you'll end up running over it at least once thanks to the usually small arenas. They also have a ranged enemy that throws 1-4 knives at you very quickly.Maybe I'll change this review to be a recommendation later, but as of now it just gets too frustrating for me to recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												***DO NOT EXPECT TO EVER FINISH THIS GAME. STACKING PENALTIES, MULTIPLE BOSSES AT THE SAME TIME AND DECK-STACKING ARE ALWAYS AGAINST YOU***An excellent mash-up of deck building, card-progression/upgrades through success, and timing-based combat. You find yourself in a Plutonian hall before the Dealer, the Game Master of a card game that reflects your life and memories. Will you donate blood to a vampire? Save a maiden while you are severely outnumbered? Break open sand-buried tombs for a chance at treasure or curses? It was your life, what memories of yours do the cards hold?This rogue-like combines card game with random chance, mini-games with careful preparation, and mystery with thirsty curiosity. You WILL be tested.You WILL smash your keyboard at the unfairness of the decks and bosses.You WILL face those bosses again, as they are added to the chance encounter deck as soon as they are beaten......and you will come back for more. Again and again you will be rebuffed, and again and again you will come crawling back to unlock more powerful cards, win at games of chance and squeeze all the efficiency out of your food (movement) and gold (money) as you can.Thirteen Challenges await. The further you progress the smaller the arenas get, the tougher and more numerous the enemies get, and the more unfair the Dealer stacks the deck against you. What's your threshold for pain? I hope it's high. This game is gorgeous in it's own mystery and difficulty.

												ROCK FALLS. ROCK FALLS. ROCK FALLS. You lose your equipment, and slowly your health. You have (unskipable cinematic) to watch the guy deals cards again, then go through the first floor, again, to get basic supplies, again. Rock falling is only one level right? number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I dont think this game is for everyone, though i would still not say that it is for a very specific audience. Set up as a board game where you go in and out of combat sequences you make your way through a maze of random cards containing different events where a combinations of your decisions and chance determines if you get new gear, supplies, gold, or health or if you are stripped of these things. Although my genereal experience of the game is positive, there are things that are lacking, especially the combat, seeing how this is a large part of the game, it drags down the experience quite a bit. Hand of Fate is using a very weak incarnation of the arkham mechanics in battles, a system that I didn't personally even enjoy in the batman games. The criticisms of the arkham system are not hard to find on the internet but to me it seems to be little more than a dynamic quicktime event "Press q when green stuff is flashing, press space when red stuff is flashing". Although some things are thrown into the mix to spice the combat up, such as traps and aoe effects, such a weak system needs alot more to make it interesting.I still recommend this game, the gathering of cards is still interesting and the decition making still keeps me intrigued.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												I was really excited to play this game, but the more I play, the more it feels like a chore to play.I'll cut all the crap and get to why I don't think this game is worth it1. The combat sucks. It's a much lesser version of the Arkham style of combat. The problem with it though is that it's terribly imbalanced. Enemies love their ranged attacks, so when you're in a fight with 5+ enemies, you're constantly dodging or countering ranged attacks. Even when you can counter ranged attacks, it seems to do almost zero damage to enemies and they never die to their own arrows. Meanwhile, you're getting pounded on by 3 enemies, and you end up getting hit anyway because you can't counter the melee and ranged at the same time. So you try to dodge. And something manages to hit you while you're dodging. And things take forever to die if you didn't find a good weapon. As simple as the combat is, it's frustrating and not fun.2. The randomness. I know it's a card game, and that's something that piqued my interest in the game, but it's too much against your favor. To unlock new cards, you have to meet prerequisites, and more often than not, you're not going to have them. But there's nothing you can do to meet them, because everything is chance. But all you want to do is unlock new cards. It's just luck. And the cards don't reward you enough. My last 3 runs were against the skeleton king, and all 3 times, I ran out of food near the end. You can only get food by chance or by buying it at randomly placed shops, but you get gold to buy things randomly and none of my cards ever gave me any gold to buy food. I never felt like my losses were my fault.And those two faults are what make up the entire game. You only do two things: go through RNG cards and see what the results are, and fight. The RNG results aren't satisfying, and the combat isn't satisfying, so there's no sense of accomplishment. I'm really sad I don't like this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Alrighty, I've been playing this game for quite a while, and it's been a treat watching it develop towards launch. Now that the time is finally here, I'll try to break down what makes this game such a gem.The premise of the game is simple; you, the player, are in a tabletop game against some random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wizard called The Dealer. That may seem harsh, but, trust me, you'll hate this guy by the time you finish story mode. He's a card sharp and a cheat, and he quite shamelessly weights the deck against you at every turn. This becomes particularly apparent towards the endgame, where you can die on the first board due to the insane limitations he can put on you in terms of both combat and curses. That doesn't make him a bad character, however. The Dealer is quite effective as an antagonist, and his growing desperation as you (whom he implies to be a meathead jock adventurer) mow down his court is somewhat reminiscent of a DM growing exasperated with a party that refuses to die.The nature of the game is a Shoggoth monstrosity that can shift its genre at will between choose-your-own-adventure, Arkham-style brawling, tabletop RPG, and roguelike. To be honest, I could spend hours trying (and failing) to describe it in any decent fashion. Watch a video of it. Jim Sterling's Squirty Play is a good one; it's the release version, and you get to see the reaction of someone who: a) has had no exposure to it, and b) was expecting something very different.Basically, what makes this game great isn't really the gameplay; the individual parts of it are rather bland. By itself, the combat would be mindlessly dull. By itself, the board game would be ridiculously unfair. By himself, the Dealer would still be a jerk. It's the smooth integration of all the facets of this game that make it such an amazing catch. I'm not sure it will ever be considered a "great" (although one can hope), but it certainly has all the markings of a cult classic.Pros:+Very simple and effective gameplay+Good voice acting (although it IS only the one voice)+Lack of backstory allows the player's imagination to do its thing+Although the individual sections of gameplay aren't unique, the combination certainly is+Will shamelessly kill you without truly punishing you+Doesn't interrupt gameplay; even on death, you can immediately jump back in+Endless mode is pretty entertaining+No ♥♥♥♥♥♥ crafting systemsCons:-Combat can be a tad wonky-The optimization is quite iffy; it will tank your CPU for no apparent reason sometimes. Seems to occur more prominently later in the game. This'll probably be fixed (and it's ALOT better than it used to be), but it should be noted.Niggles:~It feels like some of the event triggers are a tad insane, particularly the ones with multiple RNG draws. I still haven't completed the River encounter.~You can wind up in positions that can break the game in your favor; I've had more than 1k health at one point due to a bit of RNG luck after finding the Ring of Poverty.~Flame golems are ridiculous. They take a lot of hurtin' and they dish out even more. When they show up in multi-monster encounters, it usually means a wipe.~The Dealer is an incorrigible cheat. No really, he's a prick.I'd give it a hearty thumbs up. Buy it.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												This game brings something new to the table that I think many people will enjoy. There are aspects of strategy, roguelike, deck building, and hack n slash. It is assembled with very appealing visuals and executes its unique style very well.While playing there were definetly qualities that established it in my mind as similar to classic choose-your-own-adventure games, and aspects of DnD. The set up of "randomized" events set up on uniquely simulated dungeon maps and illustrated through card play is spot on.This is also one of the few games that is absolutely delightful when played in endless mode. It is almost as if the developer started out crafting a game based on endless mode, and put a well made story mode in to pull it all together.That combined with the just-long-enough, but making-me-beg-for-more, pacing of the main game makes for an excellent experience.In game dialogue between the dealer and player regarding events, bosses, successes, and failures just brings the whole experience home and puts it up among my top favorite games.I love this game so far, and can't wait to see what they produce with DLC.I highly recommend this game.9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Wow- pretty amazing game. It's a cross between Talisman (the board game), Pathfinder Adventure Card Game, and Diablo, and it integrates all of those into a consistently fun whole. I have found myself willing to fight a hard battle before the boss (even knowing I will die at the boss if I do) because I will get a card to add to my deck. The decisions create tension. Even the luck elements - of which there are many - feel different than a die roll because you get to choose. Yes, it's still the exact same amount of randomness, but it somehow feels like "If I had only chose that one...I was going to choose that one..."The negatives:1) Luck can be a harsh mistress2) On my very middle-of-the-road system, the frame rate drops on complex battles to where it's almost a guaranteed fail3) I had to go get a controller - the mouse and keyboard were just too clunkyThe positives:1) The dungeon master's voice. I usually get annoyed by voice acting, but this is masterful. 2) In story mode, even though it's roguey, it still feels like a story3) Fantastic mash-up of different types of gameplay - the ability to pick the encounters I'm going to face and the range of equipment I'll have access to is brilliant. 4) The arkham-style combat is fun, and as frustrating as it is to have goblins steal your shield (which makes counters and blocks unavailable), it emphasizes that these are not just multiple game modes strung together, but multiple facets of a single experience.Even though I've died a lot, I have almost always earned something, and I've always wanted to continue. I tend to have a low frustration tolerance these days, but the thought of "having" to play a level again just doesn't bother me. Excellent game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm not much of a reviewer but, I'll sumarise this game as best as i can. And I hope this review will help to support this game.This game is what i would call a story telling rogue-like/lite adventure rpg card game with the Arkham Style fighting system. Seem like alot to put into game but it works well.In this game you must traverse the card layed out by the card dealer. The cards are semi- randomised but, I'll go into more detail later. You click on the card adjacent to where you current position is and then experience the story behind that card which results in either a fight, a choice, a lucky dip or any combination of the three. Then eventually reach the end of the level.CombatThe combat in the game seems to be solid for the most part. The way you fight is simillar if not the same to Batman games style of combat. You move with "wasd", "space bar" to roll/dodge,"q" to counter, "left click" to attack and "right click" to stun. There are also ranged units which can be blocked by your shield. Unless they have a rifle in which case you have to dodge. With as much as I have played so far, the combat seems to be solid, it's not as smooth as it could be and seems a bit jittery, but nothing too extreme. There are also ranged units which can be blocked by your shield. Unless they have a rifle in which case you have to dodge. I have had no problems with the combat so far.BossesThe bosses seem to have a bit of variation. Their mechanics are different depending on their species and the amount and way they attack differ from one to another. There are 12 bosses and so far i have beaten 3, fought 4 as of initially typing this. I have yet to face the later on bosses so unfortunetly I have no experience against them to share as of yet. But, you can still tell when you are in a boss fight and you feel satisfyed to win against them.EnemiesThere are 4 mains enemies you face against, Dust - Bandits, Skull - Skellingtons, Lizard and another which i have yet to encounter. They each are weak to a diffent thing which makes you fights easier or harder depending on the elements of your gear. There are other enemies such as golbins and rats which you face against from their specific event but they all got their own gimic to. Rats will leave a poisonous cloud, goblins will steal your items and won't fight back but will instead try to escaps, so on, so forth.CardsI huge mechanic in this game is the cards. The cards you get in the events you play depend upon the cards you use to build your deck. You get two decks, equipment and events. You unlock more cards through completing events. The cards you unlock are set so it's not all randomised. However, the cards dealer throughs in a couple of his own cards to teach you more mechanics about the game such as enemy types and to prevent you from picking cards which give you a load of free stuff.DifficultyWhen you start off the game, it start off at a beginers pace, to allow you to get use to the controls. It then steadily escilates in difficulty so you are more reliant on your skill and cards you pick. I personally think that the game scales well in difficulty, but you also affect it by the cards you choose. Exsample - If you choose all fights cards, then you could get good loots, but at the same time loose alot of health. If you choose alot of simple equip events, then you will be stuck with low level stuff against the boss. Finding balance is crucial.My OpinionI personally think this game is well made. It plays quite well and the combination and implementation of all the mechanics are great. I would recomend this to people who enjoy rogue-like and/or RPG games with similar combat systems. Regardless of the fact that this game is in early acess at the time of this review, I think if it was released how it is, it would be well worth the price.I would give this game a 8/10 - If you wanna find gameplay of this game, looks at Jessie Cox's Video for fan friday.I haven't played the endless game mode yet so i can not say how good it is, but regardless, it is well worth the price and a ton of fun.I hope this review helps and this is my first review so sorry for any mistakes. This is my opinion of the game, I am not a critic but i decided to write this as i saw there were no reviews. I hope this helps!

								Even in it's current unpolished state, this game is a joy to play. If you have any interest in rougelikes, fantasy RPGs, or just want to see a crazy fun genre mashup, this game is well worth your time.PROS: Well crafted mix of CCG, fantasy RPG, arkham asylum style fights and rougelike          Great voice acting for the dealer          Simple but engaging combat          New and clever game mechanics, including picking the instances you see in your next run-throughCONS: doesn't look great, even on high graphical settings           combat isn't perfectly fine tuned, which can lead to frustration           occasional game-breaking bugConclusion: While this game has its faults, they are mostly due to the place it's in with regards to development, and may be fixed some way down the line, and none of them make this game any less worth your time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm not much of a reviewer but, I'll sumarise this game as best as i can. And I hope this review will help to support this game.This game is what i would call a story telling rogue-like/lite adventure rpg card game with the Arkham Style fighting system. Seem like alot to put into game but it works well.In this game you must traverse the card layed out by the card dealer. The cards are semi- randomised but, I'll go into more detail later. You click on the card adjacent to where you current position is and then experience the story behind that card which results in either a fight, a choice, a lucky dip or any combination of the three. Then eventually reach the end of the level.CombatThe combat in the game seems to be solid for the most part. The way you fight is simillar if not the same to Batman games style of combat. You move with "wasd", "space bar" to roll/dodge,"q" to counter, "left click" to attack and "right click" to stun. There are also ranged units which can be blocked by your shield. Unless they have a rifle in which case you have to dodge. With as much as I have played so far, the combat seems to be solid, it's not as smooth as it could be and seems a bit jittery, but nothing too extreme. There are also ranged units which can be blocked by your shield. Unless they have a rifle in which case you have to dodge. I have had no problems with the combat so far.BossesThe bosses seem to have a bit of variation. Their mechanics are different depending on their species and the amount and way they attack differ from one to another. There are 12 bosses and so far i have beaten 3, fought 4 as of initially typing this. I have yet to face the later on bosses so unfortunetly I have no experience against them to share as of yet. But, you can still tell when you are in a boss fight and you feel satisfyed to win against them.EnemiesThere are 4 mains enemies you face against, Dust - Bandits, Skull - Skellingtons, Lizard and another which i have yet to encounter. They each are weak to a diffent thing which makes you fights easier or harder depending on the elements of your gear. There are other enemies such as golbins and rats which you face against from their specific event but they all got their own gimic to. Rats will leave a poisonous cloud, goblins will steal your items and won't fight back but will instead try to escaps, so on, so forth.CardsI huge mechanic in this game is the cards. The cards you get in the events you play depend upon the cards you use to build your deck. You get two decks, equipment and events. You unlock more cards through completing events. The cards you unlock are set so it's not all randomised. However, the cards dealer throughs in a couple of his own cards to teach you more mechanics about the game such as enemy types and to prevent you from picking cards which give you a load of free stuff.DifficultyWhen you start off the game, it start off at a beginers pace, to allow you to get use to the controls. It then steadily escilates in difficulty so you are more reliant on your skill and cards you pick. I personally think that the game scales well in difficulty, but you also affect it by the cards you choose. Exsample - If you choose all fights cards, then you could get good loots, but at the same time loose alot of health. If you choose alot of simple equip events, then you will be stuck with low level stuff against the boss. Finding balance is crucial.My OpinionI personally think this game is well made. It plays quite well and the combination and implementation of all the mechanics are great. I would recomend this to people who enjoy rogue-like and/or RPG games with similar combat systems. Regardless of the fact that this game is in early acess at the time of this review, I think if it was released how it is, it would be well worth the price.I would give this game a 8/10 - If you wanna find gameplay of this game, looks at Jessie Cox's Video for fan friday.I haven't played the endless game mode yet so i can not say how good it is, but regardless, it is well worth the price and a ton of fun.I hope this review helps and this is my first review so sorry for any mistakes. This is my opinion of the game, I am not a critic but i decided to write this as i saw there were no reviews. I hope this helps!

Early Access Review
								Pretty good balance between combat and deck building. Bought in the Bumble Bundle and got a foil card drop from it so it essentially cost me nothing! I'm really enjoying it so would recommend. Pros: I like the fact that at the end of each chapter the game will re-build your deck for you with the optimium cards. For those that don't particularly want to build their own decks it means they don't get left behind.For the pick a card shuffle rounds I really like the fact that you can actually follow the cards - I've played too many games where it's just randomised but here it's pretty simple to pay attention!Cons: The direction keys aren't too fantastic, I find that I need to let go completely to move in a new direction as I get stuck, it doesn't flow so well but it's not that big a deal as it isn't enough of a handicap to get you killed. Tip: Don't even bother trying to remove the curses, it's not worth the gold. Good weapons and lots of food is far more valuable. From the strange looking maiden I always go for blessings, you generally get something pretty decent and long lasting - there are plenty of other places to get gold, food and life.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a very pleasent suprise. It's randomly generated dungeon board game. It's also a solid roguelike action rpg. Lastly it's a strategic card game. You unlock cards to build a deck that that you randomly draw from during each game. Unlocking cards feels reawrding since you get to 'load your deck' with them later. If you get bored with table top games, or hate having to start your character over, then this game isn't for you. If you dislike the combat in the Batman Arkham games then you should stear clear. The combat has some actual depth with a dodge/counter/block system. It's pretty easy to view the combat as a button smashing action rpg, but you'll get your butt kicked pretty fast if you do that. It's not my favorite part, but taking time, planning out the order of your attacks, and being ready to counter is key to victory.I give this game 8/10+Original, refreshing+Addicting, FTL style+Feels like a good tabletop game-Combat could be flashier-Lacks a storyPlay if you like:Munchkins (tabletop), Dominion (tabletop), Magic the Gathering (tabletop), FTL, Fable, or Dark Souls.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hand of Fate is slightly more humiliating a lot more fun than playing a children's card game.It's a very special blend of hack and slay, card game and tabletop--and it's all very stylish. Forget leveling up and hunting for the ultimate loot au Diablo 3: There are no levels to gain, and you always start with a crappy weapon. You want a better one, you have to earn it; you can only find/buy equipment whose cards are in play so as you unlock new cards, you get to influence the type of gear you can find, and also to some extent what can happen to you.As of now, the beta (early access) looks and plays nice--apart from the occasional out-of-sync sound effects, everything looks and feels very much worth the $$$. It will be interesting to see if it has any replay value though.Did I mention that it runs on Linux, and flawlessly at that?One thing though: Multiplayer. No, I don't know how that would work. Actually, scratch that, that's a stupid idea.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Okay, so this game's concept is EPIC. It really is. I don't have many hours on it, but I had to give a review early on because of how this game was conceptualized. But. . .  I can't recommend this game at its regular price, but for the sale price of $7.49 - you better believe it's worth it. I'd say the most this game should ever cost is 14.99 with 4.99 (big) DLCs in the future. Why would I not recommend a game I'm recommending? Because for $24.99, this game should be a lot more. For that, let me list some pros/cons.ProsOriginal Concept - There really isn't another game out there like this one. It ties small elements of rogue-likes, D&D, DD card games, C card games, RPGs, and ARPGs into a sweet-looking, auditorily-pleasing game of chance and skill.Visually appealing - This game looks great, it really does. It's not going to make you think you're sitting across from some gypsy, but you are certainly going to be satisfied with the overall graphics of the game. Auditorily appealing - Most games make me want to turn the background music all the way down, but this game really hits the ambience with its music, voice-acting, and sound effects.Choice of short/long games - if you want to just hop in and play for a bit, you're able to do just that. The game-plays are relatively short (15-30m) and are very easy to pick back up again.ConsLong Animations - The animations (card dealing, turning, token selection) are nice the first two (maybe three) times but they get very old after awhile. The cutscenes leading into normal battles and shops can be skipped, but the boss cutscenes and all other card dealing animations cannot be. This really draws out the game unnecessarily.Hidden Cards from Tokens - As you play to defeat each boss, you will obtain tokens, unlocking other cards. The animations used to present the new cards to you drags on forever, but is pointless given that you have no clue what the cards do until you actually use and play them in a round.This goes for ALL cards. This is a major annoyance for me, because after you defeat the boss, flipping all the cards takes awhile . . .  It is for naught because you still have no idea what the new cards are for, which makes deck building (as you progress the first go-round) pointless.Combat - I have to give combat a 'negative' score because it's very repetitive and not very seamless. I think the 'matrix-style' finishers are pretty epic, but even those get buggy from time-to-time. There needs to be a little more room in each 'arena'. They should also add move combinations (perhaps as 'blessings' or attached to the weapon itself). An example:- you can perform a certain maneuver by hitting: x,x,y,z (just example) - but the computer could swap these keys around, making the combos always different each playthrough. At any rate, the combat is definitely not a 'winner'. Luck v Skill - This game relies on luck over skill far too much. It would be one thing if players were given a chance to win in every  playthrough, but they aren't - if you're dealt a bad hand, then that's just tough, because you're going to probably die and you'll have to start over again. Having a bit of luck dictate parts of the outcome (or the difficulty of achieving a goal) is one thing, but having that be the sole determinant over winning/losing is not okay and it takes the fun out of the game and simply adds a component of frustration.SummaryI really love the concept. We don't see concepts like this come along very often to where it's just a completely new game type all on its own - an innovative game that sparks the next 1k dev teams to copy its game-type.This game took parts of various games and, like a gourmet dinner, made all the flavors work together quite well. Unfortunately, the game relies too much on luck. That's its major flaw. That's the overcooked protein in this dish. If they could fix that, and make the combat a little more 'skill-reliant', then this game would find itself being copied by the next 1k dev teams. Until then, it's only worth about 14.99 (and that's stretching it). So, if you can get it on sale, GET IT! If you are being asked to pay $24.99 for the game - don't. . . because it's simply not worth it at this time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Alot of people talk about Rogue-likes as these hard-core, unforgiving, all-or-nothing, RNG dependant dungeon crawls... and many of them are. However, if you've played the original Rogue (or Rogue Legacy), you'll find that many game designers who classify their game as a "Rogue-like" have only copied the most sadistic parts of that game and ignored some of the more interesting and rewarding parts. Hand of Fate manages to replicate some of the progression aspects that the original Rogue utilized that made me actually love that game and reconsider the "Rogue-like" genre entirely. Hand of Fate, like Rogue, is not all-or-nothing. Rather it's a game of incrimental progress. You fight your way as far as you can, gathering tokens (think, card booster packs) along the way, and apon reaching a reset condition (either beating a boss in storymode or dying), those tokens reveal and add weapons, encounters, or armor to your deck which you can then use to enhance your next experiance. That way, you don't feel like you're bashing your head against a wall of RNG spite. In almost every playthrough of Hand of Fate, you're going to come away with something you can add to your deck to slant the odds ever-so-slightly more in your favor, and that's a motivator to keep on playing.As for Hand of Fate's drawbacks? I'd have to say it's combat leaves alot to be deisred. It's a watered down counter-system ala Batman Arkham Asylum that offers very little in terms of variety, fluidity or technique. You occationally get abilities to use and dodges to execute but that doesn't save the whole engagment from being awkward. If there were ever a Hand of Fate 2, (which I'd certainly hope for,) I'd say the combat stands to benefit the most from a reassessment.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												This game came up in my recommendations list with a lot of positive reviews and looked interesting so I gave it a shot.  Very glad I did, this game is really good.It's a deck builder - a card game where you gain more, better cards to add to your deck as you progress through the game.  You sit at a table facing a hooded mage who controls the cards and narrated the story.  The voice acting is very good and once you have drawn the same card a couple of times the narration for that card is muted so you don't end up running through the same dialoque game after game.  It's kind of like playing a single player RPG with the mage as DM expanding the story around the cards drawn.  The voice (and the image of the DM to a degree) put me in mind of John Hurt which is cool.The DM deals out a number of cards in a pattern depicting the path (or paths) you have to travel before meeting the final enemy.  You can choose which way to go by which cards you turn over on the path (although some are straight so no choice) and you can be lucky and find the exit to the next level quickly meaning you can skip forward but possibly miss out on finding a shop or other useful encounter.  I prefer to take my chances of drawing a bad encounter for the benefits of potentially better equipment/more cards.The decks consist of armour, weapons, enchantments and food as well as enounters both good and bad.  Some enounters involve a test of luck where you have to choose a 'success' card from a selection of four cards.  These are displayed before being shuffled so there is a chance you can follow the best card before they are dealt face down.  Winning encounters let you draw cards from your deck giving you the chance to upgrade your armour, weapons or giving you more food (needed to heal)It's not just a static card game however.  The battles are actually played out as a third person skirmish with you controlling your character fighting, blocking and using any special abilities granted by your equipment.  This is the part that really marks the game out as different and deepens your sense of involvement - you're not just sat at a table playing cards, you are truly part of the story which is unfolding.Completing the final enemy grants you additional cards for your deck and every fourth quest grants you an item from the DM levelling up both your character and the enemies you will face.If you are unfamiliar with deckbuilding or just want to progress to the next game quickly, at the start of each quest you have the option of using a recommended deck based on y0our cards.  If you wish, you can then go in and edit the deck to your satisfaction although newly gained cards will not reveal their effects until they have been played.There is the skill of choosing which cards you own will be best suited to the upcoming quest.  This gets more important the further you progress and the more cards you have.Overall, a very enjoyable and quite relaxing game, definitely worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
Fun. Straightforward. Atmospheric. Pick up and play. If you've ever wondered what it would be like to play a card game against a mysterious wizard, then this is the game for you. Just by sitting at a table to play cards against this man, the game does a wonderful job at world building. It creates the impression you're in some sort of Arabian Nights tale, or perhaps one of the Call of Cthulhu back stories. Either way, I was quickly sucked in.All the card game's rules are handled by your wizard friend, who is both your opponent and your friendly dealer. The learning process for this game was quick. The tutorial is a natural part of the game and a natural part of story progression, which I thought was well done.+ The Game ItselfThe wizard lays out a series of face down cards connected like a road. Your little chess hero starts at one end and has to jump from one card to the next to reach the Big Bad at the other end. Each card you land on is turned over and will result in a random event. Sometimes it will mean combat (that will take you into 3rd person combat mode) but many other times it will be games of chance, or decision making that may affect you later, or risky opportunities. In the end, you reach the Big Bad, enter combat and fight to the death. Victory means you win new cards to add to your deck and a chance to play again to fight a new Big Bad. Defeat means the wizard reshuffles and deals again. You keep your victories over the previous Big Bads though.+ CombatFighting is all about building up hit streaks and finding a rhythm. Mouse and keyboard controls are slightly 'janky' but not bad enough to get in the way or make you lose a fight. There are many cards that enhance the things you can do in combat - they add weapons, equipment, spells, and so on. The combat mechanics are simple and could be improved, but the simplicity of the combat is also what allows this game to be a "pick up and play" type of game. I like the starting animation when your hero enters combat and puts on his gear, it's clever and it's an excellent in-game way to remind the player what cards he or she might be able to use in combat.+ Card CollectingEach time I won a game I unlocked new cards which I could add to my deck and play in the next game. The cards I unlocked were random, but also related to my wins and losses to the little battles and tests of luck against the wizard during the game. It made me feel like I had earned them. + Deck BuildingIf you know that the next card game is going to focus heavily on undead, for example, then you may want to tailor your deck in that direction. The deck builder is straightforward, but if you don't want to bother building a deck, the game will build it for you and it does a good job. I never unlocked too many cards per game, so I never felt swamped, so I always made my own deck. Just to add some spice, the game hid the precise details of new cards until I landed on them in a game, so if I added them to my deck it was a gamble, but a necessary one.+ Random EventsThese cards are the bulk of the game and they are what make it so much fun. They are surpisingly varied, and you can even encounter the same card you've seen before and get a totally different experience from it. These cards, coupled with the dialogue from the Wizard, who was talking directly to me, made the game feel personal and turned every victory or loss from these cards into a fun wager.+ Lore & AtmosphereThere is some lore surrounding the Big Bads and there's some lore present in the description of the various characters you meet while travelling, but overall it is light. All the atmospheric strength and character of this game emanates from three places: The first is the wizard and his desk. His hands and his eyes are expressive, I just dig him. The second is the Wizard's voice. I found him wry and sarcastic at times but also dark when he needed to be. And the third place is the deck of cards. I thought the art on the cards was well done and perfectly suited to this type of game.+ Game TimeA single game might be 15 to 30 minutes. So it's perfect for that moment of downtime. I'd say that during that harder difficulties you're more likely to spend 30 minutes on a game than 15, because you'll try different strategies or try for more cards, or get more combat. It just depends on your luck. Except for combat, the game runs at your pace.+ Other Thoughts- This is a game for someone who values their time, enjoys Call of Cthulhu, M:TG (3rd Ed, Ice Age, or Tempest), watching tv and playing a computer game at the same time because they don't really want to concentrate, and graphic novels.- It's probably best with a controller, good with a keyboard and mouse, definitely not with a trackpad.- Works on low-ish settings on my Lenovo Yoga 2 Pro.I hope you got something from this review. I'm currently developing my own game called Heroes of the Antarctic[thinkpadius.com] which is an exploration roguelike set in the Antarctic during the early 1900s. Check it out if it interests you.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Quite fun as a mix of a board game & card game in mechanics with a bit of combat thrown in. Highly addictive game where you assemble a deck of cards on what you might encounter for equipment or encounters with the stranger you are playing against has his own cards to throw against you. From there the cards you pick for encounters are put out in a path for each section where sometimes you have a choice & others it's a straight path. Sometimes it's more of a 3rd person adventure style of combat against different opponents, other times with the encounters, you are given cards that have various success & failure, take your pick & your gains or losses will sometimes unlock new cards adding to the addictive nature of the game. Blessings & curses are random later on to make things quite a challenge as you gain new tactics to use or avoid to help you on your quest. From the unlocked cards, you can go back to battle old bosses with the added challenge of taking new cards in to make a familiar encounter completely new depending on the cards you get from what you picked. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												A beautiful and strange combation of card game and Batman-style fighting game. You play through a randomly generated dungeon layed out via cards on a tabletop. You move through the dungeon collecting gold and equipment, keeping an eye on your food, dodging traps and avoiding obsticles via "pick a card" style results. When you encounter combat, you are transported into what feels like an entirely different fighting game to resolve it. Everything about this game is pretty to look at and fun to do, however the combat is so incredibly simplified that it doesn't feel very challenging. You can't change the default character and skills come via equipment, which come via the collection of cards. You earn tokens and increase your hand by completing levels. If only combat was a little more involved this game would be near perfect. The best part by far is the narrator who's also the game master.

But sadly there is one thing that is missing from what "damn near" covers, this being the combat. The combat just seems to me too easy. It being in the same style the of Ac and Batman: arkham X games, although granted the further you progress, the harder the enemies are and the harder combat gets(obviously), it has just felt to me that combat in these games lacked something. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Hand of Fate is basically mixture of RPG's (like Hero Quest tabletop or Fighting Fantasy books), tabletop card games (like Magic The Gathering or Dominion) and it has few elements from Roguelike games (Nethack, Adom etc). Everything this is combined to good graphics and real time hack'n'slash. Fighting system is simple, intuitive and fun.There's plot, sort of, or actually there's lots of mini-adventures and missions in-game and there's plenty of mutators which make every game more or less different. Basically it's about challenging yourself and your decisions in the moment of truth - life, death and resurrection. It's combination of old-school fantasy atmosphere and modern interpretation. Most of all, this game shows love to the genre, love to the gaming itself and having fun while swinging sword. Original piece of game that's easy to enjoy time after time again.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												Hand Of Fate, not so family friendly Fantasy card game with real time combat. I love the game, I have beaten almost all of the bosses (stuck on the last one) and I love how hard the game is!My first expressions to Hand of fate were something like this: "Another fantasy card game? Hearthstone ripp-off?" But I was suprised how there is third-person realtime combat in this! So how does it work?The idea is this: There is the "table" where you have cards. You don't know what the cards are and as you move you unfold the cards one by one. Behind every card there could be a Fight, a choice, a shop or the Devil giving you something to kill. The more you play the more cards you get, and more cards you have, more difficult the game gets. Also the first time you kill a boss, it becomes a reqular encounter in the game. So don't be like me and say "Now I will never have to fight him again.." WoopsieThe game is wonderful and I recommend it from my frozen heart,,, now I have a meeting with the King of Scales (again)

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												It's a turn-based roguelike card-game with realtime combat, a tremendous amount of replayability, and a fantastic atmosphere that brilliantly mixes the creepiness of the dealer with the thrill of a fantastical adventure. The writing is wonderful, and engine updates have made the game visually excellent by most any standards. It's a brilliant game, and easily one of the best of the year.The cherry on top? The developers are wonderful. A long time back when the game was still in early access, someone complained about a spider that would crawl around on the table at random times during play. I fired the game up recently to check out the (completely free and quite extensive) Christmas updates, scrolled through the options to see if anything was different, and noticed an option to turn the spider off. These guys are the best, and if the game interests you, they absolutely deserve your money.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												The arrival of cards is barely balanced out. Such uncommon game mechanics can be fun but mostly frustrating. As a player you feel very detached from what is going on since you can't influence anything (either encounters or you can't go back to a previous level or you can't even heal yourself and the story is almost non-existent). This game is a feast of randomness. You can get a tough fight and almost useless reward or vice versa. Or you can get several hard fights in a row. The game can plant a couple of mini-bosses into a regular fight. Another session you may get a boss fight just one card away from the start armed only with basic equipment. What kept me playing was the melee system which resembled very much the one of Batman: Arkham Trilogy. Overall, it's a brilliant time-waster and it's worth taking a look because of its game mechanics. But most likely it'll be a short look.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Awesome game, one of the rare games I completed.It's sort of like 'Binding of Isaac' for not so hardcore players.- It has a sort of Heartstone-ish ( or Gwent from Witcher) play with the cards, deciding your adventure - depending on your choices.It's just easy and fun. But you will die, you will die a lot. But each game is new and helps keep it fresh.- And it's fun hunting new cards or try to unlock the token on new cards. And in the end, build your own deck - So you can remove those pesky annoying cards you dislike.Oh, and there is Endless Mode when the campaign is done. I die so much in that mode, so I've given up on that part of the game, I just enjoy the (doable) campaign - And really would like more!(Endless mode is a game mode where all cards are in play, and you can continue forever).Also, the developers have made tons of updates and listen to the community, and now they work on Hand of Fate 2. Which I will buy at full price, as soon as it is out.Pro Tip; Use it with a controller.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												This is a deck building roguelike RPG with an awesome art direction. Each "level" is a series of cards drawn on the table. You're represented as a golden pawn that cah go to the verry next cards. Each card is an encounter. It can be good for you, bad for you, test your luck (or ability to not be fooled...) or oblige you to fight.Your equipement are cards. You earn token that unlocks more cards. Every random aspect of the game is handeled by cards.The compat system makes it an action-RPG. The combat mechanices are the same as in the recent Batman games and it's really pleasing. From a Game Design standpoint it's a little marvel. I urge you to try it out!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												The game may not be everyone's cup of tea, but if it matches your personality and what you like, look out. I don't have a lot of hours on record yet--mostly because it's a little hard on my outdated laptop--but I fully expect that number to skyrocket. It's everything I could want and more, despite being a relatively simple game.Which is why I say it's likely not for everyone. The gameplay is very straightforward. There's not much to it. If you get bored easily, it might not be more than a time waster for you (and a possibly pricey one). At worst, you may grow tired of it completely. For me, though, I can't get enough. Granted, as a Dungeon Master, it really taps into my sense of adventure designing. Even though you come across the same cards and do the same things, it's still delightfully interesting thinking on how things interact and work to bring you where you are. Every play is a different adventure, and that appeals to me.And though the gameplay is relatively simple, that also means that it's very solid. While there's some luck to it, admittedly, I still feel like I am in control. When I lose, it's my fault, when I win, it's because I planned well.All in all, I am incredibly pleased. For the adventure lovers, for those who kind of like coming up with their own story with a vaguer backbone, this is for you. For the rest... I dunno, go watch somebody play for a bit, and decide for yourself.

												Hand Of Fate, not so family friendly Fantasy card game with real time combat. I love the game, I have beaten almost all of the bosses (stuck on the last one) and I love how hard the game is!My first expressions to Hand of fate were something like this: "Another fantasy card game? Hearthstone ripp-off?" But I was suprised how there is third-person realtime combat in this! So how does it work?The idea is this: There is the "table" where you have cards. You don't know what the cards are and as you move you unfold the cards one by one. Behind every card there could be a Fight, a choice, a shop or the Devil giving you something to kill. The more you play the more cards you get, and more cards you have, more difficult the game gets. Also the first time you kill a boss, it becomes a reqular encounter in the game. So don't be like me and say "Now I will never have to fight him again.." WoopsieThe game is wonderful and I recommend it from my frozen heart,,, now I have a meeting with the King of Scales (again)

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												It's a turn-based roguelike card-game with realtime combat, a tremendous amount of replayability, and a fantastic atmosphere that brilliantly mixes the creepiness of the dealer with the thrill of a fantastical adventure. The writing is wonderful, and engine updates have made the game visually excellent by most any standards. It's a brilliant game, and easily one of the best of the year.The cherry on top? The developers are wonderful. A long time back when the game was still in early access, someone complained about a spider that would crawl around on the table at random times during play. I fired the game up recently to check out the (completely free and quite extensive) Christmas updates, scrolled through the options to see if anything was different, and noticed an option to turn the spider off. These guys are the best, and if the game interests you, they absolutely deserve your money.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												This game came up in my recommendations list with a lot of positive reviews and looked interesting so I gave it a shot.  Very glad I did, this game is really good.It's a deck builder - a card game where you gain more, better cards to add to your deck as you progress through the game.  You sit at a table facing a hooded mage who controls the cards and narrated the story.  The voice acting is very good and once you have drawn the same card a couple of times the narration for that card is muted so you don't end up running through the same dialoque game after game.  It's kind of like playing a single player RPG with the mage as DM expanding the story around the cards drawn.  The voice (and the image of the DM to a degree) put me in mind of John Hurt which is cool.The DM deals out a number of cards in a pattern depicting the path (or paths) you have to travel before meeting the final enemy.  You can choose which way to go by which cards you turn over on the path (although some are straight so no choice) and you can be lucky and find the exit to the next level quickly meaning you can skip forward but possibly miss out on finding a shop or other useful encounter.  I prefer to take my chances of drawing a bad encounter for the benefits of potentially better equipment/more cards.The decks consist of armour, weapons, enchantments and food as well as enounters both good and bad.  Some enounters involve a test of luck where you have to choose a 'success' card from a selection of four cards.  These are displayed before being shuffled so there is a chance you can follow the best card before they are dealt face down.  Winning encounters let you draw cards from your deck giving you the chance to upgrade your armour, weapons or giving you more food (needed to heal)It's not just a static card game however.  The battles are actually played out as a third person skirmish with you controlling your character fighting, blocking and using any special abilities granted by your equipment.  This is the part that really marks the game out as different and deepens your sense of involvement - you're not just sat at a table playing cards, you are truly part of the story which is unfolding.Completing the final enemy grants you additional cards for your deck and every fourth quest grants you an item from the DM levelling up both your character and the enemies you will face.If you are unfamiliar with deckbuilding or just want to progress to the next game quickly, at the start of each quest you have the option of using a recommended deck based on y0our cards.  If you wish, you can then go in and edit the deck to your satisfaction although newly gained cards will not reveal their effects until they have been played.There is the skill of choosing which cards you own will be best suited to the upcoming quest.  This gets more important the further you progress and the more cards you have.Overall, a very enjoyable and quite relaxing game, definitely worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Alot of people talk about Rogue-likes as these hard-core, unforgiving, all-or-nothing, RNG dependant dungeon crawls... and many of them are. However, if you've played the original Rogue (or Rogue Legacy), you'll find that many game designers who classify their game as a "Rogue-like" have only copied the most sadistic parts of that game and ignored some of the more interesting and rewarding parts. Hand of Fate manages to replicate some of the progression aspects that the original Rogue utilized that made me actually love that game and reconsider the "Rogue-like" genre entirely. Hand of Fate, like Rogue, is not all-or-nothing. Rather it's a game of incrimental progress. You fight your way as far as you can, gathering tokens (think, card booster packs) along the way, and apon reaching a reset condition (either beating a boss in storymode or dying), those tokens reveal and add weapons, encounters, or armor to your deck which you can then use to enhance your next experiance. That way, you don't feel like you're bashing your head against a wall of RNG spite. In almost every playthrough of Hand of Fate, you're going to come away with something you can add to your deck to slant the odds ever-so-slightly more in your favor, and that's a motivator to keep on playing.As for Hand of Fate's drawbacks? I'd have to say it's combat leaves alot to be deisred. It's a watered down counter-system ala Batman Arkham Asylum that offers very little in terms of variety, fluidity or technique. You occationally get abilities to use and dodges to execute but that doesn't save the whole engagment from being awkward. If there were ever a Hand of Fate 2, (which I'd certainly hope for,) I'd say the combat stands to benefit the most from a reassessment.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
Fun. Straightforward. Atmospheric. Pick up and play. If you've ever wondered what it would be like to play a card game against a mysterious wizard, then this is the game for you. Just by sitting at a table to play cards against this man, the game does a wonderful job at world building. It creates the impression you're in some sort of Arabian Nights tale, or perhaps one of the Call of Cthulhu back stories. Either way, I was quickly sucked in.All the card game's rules are handled by your wizard friend, who is both your opponent and your friendly dealer. The learning process for this game was quick. The tutorial is a natural part of the game and a natural part of story progression, which I thought was well done.+ The Game ItselfThe wizard lays out a series of face down cards connected like a road. Your little chess hero starts at one end and has to jump from one card to the next to reach the Big Bad at the other end. Each card you land on is turned over and will result in a random event. Sometimes it will mean combat (that will take you into 3rd person combat mode) but many other times it will be games of chance, or decision making that may affect you later, or risky opportunities. In the end, you reach the Big Bad, enter combat and fight to the death. Victory means you win new cards to add to your deck and a chance to play again to fight a new Big Bad. Defeat means the wizard reshuffles and deals again. You keep your victories over the previous Big Bads though.+ CombatFighting is all about building up hit streaks and finding a rhythm. Mouse and keyboard controls are slightly 'janky' but not bad enough to get in the way or make you lose a fight. There are many cards that enhance the things you can do in combat - they add weapons, equipment, spells, and so on. The combat mechanics are simple and could be improved, but the simplicity of the combat is also what allows this game to be a "pick up and play" type of game. I like the starting animation when your hero enters combat and puts on his gear, it's clever and it's an excellent in-game way to remind the player what cards he or she might be able to use in combat.+ Card CollectingEach time I won a game I unlocked new cards which I could add to my deck and play in the next game. The cards I unlocked were random, but also related to my wins and losses to the little battles and tests of luck against the wizard during the game. It made me feel like I had earned them. + Deck BuildingIf you know that the next card game is going to focus heavily on undead, for example, then you may want to tailor your deck in that direction. The deck builder is straightforward, but if you don't want to bother building a deck, the game will build it for you and it does a good job. I never unlocked too many cards per game, so I never felt swamped, so I always made my own deck. Just to add some spice, the game hid the precise details of new cards until I landed on them in a game, so if I added them to my deck it was a gamble, but a necessary one.+ Random EventsThese cards are the bulk of the game and they are what make it so much fun. They are surpisingly varied, and you can even encounter the same card you've seen before and get a totally different experience from it. These cards, coupled with the dialogue from the Wizard, who was talking directly to me, made the game feel personal and turned every victory or loss from these cards into a fun wager.+ Lore & AtmosphereThere is some lore surrounding the Big Bads and there's some lore present in the description of the various characters you meet while travelling, but overall it is light. All the atmospheric strength and character of this game emanates from three places: The first is the wizard and his desk. His hands and his eyes are expressive, I just dig him. The second is the Wizard's voice. I found him wry and sarcastic at times but also dark when he needed to be. And the third place is the deck of cards. I thought the art on the cards was well done and perfectly suited to this type of game.+ Game TimeA single game might be 15 to 30 minutes. So it's perfect for that moment of downtime. I'd say that during that harder difficulties you're more likely to spend 30 minutes on a game than 15, because you'll try different strategies or try for more cards, or get more combat. It just depends on your luck. Except for combat, the game runs at your pace.+ Other Thoughts- This is a game for someone who values their time, enjoys Call of Cthulhu, M:TG (3rd Ed, Ice Age, or Tempest), watching tv and playing a computer game at the same time because they don't really want to concentrate, and graphic novels.- It's probably best with a controller, good with a keyboard and mouse, definitely not with a trackpad.- Works on low-ish settings on my Lenovo Yoga 2 Pro.I hope you got something from this review. I'm currently developing my own game called Heroes of the Antarctic[thinkpadius.com] which is an exploration roguelike set in the Antarctic during the early 1900s. Check it out if it interests you.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Imagine Hearthstone, Batman AA, D&D, Darkest Dungeon, and Gauntlet had a baby...that baby's name is Hand of Fate. Then add a card dealer that actually feels like a real person is playing cards with you....I just cant say enough good about this game but I'm going to try.     This game is unbelievably good. The voice acting is literally perfect. It is so immersive watching all of the little animations that the  dealer uses and his comments are so on point that it is akin to psycho mantis from mgs. I really get the sense that I am playing cards with a powerful, mysterious and devious being and he is talking to ME! His covered face was a brilliant idea to add to the sense of mistrust.      This is truly a seamles mashup of several components. TCG, action, RPG, strategy. While Hand of Fate isn't a complete experience in any of the forementioned genres there is enough of each one that somehow when combined...is so throughly entertaining and enthralling I simply cannot put it down. The concept is so simple yet so brilliant it's a wonder noone has made a game like this years ago. The gameplay is so fun that I played the game for 7.4 hours straight the same night I purchased it. It is realy a unique experience. What a gem! I really cant say enough about the dealer's character he makes every single moment of this game feel meaningful and the absolutely nailed the atmosphere. The presentation is top notch. there are so many wonderful details such as the way the candle burns down as the game goes on and as such the room becomes darker.      I was so filled with wonder, excitement, terror, joy and anger while playing this game. The games difficulty seems to ramp up nicely. I am not even half way done with this game yet but I am so looking forward to the bosses and cards that I will unlock next but most of all I am looking forward to unraveling the mystereis behind the dealer and what this game is all about.      Fascinatingly there is no tutorial you are simply thrust into the game and yet I can tell that this is not an oversight, it is deliberate and the dealer makes mention of it several times. If you've ever played a videogame before you will figure it out and the gameply is so intuitive that to my surprise, no tutorial is necessary! He will wager some precious artifacts if you win you earn them if you lose you will have to roll your deck again and he will deal the dungeons from the beginning.      I took a chance on this game because I really like TCG and the way that this suppossedly had an action elemant sounded interesting and unique and I am so glad I did. Now that I know how good this game is I would have gladly spent twice the price I paid. Unless you are some sort of gibbering idiot who only plays madden games you will definitely love this game. I seriously cannot imagine anyone not liking this game; it is straight up fun! The game really put a smile on my face very quickly and then gradually became very challanging. I really love Hand of Fate. I give HOF my highest reccomendation and I would place this game among my top favorite games of all time.
