content:
Posted: March 8
												Fun game. Different concept. You essentially play a card game that combines real 3rd person fighting. The fighting is pretty easy at first with certain mechanics almost broken, but it can be more challenging with hardmode. The combat doesn't initially seem all that diverse though and could become tiresome. I don't feel like the game is worth its initial $20 price tag, but if you get it on sale or in a bundle then it could be worth it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Hand of Fate is a really fun card game with beat 'em up elements. The game features two modes; Story and Endless. This will mostly be focused on Story, as I've not played Endless yet.The game is fairly simple; the dealer will lie down cards on the table and you will move your piece onto the cards. Sometimes, this is linear, but sometimes it isn't. Some cards will activate things like visiting a shop, encountering baddies to kill, traversing a maze or coming up against a situation where, of 4 cards, you must pick the "Success" card in order to win. You will have, at the bottom right, three "stats": your health, your food & your gold. Every move consumes 1 food, but you'll restore lost health. Gold is fairly self-explanatory.When you get an encounter card, you are placed onto a small plot of field where you will fight against monsters, ranging from goblins to skeletons, zombies and bandits. While variation is limited, it doesn't pull away from the experience. However, the fighting / combat is rather wonky; borrowing from the Arkham series, you will basically use WASD to move around and left click to attack. You cannot hard target a specific enemy, which can be a bit frustrating, but again, really doesn't affect the game greatly.Situation cards vary, from finding a weapon in a crevasse to saving someone from being swarmed by enemies. Successfully "winning" these situations nets you a token from the dealer. At the end, all of your accrued tokens are counted up and you are given specific rewards based on the tokens. For example, I was tasked with defeated a knight that had been overrun by some skeletons. Once I defeated them, he told me I could keep the mace I was given prior to the fight, as his kingdom was flush with them. Once I completed the level, his token rewarded me with 2 Mace cards.You progress through the 'levels' by travsering through the cards, finding that particular level's 'end card' and moving onto the next level. At the end of the final level, you will fight a boss. Defeating the boss gives you more tokens, which unlock things like weapons, armor, encounters and other varying cards.One of the coolest things this game offers is the Deck Builder. On one side, your deck has cards for Equipment; weapons and armor and trinkets. The other side are your encounters, from visiting shops to situations. If the card has a lock icon on it, that means it has a situation / encounter you've yet to face. Drawing & defeating that card will net you another token.Last but not least is the Dealer himself; an elderly mage who speaks to you throughout the game. His dialogue is superb and I found myself actively listening to what he had to say. The first level, I drew a card that had a goblin giving me a shield. The next level, I drew the card again and, in this very dry tone, he said "I think you purposefully put that card in there just to get an early shield." (or something to that effect) It's minor, but the fact he recognizes that made me smile.I know my hours played as of writing this is low (think it's barely 2 hours), but honestly - the game is immediately fun. The combat is a bit wonky, but everything else excels so well that I don't mind. It doesn't hurt that the game also looks really good & sounds pretty good, too. I can't wait to jump back into the game and have more fun with it. :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												An excellent roguelite based on the idea of choice, chance, and consequence. Many players have commented on the increase in difficulty. This is true. But several people ignore the fact that it's about chance and consequence. One reviewer mentioned a card that makes you lose 66% of your max health. This is true. But you can ignore that completely and just not take the chance. If you do it and succeed though, you get a HUGE reward. There aren't any cards that just exist to kill you. There are many that exist that let you risk death for the prospect of reward, though.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												Honestly, it does not feel much like a card game, probably because you never really get to interact with the cards or make meaningful choices with them, except for when you're editing the deck. It plays and feels more like a randomly generated dungeon crawler, with you being able to alter the probability of various instances in the dungeon, through deck maniplation. And with some Arkham-style combat thrown in, for good measure. But acknowledging is not demereting the game, as the systems being used, and the gameplay, is very enjoyable and presented in an interesting fashion.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Overall a very enjoyable experience.The story unfolds through the cards, giving little glimpses of a plot that the game leaves to your interpretation.The combat in itself is pretty basic, but then again, there sholdn't even be action combat in this kind of game, so it comes off as a very nice breath of fresh air from the standard rogue-like game.The soundtrack is pretty sweet, the sound effects are never exxagerated or annoying and the dealer's voice is just perfect.The only really bad side of this game is in the last 2-3 story runs:While the game ups its difficulty by adding new cards and mechanics and presenting you with choices for its full (very enjoyable) duration, the last runs, especially the final run, is completely based on RNG and there is absolutely nothing you can do about it. You try and die countless times until you finally get that perfect run where everything just runs smoothly.However, that is only true for the last story run, the whole game is really enjoyable and the Endless Mode gives some pretty nice replayability.[Possible Spoilers Do not read further]The game ends in the most abrupt manner.You beat the Dealer, screen goes black, you're back at the starting screen.No cheeky comment, no ending, no nothing.It ends so badly that i actually thought i experienced a glitch, that some cutscene of some sort just got jumped for some reason, but that doesn't seem to be the case.And honestly after the phisical torture that is the last Story Run, i at least wanted some insight on the Dealer, the Player, the game, something, ANYTHING, but it just didn't happen and it tastes so bitter.

I love the atmosphere, ideas and gameplay yet the game design gets too limited when you move further in this game. You play the same fights over and over. You pick the same cards over and over. content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												The Arkham Combat System (ACS) is the weakest part of the game and highlighted by some of the relatively small arena spaces and somewhat stiff animations. However, every other mechanic of the game makes up for the ACS. Hand of Fate is an excellent, unique combination of gaming sytems that would best be described as the hidden mechanics of many videogame RPGs brought out and given a life via the cards and their 'choose your own adventure' dealer. The themes and art are great and the narration is fitting and well done. Aside from some personal issues with the ACS, I recommend this to anyone that is a fan of card games and Medieval-style RPGs.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Played this game since early access and it's only gotten better upon release.  This is a wonderful blend of deckbuilding, board games, and arena combat.  It features great organic storytelling with individual encounters stringing together a journey towards a big boss that you play in sessions.  The combat is smooth, fluid, and highly skill based.  You are dropped into an arena for combat and you need to fight, break guards, and counter your opponent to kill them before they kill you.  Outside of combat, you make choices and take chances to advance your story and unlock new cards for different encounters.It's a magical experience where you feel immersed in a world even when not fighting.  The game is very heavily RNG based, but I'd say it is more reliant on skill than other rogue-like games.  You can still get screwed by RNG, but you can survive a surprising amount through sheer force of will and skill.Musically, the game is superb, with memorable battle music, suspenseful main themes, and a very peaceful shop and certain encounter music.  The best part though is the narrator, who is equal parts friend and foe, your companion through the game who both tries to kill you, but also encourages and balances your experience.  Every line of dialogue from him is quote worthy and awesome.Graphics are...one of the games few problems.  Card art is great and even the 3d designs are cool, but it's a bit low quality and prone to clipping.  Numerous times I've played the game and monsters or my character will get caught in scenery or the character models will freak out rag doll style at the end of combat.  Most of the time its not game breaking, but it can be annoying.  And there are a few bugs that need to be worked out.  More than once, I've had my music and sound effects fail on me.These are minor annoyances for a highly unique and surprisingly addictive game though.  Highly recommended.  Fair warning though, the final boss is total BS and feels very unfair, so be prepared for a little frustration.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												I would like to keep this short, so here I go:If you are a fan of rogue-like dungeon crawls, deck-building/trading card games, strategy, sword-and-sorcery storylines, and a small dose of blind luck, then this game is for you.I highly reccomend it for people who like such things, but if you are hesitant, maybe wait until it's on sale. It definitely isn't for everyone, but don't listen to the people who say it's all or heavily luck based, because it's not. A good strategy will win in the end (I reccomend building your own deck, not using their pre-built ones).It has some minor glitches, so keep that in mind, but they release bug fixes periodically, which makes this okay.This is a good game to pick up and play either casually, or to get immersed in for hours.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												The way I see it, this game is like the best piece of dessert in the entire planet with a unique property.You have no idea that it *IS* the greatest tasting confectionry in history, but when you do consume some, your mind simply explodes with the indescribably wonderful flavor. But once you are finished with that bite, the memory of it fades, and you are left curious as to what it would taste like again. If you continue to consume it, you eventually finish it off, with none of it remaining, and you are left with only a stomach full of disappointment.The same applies to this artful game of chance, wonder, and imposing threat. When played in only single-run sessions, the curiosity remains as fresh as the day you bought this game. The possiblities of new events are ever enticing, to the point where you might lose sleep over the thought, "What if I HADN'T given that peasant some food?"Overall, I'd have to say this was a very worthy purchase. Best $20 impulse buy since The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Very unique, and interesting game and most importantly a lot of fun! If you like gamebooks (esp. fighting fantasy series), you will like this game, and if you enjoy RPGs I highly suggest giving this game a chance. You play as an adventurer who has to defeat a set of bosses that are like tiers of each other, but not really in a way making it repetetive. You collect cards that make up the game and put them in the main playing deck and basically yours are meant to better your chances, and the dealer puts in cards to make it more challenging. Its amazingly fun collecting the cards to unlock new encounters and the dlc is actually a rare dlc that does in fact give you something new, it adds cards that change the rules from the start which makes it a LOT more replayable.The artwork is GREAT, like I mean really, really good and the fights sequences gain a lot from that. I esp. like the tomb/crypt area when you fight undead. The real only negatives are that the fights can get a bit boring, but not really such a big deal....another thing is a pretty annoying bug that causes background card shuffle noises (pls fix!!!!) that drives you mad if you don´t restart the game lol. All in all great, unique title worth its money with innovative ideas and solid gameplay I rate 9/10

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												As someone that doesn't normally like card games? This is an excellent title. It doesn't focus on the "Trading Card" mechanics in the fashion you normally see in alot games where cards are the biggest driver behind how the game functions. The cards instead allow you to essentially fashion your own dungeon, allowing you to play the way you want to, with the 'dealer' (AI) adding in his own cards to spice things up. Rather than a coin-toss or RNG for encounters where something is handled outside of combat, you are given the choice of 4 cards, Huge success/failure or normal success/failure, with the number of each varying between different encounters (for example, 50/50 success/failure or 3/1 failure/success ratios). The nice thing about this is that, for players with a fine eye for observation, you can actually watch and see which of these 4 cards land where, there is also equipment that will highlight one of the failures in these 4 options. Its...KIND'VE akin to a boardgame, but at the same time it is also a third-person action RPG. Whenever you come upon an encounter that requires you to fight you are dropped into 3rd person view with all the gear/bonuses you have equipped. Combat style is akin to a mix between Fable and Assassin's Creed. Dodging heavy attacks (which become far more frequent as you get into harder runs or further in endless mode) or countering when a marker pops up over an enemy's head. Despite the heavy 'telegraphing' (icons/warnings when an attack is incoming), combat doesn't feel as simplistic as it is in Assassin's creed, where 90% of all fights can be won by simply waiting for a counter then pummeling your enemy while he is stunned. Recent updates/free DLC content (as of the 5th of March, 2016) added numerous extra encounters, equipment and certain 'profiles' for lack of a better term (the exact name for them escapes me now). These new 'profiles' offer both unique challenges and bonuses for playstyle. For example, there IS an 'easy' mode now, where you gain substantial bonuses, but many achievements will not be accessible while playing on that profile. Whereas on the 'hard mode', you gain an increase in counter attack damage, but combat moves far quicker, enemies do more damage and you start with 20% less health. One last example (of the more 'unique' profiles) is 'merchant guard'. Throughout each 'run', players can earn gold coins to gain food (1 food per movement restores health, each time you move WITHOUT food however, you LOSE health), this can be refilled in encounters or at shops littered throughout. One of the profiles requires you to go to each and every shop on the board before you can move to the next part of the board. While shops offer everything cheaper, you ALWAYS have to fight before you enter the shop, and ambushes are far more frequent. Overall, I feel it is a refreshing change of pace from many RPGs on the market lately, that being said, I will decline from giving this game a 1-10 rating, however for those that are looking to step outside the norm, but love fast-paced combat, I would highly recommend Hand of Fate.﻿

content:

												Think DnD mixed with RPG combat style and some rougelike elements and you have a basic idea what this game is.The idea is creative, the graphics are very well done and it works suprisingly smoothly. The game itself has some elements I was looking for in MMORPG games for far too long, like ministories that reveal themselves only when you successfully beat something that has nothing to do with the main story (or anything, really) and it is great to see a game that uses these mechanics so well. To me it is a surprise that virtual card games can be so engaging. Only problem with the game is that sometimes when entering a battle the crashes, but even that is not such a big deal since the progress is saved for every card you complete. I would totally buy a set of these cards in real life. With some dice and small changes like not saying the same text every time you get the same card this would make a great bored game.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I picked this one out on sale cause i thought it would be a good addition to my rogue-like collection turned out to be more then great i got hooked on it. The replayability is pretty high in my opinion since most other rogue-likes are meant to be clean and simple, and some publishers make fps and different kinds of rogue-like elemented games but most of them can feel very cheap even if with lack of textures or that feeling to want to start over when you die a couple of times, this one on the other hand oh well ill have some explaining to do.first of its a card game, dont get me wrong its not just a card game ill get into more detail soon, so you start of with your basic cards against this anonymous and rather mysterious man who gives you enemies to fight and adventures to explore and each card is rather unique and have some ''chance'' in them wich he gives you four random cards to choose from such as success,huge success, failur, and huge failure depending on what you get in the situation of the card you are bound to make profit of it or fail miserably and loose something.You do get to make your own deck out of three possibilities you get your weapon deck where you pick weapons you like or even new once and just throw a bunch of them into a deck, then you have your charekter deck this kind of counts as a difficulty system where each charekter has perks and effects the difficulty of the gameplay there are a few classes you can get wich are dlc's and this game is totally worth buying them for but if you are still thinking wether or not you should buy then i reccomand buying it on sale and get those dlc's cheap but the price of 25$ is a low bargain for the content in my opinion and should totally be in your inventory unless your broke,Anyways theres also a third one and this one is interesting indeed, you get to pick your encounters and adventures in this one, now when you start the game you start of with a first boss there are 12 in total and you get a randomly generated card placement on the board, you move your charekter along those cards and use 1 suplie for each movement you make and regenerate some health along each movement when you lend on a card you will read your encounter and he will interact with each card you land on he has a rather awsome voice wich keeps you interested at every step so as i mentioned you can land on acts wich you must either counter by ignoring or trying to escape or take the high roll and accept requests from a stranger or offer somthing for a totally random aproach from the person, there are people who can be trusted and not and its up to you to decide about that.now in some occasions he will offer you a token for some encounters and if you do them successfully he will give it to you, hell just whip it out and throw that stuff right into your very own bowl and you'll get to open them even if you die or beat the whole playthrough, now the tokens can be opened after the game and you will recieve random brand new cards to your collection wich you can add in for your next playthrough so after a few playthroughs you will end up having a bunch of new cards and you'll have so many options to make so much stuff to add and to explore.Now we get to the sweet part when you get ambushed wether its from a failure of a card or if its a card wich triggers a fight you get into a battle and are given all the equipment that you start with or if you have found some weapons in a story or just when you went on a stroll it will go onto your charekter and you''ll enter a fight where you control your own charekter and you can use weapon abilities on some of them wich will may aid you in battle, if you have a shield you can counter attacks wich is really helpful, really if you dont have a shiled its just going to make the fight harder so be sure to have one, you can also have abilities with alot of verity. the battle system in this game is really fun and the game runs smoothly. now after you beat up and smash your way to victory you'll encounter the boss wich will always have unique abilities or enemies to aid him/her, after you beat him you will recieve a token and you'll get the chance to open/break all the tokens you have earned throughout the run, after you beat three bosses you will always be awarded with an item of his wich will both give you benefits and make the game harder at the same time, and the mysterious man will always be more and more irritable and nervous, but hes an awsome guy non the less and will always be found likable in any situations.This sums up some of my experience with the game it has much to offer and discover and is probably one or of if not my favorite game at the moment. Im really pleased that i got my hands on this gem i give it a 10/10 dont just sit there buy it! :-)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												The Dealer is what makes this game. Considering you spend 95% of your time interacting with him and listening to him, if he was in anyway written terribly, or voiced terribly, then it would kill the game for you because otherwise, all you had was some fun quests and mediocre Arkham combat.Thankfully, the Dealer is engaging, hardly ever repeats his lines, and even then, his delivery is so snarky and full of personality and flavor, you don't mind occasionally hearing the same line again. He will have up to 3, perhaps even more, different lines for the same card, or same kind of card (like the Helpful Priest line of cards, where he shows his disdain of the clergy).The Dealer's performance is what sells and buoys this game, especially as the rest of its features and mechanics, while serviceable, really aren't much to talk about. Specifically, the combat is closer I think to Assassin's Creed, where sitting and waiting on the counter indicator to appear is the best way to go, especially if you put it on Hard Mode from the outset (which I recommend, as otherwise the combat pace is even slower and easier).I would recommend buying this game on sale. I got mind for $10 during 2015's Holiday Sale, and it's completely worth the $10. At its full price, I would have hoped that the combat mechanics be more polished, as they do bring down the whole package and presentation of the game.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												A very successful blend of tabletop gaming and hack n slash fighting, The in-combat characters could use a bit of variety. "Hellhounds" are just rats with a fire like texture over the top. That is my only gripe with it other than i've only played 4 hours and I've over half completed the story.Make no mistake though, the developers did an amazing job creating such a unique game and the positives FAR outweigh any negatives I can think of, and the sheer amount of possibility with the different types of cards/decks make for great replay value though the main story does feel a bit short.Many different types of cards to play with. The ability to create your own decks for each run and the overwhelming feeling that you are playing for something much larger than mere cards and reward but for so much more, will you become the next dealer? Let the games begin.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Hand of Fate is a good game, the simple brawler mechnics of the combat sequences are fun and challenging enough, like a slightly harder version of the Arkham/Batman games with far fewer variables or moves.  The narrator is amusing, the graphics cartoonish in a lovely way that pops on the screen totally appropriate for a game that is within a game.  The basic conciet of the game though is pretty briulliant - the player is playing cards against the enigmatic narrator who is some sort of dyspeptic frog voiced oracle or wizard. He's fun enough and he has new quips for most new cards, but I could I can see a DLC with a different dealer being profoundly satisfying - say a urbane devil, petulant child or defeatist death.  The card came is itself an adventure, with the randomly selected (you can build the decks though - within certian limits) card laid down and most cards offering a garphic of a charming woodblock image, a paragraph and a choice.  most selections lead to a pick and choose mechnic where four cards representing degrees of success and failure are shuffled monty style and the player picks one.  Other cards lead to combat.  In general when the player is successful with a card they gain a token that's convereted to another card at the end of each game.  Thus as one plays more and more choices are added.  It's fun, and for an "unlock" method of providing content feels very natural.Despite that praise, I almost gave this gave a thumbs down because even now, long after release (and to the developers' credit the seem to keep adding cards and content) the game seems to suffer from technical issues.  It lags, it slows and it crashes with alarming regularity on my laptop - which while no gaming machine is well above the minimum specs.  This isn't a general set of errors, more a steady degradation of capability culminating in multi minute load times for combat sequences or simply sudden crashes in the combat engine.  Whatever the cause these errors, they make the game frustratingly unplayable - becauase I want to play it and it's a good game.  I'm still giving it a positive rating here because when it does work (and sometimes it's fine) it's a very fun, very smart game.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Really interesting enjoyable card game that happens to have 3D combat as well. The combat itself is the worst part of the game and it's not that it's bad, just that if the game was based around the combat it would not be a good game. Apart from the combat being very simplistic and pretty easy, the rest of the game is great, the card mechanics and way the dungeon master tells the story as you travel through the cards is great. It is a game that you can play through in a short period of time but has a ton of replay value as you do challenges of event cards you unlock even more event cards and items to add into a deck to unlock even more. And despite what some might say of the cards being shuffled face down randomly and impossible to track, if you watch the 4 cards that start face up and then get fliped carefully you can actually watch where the card goes to, its just a bit challenging if the card doesn't end up on the top or bottom of the deck when its shuffling them because its a lot harder to see how the middle cards come out. But it is possible to watch reguardless. So while to some people the 4 cards may just look like a random luck of the dice pick, it is possible to pick with a fair amount of confedence of what your picking if you watch the animation.All in all, if your looking for a game where the story is told through cards with alot of different interesting events, with some light combat, this is a really good game. If your looking for a good 3d action combat focused game then this is not the game for you. The combat is the weakest part, but it doesn't drag it down to not enjoy the rest of the game. So if you think you might like a story told to you in a mixure of cards you travel through with a bit of choose your own adventure with each of those cards, and a shell game to resolve the choose your own adventure events, with light combat tossed in as well, then its worth getting.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												This game is AWESOME! It's a new take on an RPG that I've never experienced, that and the create your own adventure part of it brings back memories of the books I read as a child. It mixes RPG/Card Game/Create Your Own Adventure so well, I am about half way through the story mode, have yet to touch the Endless Mode but I definitely will after I finish the story. I couldn't stop playing, I put 8 plus hours in straight, minus roughly 1 hour for a break I took to eat and watch a show.Basically how this game goes (its awesome) is you sit face to face with the guy who created the game essentially at a table, he opens his cabinet of boss enemies and you must take one boss out at a time. So each journey you unlock cards, weapons, armor, blessings etc etc that become part of your deck. You can build your deck between journies. One boss takes you through a journey where you'll face numerous enemies, mazes of death, merchants, people that need help, all kinds of things. You get a choice to whether or not you are good or bad or you will help or you won't. You'll be rewarded in some way, either way whether that's good or bad. That's the create your own adventure part, gives you control of what choices you make in the game and the consequences of those choices. It's very cool.What is also REALLY awesome is you actually do battle yourself when you come across enemies or a boss etc, the cards dont just animate the fight, you'll take control of your character and have to take on all the enemies yourself, it's really fun. So the character (which you can look at anytime in the inventory along with your other goodies/curses/blessings etc) will change his appearance based on what armor or weapons you have equipped. You can counter enemies when wielding a shield and get various items that do different things, different weapons, helmets, armor, braces etc that have different properties, it's quite cool.This game is worth every penny, I can't say enough about it, one of the best games I've played in a long while. I'm glad a friend of mine told me about it.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												This game is one of the games that must be done long long time ago.You remember that games on forums when you just post what happens when you cross river and you roll the dice to see if you fall down or cross river?Or you meet a devil and make exchange with him and get screwed on this exchange?So here is game that is not on forum but it's all nice graphical styled.Whenever you step on event card you need to choose if you failr or not.There are 4 cards that define if you suceed:big sucess,sucess,failure,huge failure.Fights with monster are RPG styled what is AWESOME because you can control your character when you fight,you just not see a text that your hero take -4 damage due to hit,you just fight with monsters and can dodge attacks and fight against monsters,not see text just fight.Our hero looks badass:beard,pony tail,and manly face like a real adventurer.Dealer narrative every single thing which is nice because thanks to this it's not just quiet card stepping.And last thing,when I lose like half hp due to events dealer just say:"Ha!" and I was like:"F**K YOU B**CH I TRY TO WIN THIS GAME" with I found hilarious.Pros:+Endless mode,you can see how good you compare to others.+2 phased game.Card walking phase which is text phase and chances and fighting phsae which is RPG styled combat.+You can choose by cards if you will suceed in event or failure which is good because it's not random.+Tons of weapons,armors,blessings,curses,rings,shields.+If you want you can either kite and poke enemies or rush to they and fight like berserker by repeadly countering all attacks.Yours choice+Traps give a little bit spice to game.It's not only boring fight against enemies in fight phase but also dodging traps sometimes.+Dealer talks to us in every stepping a card.Thanks to this stepping phase not boring us.+Our hero looks badassCons:-Should be more bosses for longer story mode.I really like story mode.-Bandit bosses and skeleton bosses looks similar to basic bandits and skeletons.-You can select encounters that will happen during game what kills a little bit fun.-Finishing blowing enemies is kinda akward by jumping to it,it's looks unnatural.Overall score strong 7/10.It could be better but it's good in this stage.It's need only a little polish.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												This game is based on a clever idea - a turn-based card game with mini-arpg battles mixed in.  But the gimmick wears off after a couple hours. Many of the "chance" card choices you are required to make with increasing frequency later in the game don't really seem fair, and the penalties for not getting lucky are very harsh.  While this is somewhat entertaining in the beginning of the game, it can be frustrating to the point of making the game unplayable later on. Overall, I wish the game had a lot more fighting, and a lot less hoping to get lucky through picking arbitrary cards.  This is really the only mechanic that gives the game replay value; in that you hope you won't get terribly unlucky to make it to the next level.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Starts out promising enough; it's like a mixture of Thunderstone, a "choose your own adventure" book, and the combat from Arkham Asylum.  It's a rogue-like, but it's worth noting that there are checkpoints at the end of each "stage," so death isn't as punishing as it is in other games.  The narration is great, and deck building and choices are initially fun and interesting.  The problem is that the game gets very repititious, very quickly, and the strategies that you employ in the early- to mid-game completely unravel when facing the last stage.  (I won't spoil why, but it suffices to say that luck becomes a larger factor than skill or strategy during the final stage.)  Overall, I don't regret buying it on sale, but I cannot recommend the game at full price.

Early Access Review
								A very unique card game that transports you from the table into adventures/battles that are somewhat randomly generated by the cards that are dealt. The game itself oozes style and originality and is executed very well. I felt myself helplessly and gladly being drawn in by the great atmosphere, music, and voice acting that is top notch and very appropriate for the game.   I've only came across minor bugs as one would expect in an early release that were admittedly annoying at times. The game in its current state has an unrelenting learning curve that comes out of nowhere after the first few bosses. I also felt the combat tutorial was somewhat lacking as it didn’t explain everything you can do such as ground executions.    Other than these minor qualms I highly recommend buying it. I was very pleasantly surprised by how fun this game is to play and I look forward to future releases.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Hand of Fate is a game I've been seeing around lately, hearing a lot of solid words from trusted sources and fellow gamers, and of course some harsh criticisms, which is to be expected, but the one theme that keeps popping up is that it is addicting as hell. Combining elements from card games such as Hearthstone and Magic the Gathering, board games like Dungeons and Dragons, as well as RPGs like Skyrim, Diablo, and The Witcher, this game has all the elements to be the meth of gaming, a blend of a lot of different things making for a hell of a drug, but is it fun? Let's find out, shall we?Gameplay: 93/100 A-As I mentioned in the intro, Hand of Fate is a mix of a lot of different things, taking the best aspects of each and nearly seamlessly melding them into one, a feat that is hard enough to do separately, let alone flowing from one to another, but it is an achievement that Defiant have successfully done. Playing through the cards and planning ahead with equipment, magic, traps, all the standards that you can find in other card games, but then the RPG side comes in a bit as you can trade with caravans, should you draw that card, and finally landing on the combat, which is fairly simple to get used to. Attack, blocking, countering, all can be done and the game does flow like water over river stones in the spring time.Audio: 94/100 A-The sound effects and music is also done very well. It was never intrusive or overwhelming, Calm when it needed to be and action packed elsewhere. The voice acting has to be the crowning jewel here, where listening to your "trainer" felt real. For example, leave the game playing during a turn or when picking cards, he may start babbling or criticizing you for taking too much time. It's an organic feel that I really welcomed and made me chuckle a few times. The combat sounds and ambience is also very well produced, a solid effort on this end.Visuals: 94/100 A-Hand of Fate is good to look at, even at the lowest settings. There is of course clipping issues here and there, but I feel like that's going to be an issue in gaming for at least another generation and a half. Anyways, the colors are all done well and placed in logical locations, things look like they belong as well as drawing inspirations from all the genres that are mashed together in the game: medieval fantasy, gothic dark ages, D&D, it all comes together quite nicely, giving Hand of Fate a distinct style. Content: 95/100 AThere are a LOT of cards to play with here, easily competing with other big dogs in the market, both old and new, couple that with the other elements of the game and you're into a lot of replayability, but with that also comes some repetitiveness, and while the latter is annoying, it is also expecting in a game that uses themes from other games which rely on such a large selection of options and randomness. But the game works well together, keeping me interested even when things became repetitive. It is something you come back just in case that awesome moment happens this time around and you get that ultra rare thing you've always wanted.Design: 96/100 A+Like I said, the game flows very well together. Everything is done in moderation and not one aspect of the game overwhelms or overpowers another and I think that is the key to Hand of Fate's popularity, despite the often complicated genres that it takes inspiration from. A testament to Defiant's understanding of the multiple elements they've taken from.Performance: 80/100 B-Now we get into the issues I ran into. While the game itself is brilliant in combining everything together, the technical side of things are a bit choppy. Again, this is from my experience on my machine, got it? The biggest issue I had, first, involved the Steam overlay glitching and remaining on the screen when I took screenshots. Another issue was often times during the loading of the combat scenes took ages to load, often making me think that the game had frozen, only to come alive suddenly. There was some detection issues with the combat as well, but that could just be my suckiness at said combat. Not to mention glitches here and there bugged me in many ways, but the game is good, so I just learned to ignore them and kept going.Verdict: 93/100 A-At the end of it all, you can't deny the strokes of brilliance in Hand of Fate. The developers picked and chose the right things from each genre melded them together, where they would be most effective and instead of falling flat, it stands tall, albeit a little shaky with a lot of polishing needed, it is still a great start. The potential for this game is through the roof.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												I don't write reviews often, but i started writing this for my friends on facebook and accidently reviewed it.So here is my very positive review.Guys, If you ever wanted a game that supports Australia in the game development industry. I cant stress this enough.GET HAND OF FATE.This game is amazing.Created by Defiant Development, this game mixs a table top card game with a top down action rpg.After the tutorial, you have to edit your deck (or use a reccomended preset) and in doing this you choose what encounters, shops, weapons, armor and enchantments will be randomly drawn throughout the game.These items get reset every game, but you add to the total cards in the deck. Which means you have wider variety to build a play deck with.Each floor consists of face down cards. These are encounters. You have to move your token across these, one after another, down the depths to find the boss at the end of the dungeon.This part is similar to Nethack.Each time you touch a new card, you have to decide how to deal with it.Be it scaling down a cliffside to reach a weapon or an angry mob wanting to steal your food.Resources!In this you have 3 resources.First, obviously, is your health. This is gained each time you move or take a heal action through an encounter. Maximum health can be gained or lost through different successes or failures. Lose all of this and you have lost the game.Second. Food.Food is used to move. Consuming 1 food per movement. There are events in this where you can lose or gain food, sometimes lose all of it too, very harsh as i learned.If your food has fallen to 0 then every movement will cost -10 health.Food is gained through combat, gain cards or shops.Third. Gold.What dungeon crawler would exist without the treasure?Gold is used to shop with, buy off bribes or charity through events.Gold can be stolen from you and you can also gain it through events or combat.Now, this gets better. because you have a full inventory.Head, Armour, Hands, Weapon, Shield, Trinkets.Lots of combos that do lots of things.Some weapons have elemental damage that do extra to different creatures, or less!.This can be found in treasure chests through events, given to you, bought, sold.These items are preset into the deck by the deck builder, but you dont just get them, you need to EARN them in the game.Combat is simple and short, but enjoyable.The dealer will select monster cards (or you do, depending on the event)These monster cards will say things like Four of Skulls or 3 of Dust.The 4 of Skulls will summon 4 Skeletons. 3 of Dust will summon 3 bandits.The combat now moves into a character control, no longer a card game but a top down action rpg, think of Diablo and you will be getting close.Combat is a little clunky, but nothing to make this game anything of any sort of shabby.Some weapons have abilities like exploding, gaining damage through combos, do more damage the less health you have, that sort of thing.Some shields can reflect range damage back and some trinkets will do things like throw 8 daggers around you, some will activate and give you gold-per-hit and some will give you temp poison.The goal of this is to kill all 12 bosses in the story mode, all with a varying range of tactics.So once again, Want to support Australian developers and get something worth while out of it?Hand of Fate.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												God I really wanted to put hours upon hours in to this game and then give it a big ol' thumbs up but I just can't.I was loving this game for the first hour of play. It's fun, unique and satisfying though the combat leaves very much to be desired. It's slow, clunky and what I like to call "The poor man's arkham" but after a smooth first hour I'm suddenly bombarded with constant crashes to the point where it has become unplayable. I read on the forums that windows users should select the "Direct X 9" option on launch as it might help with the crashes but it only made them worse. Instead of the game crashing, my entire system crashed and blue screened...twice.I haven't had a blue screen in a very, very long time. I take very good care of my PC, I make sure everything is always up to date software wise and it gets maintained and checked on a regular basis ,hence not having had any blue screens for a long damn time but in the space of twenty minutes I ended up having two while playing this game.PC SPecs:FX8350 Black16GB RamR9 290X Strix 8GBWindows 10I am beyond confused with this whole blue screen shenanigans (And judging by the forum I'm not the first to have had this issue when it comes to this game) and it's such a damn shame because I was really enjoying myself.[I wrote this review in December of 2016 and stopped playing. It's now February of 2017 and I have not had a single blue screen since I stopped playing this game. The game has an issue which causes your computer to blue screen and the only "support" the developers will give you is "It doesn't cause blue screens"]

												It's a decent game, but the devs made some very apparent shortcuts in that outside of combat there is practically no animation except for flipping cards and a man waving his hands around.Still, the combat is solid if a bit ugly with a camera that is very lkely to hide enemies in the corners of the arenas you fight in.Progression in this game is the typical "Throw it at the wall until the wall stops being there" in that you can very easily jump through walls of cotton and silk but the moment you face a hedge of thorn bushes 2 meters deep except in random places, then the game stops being funny, unless you only play the game for the little fighting and a lot of lucky draws there is. Beleza???Vamos ver um pouco do que é Hand of Fate?Esse é um jogo que mistura deckbuilder e tabletop card game com ação em terceira pessoa, RPG roguelikish e pouquinho de sobrevivência.A apresentação do jogo e animações são elegantes e fluídas, e apesar de o gráfico não ser top, é melhor que qualquer coisa que já vi na engine Unity.A trilha sonora também é maravilhosa e esses 2 elementos provocam uma incrível imersão no jogo e no mundo criado pelo jogo.A variedade de cartas parece bem grande e interessante.A geração do ambiente de jogo é baseada nas cartas escolhidas pelo usuário mais as adicionadas pelo... cigano ou sei lá... mas o posicionamento aleatório faz com que cada partida seja única.O jogo mistura sorte e habilidade de uma maneira bem cativante.A parte de combate do jogo é um pouco fraquinha, com animações meio lerdas e pouca dinamicidade, mas a aleatoriedade do jogo acaba por adicionar um pouquinho ao combate com skills de armas e artefatos, além de efeitos passivos do equipamento.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Floor 3, do I chose to run from the angry mob and chance keeping all my remaing food but risk losing it all and thus succum to the subseqent inevitable starvation? Do I risk searching the remaining cards on a floor in hope of finding better equipment but risk losing everything trying to cross a river, leaving myself bare of armour and weilding only a rusty axe when it comes to challenging the deck boss? These are just some of the many difficult decisions you will face in Hand of Fate. Gripping dialogue and voice acting straight from the off. (The voice actor of the dealer is superb). Immense replayability and customisation through the use of the randomising deck system. Challenging bosses, enemies, events and decision making. I have not seen a game that can blend card based gameplay, with RPG elements such as your equipment, curses and 'artefacts', and actual in game combat. (One criticsm would be the combat system is a bit, well lots of rolling around randomly dodging enemies whilst mashing the LMB...But theres potential for a more substantial combat system in the future, furthermore this is only a minute criticsm in my opinion and should not overshadow the vast quality and diversity this game offers). Icant wait to see what the developers include in later patches and updates, perhaps character facial customisation? Some sort of tech-tree or research tree to go alongside the RPG aspect of the game? Hope everyone, developers included if you are reading this, found this a useful and honest review. Definately recommend getting your hands on this game!

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												Mixing cards, D&D setting and Arkham Asylum-like combat couldn't go wrong now, could it?Short answer: Yeah, it can.Long answer:You get to build a deck of cards: Encounters, shopkeepers, stuff, curses, blessings and such.I really wanted to like this game. And I definitely did. And still sometimes do. But there are far too many things that keep me from fully recommending this to you. So, good things first, the setting is part of what I liked. The ambience the game sets is pretty cool and involving, while not too extravagant. The game master's taunts and comments might be redundant in the long run, but they're still well made and help the player get into the game a bit more. The way you unlock new cards and encounters with tokens, pretty cool too, makes you want to play more and more to unlock more cards and move deeper into the different storylines. The game system, nothing complicated, but making it simple is what makes it work : You move from encounter to encounter, spending one food at a time, healing a bit while doing so. As I said, it's simple, yet allows you a bit of planning when you look at which way you'll go.What could go wrong then?First, the encounter themselves: While having them randomly placed on the map makes sense and allows for replayability [GOOD RNG], most of them involve luck way too heavily to be amusing. You just pick a card and see if it's a success or failure, which can lead to frustrating events (looking at you there, devil's carnival) at worst and not so involving at best [BAD RNG]. I understand the need of randomness in such a game, but I wish I could have a heavier impact on it.And then the combat, oh my the combat. Arkham Asylum wasn't incredible and definitely was too easy, but it was nervous, fast paced, and pretty to look at (most of the time) because of its dynamic nature. Hand of Fate's one is just plain boring. At first it might seem enjoyable, because of the equipment possibilities and monsters that you imagine will come against you, but after two hours you've seen most of it. It's bland, slow-paced, not hard by any mean, unless the game's RNG decided to ♥♥♥♥ you up and stack everything against you (curses, loss of equipment...). Seeing that it's supposed to be an important part of the game, it's sad to see it fail to convey the atmosphere of epicness the games tries so hard to set.That being said, understand that this game is fun, but that you won't have fun for more than a few hours at best, therefore I don't recommend you buying it at full price. Wait for a sale, don't pay more than 10 bucks for this, really.tl;dr : Yes, I'd recommend this game, but for no more than a few bucks.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												overall - great game, But do not buy it as a hack n' slash game.hand of fate offers a pretty unique experience, melding cards, adventure, combat, and a bit of role-playing. This game does not do one of those things terribly well, my opinion, some may argue. What it does do well is make the whole situation work, all of these elements together, how random and unsyncable they may seem, come together to make a really interesting experience. I would compare hand of fate to a very simple table top game, munchkin perhaps. You get a map made up of cards, which are adventures, meetings, shops, curses, and eventually - an exit from the current map. Each game has a certain amount of maps, and then you get to the end, where instead of an exit, you get a boss. So far, the boss has been an upgraded version of one of the vanilla enemies, with a twist. The combat is boring at best, but this is coming from someone who has difficulty capped 2 souls games. Honestly, I give the game about a 8 right now with the boring combat. The narrative of each game makes up for it, I would really almost prefer a table top combat to the hack n' slash that they have. more strategic, maybe involve rolls - but that might ruin the balance they got going, so i dunno. One thing it does need is a workshop for endless customizability. Also, I would be over the friggin moon if they figured out a way to make multiplayer work.

number of helpful: 13 of 29 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Been playing games on Steam for nearly a decade now. It is June 25th, 2016, and this is the very first game I have ever requested a refund for.The game is trash, disguised as a treasure. It seems like a lot of fun on the surface, but once you get about 3 to 4 hours in, you realize that none of the decisions you make matter at all. You follow the same tired formula of "choose to do nothing, and nothing happens, move on to the next card" or " choose to do something and unlock a token, which unlocks a new card". Return to beginning of the loop. There is not a modicum of skill or involved, and very little decision making. Every "success" or "failure" is literally you drawing randomly from cards that say "success" or "failure". You can try to follow them being shuffled, and sometimes that results in success if the same card stays on top twice in a row... but really, it's just pure luck of the draw. Once you realize you're playing an RPG on rails, and your choices don't matter... it gets bad. When you then realize that it's just pure luck to hope you randomly pull the one "success" card out of four cards, so that you can advance the storyline for that one series of cards... it becomes absolutely, insanely frustrating. And that's an awful thing to feel, playing a low-key, deck-building RPG.The only good things I can say about it is that the production value is quite high. The writing is very good. The art is good. The voice acting for the dealer is excellent. The core idea of trying to merge these RPG, deck-building, action and rogue-like elements is really quite innovative and is what lured me in.Unfortunately, the gameplay just wasn't thought out in the long run. It is not fun to fail over, and over, and over again when there is absolutely no mechanism in your grasp to try to prevent it. It never goes well in a video game when you remove every semblance of control or input from the player's hands. At the end of the day, you'd be better off just clicking "roll" over and over on a random number generator. That's pretty much what's happening here.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Fun concept, horrible execution. Game is interesting and enjoyable for about an hour or two but once you're past the first few bosses every run turns into a slow and tedious slog as each one adds more and more events that are basically just boring static debuffs that you don't get any opportunity to mitigate or avoid. Every time you finish or fail a run it sends you all the way back to what is essentially the title screen and you have to sit through a million unskippable animations and spam through a million clunky menus to start the next run. The dealer's voice acting is good and enjoyable until hour two when you realize you've heard the exact same lines twenty times already and you're sick of constantly being forced to wait to make actions until he finishes saying the entirety of his 15 second tangent about fate which wasn't even interesting the first time.The combat just gets worse and worse as the game goes too, they throw more and more guys in but the arenas are all tiny and there camera is fixed so you get tons of guys attacking you from onscreen and all the enemy types and especially the later ones have terrible animations that all look the same but are randomly unblockable. There's also really inconsistent bullet time slowdown to try and make your attacks look cool but it just makes your character look like an idiot as he slowly floats through the air swinging his axe while enemies just walk around and set up attacks at normal speed in the background. The combat system is standard Arkham-style Simon Says stuff but it's the clunkiest version of any game to use it and nothing about it feels good or consistent.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Updated: 7th July, 2015I love this game and want to have the Australian developers' kangaroo babies.The game mechanics are difficult to explain, since I've never seen any game like this. You get to pick half of the cards that will appear in the game ( your favourite weapons, armour and positive encounters ), the computer picks the other half ( rusty weapons, monsters, curses and negative encounters ).The computer shuffles your deck with his deck, this creates true procedural generation. No two games will ever be the same. The cards are placed, so as to simulate floors in a building and corridors.This is Kenuty's excellent Early Access gamplay video:


YouTube™ Video: Hand oF fate 

			Views: 1,235		

			Hand of fate play for steam This is pretty raw footage of me playing with a mic and actually talking about the game and playing it, so please excuse the sensitive mic noises and the bad play, wasn't...		

The combat for the first few quests consisted of simple attack and parry but scaled up to "God of War 1" meets "Golden Axe" with: tumble, shield bash, magical weapons and magical artifacts.There are 12 different quests. It took me 20 hours to finish three quarters of the game ( at which point I had only unlocked a little over half of the equipment cards and half of the encounter cards ie. the game is massive ). It took me another 20 hours to finish the last three missions because they are brutal. I highly recommend this game to hardcore gamers!If you want to make the game easier or harder, there is a "Wildcards" expansion that will do that: The voice narration is eloquent. I thought that it was narrated by Jeremy Irons but it was voiced by Anthony Skordi. The dialogue is immersive and teaches you the game mechanics on the fly, as you encounter the different cards.Northern Lion: "Let's Look At: Hand of Fate!"

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												Addicting.... very VERY addicting.I asked the forums if the game has any solid replayability and I believe it does, a lot of it actually.  But the review..The Good:Addicting game play, obviously I mean who doesn't like card games and rpgs and dungeon crawlers and blah blah blah you get up grades that do different things and they do them well.The gear assortment is pretty neat, lots of different piece of gear that have little thing here and there like extra life if you heal or a sword that can shoot frost all at the touch of a button.The random encounters are also really cool from the Elf Maiden to the Priest or perhaps A fallen hero, lots of different encounters with rewards.there is a lot more but I have just scratched the surface.The Bad:Not really BAD but kinda annoying so be ready but some random encounters are BAD like falling rocks... damn rocks I mean you would figure the guy could dodge a falling rock but NOPE! you get 1 chance to succeed in this actiong to avoid the falling rocks and if you don't it hurts... A LOT.FOOD!!!! for the love of everything everywhere bring FOOD! if you have a chance to get food some where TAKE IT omfg if you run out you are now running on Health until you die, try fighting a boss with 14 health I had to change my underwear.On the subject of random encounter some of them have pretty bad optins as far as how much you can succeed like 1 success and three failure or even one Huge failure, it makes the game interesting but still fresh into the game it can hurt a lot.Difficulty ramps up pretty quick.. once you get past the first gate things become more dangerous and you can die.. like dieing in a trap maze to a bush -.- yeah there is a defining moment for you you died to a damn bush a BUSH! ANY WAY...All in all this is a GREAT game and I am REALLY REALLY glad I got it, I hope the game take off and adds more content because wow... I love it and I have like maybe a few hours at the time of writing this.  So if you have any doubts DON'T this is worth the money 100%.. now excuess me I have a bush to go take care of... giggity!.  (I mean the one in the maze >.>)

content:
Posted: January 4
												Despite being a fun time for several hours unfortunately I cannot recommend this game due to some bugs which causes the game to freeze while loading monster encounters. I've played through 3/4th of the campaign but this issue becomes more apparent in the last quarter, and also in endless. The gameplay itself is solid, but I feel the chance of success is a bit too random (at least in hard mode) and unlike other games where you have other ways to offset chance (for example multiple ways of dealing with enemy encounters or pathing through a dungeon depending on resources), the only real way to succeed is getting incredibly good at monster encounters. Deck customization doesn't influence the game much when most cards follow the success = food, failure = pain card + battle formula with roughly equal chance for either. Additionally, the lack of food forces the player to rush to the exit more often than needed.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I usually avoid Early Access games because I'd rather make sure I'm getting a whole game and to avoid spoiling anything. I picked this up as part of a bundle because Extra Credits said it was worth the look for its uniqueness alone. Boy were they right. What they left off was how delightfully fun it is. It takes what could be a boring basic premise and dresses it up in just the right way to make it fresh and engaging. The voice acting (and the writing) is nigh flawless. The visual design is never stunning, but always full of loving detail. The setting sits right between being broad enough to feel deep and repetitive enough to feel symbolic. What's more it's always explored indirectly as a side benefit of progressing through the game mechanics itself. Rich with theme, a pleasure to explore, and with more to come, you'd be hard pressed to find a better choice for that distraction game you've been needing.

Early Access Review
								It's an interesting mix of deckbuilding, exploration, and action.  Build your equipment and encounter decks, then explore the randomly dealt map of encounter cards you put together, hope to earn equipment from the equipment deck you built, and use it all to hack'n'slash your way through baddies and bosses to unlock more cards!  It doesn't sound like it'd mesh but it really works well.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Being a person who like procedurally generated games, this of course immediately got me interested when I saw it.At it's base this game is a part RPG, part action combat game, slight part deckbuilding game.The game is broken into adventures which get longer as you progress and unluck the next adventure. Before embarking you can put the cards you have into the encounter and equipment decks which will be used during the run. Some cards are locked for the specific adventure, some cards you may not know the effect of until you've encountered them in game at least once. For some adventures there are special circumstances like more damage from projectiles or taking damage if you carry too much gold at a time.Once you've started the game, the narrator will deal out cards to form the dungeon floor you're on. Either your target is on this floor, or there's a stairwell to go deeper. You move one card at a time either horizontally or vertically using food as you go. Each card is an event, some with just text, others with battles. It does lend a good feeling to this being an adaptation of a card game and you're playing against the deck out to kill you.If you enter battle, the world changes into 3D for a battle sequence flowing a bit like the Batman games or Asassins creed, though without the vertical element to it. Initially the combat feels clunky, maybe it was just the state I played it in, or maybe it owes to the fact that I didn't get a shield until later and didn't realise there was a dodge roll button either. The combat can be a bit tricky to see at times, but otherwise feels very satisfying connecting with your mace or warhammer.In all this is a nice game with a bit of randomization. It carries the atmosphere of playing an engrossing cardgame quite well, and breaks up the text events with a robust battle system. It gets rather tense when you're down to one food hoping you'll run into a merchant or a treasure chest with food in it, and it can really ruin your run when you have little health left and run into a tough battle you were hoping to avoid till you'd regained more health.As for negatives: There is some text to read in this game, so if you dislike reading, skip it. Maybe down the line it'll all be narrated, but for now it isn't.Also you will encounter the same card and thus even several times over your playthrough. If you're the person who want new stuff constantly, this might put you off. As it is, once you know an event by heart you can usually click past it and get the effect you'd like. And of course you can alter the frequency by removing some of them from your deck if you so desire.The camera can be a bit tricky in the action sequences. I only found it got in the way of fighting once or twice, but if you're the kind of person who demands manual camera control or perfect viewing angles, this is not the case here.Lastly: I played this game using an XBox 360 controller, it works quite well. I don't know how well a keyboard and mouse setup would fare, but so far I've not found any ranged weapons so the 8-directional movement afforded by Keyboard should be sufficient if done well. Just know I have not tested this.

number of helpful: 11 of 26 people (42%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												This game is good...not great. Hopefully with some dev tweaks - it could be really excellent.It's very innovative and well done. Graphics are pleasant, the concept is refreshing and the execution is...well...it's ok.Some of the positives:1) Great concept. This is a card game and a button masher. It's not an RPG. There's no levelling of your character, no stats to decide in which to invest, no classes, no abilities.  It's a card game that unfolds into button mashing sequences based on the cards that are randomly drawn. The mix of card and action elements combined with a fantasy/D&D type setting are neat and are done well.2) The game is polished. The graphics are nice, the voice acting is very good, the presentation of the encounters are well done, etc. It's a well put together game with nice artwork, GUI, sounds, etc.Some of the negatives:1) The cards PART 1. For me , I dislike the card designs greatly. The devs chose to go with a basic brown card with black text - and it's drab. The rest of the game is graphically very colorful and interesting. I realize the card design is going for an old parchment feel - but it just seems uninteresting to me. I could have done with some interesting edge work, slight color tints, or edging...something. There are tons of card games out there and the cards themselves are always something of great time and effort in the design , sometimes even with collector editions, gold versions , etc. 2) The cards PART 2. For some reason, the devs thought it would be interesting to "lock" cards. When you get them, you don't know what they do until you come across them in your journey. This makes the whole part where you get cards at the end of your journey nearly pointless. When you complete a card/journey, you can get a token , and at the conclusion of a journey your tokens are exchanged for cards. The cards turn over on your screen and all you can do is look at the title and picture and wonder what they do....unless it's something you already unlocked. Perhaps this is fun to others and not to me, but I compare to Hearthstone - when you open a new pack - you can instantly read the description of the card - and start understanding if you should be excited about it or not. For a portion of the game where I feel getting new cards should be very rewarding and exciting - it's not. It's actually quite tedious as I have to turn in all my tokens, get my cards (which I don't know what they do) and that leads me to #3.3) Deck building. The same issue rears its head in building your deck. You can have many cards that are locked - that you don't know what they do - but if you want to know what they do - you put them in - hope to draw them during a journey - and hope you like it. That's really not a design choice that is rewarding to me. 4) Help. The game is easy to grasp once you play - but at the start - nothing is explained - and there is no good on screen help. An example are the tokens. It wasn't at all clear that a token was on the card, and that upon completing that card - you get the token - and that at the conclusion of the journey and beating the boss - that you get all the tokens you collected along the way and turn them in for cards. It also wasn't clear initially that you lose food each time you move, or gain health each time you move. You learn this super fast, but a tiny popup or something would be good. In fact, there's a couple different token shapes - still not sure the differences between them all.5) Easy + Repetitive. The game is fun, but so far, it's very repetitive. After just a couple journeys - I've run across the same cards over and over. It's also the same pattern - card, battle...card, battle. The battles are also the same for me...roll, x,x,x....roll, x,x,x....roll,x,x,x.....win.  I'm about half done with the game, maybe it gets more complex , but so far -it hasn't.In summary, it's a neat game...it's solid. There could be more done with the cards and the deck building to make it more interactive, but its repetitive and the card element isn't rewarding enough to compensate.Update: Saw there is DLC 1 month after release - so , since game is decent, but was on the fence, am going with not reccomended since DLC immediately after release is a money grab.

												This game is so close to being great. Sadly, it rather misses the point of a deck-building game and actually gets worse as the game continues, getting harder while providing no tangible way to compensate for that with its mechanics. You have no true control over your deck, the odds of drawing anything, or any way to build a real strategy with your cards, as you're restricted to certain card minimums with no way to modify the variance in your favor. It's a fantastic idea for a game I'd like to see done better in the future.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Great idea for a game, but unfortunately, the more you play, the more frustrating little things that didn't seem too terrible at the beginning become.  The biggest failure is the combat system.  Being able to use your mouse to control the direction you move would be great, but instead you're limited to A,W,S,D as though you're just a piece on a chessboard.  That doesn't work so well when you're surrounded by bosses and add ons in a tight space.  I saw some of the unlockable achievements being to fight X number of battles without taking any damage.  Yeah, right.  I'm all for things being more difficult the more I progress, but as others have commented, the difficulty spike soon makes the frustration outweigh the enjoyability factor far too quickly.  I've tried to love it, but the more I play, and the further I move along, the more likely I am to delete this game, count my blessings I got it on sale, and find other, more enjoyable games to play.  Hopefully the developers will read through some of the negatve reviews and continue to revamp the game.  Great idea for a game, but still needs a lot of work to deservite its "Mostly Positive" rating it currently has.

number of helpful: 16 of 37 people (43%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Quite a fun little mismash of genres - Up to a point. Hand of Fate lays deckbuilding card games, roguelikes, action brawlers and choose-your-own-adventure books onto the table and shuffles. The end result feels surprisingly fresh and innovative, even though none of the individual components would really stand on their own.Initially, the game works wonderfully because of its brisk pace and laidback feel - There seems to always be something new around the corner and the game is just a joy to play. However, as the end draws close, the difficulty is suddenly amped to eleven and the game turns into a grind. During the last few rounds the deck is so stacked against you that even with immaculate play, you can still lose terribly.Yes, I understand that the game is a roguelike and you're supposed to die a bit, but going from not dying at all for 90% of the game to losing twenty times in a row is just poor balancing and design. A shame really, since with a bit less punishing difficulty curve Hand of Fate would've been a surefire recommendation. It delivers innovation, fun and respectable production values, but eventually turns into a plain old Three-card Monte.

												I wanted to really love this game, but I feel like there is some big room for improvement.First, I must say that the concept is great. It makes for interesting and variable playthrough. I think with a few improvements this could easily turn into one of my favourite games. So the big problem I had is that the combat became very dull and one dimensional about halfway through the game. I felt like as soon once the number on enemies faced in each combat scenario got high enough I ended up just tapping the counter key constantly and could not do much else, and without a shield the was no hope of completing more than a couple of combat scenarios.The deck also started to feel unbalanced partway through the game, which I suppose added to the difficulty, but it seemed like too many cards had a 75% failure or epic failure chance with signifcant consequences and samll chance of reqrd, which was frustrating at times.I think encorporating a bit of dungeon crawling could really liven things up as well. Rather than just being thrust into an arena for each combat, creating a larger level where you could approach the enemies and the combat situation in multiple ways would really improve the gameplay.I am a bit torn about recommending or not recommending this game; I still think it is an interesting concept and worth a playthrough, but there is definitely a lot of room for improvement.
