content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												This game was almost good.I understand that this is not a AAA game. I'm fine with the memory hogging, the stuttering in fps here and there, even ok with the combat not being that fluent when a lot of attackers are attacking at the same time. Even semi-ok with a few of the button prompts in combat popping up a bit late (after it's to late to actually block).I'm a bit less ok with some other stuff. Like the camera, seriously why even make the game 3d if you can't control the camera (also WAAAAAAAAAY to zoomed in)? Just make it isometric and use 2d graphics a lot less work same result, probably better. Why can't you skip past some of the shuffling, I was removing event cards that I almost liked just cause I don't want go through 4 pick this card events...Even with all the above I would have recommended this game to my friends, cause I enjoyed playing it (on hard) progressing through the sometimes quite unlucky near insta fail runs... until...Last boss 1 shot insta fail QTE from 90 hp with heavy armor. ♥♥♥♥ off. There are several games with instant kill QTE, none of them without continues/saves or similar and none without it being a regular part of the game mechanic. Tossing this in on the final boss is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, seriously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I'm sorry but I will not be buying any more games from you guys, cause I can't in good conscience support game design like that.Whomever made this design choice shouldn't be designing games.P.S. I actually made the QTE (but still died from it).

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Unfortunately I have to give this game a thumbs down, for now.  tl;dr - It does a lot of things well, and starts off fun, but the difficulty gets extreme enough to make the game unplayable as anything but a suicide simulator.It frustrates me that I have to give a negative review to this game, because it was really fun when I started playing.  The animations were nice, combat was fun, the voice acting was great.  It was a really well polished random adventure generator game.  The basic mechanic of the game is that encountering cards generates an encounter, whether combat, puzzle, story, what-have-you, and completing the card will unlock that card's token, which will in turn unlock more cards to add to future decks.  It gives a good incentive to try to encounter many cards and figure out how to unlock more.  Quite cool.  As you progress in the game, unlocking more cards, you will also encounter bosses.  Beating them unlocks the next boss card, and after you beat enough bosses you will unlock an artifact that gives you some bonuses but will also make the game harder.This is the point where the game goes wrong for me.  The difficulty increases introduced by the artifacts make the game virtually impossible by the end.  It was not unusual for me to start a game and the very first card would be a combat against a prior boss, 9 of their minions, on a trapped battlefield with an accompanying totem.  There were so many high powered threats my brand new out of the box adventurer had no chance to win.  What makes it worse is that there's no going back.  Once those difficulty spikes are unlocked, they affect the whole game, retroactively.  If I go back to the very first boss of the game, my first encounter on that level might be the aforementioned impossible fight (and was, the time I tried).  The fun of the game, of running around kicking bandits in the face and solving problems for townsfolk became overshadowed by a constant string of deaths brought on by unwinnable fights.  There's an easy mode that gives the player some benefits, but activating it disables achievements (gotta punish those filthy casuals) and you can't access any of the other character archetypes in the game, which locks out almost all of the games replayability.  Currently the only solution to get rid of the difficulty spikes is to use the 'Erase Progress' feature, which you don't realize until it's too late.  Now, after playing for 12 hours, I'm forced to decide to either erase everything I've accomplished or give up because the game is unplayable.  Neither of those choices make any sense, and are a big part of the reason I can't recommend this game.  There's a great premise here, and the underlying system is really, really cool, but it becomes difficult to the point of impossibility and I've got better things to spend my gaming time on than dying forever.  Should the devs put in a way to disable the artifacts, or otherwise customize the difficulty of the game in a way that doesn't lock out every other character option, I will revisit this review and hopefully change it to a positive.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Hand of Fate is a silly, pretentious game that confuses originality with bad ideas. No matter how charming the presentation may be, the core of this game is rotten and bland.Everything you do in this game is connected to combat. The equipment you collect, the spells you learn and the encounters you get through. Which would be perfectly OK if that combat was any good.You will fight a bunch of monsters in tiny arenas over and over again, using a dementia inducing combat system.If you do die, you will die due to either RNG from encounters (-50% HP and similar events), or to traps. Not because of your skill level.Don't get fooled by lets plays, it might seem like fun after the first hour or two, but it's really not.

number of helpful: 7 of 19 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Original concept, but too many flaws.The camera point of view is absolutely horrible, up to the point of being unplayable sometimes, especially in the trap maze and with large enemies.The game's difficulty curve is broken. The first 3 tiers are extremely easy, the last tier is suddenly hard. One wrong curse card can nearly instantly kill you.Too many encounters are based on luck, instead of skill. Not quite like rolling the dice, but close to it.Certain playthroughs become impossible to complete because of the above. Nothing you can do about it, except retrying and hoping for better luck.Equipment is not balanced. The most important piece is the weapon. Almost more important than the other equipment pieces added together. Also, most of the blessings are of little use.

								This game has a lot of good ideas and some really good implementation, and up until you beat the Jack of Plague you will be having a great time. It only goes downhill from there. content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Other reviews are more in depth and they echo my thoughts, so I'll be consiseThe atmosphere is 100% perfect. It draws you into the world magnificently. The dealer is perfect.. however that's not the whole game. What destroys this atmosphere is the gameplay..Once you're about 2/3rds into the game you'll realize why people left negetive reviews. The combat remains simple and unrewarding, however the monster HP goes up as you get better items to your deck. However you don't start with those items, you have to be lucky enough to find them. So monsters are now punching bags, and every time you run into a combat card you sigh from exhaustion. The end game is just brainless masochism (and I've beaten the castlevania, ninja gaiden, and Ghouls n Ghosts trilogies). You lose because of dice rolls, and the odds aren't in your favor. The final battle is depressingly boring- just a repeat of old bosses and the final boss is just a QTE.I gave the developers months to change it, but they haven't. I recommended this game to many of my friends and I honestly regret it once I saw the full game.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												I was looking forward to playing Hand of Fate after reading some of the reviews. This wasn't a gameplay style I'd really indulged in before and when people have a lot of love for a game I'm immediately drawn to a title; unfortunately after a short dabble I was feeling left out of the group of people who seem to have nothing but positive feedback to add to a list of admirable blurbs.It may be one of those things where I just don't enjoy or even get the style and my intention isn’t to deride the reviews of people who seem to adore Hand of Fate. Unfortunately I was left with a feeling of dull disappointment and a small hole in my pocket after just over an hour of learning the mechanics. Don't get me wrong I'd happily pay my last cent for something enjoyable and the concept is refreshing but everything else was just overwhelmingly average. Gameplay was OKAtmosphere was OKIt looks OK Controls were OK (if not a little clunky)The music and narration are well put together with the aid of a great fantasy style voice actor but even after just over an hour play time the gameplay quickly became repetitive and irritating. I so wanted to love this game; generally if I’m excited by something I’ll be anxious to return to it or navigating obsession but the idea of having to return to this does feel like a bit of a chore.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Would you like a game that combines deck building like Magic and hack and slash like diablo meets streets of rage?  Well so would I and this game falls far short of the mark.  The deck building is pretty pointless as there seems to be no strategy to it at all.  There are no synergies to be exploited so what's the point?  All it does is give you the space on the board to play and some equipment that the RNG will deem fit to annoint you with or screw you with.Then you have encounter cards that have you picking between four cards with success or failure.  This is such a lame feature I have no idea how it got into the final game.  Maybe somebody is a big 3 card monte fan or played persona 3 too much.Then you have the combat which basically entails whacking a couple guys, some dodge rolling and the occaisional counter telegraphed by the giant green symbol above the enemies head.  Wow.  Excitement it is not.  They try to spice it up with throwing some traps in the levels but all that does is make the combat even more tedious.  I beat some boss called the Queen of Dust with a rusty axe  (thanks RNG) by just running around in circles and then just whacking her after her unblockable attack.  It makes fighting the lamest enemies in Dark Souls seem like Swan Lake in comparison.So let's say you die during a level.  Well you get to keep any cards you get and then try it all over again.   Great.  It's a grindy game as well.  Sorry guys, the actually combat portion of the event is not fun enough to warrant any sort of grind.  Maybe if you made the levels bigger and it were more like a streets of rage type level (waves of enemies) instead of an arena level based upon a whack and roll mechanic it may have been more fun.tl/dr  Not all new ideas are good.   The equivalent of a deep fried salad.

Posted: August 18, 2015
												This game blew my socks off... for the first 4 hours. Then it all came to "Ooo. this boss can summon a cannon." As a long-term investment of your time, Hand of Fate lacks in repeatably entertaining and engaging content, as well as giving you less of a satisfactory, job-well-done feeling when you finish a level as when you build your first house in Minecraft. This may not apply to all people, I realize, considering that, for me, this game was the first deck-builder I have ever played. Still, this game gets boring after about 8 hours of gameplay, leaving you unwanting to finish the whole game and yet feeling like you haven't finished the job. Still, those first 4 hours were fantastic.6/10 For those first 4 hours.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												The artwork is very pretty.  That's about the only positive thing I have to say about this game.It is *intensely* boring.  If you want to make a card game, make a card game.  If you want to make an action combat game, then do that.  What you have here is a very mediocre card game and an extremely mediocre action combat game put together.  If they had given up one concept they might have had enough resources to devote to the other to make it good.Here's how it works, you build a deck of equipment, bonus cards and encounters.  And then the game master lays some encounters on the table face down and your game piece "walks" across them, you pick the next card to walk on, and frequently you have only one choice.  Each encounter is either a choose-your-own adventure style multiple-choice question with a bit of random chance thrown in, or a "battle" if you can call it that.  Each battle is a mouse mashing clickfest.  The mechanics are stunningly bad and you can't even rotate the camera which is very annoying because some of your opponents will run off camera where you can't see them.That's pretty much it.  Card after card after card, monotonous battle after monotonous battle, all accompanied by the narration of the game master, whose mouth is masked but unfortunately not gagged.  The lines are delivered by a capable voice actor, but they are so vapid, uninspired, and ultimately irrelevant that eventually they just become annoying noise that you have to sit through.Sadly, there is no "shut up" button in evidence, maybe somewhere in the options?In any event I only played about a half hour or so... if you're bored in 30 minutes it's a really bad sign I figure.  Anyway, I guess it's not a game for me, and listening to other people rave about it, I am clearly in the minority. You may enjoy it, I recommend going on youtube and watching someone else play it for an hour.  If after that you are still interested, you'll probably love it.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												The critical foundation of any fantasy card game is the strategic use of cards. It's the development of your own customized deck. Combining cards in your customized deck to provide multipliers in combination with other cards, for use against a specific opponent. Hand of Fate is the most perfect name for this game because literally there is no strategy in developing your own deck, it's all left to Fate.Issues-Right off the bat, getting the chance to pull an equipment card is so rare, the whole point of having a customized deck is almost useless. The default size of your customized deck grows every level, decreasing the chances of you pulling any one card. For instance, I believe the start deck size is near 20 cards and since the chance of getting an equipment card to pull is less than once per level, this means the chance of pulling any one card is less than 5%. It's almost as if the dev's intentionally made the user deck larger as you advance levels, as a way to nerf the effectiveness of the cards and having a customizable card deck, in an attempt to make the game more difficult and stretch the game out. If this is the case, it's a bloody shame because its sacrificing crutial gameplay in an attempt to balance. If you guys want to play a really good card game then I suggest going to Pokemon or Hearthstone. There is a reason they are so popular because they are REALLY REALLY well done.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I really want to give this game a positive recommendation. Its innovative card / action battle structure has all the makings of a totally addictive and fun experience. I want more cards, want to find out what they do, and am on the edge of my seat with every move forward onto the next encounter.But there are two really big flaws, which I suspect will limit how much time I put into the game. The first is a clunky and sometimes non-intuitive interface, with lots of unnecessary and repetitive micro-pauses. Every time you hit a merchant, you have to wait for a few seconds as the game transitions to the same 3D rendering of the merchant cart, before you are allowed to get on with the transaction. Fine the first time, really annoying by the 20th time. Ditto with shuffling the cards before making one of the game's very frequent 4-hidden-card choice routines.The second big flaw is the tactical combat. It just feels fuzzy, with a lack of precise control over your character that it already turning me off. It's not like Diablo 3, with it's crisp and immediately responsive controls. It's more like playing Diablo 3 drunk while wearing ski mittens. I would have preferred a crisp isometric 2D action sequence, or even a turn-based battle approach, rather than the sluggish and woozy 3D battles here. Maybe some fine tuning is all that's needed to turn this into a very fun game. For now, though, it's not going to be on my play a lot list.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												This is a case of a great idea with a poor execution. In general, the cards seem to be poorly planned for how they will actually affect the player - but that is the least of this games problem. The one, huge, fatal flaw of this game is the combat. It is the worst combat/action of any game I've played in a good while, and for a game that seemingly without rest throws combat at you all the time, this isn't good. This isn't good at all.It's a matter of 'press Q to block', and 'left click to attack', without the ability to use the mouse to choose directions - yes, they didn't even manage to implement something as simple as that. The camera is also set, so you can't really turn the angles to get whatever perspective you want.Though to be fair, the game isn't exactly terrible... I'm just... Dissapointed. I read the warnings, I ignored them because it looked interesting, and I paid the price.

Game is goregeous but there is no depth - unless all you care about are beautiful animations. Most encounters and I know they are early-on game levels -- where over in less than a minute for me. Beautiful game poor execution - I enjoyed the repetative battles more than the card mechanics. @ Dev Learn from hearthstones - don't just reinvent the wheel.Good talk on GDC by the way.

												Cool concept; limited entertainment value.I purchased this game after reading a number of positive reviews because I was intrigued by the concept. I enjoyed playing it for approximately one hour, at which point the novelty wore off. The game became extremely repetitive and offered few, if any, chances for succeeding because of strategy. Combat is a little clunkly and not enjoyable. I found myself getting agitated every time I encountered a combat situation not because it was difficult and I didn't know if I was going to survive, but because I had no desire to endure yet another few minutes of spamming the left mouse button, q key, and space bar.Quite frankly, there's not much left to say other than after your 60 minutes of enjoyment you will experience a prolonged bout of depression stemming from the money you just wasted on this game.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												The thing that you have to understand about Hand of Fate is that it is NOT a "deckbuilding" or "card game", even less than Ticket To Ride is a train simulator. In both cases there is some thematic resemblance to some other genre, but really the core mechanics are thoroughly different and in order to enjoy yourself, you need to understand what the game really is.In order to qualify as a "card game", the primary device of the game should be cards. In a typical card game, you might have a hand of cards to select from, or you might play cards to achieve certain effects. On a mechanical level, Hand of Fate is instead more like a roguelike beat-em-up. A game consists of a series of randomly-selected encounters, most of which culminate either in a 3d third-person combat scene, or in a "select the good outcome" shell game. Your goal is to plow through the encounters, managing your resources of health and food, to get to the end, where you fight a boss. Hand of Fate uses "cards" as its theme and narrative -- encounters and equipment are represented by cards, and you can customize the "decks" before play -- but otherwise it bears no similarity to card games whatsoever.But despite that, it's still an enjoyable game. Some encounters unlock other encounters, and there's a certain charm to trying to focus on some resource like food in order to try to be in a good position to "win" some encounter. Of course, it can be extremely frustrating when you're all set up, only to get wiped out by an unlucky "draw". Like most roguelikes, it can be punishing and it has quite a bit of replay value.The biggest problem with the game is tedium, which sets in around the 400th combat. I'm not sure if it's something about my computer or what, but it takes a long time to "load" certain of the (admittedly quite beautiful) encounters, and many of the combats cease to be challenging after you've played them enough. Because so few of the encounters give you resources, you need to be pretty lucky to have a round where it's even possible to "beat" some of the final encounters. And of the encounters that do give you resources, many of them are combats, which (again) lose their charm after a while.All in all I'd probably give HoF a 6.5/10. It's entertaining (and somehow I'm addicted to it), but you can safely skip it.[N.B. This is before the recent update adding "fates", so maybe things have changed a little bit.]

number of helpful: 5 of 17 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												TL;DR: Hand of Fate is two repetitive, hardly innovative, unfortunately vague, sometimes-working games stuck together in a way that's at least pretty. Don't buy it without doing your homework.FULL REVIEW:Hand of Fate boasts an aesthetically gripping melding of two unlike games into a single experience that varies from unplayable to underwhelming. On their own, each of the ‘games’ of Hand of Fate fall far from being worthwhile. Together, the card game and the three-dimensional fighting game intermingle in a way that works just enough to keep players invested in a fairly transparent skinner box. Players are subjected to a deck-building card game that rewards repetitive play with a larger card base and challenges players through proper resource management. Game-to-game rewards are meted out through a shell game that is either too easy or too hard, an aspect that belies the RNG nature of the card game. Overarching rewards are given after successfully completing ‘token’ cards, which have a variety of conditions to complete (some of which are obvious, some obscure, almost all of them lacking explanation). Common issues of RNG exist and are easy to overlook, but there are some more severe instances such as stumbling upon very difficult encounters too early on that force a player have to quit a run of the game or even completely reset their progression overall. Card balance is a huge issue, with several cards being outright stronger than others regardless of situation. Furthermore, the encounter deck that the player must create is a vague collection—there are no indicators of what the encounters do, and some encounters seem variable in their options and outcomes. This makes constructing an encounter deck a chore of either looking up each card online or simply not knowing what each encounter brings in terms of challenge and reward unless the player has drawn that encounter several times. Hand of Fate seems to beckon players to experiment to discover what works and what doesn’t, while punishing players every time that it does not work out both in their current game played and across multiple future games.The fighting game, unfortunately, has even more severe issues. Combat is without weight, several mechanics of the system go unexplained, difficulty of encounters has to be inferred, some arenas are far too unforgiving, and so on. There is a simple system of click-to-attack, click-to-counter incoming moves that’s been popularly attributed to the Arkham series of games. Here, it barely works, as most encounters find the player vastly outnumbered by enemies that constantly attack. It is often difficult to even land two attacks in a row on an enemy without being interrupted in some way, giving combat a hectic and choppy flow. Camera angles can be a detriment to properly positioning the character, especially as some arenas feature traps and enemies can attack the player from off-screen. There’s a rolling maneuver that the player is intended to use to avoid several of the heavier attacks in the game, but the roll often comes out too late and does not offer much in terms of defense thanks to aforementioned issues along with painfully awkward hitboxes. Enemies take far too many hits, with the exception of when the player has specifically itemized to defeat an enemy type, and then combat becomes laughably easy against said enemies. There simply is no middle-ground, though. To further frustrate things, rewards are tied to number of monster cards drawn rather than individual monster difficulty--sometimes beating four skeletons can be just as fruitful as overcoming ten skeletons and a boss you fought before. Overall, combat is a mess, ranging from repetitive and easy to punishingly difficult thanks to a culmination of issues that are out of the player’s hands.Throughout the whole of the game, there simply is a lack of clarity—how much damage am I actually doing? How much damage does my gear reduce? What does an ice-cone attack even do? Is holy damage only extra-effective against undead? Who are these various characters? What does this encounter card even do? What is the purpose? Too many aspects are left to be inferred, both in terms of narrative and mechanics (an appendix would help, even). Oft-times, I find myself recursively fighting through boring encounters, hoping that I actually win the shell games this time around, so that I can unlock more shell games and progress to just being done. There isn’t a gripping narrative arc that makes me want to continue to play to the end. The gameplay from moment to moment is droll and forgettable. There’s nothing that stands out.This all goes without mentioning the several issues the game has just running. It outright crashes on startup, it crashes when loading some encounters, it sees framerate dips on some machines; so on and so forth. Thankfully, the support team for the game has been working on patching out and addressing these issues, mostly via their forums.This isn’t to say it’s all bad. I’d be kidding myself if I said the style of the game and the goals it sets out for aren’t awesome. There’s a very strong aesthetic that permeates the game just as there’s something refreshing about having these two genres put together in such a way that one doesn’t get too boring before the other takes over. Sure, dialogue gets repetitive and lore is a bit sparse at times and obfuscated at times, but it’s charming and interesting when it isn’t.All in all, Hand of Fate is promising, but lacks polish. There are plenty of options that can be fixed, plenty that can be clarified, and several aspects that can be advanced. Sadly, it seems that a complete overhaul would need to be done to each of the games that exist within Hand of Fate for them to work on their own. If you’d like to pick up two flawed, repetitive games that can distract from their flaws and repetition by means of alternation, go for it. If you’re a sucker for how a game looks rather than how it plays, buy the game like I did. If you want a worthwhile playing experience that’s rewarding outside of just earning more stuff in the game, though? Look to spend your money elsewhere.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Find armor and weapon upgrades, then have them all taken away.  Travel past lots of shops and have 0 gold available.  I certianly enjoyed the first hour or two of play time, but as the levels became longer, and enemies tougher, all the gear I had collected just became more scarce and it would fall on me to complete entire levels with my starting gear, whlie being endlessly penalized along the way.  After the fourth or fifth level this became nothing but an edurance challenge of apathy, as I knew any good items I found along the way would only be striped from me, yet again, when restarting.I certainly don't want to mindlessly disparage the developer(s).  The game art is beautiful, the concept wonderfully original, but after a while I realized finishing levels became more of a coin-toss than much with skill.  And the odds were heavily stacked against me.  I called it and uninstalled.Since I must weigh in one way or the other on whether or not to recommend this game I'll have to say I do not.  Certainly not for $25 USD.  As of right now, I feel anything over $4.99 would be over-priced.  That's certainly not a reflection of how much effort and work has gone into the game; no, that would be much more, it is very well polished.  But five dollars is about as much fun as I can honestly admit to having.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												The advertised feature of this is the combat.It is relentlessly shallow.You press a WASD in the direction of an enemy, and then left-click until a green icon appears, and then you press Q. If a red icon appears, you press space.That's it. That is all that there is to combat. WASD to an enemy. Left-click if no-icon. Q if green icon. Space if red icon. You do not need any weapons or powers to defeat every level without getting hit once. This is almost a good game. But the combat sequences are the worst part of it. They're also the hyped feature, which leaves this being a trashy gimmick. Oh and, by the way? If the crummy combat wasn't bad enough? You also gotta wait for it to load into each one. The worst part of the game takes the best part of your time.There's a bit of fun with exploration, cash and food. But you will never, ever, ever, run out of food. And the cash bonuses are who-cares weak, because they only affect combat. Which, again, is so easy that you've got to be mentally-deficient to actually take any damage during.There are occasional trap-gauntlets. Those are sorta fun, just because the controls are so wonky that it's basically random whether you'll get hit or not. I almost came close to getting halfway towards fifty-percent of my health, in a trap room that lagged like butt, one time.Just pass on it.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I do like the concept of the game and I want to make clear that this is not a bad game, it is however not a very good game either and I can't recommend it in its current state.This game is a mixture of 3D Brawling and a pen & paper card game.The p&p part is the "strategic" part of the game. You navigate through a grid of cards which are spread out on a table, face down.Each card represents a "step" and is revealed once selected, these cards tell a story and can have positive and negative effects. You can find equipment, be blessed, cursed, walk into traps or get assistance on your journey.Once in a while you encounter opponents you need to fight which brings us to the combat.You enter a tiny 3D combat arena, facing enemies specified by the card revealed.The controls are limited to attack, stun and dodge, if you have a shield equipped you can additionally block ranged attacks and counter melee attacks. Combat usually takes about 30 seconds to a couple of minutes.All this sounds great on paper but there is major caveat which runed my entire experience. The game is trivially easy or impossibly hard and unfair.The campaigns can be completed by simply hitting "enter" all the time moving to the next card. Your strategic choices hardly matter because combat is practically an extended QTE sequence. Block when you are told to block, counter when you are told to counter and tumble when you are told to tumble. Since the combat is trivial, any choices you make improving your combat skills by buying weapons, armor and shields, seem irrelevant and of little consequence. After a while I simply stopped buying stuff, skipping any treasures or risky opportunites for improvement, since they are simply not required.After a while the difficulty does indeed increase, however, not because more skill is required but simply because the combat is clunky and insufficient. You will encounter situation in which you will take damage no matter your equipment, because you are forced to react quicker than the games combat system allows you to do.So again, your equipment and skill do not influence the combat but chance and luck are the dominant factors.After the third or fourth campaign you are allowed to enter "Endless Mode" which does up the ante a bid since the cards no longer have to match your level of development. While challenge went up a bit, the meat of the game did not change, it is still playable by simply hitting "enter" all the time and having a small QTE sequence every now and then. The game has potential, I do like the idea, but for now it is not worth 20 bucks.

Posted: February 21, 2015
												There's so much to love about this game and I absolutely wish Defiant success with it, but I can't recommend it at the present. I love the graphics, voicing and concepts but the input method makes it awful and unpleasant for me. It's as if it started off life as a console game, was converted to PC and no-one bothered to consider how interacting with the game could be made a high quality experience for PC users.Keyboard input during combat is a recipe for repetitive strain injury and horrible control. If HoF had a remappable click to move system for combat (Diablo, PoE etc) that lent itself to putting the mouse click on say a Nostromo thumb wheel and counters etc to the keypad, I would recommend it - as it is, regrettably I don't recommend it to those who don't use a controller.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Well, I love the game.. it's so unique.. but I will have to say one thing.. once you get past the first row of games, it becomes virtually impossible to win one.  That can be very discouraging.  it's like there is a very hard line between one row to the next with very little chance to get the new cards you need to make yourself stronger before these big fights happen.  Don't get me wrong, it's amazingly unique and I love a challenge and I recommend it if you don't mind constnatly losing early on.  The first row of story line was a decent challenge but after almost 20 attempts I can't get past the first one in the second row.  iF you go back to do an earlier one it's still harder because you passed the first row challenge... and less cards to work through in the game because it's early.  I can't decide if I recommend it as a whole or not just because of that one aspect.  So I'm going ot give it a thumbs down just to call attention to this in hopes that there is something that can be done to fix the almost impossiblity of moving ahead. Maybe it's the cards I ended up randomly winning that weren't so hot or something.  I'm sure some have gotten past that of course but I'm a long time gamer and these controls and concepts are not beyond my abilities.. ther is no way I am that bad at gaming that 20 attempts won't get me past that 4th game

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Made it all the way to the last *stage* so to speak, and I'm never playing this game again.Why? Completely unbalanced random BS utterly destroys any momentum you can build on your own. Too much the game is bogged down with random curse cards that leave the outcome entirely up to chance. Too often I have a good run going, then randomly I get attacked with three curses that destroy my health or give me a stupid handicap like making it so everytime I block I use up food (WHAT!?).And the combat, ugh the combat. First of all, it's basic Batman combat, but it's done rather poorly. Many times (EVERY BATTLE IN THE END GAME) I'll be evading one attack only to have another enemy attack me mid-evade, which I cannot avoid. Screwing me over. And the arenas are so small that in many cases divide and conquer is impossible. Oh, I'm pretty sure this game would be impossible to play if you're red/green colorblind. So keep that in mind. A great idea destroyed by lazy design. Avoid.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												TLDR: This is more of a unique random arcade game than an RPG. I recommend this game for playing but not for purchase. I like this game but I can't recommend buying it because price. I wouldn't have it at all if it hadn't been in the humble bundle. If it was always at that price, then yes, but otherwise your money and time is worth more.Full review:Since people reading these things love to blame the players for anything unflattering they read about a game, let me get my conditions out of the way. I've been playing on normal with the default fate or whatever and I'm almost exactly half way through the story mode. (one card over half) If that makes me unworthy to have an opinion in your opinion then stop reading.This game feels like a good indie game. This game is rather fun but it is in no sense an RPG. There is no real character building, even cosmetically. Everyone gets to be the same biker looking pirate dude and everyone gets the same starter garbage.This game qualitatively defies genre placement. Roguelike would definitely be the closest fit in the sense that you have a near totally random set of contexts and events. But the deck building aspect, the essentially unchanging arcade beat'm up combat, with quicktime event counters (that I never ever get to execute because crowds), on top of a turn based almost board game layer, just moves you so far away from the typical roguelike and any other concrete genre definition, that you start to question all the labels.Each encounter card is more or less trying to be a minigame, and the major story objective cards require a build up of power in order to have a prayer of victory, but since each card is trying to be a minigame you have some chance to fail at all of them incurring weakness, damage, loss, or simple failure to gain. That's fine in a vacuum, but the upshot of this at the larger scale is that you very easily fall into a rut where you are playing slots, just dying over and over hammering at token cards hoping they unlock stuff that will slightly improve your RNG odds at the deck building stage. But still, even then, because each card is trying to be a mini game, and victory requires a string of RNG victories (unless you're just a total twitch kill/counter/stun battle ninja) progression basically becomes exponentially unlikely.And that's the important distinction here, the difference between difficult and unlikely. Gamers generally I find don't understand the difference between challenging and difficult and unlikely. They also conflate various aspects of time investment, practice, luck, game play, micro management, actions per minute, command inflation, grind etc etc.Difficulty is about making choices and experiencing varying levels of game response to them. Probability on the other hand is about pulling the handle till you get 3 in a row. But getting back to this game specifically, yes in theory I could train to become a battle ninja, and I could train to be a spreadsheet flow chart probability ninja when it comes to deck building, I could train to be a shell game card shuffle expert, but even if I did all of them the RNG gods are probably going to screw me a consistent percentage of the time.What I'd like to see:The main thing this game definitely needs is a character creation step, even if it's just a choice of prefabs and a name box. Something to emotionally invest me in and link me to the character. I picture something like so many points to spend and you can spend them on anything from cards to stats. Some cosmetic choices would be awesome as well. Nothing wildly complicated. Think Torchlight 2. Maybe some low intensity long term progression, like the badass points system in BL2. I'd also like it if endless mode had everything in the game unlocked by default.Comment policy:I will delete any crap that annoys me for any reason. Life is too short as yet to endure being tormented by morons.P.S. If you don't say stuff the dev likes, you get banned from the community.

Early Access Review
								Hand of Fate is a good concept and has good potential. A player gains cards to add to a deck that is used to randomly generate a "dungeon" that must be expored/fought through to reach the end card which is a boss creature. The graphics are very good and the card system is creative. However, the game gets quickly repetative especially on creature encounters. All fighting encounters are basically the same and once you learn what choices benefit your character on cards tht allow a choice you can avoid negative effects easily and make easy gains. The game is a little slow in playing as you jump back and forth between encounter and card dealer. While the concept is solid the game play needs revising. While Initially the game interested me and the reviews I read lead me to beleive I would enjoy the game overall I was disappointed. The current price of the game is to high for what you get, perhaps once the game is finished it would be better.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Caution: This game is not out of beta! Don't let the 1.0 fool you. If you buy this game you are buying an early access title, and a broken one at that. This one has been on my wish list for a while, but I have been burned on early access before, so I waited for the full release (ha!).  My first hint that something was a little ♥♥♥♥y was on the opening screen when it told me to hit the X box "A" to start the game. I get that this is a port over from the console world, but it strikes me a lazy and shoddy to not change those X box icons out for the players on PC. Whatever…not a deal breaker…I hit "A" (enter) and I'm put into cinematic of a hooded and masked gent levitating cards. Very spooky, great ambiance. However, the scene is ruined by the fact that his mask is glitched, and doing backflips as it clips through his head!( http://i.imgur.com/gyxRdyK.jpg) I'll let some glitches and clipping go on the final release on a huge game like GTA, Day Z, or Skyrim; but this game has one guy and he is bugged in the first 5 seconds of the game.Again, this is annoying, and not something I expect out of a game that claims to be out of beta, but it does not ruin the game. So let's talk gamplay. . . but wait , I can't play the game!  I have been playing mouse and keyboard and I have yet to find any way to navigate on the main game board, inventory screen or merchant screen. I can only click on what is highlighted as the first default option.  game: "choose one of these 4 cards"me: "number one"game: "you can fight 40 bandits, 5 bandits, or 2 bandits"me: "40"game: "you can jab yourself in the eye with a fork or have 500 gold"me: "well pass the fork because I CAN'T CHOOSE ANYTHING ELSE!"This is maddening; table flipping, rage quitting, neighbors calling the police maddening. Underlying all this is a nagging feeling like I'm somehow ♥♥♥♥ing it up. I'm not a casual gamer, so I'm assuming I'm not making some sort of "keyboard not plugged in" type of obvious mistake, but after hours of trial and error I have concluded that the game is either broken or requires actual telekinetic powers as demonstrated by the dealer to be able to play. I'm going to assume that I'm intended to use the AWSD controls to navigate, but these do nothing. I have sat in the inventory screen and pressed every button on the keyboard and mouse, and nothing will navigate. No way to select any weapons or armor, no way to pick different cards when I have any multiple card choice. Nothing but accept, or exit the game.This game is still VERY broken and if you pay for it be advised that the "1.0" "not in early access" is a total lie.

number of helpful: 8 of 28 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Hand of Fate 

			Views: 212		

			Hand of Fate is a Card Game mixed with A 3rd person Dungeon Crawler, Rouge like experience on Steam here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/266510/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if that is your...		

	Hand of Fate is a unique combination of adventure/card/rogue-like withwell done audio, and decent enough graphics.  The character you play as is amale warrior, so if you're hoping for a female character or a different styleof character, this may not be the best game for you.  I give the game devsprops for creating a card based game that is expanded, and pushes the envelope for a new style of game, and they did it well, but did they do it well enough?	Each level is an individual dungeons where you follow a path of cards, at the end of which you fight that levels boss.  This game wouldmore appropriately be titled 'Hand of Chance', as the random elements thatmake up a rogue-like combine with the card game elements to make an experience that relies more on the luck of the draw rather than skill or strategy.  	You start over on every level, and by that I mean you lose any itemsor money that you have, making every dungeon its own mission.  This negates the impact of dying, as you start the level fresh. The only loss you have would be of time spent playing.  	As to the equipment cards you have for your deck;  it is unlikely youwill be able to play that perfect card you need or want during a typical dungeon; of the 28 cards I had in my collection, it would be generous to say that I  saw 10 during any one dungeon. Obviously you want to have more cards that are chosen based on what you enjoy, but overall the gear or weapons in your deck become less important, due to the small chance you will actually see them.	Every level is randomly selected, which may give it a new look and feelas you progress forward, but it takes away control or any sense of power as there is no choice in where you go.  The randomization of what gear you may get combined with the random level you may end up on, and the random number of traps on that level can determine how well you do on a level.  The combat was not challenging; a matter of mashing the  mouse button and dodging when the green light flashes.  Skill and tactics play no part in the battles, only having the correct timing.  This gets quite boring very fast after a few battles.	This game boils down to chance;  equipment, levels, perks, relics,weapons, traps, all is dependent upon the chance that you get the right one.  There is no tactical challenge in this game; what combat there is is simplisticand offers no challenge.  If you're looking for a casual game, and like cardgames and rogue-likes, this may be for you, but if you're looking for a gamebased on skill rather than chance, I cannot recommend it.This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watchif you are looking for a more in-depth review.Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here:http:/www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								-A Pretentious Roguelike That Likes to Think Itself A Much Higher Station than it actually Is-I like roguelikes, hell, I love roguelikes. And the Pretense of thise game is pretty cool. Whereas most roguelikes have been a crutch for relatively rookie developers to lean on while they find their feet. This is no different for these guys, except that they managed to hire a voice actor to say things in their game so they've decided they're big time. Although a lot of roguelikes are very similar this one is really quite similar to Faster Than Light. They both have the same format of traveling from point to point and facing random encounters. But when it comes to combat once opts for a top down RTS approach whereas Hand of Fate goes for an Arkham Series hand to hand combat schtick and I'll give it that, the combat is ok. It's smooth enough, there are some bugs which should have been priotities to fix even for an early access game (They're doing UI tweak patches now so they must feel they're near the end).   The main failure of this game is in between. The narrative of Faster Than Light is simple but direct. You come across a situation and you decide what to do. You weigh up odds, what your crew is like and  the outcomes to your decisions are rational. Stupid decisions get you killed. Whereas in Hand of Fate, everything is reduced to a game of 4 card trick to see if the outcome is good or bad. By the time you have enough information to weigh up the pros and cons of what you are doing, it is too late and you have to pick a card. Cards are deceptive and irrational. You will not be rewarded for being cautious or brave, you will either be lucky or unlucky and in Roguelikes I like to feel that my judgement and my skill as a player is one of the major factors in defining my progress. If I wanted the experience that Hand of Fate provided I could just roll a D20 and punch myself in the nutsack every time I rolled a 5 or less then play 5 minutes of Arkham City every half hour. Early access isn'r responsible for these problems. These are inherent failures in the decisions made by the game developers and their determination to drive home a pretentious card gimmick at the loss of things that actually make the game fun. Especially when a single run can take upwards of half an hour with a slow iteration time and poor communication. There are plenty of Roguelikes out there that knock this game into a cocked had. If it's in a humble bundle or on sale for like $3 I guess you could buy it, but otherwise there are plenty of better games made by better developers who could use your money to make better games in the future.

number of helpful: 6 of 24 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								While I love the concept of the game, it needs alot of work. Likes:Basically you have 2 decks; yours and the card master. After the card master adds more cards to the decks, cards are "randomly" laid on the table in a path or area setup. You move your token to each card or choice of card and it can be a good or bad, you continue this until you reach a card that takes you to the next level or the named. Dislikes:There isnt a character builder to set gender/age/skin color, etc.. Who wants to play an old, mostly bald, white male with no abilities in combat? There isn't a choice of tokens to represent the player as he/she transverses the card levels.The tutorial fails to correctly explain how the cards work.  Example what the red dots on the monster cards and card tokens mean, deck building mechanics, how food/gold really works, curses/blessings etc... While you can choose what cards you have the chance to get and what encounters you will face, the game always skews towards the extra cards the cardmaster added.The combat interface/controls/movement are rough at best and past the 3rd named the number/type of monsters is overly stacked against the player.  It's disappointing that no gold or equipment you gain in a level carries over to the next. So you start each level with limited food/gold, nearly defenseless with a rusty axe attempting to battle 10 or more creatures in a small area that has resetting traps using jerky controls on your first movement. You are saddled with a curse that drains your gold that you can never afford to get cured. You barely have enough to get food if you ever get a merchant card.The game as it stands now isnt worth purchasing. Hopefully there will be an update addressing some of the problems.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												This game is like going to one of those Japanese Hibachi restaurants when you're starving. All you want to do is eat, but you've got to sit through the whole production before you can get any food. You go in to sit at a table and the chef has to make small talk while you watch him try to flip morsels of meat into your tablemates mouths, you have to endure the stuipid onion volcano trick (wow great job) and finally, twenty minutes later, he scrapes some rare steak onto a pile of rice and since you're starving you go hog wild and eat everything you've been given in large mouthfuls. Finsihed with your meal and still hungry, you're handed a bill that seems entirely disproportionate to the amount of food you actually got.A deck building roguelike you say? Make my own deck and then fight through it? Wow this sounds awesome, here's $25!And then you download it and you have to wait every turn while the stupid dealer cinematic plays and he sluggishly deals the cards out onto the table, making the same remarks every time he deals a particular card. There's combat in this game, if you can call it that, since it's about as fun as a QTE and just as challenging. This game would be awesome if they had more card variety and they removed the third person combat and (especially) the whole sitting-at-a-table-playing-cards-with-a-wizard gimmick.This is a very bad game. Do not buy this.

								Hand of Fate is something new. It has some gameplay that I havent seen before. But the elements it uses are very familiar.The game revolves around a deck of cards which are shuffled and then laid out to form a path that you need to follow to the end. Every card will give you a challenge which depends on luck or combat. There are also some exceptions to this rule if you run into a shop or if you end up in a maze of traps to get to a treasure. Besides going from card to card you will have to keep an eye on your health, money and food. Every step you take costs 1 food. If you land on combat it can cost you food and if you land on a shop you can spend your money.The main reason for not recommending the game is the combat. Although it's definetly not the worst implementation of a fighting system in a game, it doesnt feel fluent enough to feel good. As this game is still in Early Access it might improve, but for now I wouldnt recommend it based on this element. This has also to do with the price point of the game. For a game like this around 10EUR seems to more fitting.5/10

content:
Posted: March 9
												I bought this game through Indie box so my hours on here aren't fully representativeThis game was everything I hoped it would be.The music is more ambient than instrumental, but I think that compliments the game well since most of the action in this game comes from the cards the dealer gives you. In that vein I've never felt like I was given an unfair situation when a card was flipped. There's also a simple progression system where as you complete levels, win challenges that are bet on by the dealer and other events you gain more cards to build your deck using. You don't know what the new cards do until the first time you draw them in regular game play.In this game combat is handed through you using equipment cards you draw or buy from the various merchants you may encounter on some cards using gold you collect. The enimes you encounter depend on what challenges you end up facing and what enemy cards are drawn. You replenish health either by healing or each time you travel while you have food. The only complaint I have about the battle system is sometimes you end up soft-stunned if you get attached by a bunch of enemies at the same time.Very solid game!

								This game has a very unique aesthetic that I personally really enjoy, table top games are personal love of mine. Game play focuses on you overcoming an enemy deck with your own crafted decks choosing what encounters you will find on your path and what rewards you will receive.  With an active combat system based on the batman series it keeps things fresh from the non-active story telling moments. A healthy amount of RNG to keep things fresh. Works sort of like a single player DND in some ways. Thing I love most is when entering combat how the cards actually physically appear and create your gear gives a very good vibe of connection between both parts of the game. The price point a strong plus, cannot wait to see the finished product.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Magic, mystery, twists of fate, and lots of deaths awaits you. All guided by a man you need to trust but really shouldn't, as he is out to kill you for the last and final time.  The 'Dealer' awaits you to enter his domain, waiting to shuffle his deck of Fate, and draw an enchanting journey from its heart.What is it:It is kind of hard to explain. It is cross between Munchkin and Fable without bright humor, it is Fable without the Open World. Your equipment is collected like Munchkin, with the cards you collect through the encounters you meet. Every time you die a 'Game of Fate' you start over again, all cards reshuffled and your hero back to square one. However, not all is lost: Progression is made whenever you beat a 'Game'-boss. This and succeeding in other encounters will earn you 'tokens' which unlock more encounters and/or weapons. These new cards can be added to your deck to change your adventure. Some encounters are part of a chain, some sort of side-quest, with all its own mysteries and loot.Basically it is the bare minimum of a  collectible card game, with deck-building elements, mixed with some RPG-elements where you have to fight for your life, spiced up with a choose your own adventure type of decision making.Why I like it:It resonates deeply with what interests me. It reminds me of the Story Time from the Longest Journey. I know what it is, but what is IT really. It reminds me of Fable (minus the bright humor, it is all dark here), but I could laugh at certain points at what happened to me. But most of all, it is mysterious. The 'Dealer' taunts you with snippets of knowledge of what you are, where you are, and why you are all doing this. What I don't like (Keep in mind this is Early Access, things might have changed since the moment of writing/updating):The current combat system, and camera need some work. It has been in state of flux for a while now. But the big issues still is that the camera is so damn unhelpful at times. Monster can block up a lot of your screen if you aren't careful with your own positioning. I lost from full health just because I couldn't see what I was doing behind a Fire Golem who decided to use a massive damage AoE every second or so.Other thing is that game is best played with a controller, and you damn well know it is designed around it. Navigating the menus with the mouse is tedious and in combat you only use the buttons on the mouse for block or stun. The 'Cancel'-button is the 'Tab'-Key, while the 'Confirmation'-Button is the 'Enter'-key. My advise, rebind the 'attack'-key and the 'stun'-key to two keys close to the enter and you are golden. Drag the mouse in a corner and play the game with Keyboard only. It is completely do-able.My final gripe are animations. For example the 'Dealer', especially later in the game, will freeze up when dealing a large stack of cards. As the time needed to 'deal' the cards is longer as his animation-length. Besides that, you are forced to watch him deal every time your start a 'Game of Fate' with him. The animations in combat are okay. Sounds might be missing, call me spoiled but the lack of sound during some encounters are a bit... lacking. But that is Early Access, not all is there.Should you buy it?Depends. Keep in mind that this is an Early Access, things might change. However, in its current state and what I have read about what it will become: I recommend this game to anyone who likes the idea. My advice though is to watch a few videos, or read a bit further before buying into an Early Access.nted

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												The game is a 3D brawler, which uses cards to present opponents, loot, gear and the random encounters you'll meet.  It's a very good first game by an indie developer and I'd love to see more stuff by this team.  It's obvious that this game was made with tender loving care.  Pros:The game has a wonderful aesthetic and the music and atmosphere are fantastic.   The presentation is absoultely the best thing about the game.  The voice naration and card dealing are first rate.  The game has absoultely wonderful graphics too.Cons:The brawling animations are functional, but need work.  It feels like the game isn't as responsive as it should be, and at times the small amount of input lag can cause damage or death to your character.  It's difficult to pull off 3D brawling with a counter system and I personally feel like the game would've been better if it was a 2D brawler.  The camera can also be a source of frustration at times.  When your character moves farther away, the camera doesn't show the near end of the level and it's possible to not see incoming attacks.The game starts off very easy but difficulty ramps up a bit too fast for my taste.  The first few levels are very easy and by middle of the game I was struggling to reveal all the encounters and live.   By the time I hit the last couple of levels I felt like all I wanted was to just get through with as few encounters as possible, which imho is not how the game should be played,  I actually had to lower the difficulty from hard to normal for the last 3 levels because I could not finish it on hard.

content:

Early Access Review
								Quite a nice game.In its current state, there are bugs and imbalances, but the developers seem very responsive on the forums, so I have no doubt the game will eventually get balanced just right.Basically, each game you start, you start with the default equipment for that boss challenge (level), and progress from there.If you like rougelikes, and like the idea of building your own stack of possible encounter cards and a stack of possible equipment for each battle, as well as fighting each encounter in a Batman style... then I would suggest you get this game.I'd even say you should get it while it's it Early Access to support the development and tweaking to give the devs as much time as possible to make the game as good as they can make it.Edit: Oh, and I forgot to mention that you should run the game on "fastest", because at least on my computer on "good", my input was sometimes ignored. Running on fastest mode is a lot more responsive and still looks fine to me... at least until the game has been patched to handle a bit of lag, or of course if you have a stronger computer.You could also look at the review by ExtraCredits 


YouTube™ Video: James Recommends - Hand of Fate - Deck-Building Roguelike Action RPG

												I would recommend this game with an asterisk. This is an amazingly original and fun game, and its well executed; up until the point where 3/4 of the way in it becomes unplayable.I got a very enjoyable 8 hours out of it, and am satisfied totally with the 20 bucks i dropped on it. And I'll probably never play it again. There are a few encounters that are broken, but they can happilly be removed from your deck. 												There isn't much about HoF that hasn't already been said by other, some famous, currators. This game is pretty good, and one of the few that I haven't regretted spending the money on (19.99). I haven't even dabbled in this genre much, but the theme and randomness of the decks is a very interesting take on procedural generation. My only complaint is the wonky-ish combat system. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												As a veteran card game nerd I feel inclined to say I love everything about this game. From the dungeon crawling (why am I always running out of food!) to the deck building (don't make me choose!)  to the atmosphere. its all great.      Long story short you play through a dungeon built from the cards in your deck mixed with a few from the dungeon master. They are organized at random and make the field of play. This creates a random game board so you will never have the same run through twice. There is some equipment, gold, and food management elements that will force you to choose between completing quests or risking starvation and the like. You unlock more cards as you play, adding new layers of difficulty and possibile encounters to add to your deck as you progress. The campaign is long and challenging but not at all boring and tedious. I enjoyed it a lot. If you get through the campaign there is an endless play mode so your adventures can continue long after the story is done.      If I had to say something bad for the appearance of fairness I guess the combat is a bit simplistic. That said it in no way detracts from the amazing gameplay. Thats it, thats the one and only thing I can even sort of criticize. Now seriously go buy this game, you can thank me later.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												I have written only a couple of revies in my time on steam. I've just finished playing this for the first time and i felt i must immediatly add my two cents:What an amazing game. Yes people are complaining about the combat but i find it acceptable. Having never played Batman (which is what it is being compared to) I cant complain. It works.. they either patched it since the complaints or people are just overly picky about it. The only thing that bothered me though was the camera, it just doesnt feel right sometimes.Combat problem aside. The rest of the game is amazing. The Dealer is voiced so well he makes the game for me. Along with the cards themselves, the stories they tell hooking me in. I still havn't completed the story yet, I've had some really bad luck on some of the runs. There is enough game here to keep me coming back. Infact ive spent 9 hours on the game and that was all in one sitting. I still have a lot of cards to unlock and even when that is done, there is endless mode.There are enough variations in enemies to keep the combat and draw interesting.In one run i was doing really well and was on the last floor, after a very hard struggle of ups and downs id finally made it to within one square of the boss tile. All i had to do was defend myself from an ambush by a falling log "Easy enough" i thought.. but then the draw. First enemy "Queen of plague" .... "well atleast it cant get any wo.." second card "Jack of plague" ......... Needless to say that run ended there. But i laughed at my misfortune and moved on with the next run.Pros:Narration is A+ (I just wish there was more but even the repetative narration isnt a bad thing.)Cards tell wonderful little stories.Variation of curses on each boss dungeon to keep it challenging.Game of chance/skill with picking the right outcomes.Random runsSimple combat. (I personally think a complicated combat system would take away from the rest of the game.)Cons:Frustrating at times when the luck goes against you.camera angle in combat (very minor issue personally)

												A really good mix of deck building card based gameplay with rpg / roguelike elements. Combat is fairly simplistic but that doesn't detract from the game itself too much. I don't know if i'll end up putting in the time required to defeat the last 3 bosses, as at this point it's a mix of luck and frustration.

												Excellent game! You traverse a dungeon whose rooms are face down cards. Each card has an event or encounter that can lead to combat, treasure, fortunes, or misfortunes. You unlock more cards as you complete events, most of them being a chain (ex. Complete the Ritual event, unlock the Lich boss fight event, complete that and unlock the Druids event storyline). There is luck involved but a lot of it is also in your hands (Do you try to sneak past an enemy or face it in hopes of good loot? Do you really want to get involved in a blood auction?).There are tons of items that make combat interesting. I'll agree the animations can be a bit clunky at times when compared to something like the Batman games (it uses the basic combat mechanics as those), but it is not as bad as most reviewers will have you believe. Combat gets pretty difficult and intense in the later half of the game, and I pretty much just beat the final boss of the game because I had bought/found just the right items to keep me alive.I would highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of roguelikes or just adventure games. The narrative is well written and the stories, even though they are just text through cards, are interesting and make you want to see them through. Trying to get some of the achievements can also be fun.The Wildcards DLC adds more variety to the roguelike elements by giving you Fates (classes essentially) that have a buff and a debuff on your character. It also adds Easy and Hard mode. I didn't use any Fates during my initial run, so I can't say much about the DLC, but I don't think it's worth the full price.

												Difficult to master, easy to learn, very intriguing. It's not really a card game, even though it pretends to be.Small sound bugs (narrator repeating something he said before the encounter started, at the beginning of an encounter), graphics being not as the'yre supposed to be (come on, if 65% of your game is a guy sitting at a table moving his arms across it, his robes shouldn't be clipping through the damn table!!) and sometimes irritating slow-motions when you desperately would like to dodge an attack......can't taint an overall great athmosphere and immense replayability at the reasonable price of around 20 Euros. And the campaign is damn hard. I keep dying more and more often as I progress, but I just pick it up and try again.That's how games are supposed to be, not like "Oh, you lost two times? Let me teleport you to the end of the level and set the difficulty to stupidly easy!"9/10 (-1 for sound and graphics stuff described above) - would buy again.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Imagine the Souls series (in terms of difficulty) with more narrative, less trudging around and more bosses (simpler boss mechanics, more trash mobs in boss fights). I dred drawing two 6 of (insert any mob) and a boss cardWhen I first started the game, I laughed at how easy the combat was. I thought "I'm just going to cheese my way through this and be done in a few hours". I was sorely mistaken! This game will punish you, punish you some more then punish you again for good measure.The best thing about this game is the randomomly generated playing fields. You can go from 100% n00b gear to 100% end game in 3 turns, if you're lucky! You could also make it to the final boss with all your n00b gear and have your max health reduced to 1/100. This game has a story mode and a ranked infinite play mode. Story is like the best tutorial ever made and infinite play mode will go forever until you concede or die. The best part of infinite is it is ranked, so you can have bragging rights and make your friends jealous!This isn't just for TCG fans! this game is fantastic and absolutely belongs in your library!

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												First off, the melee Scales (Lizardmen as they're called) are bs. Other than that, this game is amazing. The rouge-like atmosphere helps keep the game fresh, and with every new card you get from card tokens, it makes the story bigger. Card tokens can either give you weapons/armor/story or all of the above. This game has a lot of luck and faith. It can read your mind when you internaly beg to not land on a certain card, and it'll give you the double middlefinger and have it right there. With that in mind, if you do over come that obsticle, it feels really rewarding to beat that unwanted challenge and gain card tokens (until you land on the next unwanted card). This game can get hard at times. but you can always try something new. You can change what cards you want to use, be it story or equipment, giving you different ways to attempt to clear a story boss. All in all, this game is really addicting and really easy to get into. 9/10 would rip my own heart out of my chest again.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								so. this game has a cool premise, pretty much as advertised. the dealer lays out a dungeon, made from seperate encounters, each represented by a card. these encounters are either just text decisions like "give peasant half or all of your food" and you have to guess, being either rewarded or punished afterwards. this card-dungeon is rogue-lite-challenging, meaning you can just starve because of plain bad luck with your draw and event choices. the other encounters, Id say about sixty percent - are the action rpg part of the game. the combat system is the weakest link in the chain still, and every single type of ranged enemy still has the potential to make me ragequit - but itll have you on your toes at least...in my opinion, the dealer animations in between cards are too long and unskippable. a lot of events determine their outcome by having you draw from four cards, say success/success/failure/huge failure. itll then show you these four, flip them, shuffle them TWICE (!), spread them out, pause a split second more just to annoy you further - and THEN you can draw one of the four. which youll do every thirty seconds. similar stuff goes for other animations, say the laying out of the dungeon in the beginning.besides from these problems, and early-access-issues like say, lack of sounds, the game is cool. the mix is a cool idea, and you can build your dungeon event AND equipment decks in between dungeons, that determine what stuff you might face off against, get benefited by, or loot.

												This is old school D&D mixed with timing based button mashing. Character development is card based. Unlock cards build your deck and influence the story before you. The random is the feel of D4 rolls. It really does feel like a dungeon master game. This is the first game in a long time to hold my attention. I am an older gamer and my only complaint was getting the interface set up to my liking, it took about an hour. Now I am enjoying it and give it 4 of 5 because I don’t give anything 5 of 5. Graphics are awesome if you ever wanted to be a Spartan in 300. There is a slight glitch/big with the interface of my monitor, so I have to launch, quit and relaunch.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												This is a great game. When i first saw screenshots of it i wasn't immediately drawn to it. But picking this up in the summer sale I don't regret it and would easily say its worth its full price. I can only hope they will do a sequel. What really rounds this game off is the voice over (think Michael Caine-like) of the card dealer whom has a think or two to say about your choices and what has happened as you make choices and at times try your luck. And there is random luck involved where sometimes you can lose a prized weapon or artifact from that.  You have a series of boss fights if you will per game. So each game could last from twenty or so, perfect for those casual gamers who want to play in short bursts.  As you defeat more foes at the end of a game you unlock more cards and events.  It is a simple game to play but really pulls you in. And as i said i hope the developer has plans on a sequel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I usually don't play games from studios that i've never heard of buttook a chance with this game. I was a bit shocked with the basic start up menu and was expecting something bad because of how simple it was but i was even more shocked when i discovered how fun the game was. You start your first 4 quests as tutorial type missions where they introduce the elements of the game and do very well explaining how it works. The Narrator who is also the man you see in the game cover adds a great element to the game. I really enjoyed his comments to make the game interesting and they did a great job focusing on his animation.Too sum it up its a game of randomness on every quest you go to making them slightly unique. As the game progresses you unlock cards that can add to the randomness and even add more difficulty of the game. The game is indeed a bit to easy in the medium and easy setting. The hard setting can get difficult because the odds are stacked against you but to me it adds to the fun.The combat is done similar to the Batman games where you have attacks and counters. Some opponents attack faster and some can not be dodge which adds a bit more difficulty because usually you're out numbered. You get random weapons and armor through out the game based on the "helpful" cards you have in the deck that you can create making the game easier or harder. Their is also a recommended setting in case you don't want to tinker with it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Hand of Fate is a unique and refreshing blend of a few great genres. It pits you in a game of life or death (though really there's not much risk to you aside from a few broken knuckles) against "The Dealer", who is a mysterious and actually pretty solid character. Mechanics: Basically this game you play with the dealer is a kind of choose your own adventure/board game where the tiles on the board are random cards which either come from your deck or the dealer's deck. I'm paraphrasing Total Biscuit here, but your cards (usually) serve to help you gain some leverage in the form of gold or weapons, where as the dealer's cards are there to mess your♥♥♥♥♥♥up. Occasionally you'll land on a combat card which will transition the game from a top down boardgame into a 3rd person hack and slash fight which is comprable to a very simplified Darksouls.Overall, I love how dynamic the mechanics are and everything just feels right on.Pros:  Solid combatInteresting tarot esq themeGreat sense of RPG progression Plenty of cardsVery dynamicFresh incorporation of collectible cardsCons: Difficulty progression isn't on point Replayability is questionableSome of the quests seem too much like a choreNot many game modesClasses seem a bit unbalanced, as do items Overall it's a great game. I'd love to see multiplayer somehow implemented, maybe 1 player 1 dealer, 2-3 players AI dealer, I'm not sure, but this game has tonnes of potential to take it one step further and I hope the devs know that.8.5/10 Definitely worth.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												I never do reviews, but honestly, this game is too amazing not to do one.Hand of Fate is a card game, yes, but not exactly.  It's also an action rpg, and that's what's so unique about it.  Not only that, but the game is totally randomized, like an actual card game.  You choose a few cards from your deck, and the card-master stuffs a few surprises in your deck, and you play the game.  You have absolutely no idea what comes next, and it's not always in your favor.Not only that, but there are quests in the cards themselves.  For example; you have a card (Let's say Desert Storm) and you find that card in the game.  If you "play your cards right" then you'll be able to get the coin of the card and get the next encounter card, which is Lost in Desert, and so on so forth.I completely recommend this game.  It is worth every penny, and if it's on sale you buy it without a second thought.
