Posted: June 22, 2015
												I highly recommend this game. It is a storytelling RPG/action game with deckbuilding elements. You go on semi-randomised quests in the story mode, which you can customise each time by changing your deck! In endless mode, it's even more randomised for endless possibilities and combinations.- An interesting narrator and voice acting (for once in a game)- An intriguing plot line- Unlock cards... and then encounter those cards!- Overcome challenges to unlock card's hidden potentials, storylines, and more cards!- Customise your adventures with the deck builder, deciding what weapons, encounters, spells, and skills you may come across- Intuitive combat- Hours and hours of funEDIT: One more thing I forgot, the devs have really looked after this game! They have continued to improve it in free updates of content and optimisation!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Where to start, I've read reviews good and bad before buying this.. But one thing is certain, it is in my opinion well worth buying, I love card based and hack and slash based games, well this is a combination of the two, while not too sure how it would actually be like other than what reviews have said, something about this game is actually enjoying. Things I'd want to share -  UnderstaNding the game isn't that hard, I looked at all of the card and had no idea after the "tutorial" but after I used recommended settings for a round I took another look and it was all plain as day, the cards are self explainatory, in the cases in which to use them are all up to the player.I wouldn't say there is too much strategy going along with this game at the begining, but as you progress into each round there is def- need to put some thought into actions before you go balls to the wall and speed through the round.It feels like each round gets harder and harder as you progress, the first round I ended pretty decently, round two was a bit rougher and round 3 I BARELY got through. So if you can just imagine what the rest were like, although there is an option to turn down the difficulty which beginners may need to if you're having some trouble understanding still.This review may not be as informative as others but it's just some things off the top of my head.Overall the concept of this game is great, while i still haven't completed it yet, I feel somewhat addicted to the game and I hope the devs fix the little things and keep on top of this game, I feel it has much potential.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Its amazing how presentation can spice up a simple game.This is a rouge like where you guide your hero through various challenges, slaying enemies and defeating the boss at the end of each level.  the twist is everything is depicted as card wielded by a mysterious stranger playing across from you.  each encounter is a card thats flipped over and revealed when your peice lands on it and it can be anything from an enemy abush to helping a wandering priest.  most of chanllenges will be simple text scenarious where your given a choice of what to do. depending on your answer you'll sometimes auto succed or fail or four cards with fail or succed will be revealed (how difficult the challenge depends on how many of the cards are success and how man say fail)  the cards are flipped face down and suffled and you pick one and pray.  your rewarded with supplies, equipment, and gold and punished with curses, injuries, and loss of provisions or fights.  Various events will lead to the drawing of monster cards and suddenly your in an arena fending off enemies with arkham city style combat controls.  Then comes another clever twist. often completing challenges will unlock new cards at the end of the round.  you see the challenges you face and the equipment you might earn come from a deck that you can alter.  each round has a requires your equimpent deck and enconter deck to have a certin number of cards and you can swap out encounters or equimpent you don't want to chance coming across in favor of ones you like so you have some conrol of what you'll run into during the game, though the dealer will always shuffle in a set of his own cards to try and trip you up.And all the while the dealer taunts teases and converses with you.  He's really one of the main highlights of the game.  Its like playing a card game with Ron Peralman dressed as a masked wizard (no its not him but thats what the dealers voice reminds me of)This game reaks of charm and personality and i highly recomend it. The game play is simple but how its presented makes it into a unique experice.

												This is a wonderfully made indie card game/action game.  This game is something I don't think has quite been done before.  You build your deck to determine what happens during a round and the mysterious dealer (who is wonderfully animated and voiced) lays traps and misfortunes for you, but he's not your enemy outright.  He plays more of a dungeon master role and lays out the game's story for you.  A lot of time was put into him, as he remembers what cards you used on previous playthroughs and remarks on your playstyle.  If you rely on the same card too often, he will laugh at you for using cheap cards as a crutch.  If you make the enemy deck too easy, he might add a few difficult cards to keep the game interesting.  He has a series of around 16-ish foes for you to challenge, each one harder than the last.You move your token and land on dealt out cards which determine the environment; then the environment comes to life and fights you in a fighting style remniscent of Arkham Asylum.  There are also trap sections you run through.  The animations during this sequence feel a little mechanical and the default difficulty is MUCH too forgiving.  You can just tap the attack button and win.  I recommend upping it to hard mode ASAP.  It causes all the run and hit animations to move faster, hiding some of the awkward motion during action sequences and keeping you engaged in the battle.The game has a great soundtrack with SFX that mirror what the card's effect on your character is.  The voice acting and animation of the cards and the dealer is fantastic.  A single game takes around 15-20 minutes depending on how fast you click through the UI, but there are challenge cards that you can throw in to handicap your character, adding to the replay value.An original idea executed better than any game on the Unity Engine I've seen thus far.  Worth playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												I've gotten huge amounts of enjoyment out of this game. It delivers in every area that it promises and if you are looking for a bordgameesque rougelike this is for you.The game transitions from easy to very hard over the course of the game and there is little input from the player that can change the difficulty. For me this is not a problem as I enjoy the challenge, but for those looking for a game you can just walk through then you're probably not going to play to the end. Something that came as a big and very welcome surprise was the storytelling. Which is told by the dealer who'll comment on everything that is happening. At first I thought that this was going to be off-putting after a while. But even now 30+ hours into the game I still want to hear everything he has to say. Through cryptic and vague pieces of information the story is revealed to you and it feels great to gather up these tidbits of information. The voice-acting is spot on and the amount of different monologues are huge. As for gameplay there is a good balance between depth and simplicity. After a while you'll learn what encounter does what, but there is still a random element to each encounter that you as a player can influence. This lends to a big increase in replayability since even though you encounter the same stuff the outcomes will differ, and so will your experience during each playthrough.The game looks good as well. While the graphics are not AAA they are certainly conveying the feelings that the atmospehere in this game needs to flourish. It also runs very well (at least on my computer).Overall when it comes to atmosphere it's where this game shines the most. Thanks the combination of voiceacting and spot on artstyle you'll be drawn into the mysteries presented. You'll want to see what waits ahead, You'll want to push on further, You'll want to find out what awaits in the end, You'll want to understand.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Wow, what a truly wonderful surprise this game turned out to be. I picked it up on a whim without having any real knowledge of the game till it hit the market. It's a procedurally generated set of dungeons (akin to the old 'choose your own adventure' novels from  20+ years ago) based on cards in a deck that you have a hand in designing. You traverse this dungeon using gear from a separate deck that you also have a hand in designing, which is comprised of gear you found throughout your journey exploring previous dungeons. It's really quite genius.The game is surprisingly deep too. During play you'll see the following:-various weapon damage types-various enemy types-mazes-curses-blessings-merchants-buffs-traps-chests-path choices-bosses-magical items-random loot-artifacts-item activation during combatI'm sure theres more I could add, but I'm still not even 2hrs played. You walk across a board comprised of over turned cards from the deck, randomly laid out in a grid. Each step consumes a food resource, so must monitor your food as you travel. You'll run into decisions in  your journey...do you give some of your food away to a weary traveller? or just pass by them. How you respond will affect the outcome of your journey.While I was originally concerned combat during story mode was too simple. The further I got, Not only was I becoming stronger, but so was my enemy.I definitely recommend this game. It's new and refreshing. Well done!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Saturday morning fun.Hand of Fate...Already seems like it has the makings of a classic choose-your-own roguelike adventure, got it through a humble bundle a few months ago, very lucky for me indeed, or perhaps I should just be appreciative of Defiant's articulate and masterful work.The 'game/dungeoun-master' harkens back to classical wizards such as Merlin, G-dalf and the ilk without seeming cliched, in fact, he seems original and fresh; layers of Easternish mysticism are presented before you and his comments on your doings, comings and goings are quite enjoyable to hear. He may tell you that the blessing you just purchased is a bit imba and he's going to bring out the nerf-hammer next time around, the game does not mean it will actually nerf that blessing next time around, it is actually beating the final level per set of cards that will increase the strength of enemies encountered and also improve your starting gear and provisions. This guy is the only person you really interact with during the game, and that makes your adventure seem delightfully personal.In addition to that, the game is played with tokens to unlock more incredibly detailed cards, beautiful arenas, dungeouns, and shop-areas with little merchant wagons, all revolving around improving your character's odds as you move his little gold playing token through card-maps to the boss event for each set of cards. You may come across a random event where you must select from four shuffled cards, and yes, if your eyes are quick enough you can follow the successful cards as they shuffle, no true randomness involved, just have to pay attention to the minute details as the cards slide across eachother. Anywho, guess the correct cards in these events and you might get a new weapon, some gold or earn the card's token which will in turn, after beating the set boss, unlock more cards for you to play with your next time around.Everything comes together with such subtlety that you almost feel like you're experiencing more than you paid for, this title screams triple-A quality throughout every chapter and turn while still coming through as your humble guide leading you through a poignant adventure largely based on fantastical ideas that leave just enough space within their nooks and crannies to be able to be completely alluded to on a personal level for you and your imagination.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												If you put action combat in a card game, either do it well or don't do it at all. We have a good and somewhat boring card game with a terrible, awful, uninspired combat sequences. Game throws too many cards at you, too many to care about what they are. And regardless of difficulty (which is easy anyways) you end up drawing cards and playing guess-the-card to win (or loose). A touch of game progression redesign (and maybe even removing combat sequences, or making it scripted, e.g. pc resolving card game outcome in a spectacular scripted fight) and this game would become amazing gem.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												As of the time writing this review I've only scratched the surface of this truly endless game, where to begin!? Well I'll begin by saying this is a must have for any fans of those old school "Choose Your Own Adventure" books or general RPG fans, when i first started playing I could see myself getting tired of the games formula extremly fast but alas I was very wrong, the amount of content in just the base game looks to be pretty staggering for the price and the combat system feels very Arkham game still (standard counter system) yes its not as fluid as the arkham games but it does hold up pretty well.The meat of the game is the cards themselves, each "round" cards from your deck and the mysterious gentleman's whom your up against get mashed together and them put down before you, there are different kinds of cards from situations, fights to items. All of which have an impact and following rounds, the goal is very simple.. Kill the end of "level" boss, but the beauty of the game is the sheer randomness at paly, you and I will or would have very different games each time we play, as such there is no real story but one crafted from each and every card on the table. there is just so much to say about this game and I've only played 1.4 hours in total, just get it already kay?..............Why are you still reading this? go, go now.. Buy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												I challenge anyone who plays tabletop D&D not to fantasize about a game like this. The modularity, genre, and the ongoing quest lines, woven together by the luck of the draw, are evokative of those games. Cross it, perhaps, with FTL style resource management and text adventure moments, done with fairly simple tools and models for this era (models and combat action are fairly standard for 5-10 years ago), but performed with pure style. Hand of Fate.I want to give particular props for the dealer, who is cryptic without seeming pretentious, vocal without being a nuisance, taps on the fourth wall without shattering it, and succeeds in striking a magnificent balance in which he has the character of both a menacing opponent and an impartial judge. Maybe that's part of what reminds me so much of D&D. He is remniscient of an excellent dungeon master who wants you to succeed; but not easily.I am a little annoyed that not only is there a pay-for expansion, but the base game has achievements that cannot be unlocked unless you buy it. Marks off for that, it's a disappointing choice. However, it's not enough of an annoyance to keep me from recommending the game.The difficulty seems well-rounded and fairly challenging to me. You certainly have plenty of opportunity to fail, but failure isn't all that punishing. I look forward to playing more.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17
												A unique experience with some very original ideas. The dealer's narration is excellent, ties together the mysterious atmosphere of the game perfectly. The deck building keeps things fresh, and acts almost like an open world in letting you choose what aspeects to explore next. I haven't finished the game, so I'm not 100% certain, but it feels like the small storylines told by the cards themselves don't connect to the overall storyline, but I think that works well. The writing is very short form, but it's all relatively engaging and even though they only appear for a short time some of the characters are pretty interesting. The fighting gameplay is significantly weaker than the rest of the game, but it plays smoothly enough and doesn't take up too much time. That said, honestly I think the game would have been better with some kind of card-based combat like (for example) Guild of Dungeoneering.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												The concept here is solid and easily creates a sense of adventure, exploration and suspense using surprisingly few and simple means to do it. Every new game feels like a quest to discover the next installment of any number of quest chains, and to gather up enough resources to be able to accomplish your goal when you get there, to avoid danger and peril that comes with venturing into the unknown and the mysterious.That said, I feel this game lacks polish and clear communication. In combat this is especially clear, the exact range in which you can attack or counterattack is extremely inconsistent and there have been times when my character will move or attack in the wrong direction and I will have no idea why. Out of combat also, the odds of success vary wildly with each encounter, sometimes an encouter offers three success and one failure, sometimes it offers three huge failures and one success, why? Is it because of some item im carrying? because it happened later in the game? You dont know! It would break the flow of the game to explain what detail is affecting each and every choice I make, but some sort of instruction here would be very helpful.8/10

												This game is better than a genre mashup like this has any right to be.The voiceworkfor on the dealer is perfect. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Hand of Fate is a fantastic game.  It's like my sympathetic bro that I don't hang out with nearly enough, but when I do I'm like why don't we hang out all the time?  But then I'm like, oh, right, that's why.  Hand of Fate is special though, make no mistake.  It fills a void in gaming for me - when I'm in that place where I don't want to steal cars and hustle, hunt and kill ancient demons, or get deep into diplomacy while building a nation, Hand of Fate's got my back.  When I'm too hungover for "normal" games, too twitchy to play twitch shooters, and too high to die (or rather, too high to want to constantly have to worry about dying..), HoF has me covered.  It's casual and somehow still challenging.   It's a special kind of game, and certainly deserves your time,.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Really interesting blend of mechanics that has some implementation problems (I go into it in the spoiler senction). The roguelike aspect, the deckbuilding aspect, the choose-your-own-aventure aspect and the third person brawler aspect all blend toghether really well. Yes, the game is not the best one in any of these mechanics, so if you don't like the whole package you'll find a better experience elsewhere. Maybe Batman, Binding of Isaac or The Yawgh.Performance wise it's not a heavy game but, since all the cards are individual models and are manipulated several times by the Dealer, it might choke on a few points on lower end computers.This would be alongside my favorites if it wasn't for some (really bad) late game decisions.SPOILER SECTION....The final boss is a complete joke. I problably spent half of my gameplay hours on him. It ramps up the dificulty, but not in a good way. The dificulty of the final level is that it slowly chips away at your health and abilities with a curse at every stage and the inability to aquire blessings (this can be changed if you're lucky and has the proper cards).The final boss is a gauntlet of all previous bosses, separetad by enemy type. This woul be easy if the three plague bosses wheren't so OP. The king and the jack have a small window of vulnerabillity and they usually stunlock you and take a lot of health, the king specially. The problem is not defeat them, but to do so without loosing much health.Between matches with the previous bosses the Dealer unleashes some magical attacks and there's a QTE. The last one is my main death reason because it's really hard to dodge all of them. It can easilly hit you for 40+ hp and with your health already chipped away by all the previous bosses... you got the picture.The cheap way around it is to kill the game before dying. The game saves just before the fight for crash prevention purposes. That way you don't have to pass through all the maze again. Hell, if you're feeling particularly cheap you can do that every time  something bad happens to you so you arrive at the last battle in better condition.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												This is one of those rare gems that really gets my attention.The concept is magnificent, blurring the lines as to whether you're someone playing a card game or an adventurer trapped in a game itself. The narration by the dealer is wonderful, some of the best voice acting I've heard in a while and it perfectly fits the setting. The art on both the cards and the game itself is excellent, evoking a fantasy world where the line between reality and imagination is a thin one indeed. I finished the first challenge and popped out long enough to write this, but I am most certainly diving right back in as soon as I do.The whole game feels like something out of an old fairy tale, or perhaps something that a writer like Neil Gaiman would create. I can see myself spending a LOT of time with this one.I do have a couple minor quibbles, but that's not with the game itself so much as the fact that it seems Steam is a bit weird with it just yet. I opened the Steam Dashboard during gameplay, but the top and bottom parts of the dashboard remained when I returned to it. There's a couple issues with the PC it seems yet, but as this game just came out I don't doubt they'll be fixed in short order.All in all if you're a fan of high fantasy and want something that really scratches that itch this game is definitely on the top of my list to recommend to you. Well done indeed.http://lenwolfgamer.tumblr.com/post/143147574202/hand-of-fate

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												I have only played Hand of Fate for a few hours but it has made a great impression.  It brings back the old pen and pencil D&D memories and it is brilliant fun.  its simple to grasp and so far hasnt been diifficult to progress, however it is hinting at more complicated gameplay and decisions to be made later down the line which i am looking forward to, such as as having enough food to explore the dungeon/scenario versus just try and find the exit.  I really like the change in gameplay between making slower decisions and taking a random pot luck (dice roll) on choosing a card, to using skill in faster paced combat.  the combat, is so far, a somewhat simplified batman/shadow of mordor type where the character can block and counter attack (equipment dependant) as well as using special cards that have been chosen. It isnt without issues, the intro video has some textural issues and after using the steam overlay in game i ended up with a letter box display, however none of the issues have been for me game breaking.   The actual gameplay however has been bug free so far.

												This is a great game. When i first saw screenshots of it i wasn't immediately drawn to it. content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Marvelous game!The concept is really nice: building and collecting your own deck, playing the cards and eventually fighting the actual encounters in 'batman' style gameplay. The different cards are always meaningfull and contain many surprises. There is always that positive 'pull' to play on and try to unlock a card's token to see what the next event will be.I have backed this one on Kickstarter and I'm glad I did, money well spent!The only downside is in the balancing. The first rounds are extremely easy. The final rounds are very hard and the last one is just impossible to the extend that it turns into a restart-restart-restart session which removes all of the fun. A random encounter puts you against 2 end-bosses of previous levels while the final fight makes you fight all endbosses all over again. The fights in itself are not so bad, but combined with an endless amount of curses it makes the level way too hard, at least for me.The game has a lot of replay-ability thanks to the random draw effect and the customizeable deck. But the repeated attempts at the final level made me lose interest.Overall I give it a 7/10. Great game, unique concept and a lot of fun. This can turn into a 9/10 if they rebalance the final level a bit.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Good, but not great. The concept is awesome, I love how it intertwines a dungeon crawler with a card game. At the beginning it's very nice and fun to play, but when you get closer to the endgame the RNG becomes too punishing, robbing you of a chance to use your skills and instead tunring events into a slot machine of sorts. Well, it's not called "hand of fate" for nothing, I guess, but it makes the endgame a little too grindy.Encounter and item cards get unlocked very quickly, which makes the game rather short, even though there is an endless mode - it's just not very fun to play if there's no element of exploration, you learn the cards fast and know what they do and how it's best to approach encounters. Hopefully, future addons and DLC will fix that by adding more cards.This is a good title to grab during a sale, it will keep you occupied for a couple of evenings, but not for much longer than that. It can be so much better; seeing the great potential of this game makes it feel a bit underwhelming in its current state. I hope that it will get there eventually.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												First off, the melee Scales (Lizardmen as they're called) are bs. Other than that, this game is amazing. The rouge-like atmosphere helps keep the game fresh, and with every new card you get from card tokens, it makes the story bigger. Card tokens can either give you weapons/armor/story or all of the above. This game has a lot of luck and faith. It can read your mind when you internaly beg to not land on a certain card, and it'll give you the double middlefinger and have it right there. With that in mind, if you do over come that obsticle, it feels really rewarding to beat that unwanted challenge and gain card tokens (until you land on the next unwanted card). This game can get hard at times. but you can always try something new. You can change what cards you want to use, be it story or equipment, giving you different ways to attempt to clear a story boss. All in all, this game is really addicting and really easy to get into. 9/10 would rip my own heart out of my chest again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												This game... Oh my, is it good. I finally finished story mode, so I feel like I can give an educated opinion now, so lets get down to the details.Hand of fate is a mixed card game and action RPG. On their own they are both average at best, but they complement and enhance each other very well. You have two decks (Sets of cards, for those not familiar with the lingo): The equipment deck and the encounter deck. The encounter deck will be used by The Dealer to construct the levels you play on, along with the cards he add himself to help and/or screw you over. These cards can be everything from a shop to buy and sell items in, to assisting (alleged) druids with their rituals. You start the game standing on a card, and you can move to any adjecent card to get closer to the boss so you can beat it and win the game. Every card is initially hidden, so you have no idea what awaits you before you move to and flip a card (certain items can reveal cards under certain conditions, though). A session consists of several levels, which are each constructed by a bunch of the encounter cards. For exampls 10 cards can build up a level, and one of these cards will be a travel card which lets you travel to the next level, where more cards will be used to construct it. Every encounter card can also have a golden symbol on it, which means that if you handle the encounter card in a certain way (usually defeating the monsters or getting another positive outcome), you will unlock more encounter and/or equipment cards. The equipment cards in your deck are the cards you will be able to obtain during a session. You can gain these by completing encounters in certain ways, or buying them at shops. As you complete more encounters you will, as mentioned earlier, obtain more equipment cards. This increases your potential power for each subsequent session (you start every session with basic equipment, although you can obtain better starting gear as you progress in story mode). Like the Encounter deck, the dealer can also add cards to the equipment deck. Equipment comes in seven different types: Weapons, shields, armor, helms, gloves, artifacts and trinkets (I suspect they are all rings as I haven't seen other types yet, but the category is called trinkets. Possibly for DLC down the line?). You can use one of each at a time, except for trinkets who are all active as long as you own them. Equipment can have both passive and active effects. The exception are artifacts, who only have activated abilities (they are your spells, basically). There are two different modes: Story and Endless mode. Story mode will put you up against one of the bosses of the game (SPOILER:::::: The last boss forces you to fight every single boss in the game, three at once four times :::::ENDSPOILER). In story mode you'll start with certain curses and The Dealer will add certain cards himself to your different decks as mentioned earlier. Usually these will be encounter cards. It is possible to just play a story session with almost any kind of deck (as long as it's not outright terrible), but specializing your deck for the stuff The Dealer will throw at you is probably a good idea unless you're like me and put as many "unfinished" encounters you can into your deck to unlock more cards more quickly (warning: this will likely result in a lot of rage as you try to unlock more stuff, fail, and get screwed over for the session).I have yet to play a lot of Endless mode, as Story mode kept me occupied for a while (I've slept with my computer running the game and such, though, so take hours/played with a *grain* of salt). From what I can see, you don't get to construct your deck here (you use all your cards), and the session continues until you die. In addition every time you travel to a new level of the session the dealer will throw in more bad things you have to deal with (feel free to correct me in the comments if I'm wrong, and I'll update it. I'll play Endless mode more now that I finished Story mode myself, though). As you start without any curses, it's probably an excellent way to go for unlocking encounter cards. Speaking of curse cards. There are two kinds of cards I haven't mentioned yet: Curses and Blessings. These are persistant effects that will buff or debuff you for the duration of the session (or, rarely, until a condition is fulfilled and it fires). Examples here can be spending food to counterattack, but doubling counter attack damage (a curse), or a lightning bolt striking down one enemy at the start of each combat (a blessing). Curses are usually really expensive to get rid of (at least the ones you start with), and blessings are expensive for their cost to obtain, and have varying levels of use. You could get a blessing which won't be of any use for an entire run, or a curse you will barely notice. On the other hand, you could also get really powerful ones which will be a great boon, or completely screw you over. Whew, ok, only a few mechanics left to mention now. In addition to what's already been mentioned, you also have health, food and gold. You start with 100/100 health, and both your current and maximum health can change during the course of the run. Current health can be knocked down both by encounters, and by taking damage during combat. You spend 1 food every time you move, and if you run out of food every movement will cost you 10 health points. Gold is simply used to buy things at shops (equipment, blessings, removing curses, food, etc.). All these resources can be refilled through encounters, or purchased at different types of shops (selling in the case of gold).The combat itself is a very simple Batman ish combat system. You attack and counter attack, and can dodge roll. You can also use the activated abilities of your different items. The combat itself can feel a bit sluggish (animations are a bit slow), but the controls are VERY responsive, and I hardly ever felt like I didn't avoid something which shouldn't have hit me. Combat itself can be triggered during an encounter card, and you will draw from the dealers monster deck whenever combat has been initiated by an encounter (although what strength/kind of monsters you can draw is usually decided by the encounter card). Do I recommend this game? Hell yeah I recommend this game. It might peter out a bit after you finished the story mode and start just screwing around in endless mode (I don't know yet, although I've yet to unlock all the encounter cards), but so far it's been a LOT of fun. That said, it can be ridiculously hard towards the later story sessions (it starts out easy, though). If you don't mind the difficulty you should definitely take it for a ride. I'd be very surprised if you end up regretting it!If you didn't like something about the review, or felt some information is lacking, feel free to drop a comment! If you felt this review helped you come to an informed decision, I'd very much appreciate a helpful rating. If you felt this isn't helpful at all, you can of course vote it down, but I'd appreciate being told what you feel is wrong so I get an opportunity to change my review if your points are valid. Have fun gaming!

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Probably one of the best blends of multiple genres there is. The game is, so far, incredibly fun and addictive with the Rouge-like mechanics, random encounters, card collecting, RPG loot system, choose your own adventure, and Table Top card game style. The combat, while fairly simple, resembles the Arkham style and it does it well. For the price I paid ($19.99 because of a sale), I highly recommend it, even at the base price of $24.99 or your regional equivalent.My only 2 gripes with the game are1. The fixed camera can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥in some encounters, especially ones envolving quite a lot of enemies2. sometimes the game fails to register the correct direction I'm aiming when using ranged abilities. Though, I can forgive it seeing how you'll be using melee combat 90% of the time.These small blemishes can easily be fixed, so I do hope they are. Granted, I'm playing on a keyboard, and not a controller as recommened. However, fixing these issues could make keyboard perfectly viable (though it pretty much is already, in my opinion).I'd give this a solid 9/10 at the moment.my thoughts so far:High replayabilityUnique set-up with the mixing of genresFun and simple, yet challenging combatThe camera is a bit of a nuisance at times.While I don't have much time in the game thus far; I shall update my review accordingly and as with any game, I advise looking up more information about the game and make sure it's something you'd be interested in. I personally love it so far, but opinions may vary.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Hand of Fate is something really quite special. Cards become a dungeon as they're laid out on the table before you. With each step another card is turned over to reveal another encounter, each feeling like they've been taken straight from the pages of a choose-your-own-adventure book.The dealer sitting opposite you engages in amusing and intriguing banter, alternating between challenging and encouraging you, threatening to make the game more deadly at every turn, and hinting at the secrets behind the mysterious game you're playing with him.It's a fantastic setting for a game, and quite a difficult one as the dealer keeps to his word and throws tougher creatures, harsher traps, cruel encounters and a seemingly endless array of painful curses to stop you in your tracks with every round you playAt times it can get a little frustrating. Being a card game, you can tweak your deck with favourable encounters, but sometimes that's not enough to prevent a string of bad encounters early on which can bring a game to a swift end. Couple this with some encounters being simple games of chance, and at times it feels like you've lost without really playing badly.Thankfully this doesn't happen too often, and with each conquered challenge rewarding you with new cards, even a failed adventure can net you some new toys.And if you really dislike having so much RNG in your game, you can stack the deck in favour of combat encounters to help limit the amount of dice rolling.The combat, however, is probably the weakest part of this game. It's a straightforward affair, a watered down version of the free-flowing combat in the Batman Arkham series. It works just fine and can get quite challenging, and there's a vast array of weapons, armour and trinkets to aid you, but I feel like it needs a few more options to keep it interesting. All you can really do is attack, block, guard-break, dodge, and occasionally use a trinket or a weapon's special ability. I wouldn't expect the immense depth the Arkham games have but I think it's a little too simple here.For the most part, the game looks and runs just fine. Personally I find the art style quite appealing and fairly unique, but I suppose some people might find it a little too simplistic for their tastes. I have encountered a few graphical glitches however, such as pink boats and monsters' limbs stretching like elastic, as well as a couple of freezes that forced me to restart the game. Nothing remotely serious or common enough to warrant a major complaint, but it's a very rewarding experience when you let yourself get immersed in the adventure, and those sorts of minor irritants draw you out from it.In summary: A wonderfully entertaining card game/dungeon crawl/choose-your-own-adventure experience with a few minor issues. A little simplistic in its combat and sometimes a little heavy on the RNG, but these minor gripes are a small price to pay for such a unique game with a sinister, secretive adversary who raises the stakes with every round. It does get quite challenging as your progress, so don't expect an easy ride.

												It has been a long time since I felt an emotional connection to a game and let me explain why;- Growing up I would devour "Chose your Own Adventure" books- I was gifted my first computer smack dab in the Middle of the Sierra - Quest era and at the end of Text only adventure games, like Zork- I have been playing Magic the Gathering since the mid 90ies with "Tempest"- Growing up, my friends and I would play Dungeons and Dragons everywhere, and anywhere. Bus ride home, waiting for a game to download, or before a movie would begin. No character sheets? No problem, just RP it.Do you see yourself in any of these? Even just one? Get it. Get the game, close the lights, place some candles, pick up a controller, play.

												I bought this game as early access.  The original releases were promising, but were riddled with balance issues - as one would expect from a raw development release.  But the premise, as everyone has said, was intreiguing. Defiant Development have always created games that put a new angle on a well trod genre, but Hand of Fate seems to be more than that.  The release version was an amazing surprise in comparison to the last development release - smooth, polished, mostly balanced.  There are still wild swings of too easy to WTFBBQSAUCE hard, but much of that comes down to luck of the draw.  Seeing as luck pretty much is the premise and title of the game, one cant really complain about it too much.  That said, the unpredictability didn't detract from my failing miserably and wanting to rerun to get a different set of cards and different luck.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												This game is quite the clever idea, and an entertaining game most of the time. Its difficulty curve is quite puzzling, though. After the initial "tutorial" hands and you start the game proper, it gets quite tough. However, when you succeed at the quests on the cards you find, you unlock new gear and bonuses which you can acquire later and on future playthroughs, and you can modify your deck (a lot easier than it sounds and not at all complicated or annoying, and this is coming from someone who typically tries to avoid alchemy and crafting in pretty much every game it's possible to avoid). The difficulty isn't so bad when you do this...until you reach the last few sections of the game. The fifteenth boss/level you take on (King of Plagues) is simply unacceptable on the normal difficulty, which is what I had played up until that point, and it was quite a challenge all the way until that section became impassable for me.Speaking of which, there is an "easy mode" you can access by going to the DLC menu (Fates) in the Deck Builder. While almost all of them are things you have to pay for, the normal difficulty and the easy mode (labeled as "Apprentice") can be chosen there, and it gives you a ton of bonuses/perks for your character to aid him in getting further. At that point, though, easy was far too easy on the fifteenth level, while I couldn't come close to completing it on normal. Beyond that point, I stuck with the Apprentice difficulty because it didn't seem to get any easier.The combat is essentially like a simpler version of the Arkham games' combat, with a number of abilities you can activate (only 2 can be taken into any given battle) depending on your gear. The battles get truly ruthless and not particularly fun late-game on normal. Even if I could handle the battles at max health, the problem is that the cards you draw along the way will hinder you even further. While you do have cards which can aid you, the bad cards very often outweigh the good.All that said, I was able to complete the game's last few bosses/levels on the Apprentice setting, and some of the late-game stuff is surprisingly challenging, even on that difficulty. Unless you like showing off, I would highly recommend playing the Apprentice difficulty because the normal one just becomes a chore to play. It's a good game, but the difficulty settings are pretty screwy, so be warned of that.Oh...and the ending after you land the final blow is maybe 10 seconds long and only six words are spoken after that blow. If short/lame endings put you off, you may wish to take that into consideration.

Early Access Review
								Another early access game. I've grown pretty weary of them, and I'm sure some of you reading this have too. I was first introduced to Hand of Fate on "James Recommends" from Extra Credits. I was interested in the concept, but I'd been burnt one too many times by great sounding ideas that were still a glimmer in their developer's eye. The price-tag made me think twice to boot. $25 for another unfinished game sounded like more of a risk than I wanted to take.Weeks went by, and I kept finding myself looking at the store page. Glancing over the screenshots and reading the game concepts. It just seemed so cool! Long story short I bit the bullet and bought the game. This one is for real! Even unfinished it promises an easy 25+ hours of entertainment. (For me at least, your milage may vary depending on your luck and skill.)I love the narration. I love the way the card game is woven into the fabric of a story that you make your own. The writing is crafty and thrilling and nostalgic somehow. This game sets the standard for early access games. It is fully playable with the promise of more content and refinement to come. If you find yourself drawn back to the idea this game proffers time and again, I highly recommend you pick it up.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								So far, a really great Beta. Certainly one of the better Early Access titles that I've played in terms of content and completed gameplay. In the game, you play as a pawn in a dealer's game. You have a choice to move between cards and randomly attack enemies, complete tasks (the success of which depends on your draw), visit shops, and gain equipment. The gameplay is less card game (which I think people might surmise from the title) and more of a 3rd person action game with "Chance" components. The graphics are well-suited to the game and have good art direction. The voice-overs (when present) are good and add to the atmosphere. The only (exceptionally mild) complaint I have is that the controls seem somewhat "floaty" at times. More along the lines of "Fable" or "Kingdoms of Amalur". It tends to snap to enemies in a slow way, and as such combat seems as though it's in slow-motion. This is a matter of personal preference and really doesn't detract from an otherwise wonderful game. As a recommendation to the developers, it would be nice also to hit enemies on the ground. In my playtime it didn't appear this was possible, which seems off given that enemies spend a lot of time knocked down. I don't know if this is meant to keep fights more balanced, but it's a mechanic that I think would help speed up combat without lowering health or boosting character stats.Great game, and I'm glad to see it's shaping up so nicely!

content:

Early Access Review
								so. this game has a cool premise, pretty much as advertised. the dealer lays out a dungeon, made from seperate encounters, each represented by a card. these encounters are either just text decisions like "give peasant half or all of your food" and you have to guess, being either rewarded or punished afterwards. this card-dungeon is rogue-lite-challenging, meaning you can just starve because of plain bad luck with your draw and event choices. the other encounters, Id say about sixty percent - are the action rpg part of the game. the combat system is the weakest link in the chain still, and every single type of ranged enemy still has the potential to make me ragequit - but itll have you on your toes at least...in my opinion, the dealer animations in between cards are too long and unskippable. a lot of events determine their outcome by having you draw from four cards, say success/success/failure/huge failure. itll then show you these four, flip them, shuffle them TWICE (!), spread them out, pause a split second more just to annoy you further - and THEN you can draw one of the four. which youll do every thirty seconds. similar stuff goes for other animations, say the laying out of the dungeon in the beginning.besides from these problems, and early-access-issues like say, lack of sounds, the game is cool. the mix is a cool idea, and you can build your dungeon event AND equipment decks in between dungeons, that determine what stuff you might face off against, get benefited by, or loot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I am absolutely in love with this game. It takes deck building, choose-your-own-adventure, board games, Arkham-style brawling and roguelite elements and mixes them all into a melting pot, and the atmosphere is the final ingredient that brings it all together. You're essentially playing through an adventure, using a deck of cards as the base, with the dealer providing colorful commentary and setting the mood. It's like playing a personal, one-on-one game of DnD with someone...or like old shows like Knightmare or similar. I can not overstate how impressive the atmosphere is of the game, with each card full of flavor and every encounter interesting and exciting. You never know what you'll find! The dealer himself is a very interesting character, who half the time seems to want to help you and half the time seems happy to watch you twist in the wind. He'll applaud you for victory, but just as quickly savor your defeat. Maybe you decide to swap out an axe for a sword? He'll snark about it, asking you if it's really what you want to do. His commentary, though sometimes cryptic, does an immense job in building the world and turns every card into a fully fleshed encounter, dripping with detail. Every monster, enemy and boss is played up with description, sometimes terrifying and sometimes mournful. Honestly, I have no complaints about this game at all and have had no issues or bugs with it...at least so far. Some of the RNG can get truly brutal in the later encounters and the combat itself isn't exactly door-busting, but it's more than servicable and for anyone who's played the Arkham games, Assassin's Creed or the like will find it easy to learn, though the difficulty ramps up greatly. I can already see this being one of my favorite games of the year. I sincerely hope they intend to release more content for it, as I'd love that, though between the Story mode and Endless Mode, I can see playing this for a long while yet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Don't want to read the wall of text below? Watch my first look of Hand of Fate here. 


YouTube™ Video: Huge Success! - First 40 of Hand Of Fate (Gameplay) 

			Views: 36		

			40 Minutes of Gameplay from Hand of Fate Much like my last video of Ziggurat, Hand of Fate is a hard game to categorize with its card game/brawler/D&D mix, yet comes highly recommended.		

Much like most of the other great games that have come out this year so far, Hand of Fate is one of those that could have easily slipped through the cracks. It is a difficult game to categorize, but it's mix of card game mechanics, brawling and table top RPG mechanics proves to mix together very well. Let's break down each part and see how it stacks up.The Card Game -Easily the best part of this game. When I heard this was a card game I went into it expecting something along the lines of Hearthstone, but I couldn't have been more wrong. Your deck controls what is in each level, and gives you equipment. the dealers deck on the other hand (heh card puns) contains the monsters you fight, the prizes and punishments from encounters, and a few cards just to mess with you. Its very unique and very addictingThe Brawling -Easily the worst part of the game. It's not bad, but if you have played Shadow of Mordor then this is going to feel quite clunky. The combat is just imprecise and the trap level that all depend on movement are hard to navigate. It should be noted though that its not BAD, just could have used some more polish and seems rushed compared to the rest of the game.The RPG Side -Much of the game comes down to what are essentially dice rolls from D&D, though in this case is a card pick. This is what ties the whole game together. With this system even playing the same deck time and time again will give you a different playthrough. It is a deep system and allows for almost infinite replayability, and in a time where games are getting bashed for not having replayability  *cough* The Order *cough* its good to see.Hand of Fate is easily one of my favorite games of the year so far, and I highly recommend picking it up is you have any interest in card games.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Absolute gaming bliss! The game is something I've never really encountered before, and I've been gaming for most all of my life. It's a card game crossed over with a dungeon crawler type RPG, and it meshes together perfectly. I was kind of weary about buying this at first (considering I've never really encountered this genre of game before) but trust me, just pay up the $25 dollars because you will NOT regret it. The game itself is SUPER addicting and keep begging me to play more and more even though I've only gotten past the first string of boss decks. I'm particularly amazed by how many lines of dialogue the dealer has. It’s as if you’re actually sitting across from him playing this game of which your life depends. It’s truly an immersive experience and I have not one complaint about the game. However, I do have one concern. What happens when you collect all of these cards and defeat all of these bosses? Will the developers implement some kind of DLC into the game to lengthen the time of play? I really don’t want this game to end but there are only 11 boss decks, and I’m already at deck number 5 after playing for about an hour and a half. There is however and “endless” game mode, which to my knowledge is probably a survival type mode of the game. However, I feel like this would make the game more of a “quick fix” type game, and not really the immersive adventure/card game it is in story mode, but who am I to say, I haven’t even tried it out. Anyways, final verdict, buy it, now, TENOUTTATEN!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Rating Scale: Offensive Unfun Fair Good EnthusiasticHand of Fate is a breath of fresh air in the Rogue-like game style. The exploration point is fun, the challenge is descent, and the rewards for playing are surprisingly well thought out. You are a warrior, who has traveled far, and have meet a person, which is The Dealer. He has spent time making cards. Cards based off your memories. The game takes place on a board fashioned by these upside cards. As you play the game, you unlock and discover more memories, in which you get to go in and briefly explore. It's part Choose your own Adventure, part arcade smash them up, part resource management, and the key feature is the deck building.The deck building is a fascinating part of the game, and hints at a deeper story. You disover new magic weapons and abilities, and they go into one deck, and in the other deck are events. Often these events have a token which you can earn by running into it and passing the challenge. Pass the challenge, you get rewarded with a new card, a new memory from your past. So, the better you do, and the more tokens you unlock, the more story gets revealed.Is the story a deep one? Is it a good one? I can't say. I've not uncovered enough. I'm kinda struggling in the middle of the game not to starve to death, but that's a good thing. It's really random how the cards are distributed after a few levels, and if you overplay events, the game takes notice and changes them up. So it pays to change your deck every now and then. It also helps to have a good eye, as part of the game is three card Monte, and if you are good at spacial awareness, you can keep track of cards as they are shuffled, which is useful.Overall, this game is well worth the price of admission. The Journey is worthwhile, and while the combat is a tad simplistic, the exploration aspect and the gorgeous art assets make this game worth several hours of play through.

Heartily recommended, even with the sequel in the near future.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Verdict: Surprisingly addictive game with a charismatic antagonist and charming (though sometimes frustrating) mechanicsTo be blunt, this game is not what I expected. Then again, what was there to expect from a game that advertises with being a "card game" with action game mechanics. When I first saw it, I figured it had to be something like "Persona" series of games, and to SOME extent, this holds true. The random nature of each "dungeon" is what you might say these have in common. The similarities end, however, when you actually play the game. If I had to compare it with something people already knew, I'd say it is a weird hybrid between a "Make your own adventure" game, mixed with a collectible (sort of) trading card game, some D&D and a pinch of Arkham Asylum - if that makes any sense.The gist of the game is this: You are a nameless Adventurer that battles against a mystic card dealer that sets you up with a different dungeon every time you start a new mission. Your adventurer is actually represented by a small golden gaming piece that you can move about the track of cards layed out before you. The cards obviously face down, and the moment you step on it, it is turned to reveal your fate - and behold there is quite alot to be revealed. The scenes are described using text in a the fashion you'd see a dungeon master read from them in any kind of fantasy rpg. "Action" in these scenes is usually resolved by being presented some choices and depending on which one is picked, some event happens. An example would be the "Angry Guildmaster": He bullies you out of the way with his horse, and you have the option to either "Humbly apologize", or try and steal from him. While the first option lets you continue on your way, the second lets you pick 1 of 4 cards to see how things develope. Dragin a "success" card will net you a reward card (coming in the form of food, gold, health potions and such), whereas a failure might result in you getting thrown into a dungeon, having to fight your way out against a number of opponents, which - you guessed it - is determined by the pick of a card.You'd be surprised how littel "action" there is actually going on. Only a minority of cards (still plentiful, mind you) actually leads to you being set into an action scene to fight. The game has a few set areas or stages where combat might take place, depending on where the descriptive card you landed on told you you were. There is quite a bunch of them, and some of them are trap-ridden and require keen awareness and movement.The combat itself is basically Arkham Asylum's Reflex system, where you have three different actions. Attack, counter, shieldbash. It is, literally, the same thing, but it works quite well and you rarely get the feeling you are not in control. It is nothing new or astonishing, but have you ever heard someone complain about AA's combat system? Me neither.As for items and such, you get a pretty standard array of axes, hammers and swords, a couple of rings, shields and armours, a bit of magic through "artifacts", pretty much standard fantasy stuff. Again, it works well enough to keep you entertained and allow for some meta-gaming.Now, you might wonder, what is my goal in this game and how does this card thing come into play appart from being a random mechanic? The longer you play, the more cards you unlock through "tokens", which are attached to some cards. Resolve the card in the intended way successfully, and you get new cards. You can then use these cards to build your decks: One is for all your own goodies like weapons and armour, the other for possible encounters - that's right, you get to determine what encounters you might have in your adventure! But beware, the sinister card dealer has a word in this, too. With every new adventure, he puts in increasingly more challenging cards. Also, each of the story mission comes with some kind of "mutation": Sometimes everyone moves faster and receives double damage, another one might forbid certain actions, make things more expensive, etc. It will keep things fresh for quite a while, at least for the "story mode", which is, essentially, just you wandering from card to card until you reach the next boss. When story mode is not enough, you can always try endless, where anything goes and you continue until you are dead.Now, with the card game mechanics come some things you'd might expect that make the whole experience a little... tainted. Especially in the later stages of the game, you might simply be unlucky and die without being able to do much about it. I had an especially annoying series of events that left me with ONE max HP (that is right: My maximum HP have been reduced from 100 to 1!), no food left (you lose Hitpoint when moving your piece without having food from "starvation) and nothing to redeem myself. In essence, the game just laughed at me. Now, these extreme cases seem to be very, very rare, but there are other cases where you realize you will probably not stand a chance against the upcomming boss because you simply had no chance of drawing equipment cards, never receiving gold or food, or the dealer drawing two old bosses (once bosses are beaten, they can be drawn as "regular" enemies in encounters) very early in the game, causing you to either die or losing many hitpoints. Also, while it caters to the games charm, it is not always clear what the developers intended with certain events and what a certain choice might lead to. This "trial and error" principle is probably there to pad out the game a little bit (which would fall a little short in content, otherwise), but be aware that this game sometimes just doesn't seem to "play it fair".I also find it a little disappointing that the action sequences are so limited and that the majority of the game takes place "at the table". The game does make up with SUPERB voice acting by Anthony Skordi, whom you might recall from voicing the more cockney'esque Dark Elves in The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. He also has quite the number of lines to boot, but still, it would have been much nicer if there had been a smoother transition between the card play and the actual action.Also, the overall card and deckbuilding mechanics fall short once you have unlocked all the cards. There is no ways to get "doubles" (apart from what the game gives you), or winning "boosters" to alter up or otherwhise improve your deck. The developers have already released one DLC, but need to bring more options if they want to bring longevity to this game. Of course, you have to consider that this is a kickstarter game and much of what I critisized could never be expected from the limited scope of ressourced the developers had at their disposal. The game is also budget-priced, so again, the equation fits. It is hard to do this game justice and it is a shame they do not provide a demo. It was a blind pick for me and I was pleasantly surprised, but it is hard to say whether this game will be to your liking or not. It is a fresh idea where the result is greater than the sum of its parts.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												It's hard to sum in in just a few sentences.On the surface it is fairly simple. The game consists of about a dozen missions (each with a different boss encounter at the end, each taking about 10-30 minutes). You have a deck of cards that represent the items you might find during each mission and another deck that represents the encounters you might come across during the mission. The encounter cards also form the 'dungeon' in that they are placed face down in a pattern and you need to walk over them to activate them.At first you only have a few basic items and a few encounters, but each time you 'beat' an encounter card, you get new cards, either new items, new encounters or both. This happens even if you don't beat the boss at the end. Thus even an unsuccessful mission rewards you with more gear for the next time you play the mission.The neat thing is that you choose the set of encounters in the deck yourself, meaning you can stack the deck towards a certain type of encounter.The other thing is that the encounter unlocks themselves tell a story, for example there is one encounter chain where you first come across to lovers who want to run away together, you will later unlock further encounters that tell you what happened to them afterwards. This unlocking of quests gives you another progression axis, so instead of just running the missions and progressing that way by beating the bosses you also progress on this encounter-unlocking axis which makes failure much less frustrating and runs much less repetitive than it would otherwise have been.The narrator is absolutely awesome and really pulls you in to the game.The combat is ok, it's a low prodction values version of the Arkham system. I see some people complain about it not being that great, but it is perfectly functional. The combat sections generally are quite short, and for that the way it works is fine. I have not had any complaints.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												A card game in which you build decks of equipment and encounters, playing against a smart-mouthed dealer who guides you from event to event, encouter to encounter, and taunts you every step of the way, goading you on until he either gloats at your failure or grumbles at your success.That sounded pretty darn good to me, so I got Hand of Fate and played it. And I wasn't disappointed.Hand of Fate is a fairly simple game, combining a very Batman Arkham-esque combat system with an overworld card game full of decisions and chances to both succeed and fail. The random nature of the game can put some players off, though, as in the later levels you can play a near -perfect game and still fail miserably due to poor luck. Choosing your deck well can help, but it will only get you so far when the game starts doling out the "-15 max health" -cards.The game is occasionally a bit crude in it's visuals and animation, the dealer's card handling puts me off every time, but everything still manages to look functional and clear, easy to read and enjoyable once you get into it, and is brought together beautifully by the voice of the dealer.Hand of Fate is an enjoyable experience and well worth it's price tag. I recommend it wholeheartedly. Playtime: 10+ hours (single near-complete playthrough)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 8Audio: 8Story: 9Gameplay: 9Overall: 9

												The game is like a " Choose your own Adventure" with a mix of Action combat and strategy implemented via cards.Nice change of pace to the typical hack and slash games, adds new play mechanics with cards of chance. Combat has increasing gotten better since this game was in EA, some of the combat motions at times seems a little slow but they have been refined enough to give that smooth combat style once you learn the mechanics of using a weapon, shield, and possibly Relic card to assist you in battle and how to respond to the different alerts that popup when an enemy is attacking.One of the more enjoyable pieces of the game is the card deck setup that occurs before you take a run at each boss, you get to decide what type of weapons and armor, plus what types of encounter cards are added each time before you start. This helps to somewhat personalize the game play, even though the Dealer has his own set of chance cards that also appear during the game.I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys card strategy games...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Just because your game has familiar and playable parts doesn't mean you can't combine them in unique ways. Hand of Fate shows as the standout example, taking influence from collectable card games, roguelikes, choose-your-own-adventure novels, and modernized brawler combat to portray something more than the some of its parts.The conceit is that you're in an endless game with the mysterious dealer, progressing through increasingly dangerous paths through the medium of shuffled cards. You can change these cards before a game to try and give yourself an advantage, or futher discovery by putting in a potentially trecherous encounter for yourself. Just as you can stack the deck, though, the Dealer will stack the deck against you more and more to counter that.Adventuring through the lands, you can buy equipment drawn from the shuffled-in deck to try and improve yourself, or perhaps grab a blessing to get a futher edge onwards. But you have food to worry about as you explore, keep your supplies fresh or pain and death await.Challenges tend to come in either a choose-your-own-adventure roleplaying format or a combat/dungeon exploration format. The choose-your-own-adventure ones go through a mini story, often with chance elements that are hard to win. But maybe that's not so much a worry when you're encountering them in the future for as long as you have them in the deck. The combat itself is very familiar if you've played any of the Batman Arkham games or even Dark Souls, as it has the mix of different attacks and additional timed counters to spice up the flow - often focusing on mobs of enemies at once.There's a sense of style that keeps things held together, whether it be the hammy game master you're playing against, or the mini-stories the adventure challenges give whenever you encounter them. Matter of fact, the chained quest lines in this game added in over time have really made a difference.I really only have minor niggles with the game, if mainly to do with there being too much reliance on chance or the food survival mechanic being overbearing, but that's really it,If you're looking for something different that's still extremly approachable and will give you hours of fun while you're at it, look no further. Can't wait for the sequel.

Product received for free
												I've received this game from friend.I recommend this game when on sale.At the beginning I ware truly astonished by the game. I really enjoyed animations and deck building. Cards collecting is the strongest aspect of this game. Also high replay value thanks to random picked cards, and the bonus endless mode next to story mode is something worth mentioning as well. Many items have special features. Unfortunately after hours of hours playing I've found some disadvantages as well. Your character is not improving in any way, all straights come from equipment and cards (for example maximum health boosts), and the combat is always placed on "isometric arena". No place to hide, no place for any complex strategy, and the enemies many times got you from not visible on screen parts of arena, camera should be better, locations should be larger. Anyway I haven't met such game until now, so even with flaws I can recommend it at discounted price.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												First and foremost I absolutely love this game for so many reasons. I can sometimes steer clear of card game video games because they can be very lackluster for me. So at first I was hesitant in getting this game. However that was until I watched a gameplay video on Youtube of this game. I then realized how wrong I was and what I was missing out. I was missing out on such a unique take on card games. This has little to do with strategy like most card games but is more about choosing your own adventure. Each game in the story mode takes about 20 or so minutes to go through so it's very easy to manage your time with this game. I've seen people complain about RNG in this game however it's honestly not that big of a deal. RNG only happens with card draws, room layouts, and success chances on certain encounters. The combat is a feature that I really like about this game. The combat is hack and slash, dodge and counter type of combat which I think is really smart to put into a card game because it deter from the possible monotony that a lot of card games have. Every game is different and it has high replayability because of it and Endless Mode which is where you can try and go in a game for as long as you can until you die. A very good gem of a game that I regret not partaking in the Early Access stage of it's life. 10/10 will always play again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Absolutely solid indie rpg for the price. Tabletop RPG fans will feel at home. The mystical theme works well, and the "Dealer" is executed elegantly with his dark wit, personality, voice acting, and nuanced gestures. The gameplay consists of a set of cards dealt faced down on the table in a random path. These represent the "level". A figurine represents you on these cards, and you move across them in a direction of your choice, one card at a time, revealing them and resolving them as you land on them. They might be fights, traps, or story events, or some combination of the three. While doing this, you are balancing how much food you have left (it is lost every move), whether your gold is better spent on food, blessings, or equipment, whether it's worth it to explore further or look for a shop on the next level, etc. You are also engaged thematically with the style of the scene, and the banter of the Dealer, while making story decisions for the cards, or engaging in combat.Fights bring you into real-time combat using the gear your have found, in a freeform twitch / reaction combat style similar to the batman arkham series or Middle Earth: Shadows of Mordor. It is not perfect; the camera is a little rough and the animation and targeting can be slightly shaky, but it is still very good, especially for an indie game. I grew comfortable with it pretty quickly, and I haven't had any significant issues. I enjoy it, and I think it's the best form of combat for this game.One of the cards on the level is an exit to the next level, which will clear the table and draw a new map of cards. Depending on the mode of play, you are either descending to ultimately fight one of an impressive number of bosses (story mode), or descending indefinitely into ever-increasing difficulty (endless mode). Endless mode uses all cards that you have found. Story mode uses custom decks that you build ahead of time.The customization and collection aspect of this game really make it shine:As you play, you unlock cards that are added to your collection. You use this collection before each game to build 2 customized decks: Equipment, and encounters. Your equipment deck isn't what you start with, but instead represents all the items that you may find in shops, chests, and as combat rewards throughout the game. Your encounter deck represents the cards that make up a level. So you are putting together the pieces of your story. You are deciding what you'll run into, and what you'll find, with some other things added by the dealer. You unlock new cards to add to your collection as you go.From a developer perspective, these guys put a lot of care into this game. There are elements of conditional dialog, animations, and menus; things like the dealer saying something different or being aware of your stats, things like a menu screen that changes based on whether or not you've completed the tutorial level, and other things that may seem trivial, but took consideration, time, and effort to include, when really they didn't have to. Bigger games have been released with far less intelligent scripting. This has quickly become a personal favorite.

												A great combination of a card game and a (sort of) RPG. Every game you begin with a basic equipement (that gets better every story tier, just like monsters) and from the deck of cards (of which some you choose and some are picked by the dealer - so more or less at random) then determine how the game plays out. Almost too easy at first and almost too unforgiving and unfair by the end, this game of pure luck and some figkting skills in an arena-like encounters is (almost) too fun.Moment of surprise is something this game is build upon, so I will say no more. But I feel a simple disclaimer is needed: this game is not build for long gaming sessions, but ideal for shorter ones. Or if you feel like playing something in between a long one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												In most RPGs, card games are a staple mini-game where you can use the cards collected in random encounters. Sometimes, these games are fun like tetra master in FFIX, but most of the time they are just a distraction and play-time-extenders.With this game, however, it's the other way around. Collecting and playing cards is the main part, while the hack-and-slay-style encounters and bosses are fun, but do not compare to the excitement of unlocking new cards and the adventures and mysteries they hold. It all comes together when a round ends: Regardless of the outcome, each token acquired in the game unlocks new cards that have effects that are yet unknown - you have to uncover their meaning in-game. Then, the dealer invites you to play another game. He let's all your cards hover in a cloud above the table and you just have to click to start another round to get to know your new acquisitions...Highly recommended, especially for players that cannot resist an innovative rogue-like or card-game with many collectibles.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												This game is pleasantly surprising. You are not trying to build an RPG character who can survive hordes of enemies. You are trying to arrange fate to favor one warrior's quest... and since the damage carries from one encounter to the next, you really feel every outcome and blow.And you can decide you don't like a specific encounter. Effing goblins took my good sword! Although, I did beat some food out of them when I was out. But there's often trade-offs.It's a rogue-like where I feel like I have a chance. When I fail, I can usually point to a choice I'd rather I'd made differently... or five or ten blows in combat I wish I'd dodged. It doesn't feel like solitaire, where you can't win a lot of hands. I mean, it is a solitaire, and I do lose a LOT. But even if I just manage to unlock a few more cards, I've gotten some new twists to explore. And it is exploration... you don't get to know what a card does until it's been in play.[Post-EA followup]Finally managed to beat the end boss! :D There's a big difficulty spike in the last 4 levels, and the end boss includes a full boss rush. It took a few tries to get the deck adjusted for a decent shot at victory. A lot of late-game cards will take a few attempts to unlock and may ruin your chances at the current run. Not sure that's such a bad thing. It's a matter of priority... and luck.Still have a couple cards to unlock. It's like being at the end of a nice RPG but there's a sidequest or two remaining.
