content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												I have only played Hand of Fate for a few hours but it has made a great impression.  It brings back the old pen and pencil D&D memories and it is brilliant fun.  its simple to grasp and so far hasnt been diifficult to progress, however it is hinting at more complicated gameplay and decisions to be made later down the line which i am looking forward to, such as as having enough food to explore the dungeon/scenario versus just try and find the exit.  I really like the change in gameplay between making slower decisions and taking a random pot luck (dice roll) on choosing a card, to using skill in faster paced combat.  the combat, is so far, a somewhat simplified batman/shadow of mordor type where the character can block and counter attack (equipment dependant) as well as using special cards that have been chosen. It isnt without issues, the intro video has some textural issues and after using the steam overlay in game i ended up with a letter box display, however none of the issues have been for me game breaking.   The actual gameplay however has been bug free so far.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Interesting mix on a card-based roguelike and a 3D action brawler (reminds me of Shadows of Mordor).  It works surprisingly well.  As far as "roguelikes" go, it's fairly easy -- it's not nearly as brutal as some of the other games more true to the roguelike formula.  For me, this is good -- I can play for an hour or so and feel like I made some progress through the story mode.Perhaps the most engaging aspect for me is the progression.  Beating bosses and quests (represented as cards) unlocks even more cards, weapons, quests, and bosses.  It's always exciting to see a quest for the first time, because beating it usually unlocks another one.  Since quests unlock other quests, often in a logical order, the result is a sort of mini-narrative as you complete quest lines through different playthroughs.  Even more interesting, quests can also influence other quests -- for instance, after completing quests and obtaining a rare artifact, a quest I'd previously seen in a previous playthrough had a totally different outcome.  There are some great dealer voiceovers as well, and it's interesting to see how he reacts to your choices/quest combinations.  It's this sense of progression that keeps me coming back for more.I expect to get about 6-8 hours to complete the Story mode, probably more to unlock all the cards.  From there, there's also endless mode, which has a competitive aspect to it.All-in-all, awesome game, highly recommend.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												After having beaten the entire game (and having gotten to about level 40 in endless mode), I figure I should give my opinion about the game. In my opinion, this game is fantastic. Not flawless, sure, but definitely worth the price of admission.The Good:No two playthroughs are the same -  You are able to select what cards are in your deck (with the exception of endless mode, where every card is included), but not every card is drawn, and the path of the cards changes in each section. This changes the game's story in a dynamic fashion.Success/Failure Screen - One of the game's most charming mechanics. Your every decision is faced with these cards, and those wary enough can track the wearabouts of each success and failure. Granted, that never seems to help me (usually I get the huge failure cards when I try), but you can succeed on (almost) every decision if your vision is clear.The writing -                          "gets the Mister Lionel card"                         Lionel gives me a shield.                         The dealer:                         "I'm beginning to think you put that card in here just for a free shield."                         0_0Anyway, the writing is fantastic. I love the dealer's sarcastic and mocking inflection, and I love the fact that the game doesn't mind mocking you when you start to cheese the mechanics. For example if you find the maiden too often, and you can be sure that you'll be mocked for your inability to go without her.The atmosphere - If nothing else, the game is just charming in its presentation. Everything from the dealer's shuffling of the cards to the memorable encounters screams theme and suspense. Definitely one to pick up if you're looking for a unique atmosphere.The bad -                  No camera controls. The game does a pretty decent job of tracking your movement, but being able to move the camera would definitely improve your awareness during combat. USE THE TABS, DYNASTY WARRIORS STYLE!                 No customizeable main character. This one doesn't really bother me, since it's an indie title and all, but the only way you can customize your character is through equipment you get in game. Personally, I think this would be much more tolerable if you could switch between male and female avatars. Perhaps somewhere down the road as additional content?                 No "main story." - The game has a sort of Dark Souls feel going on, in that you can learn about the world through the cards and equipment you gain. However, it's more about building your own story using the cards as a framework. I know, however, that this will put some people off.                The bugs - Yes, there are bugs on launch. I haven't encountered anything game breaking - instead, it's just been a few irritating ones (like the sfx being switched off after death). I expect these will get patched soon, but I had to include them.The okay:                The combat - The combat is done Arkham style, with dodges, counters, and stuns. One of my favorite parts is that you become unable to do certain things if you lose equipment. Lose your shield? You lose the ability to reflect projectiles and enemies stop displaying their "attack icon" indicating that you should dodge. However, the combat itself is both slower and less flexible than Arkham. It's one of the game's weaker points, but it is serviceable.                The slowdown effect - This one can be both good and bad, depending on your opinion. Personally, it gives me more time to take in my situation, but it does noticeably slow down the game's pace.                 The RNG - You will be screwed over, both randomly and consistantly. Sometimes you simply won't find what you need, and you'll die. A lot. However, this is kind of a basic element of the rogue-like genre, so this depends on your tolerance, I suppose.Overall, I believe that the game is worth every penny. The developers (Defiant Devs) listen to the community and are willing to change elements that simply don't work. Even more amazingly, the developer ACTUALLY USED EARLY ACCESS LIKE IT SHOULD BE USED. No cash shops, no broken promises, no controversy. They even rewarded their early access users by giving them the first DLC free. Take a note, game developers. This is how you do Early Access right.Anyway, that wraps me up. Guess I'll include my coolest attempt (sorry, couldn't resist).VS: The King of ScalesStarted off immediately by finding the royal treasuryGot cut to bits and lost 2/3 of my HPGot the "skin rash" curse, which makes you draw pain cardsGot hit with 2 max health reductions, bringing me down to 20Got hit with midas appetite, making my gold foodRan out of gold next to a shop, had to sell my shield and weapon(finally) got lucky and got a huge success at an encounter, giving me a weapon and foodRan into the sweetnymphs at 5hp and reset my characterKnocked that scaly mongrel into the ground, bringing me to the final challenge....

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								so. this game has a cool premise, pretty much as advertised. the dealer lays out a dungeon, made from seperate encounters, each represented by a card. these encounters are either just text decisions like "give peasant half or all of your food" and you have to guess, being either rewarded or punished afterwards. this card-dungeon is rogue-lite-challenging, meaning you can just starve because of plain bad luck with your draw and event choices. the other encounters, Id say about sixty percent - are the action rpg part of the game. the combat system is the weakest link in the chain still, and every single type of ranged enemy still has the potential to make me ragequit - but itll have you on your toes at least...in my opinion, the dealer animations in between cards are too long and unskippable. a lot of events determine their outcome by having you draw from four cards, say success/success/failure/huge failure. itll then show you these four, flip them, shuffle them TWICE (!), spread them out, pause a split second more just to annoy you further - and THEN you can draw one of the four. which youll do every thirty seconds. similar stuff goes for other animations, say the laying out of the dungeon in the beginning.besides from these problems, and early-access-issues like say, lack of sounds, the game is cool. the mix is a cool idea, and you can build your dungeon event AND equipment decks in between dungeons, that determine what stuff you might face off against, get benefited by, or loot.

Early Access Review
								i dont regret buying this game even a bit. it is worth every penny. despite having a more hefty price tag for an early access game (and for a broke highschoolers budget)it has plenty of content to keep you ocupied. between the lengthy (but not too long) story and an endless mode you should find yourself more than pleased with the purchase. after reading about hand of fate in game informer i was intrigued by the concept of a rouge-like card game with archem/AC fighting. i have played games for long periods of time simply because i enjoyed the concept, even if it wasnt getting fleshed out in exactly the way i hoped, so i knew that i would be purchasing it soon after i had read the article. the real question in my mind was "will this game live up to its inovative concepts full potential, or will i be disapointed with the direction the developers are taking?" and in my mind it is living up its potential. the fact that it is an early access game makes it hard to give a definitive answer, but the direction they are going in is wonderful, and there is lots of potential for more content that satisfys and stays through to the inovative foundation layed in the current build.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												My favourite thing about Hand of Fate is the excellent presentation. The dealer's table is colourful but moody; the environments are beautifully expressive; the cards themselves have a pleasing physicality, and I'm excited when I uncover new ones. The game has a ton of character, which is all the more impressive considering that it brings it all across with a few comments from the dealer and careful visual design. Here less really is more.The combat is less exciting. It's a bit simplistic, and although the game mixes things up a bit later, I never thought it got beyond decent. Still, you're here for the exploration and mood, right? The game delivers in spades on its core engagements, and I heartily recommend you give it a shot.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I've only played this one for a short while but I am so impressed I will give my opinion now. Hand of fate pretty much sums up why I am an avid support of indie developers. Recently there have been some cracking new titles such as Darkest Dungeon and others where they really have come up with some great ideas. Hand of fate is no exception. My hat goes of to  Defiant who have taken some traditional RPG elements and mixed them in with a luck based card system. This really is thinking outside of the box and it works brilliantly. The great thing is that its not just all about the cards. In combat your reactions play a part as well. The two modes story and endless will ensure a different game time after time. The artwork and card descriptions fit the games atmosphere perfectly.PS. This is not a multiplayer or card trading game. Its single player. That said I think if they ever did a sequel with those elements it would add in a very interesting aspect to what is already a superb title. Well done guys.

												Disclaimer: I backed Hand of Fate on Kickstarter for a copy of the game upon release.There's no easy way to categorize Hand of Fate. Defiant Development has looked to tabletop RPGs, roguelikes, action RPG video games, and deckbuilding card games for elements to mix into their game and they've tied it all together nicely using a mysterious man who is storyteller, dungeon master, and dealer, oozing a quiet confidence from the other side of the table.It all comes together with great atmosphere and is really engaging. content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												You proceed through a dungeon, where each room is a card that has some kind of encounter on it.  Some encounters are about making choices, some will lead to a fight scene, in which you need to win a combat against mobs.It works well as a dungeon crawl, due to the random element, but it seems to have decent balance.  The encounters comprising the dungeon are made from a combination of cards put in by the dungeon master (an NPC) and your own deck, which you build over time.There is a reasonably strong RPG feel.  Partly this is because some cards progress based on your choices (if you "win" during one encounter, the reward is often a new card with a follow-up encounter).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Wow, what a truly wonderful surprise this game turned out to be. I picked it up on a whim without having any real knowledge of the game till it hit the market. It's a procedurally generated set of dungeons (akin to the old 'choose your own adventure' novels from  20+ years ago) based on cards in a deck that you have a hand in designing. You traverse this dungeon using gear from a separate deck that you also have a hand in designing, which is comprised of gear you found throughout your journey exploring previous dungeons. It's really quite genius.The game is surprisingly deep too. During play you'll see the following:-various weapon damage types-various enemy types-mazes-curses-blessings-merchants-buffs-traps-chests-path choices-bosses-magical items-random loot-artifacts-item activation during combatI'm sure theres more I could add, but I'm still not even 2hrs played. You walk across a board comprised of over turned cards from the deck, randomly laid out in a grid. Each step consumes a food resource, so must monitor your food as you travel. You'll run into decisions in  your journey...do you give some of your food away to a weary traveller? or just pass by them. How you respond will affect the outcome of your journey.While I was originally concerned combat during story mode was too simple. The further I got, Not only was I becoming stronger, but so was my enemy.I definitely recommend this game. It's new and refreshing. Well done!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Saturday morning fun.Hand of Fate...Already seems like it has the makings of a classic choose-your-own roguelike adventure, got it through a humble bundle a few months ago, very lucky for me indeed, or perhaps I should just be appreciative of Defiant's articulate and masterful work.The 'game/dungeoun-master' harkens back to classical wizards such as Merlin, G-dalf and the ilk without seeming cliched, in fact, he seems original and fresh; layers of Easternish mysticism are presented before you and his comments on your doings, comings and goings are quite enjoyable to hear. He may tell you that the blessing you just purchased is a bit imba and he's going to bring out the nerf-hammer next time around, the game does not mean it will actually nerf that blessing next time around, it is actually beating the final level per set of cards that will increase the strength of enemies encountered and also improve your starting gear and provisions. This guy is the only person you really interact with during the game, and that makes your adventure seem delightfully personal.In addition to that, the game is played with tokens to unlock more incredibly detailed cards, beautiful arenas, dungeouns, and shop-areas with little merchant wagons, all revolving around improving your character's odds as you move his little gold playing token through card-maps to the boss event for each set of cards. You may come across a random event where you must select from four shuffled cards, and yes, if your eyes are quick enough you can follow the successful cards as they shuffle, no true randomness involved, just have to pay attention to the minute details as the cards slide across eachother. Anywho, guess the correct cards in these events and you might get a new weapon, some gold or earn the card's token which will in turn, after beating the set boss, unlock more cards for you to play with your next time around.Everything comes together with such subtlety that you almost feel like you're experiencing more than you paid for, this title screams triple-A quality throughout every chapter and turn while still coming through as your humble guide leading you through a poignant adventure largely based on fantastical ideas that leave just enough space within their nooks and crannies to be able to be completely alluded to on a personal level for you and your imagination.
